superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter x x
The seventh letter of the alphabet: called xaMCN [and xaA (respecting which latter see the letter b)]. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of those termed HaloqiyRap [i. e. faucial, or guttural]: its place of utterance is the same as that of g [which differs from it in being vocal]. (L.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Six hundred.]

xaA xA
xaA and xaMCN: see the letter x, and arts. xwO and xI.

xaAtuwnN xAtwn
xaAtuwnN: see art. xtn.

xaAnaqaAhN xAnq xAnqAh xAnqAp
xaAnaqaAhN and xaAnaqaAhiIRN: see art. xnq.

1 xabRa xb
1. xabRa, (A, L, K,) sec. pers. xabibota, like Ealimota, aor. yaxabRu, inf. n. xibRN; (S, L, K; *) or xabRa, [sec. pers. xababota,] aor. yaxubRu, like yaqotulu, inf. n. xabRN; (Msb; [in which xibRN is regarded as a simple subst.; but I doubt the correctness of this, and of the verb's being like qatala;]) He (a man) was, or became, deceitful, (Msb, K, TA,) wicked, dishonest, or dissimulating, (K, TA,) and a mischief-maker: (TA:) [or] he was, or became, a great deceiver, or very deceitful, (S, A, L, K, TA,) wicked and deceitful, and a mischief-maker. (S, * A, * L, TA.) [In the K and TA, neither the aor. nor the inf. n. of xabRa as signifying “ he was, or became, a great deceiver, or very deceitful, ” is specified; nor the sec. pers. of the pret., which indicates the form of the aor.] ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] xabRa signifies also He alighted and abode in a depressed tract of ground, in order that his place might be unknown, from a motive of niggardliness [to avoid claims upon his hospitality, thus deceiving passers by]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And He denied, or refused, what he possessed. (K.) ＝ -A2- xabRa, (S, A, K,) aor. yuxubRu, with damm, (S, A,) deviating from a general rule, accord. to which an intrans. v. of this class [of the measure faEala] should be with kesr, (MF,) inf. n. xabRN (S, K) and xababN and xabiybN, (S, A, K,) He went the pace, or in the manner, denoted by xababN as explained below; said of a horse; (S, A, K;) as also AxtbR↓: (Th, K:) and in like manner said of a man. (TA.) You say, jaAWuwA taxubRu bihimu AldRawaAbRu [They came, the beasts going with them the pace, or in the manner, termed xababN]. (A.) And xabRa fiI AlOamori, aor.
xabuba
, inf. n. xababN, He hastened to begin the affair. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xabRa, (aor. yaxubRu, TA, [inf. n. xabRN,]) said of the sea, (tropical:) It was, or became, agitated, or in a state of commotion; (T, S, A, K, TA;) the waves dashing together, and the winds whirling; (T, A, TA;) such being the case at a certain period, when the ships make for the shore, for safety, or cast anchor. (T, TA.) You say, OaSaAbahumu AlxabRu (tropical:) Agitation, or commotion, of the sea, with a whirling of the winds, befell them: (T, A, TA:) or ASAbhm xabRN, i. e. xabRa bihimu AlbaHoru (tropical:) The sea became agitated, or in a state of commotion, with them. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also, said of the dust, (tropical:) It rose high: (JK, TA:) and (tropical:) it ran along. (TA.) ― -b4- And said of a plant, or of herbage, (tropical:) It became tall. (JK, S, A, K.)

2 xbRb xbb
2. xbRb, (JK, S, A, K,) inf. n. taxobiybN, (JK, TA,) He deceived another; (S, K;) namely, another's young man, or slave: (S:) or deceived much or greatly: (Har p. 591:) and he corrupted another; (JK, A, TA;) namely, another's male or female slave. (TA.) You say, xbRb Ealayohi Sadiyqahu, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and Eabodahu, and Haliylatahu, (A,) He corrupted, and rendered disaffected to him, (Aboo-Bekr, A,) his friend, (Aboo-Bekr,) and his male slave, and his wife. (A.) ＝ -A2- He bound his arm, or hand, with a xibRap, i. e. a piece of rag like a fillet. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- It (one's flesh) wasted so that there appeared streaks upon the skin. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also R. Q. 1.

3 xAbR xAb
3. xAbR: see muxaAbRN. [It seems that xAbRhu, if used, signifies He acted treacherously towards him, and took him unawares.] ― -b2- And [the inf. n.] muxaAbRapN signifies The being heavy, or sluggish, and holding back from a thing. (JK.)

4 AxbR OxAb Oxb Axb xAb xb xbA
4. AxbR He made a horse to go the pace, or in the manner, denoted by xababN as explained below. (S, A, K.)

8 AxtbR Oxtb Axtb Qxtb
8. AxtbR: see 1. ＝ -A2- AxtbR mino vawobih xubRapF, (S,) or, xibRapF, and AxtbR vawobahu, (JK,) He took forth [or, app., tore] from his garment a piece of ray like a fillet. (S.)

R. Q. 1 xaboxaba xbxb
R. Q. 1. xaboxaba He (a man, TA) acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, faithlessly, or treacherously. (K.) ＝ -A2- He was, or became, lax, flaccid, or flabby, in the belly. (K.) [See also xaboxabapF, below; and see R. Q. 2.] ＝ -A3- xaboxaba Eani AlZRahiyrapi He stayed until the mid-day heat had become assuaged, and the air was cool: (K:) or the phrase is xaboxaba Eanohu mina AlZRahiyrapi. (TA.) [Hence, in a trad. relating to the postponement of the noon prayers,] xaboxibuwA Eanokumo mina AlZRahiyrapi, (S,) or fiI AlZRahiyrapi, (JK, [but the former is more probably the correct phrase,]) Stay ye until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool: (JK, S:) it is originally xabRabuwA↓, and is altered therefrom for the purpose of distinction: (S in the present art.:) or originally baxobixuwA. (S in art. bx.)

R. Q. 2 taxaboxaba txbxb
R. Q. 2. taxaboxaba It was, or became, lax, flaccid, or flabby: said of a thing in a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like. (K.) [See also xaboxabapN, below; and see R. Q. 1.] ― -b2- He was, or became, empty [in the belly], after repletion. (JK.) And jaMCa yataxaboxabu He came hungry. (JK.) ― -b3- taxaboxaba laHomuhu, (JK,) or badanuhu, (K,) He became lean after having been fat, (JK, K, TA,) so that his shin became lax, flaccid, or flabby, (TA,) and a sound was heard to proceed from him [when he moved], (JK, TA,) by reason of his leanness. (TA.) ― -b4- taxaboxaba AlHarRu The heat became allayed, or assuaged, (K, TA,) somewhat, (TA,) in its vehemence. (K, TA.)

xabRN xb
xabRN (JK, S, A, L, Msb, K) [said in the Msb to be originally an inf. n.] and xibRN↓ (S, L, K) [originally an inf. n. accord. to most authorities] and xubRN↓, (MF,) applied to a man, (S, A, L, Msb,) fem. xabRapN, [which casts doubt upon the assertion that xabRN is originally an inf. n., for were it so the masc. and fem. accord. to a general rule would be the same, as well as the sing. and pl.,] applied to a woman, (JK, A,) A great deceiver, or very deceitful; (JK, * S, A, L, Msb, * K;) wicked and deceitful; a mischief-maker; (S, * A, * L, K, * TA;) deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; syn. makRaArN. (Ham p. 537, in explanation of the first and second.) ＝ -A2- Also the first of these words, A long, elevated tract (Habol, in some copies of the K erroneously written jbl, TA) of sand, cleaving to the ground. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A plain, or soft,
tract, between two rugged tracts, in which (i. e. in the former of which) are truffles. (AA, K.)

xubRN xb
xubRN: see xabRN. ＝ -A2- See also xibRapN. Hence vawobN OaxobaAbN: see, again, xibRapN. ― -b2- OaxobaAbu AlfaHivi The HawaAyaA [or winding guts, or intestines into which the food passes from the stomach]: (K:) thus used in the pl. form, as though pl. of xubRN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also The bark (liHaMC) of a tree. (JK, K.) ＝ -A4- And Low, or depressed, land: (JK, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxobaAbN and [of mult.] xubuwbN. (TA.)

xibRN xb
xibRN Deceit; (JK, Msb, K;) wickedness; dishonesty, or dissimulation; (K, TA;) mischiefmaking; as also xababN↓: (TA:) guile, art, craft, or cunning. (Ham p. 537.) ＝ -A2- See also xabRN. ＝ -A3- (tropical:) A rising, or state of agitation and commotion, of the sea; (JK, K, TA;) as also xibaAbN↓. (IAar, K.)

xabRapN xb xbh xbp
xabRapN: see xibRapN.

xubRapN xb xbh xbp
xubRapN: see xibRapN and xabiybapN. ― -b2- Also A place where water collects and remains or stagnates, (AA, K, TA,) and around which grow herbs, or leguminous plants: (TA:) a tract of land neither fruitful nor unfruitful, between two other tracts of land; pl. xubabN: (AHn:) a tract of land between that which abounds with herbage and that which is unproductive: (Ru-beh:) a narrow tract of soft land abounding with herbage, not rugged nor plain, but inclining to be plain; (ISh;) but ADk disapproves of this explanation: (TA:) or a tract producing herbage between two long and elevated tracts of sand; as also xabiybapN↓: (Ibn-Nujeym:) and, accord. to AA, also pasture, or herbage. (TA.) Also, or maxabRapN↓, (accord. to different copies of the K, or both, TA,) and xabiybapN↓, The bottom (baTon) of a valley. (K.)

xibRapN xb xbh xbp
xibRapN and xubRapN↓ and xabRapN↓ A narrow tract, or streak, of sand; [in one copy of the A, I find xibRapN and xabiybapN thus explained; but in another, maxabRapN↓ is written in the place of the former of these two words;] or of clouds; (S, K;) as also xabiybapN↓: (As:) or, of sand, what resembles a faAliq [or depressed tract between two hills], except in its being wider and more spreading, and not having abrupt sides; so says AHn in explaining xbRp [thus in the TA] and xabiybapN↓: (TA:) or all three signify a piece of rag like a fillet; as also xabiybapN↓ (S, K) and xubRN↓: (Lh:) or the last two (xbybp and xbR) signify a piece of rag from a garment, with which one binds his arm or hand. (JK, TA.) [Hence,) vawobN OaxobaAbN↓, (Lh, K,) [like OahobaAbN,] and vwb xibabN, (Lh, JK, K,) like hibabN, (JK,) and vwb xabaAYibu↓, like habaAYibu; (S;) [the latter word in the first of these phrases being pl. of xubRN; that in the second, pl. of xibRpN; and that in the third, pl. of xabiybapN;] A garment, or piece of cloth, rent in pieces, ragged, or tattered. (Lh, JK, S, K.) [See also xabiybapN, below.] It is also said that the xibRap of a garment, or piece of cloth, is [A portion thereof] like the TurRap [q. v.]: and accord. to Sh, the xubRap thereof is its TurRap. (TA.) And xbRp [so in the TA] signifies A piece of rag which a woman wears, covering her head with it: erroneously written by Lth HnRp. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. xibRapN and its two vars., and xabiybapN↓, of which the pl. is xabaAYibu, A streak of the flesh appearing in the skin, occasioned by the loss of flesh. (TA.)

xababN xbb
xababN: see xibRN. ＝ -A2- Also A kind of run, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with wide steps, but falling short of that termed EanaqN; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. a quick pace: (TA:) or a certain pace which is not quick: (Har p. 157:) or i. q. ramalN [q. v.]: or a pace of a horse, (K,) and of a camel, (TA,) in which he remores both his right legs together and both his left legs together; i. e. an amble: (K, TA:) or in which a horse rests on his right and left fore legs alternately, (yuraAwiHu bayona yadayohi, S, K, TA,) and in like manner on his kind legs: (S, TA: [app., as thus explained in the S and TA, meaning the same as the explanation next before it:] and (accord. to some, TA) quickness. (K.)

xibaAbN xbAb
xibaAbN: see xibRN.

xabiybN xbyb
xabiybN A trench, or furrow, (xadRN,) in the ground. (K.)

xabiybapN xbyb xbybh xbybp
xabiybapN, and its pl. xabaAYibu: see xibRapN, in five places. It is also said to signify A fillet, or bandage. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A long strip, or slice, of flesh, or flesh-meat; (JK, S, K;) and so xubRapN↓; (A, TA;) pl. of the former as above: (JK:) or any compact and long portion of flesh: any such portion is also termed xaSiylapN: either in the arm or elsewhere: (AO, TA:) or a [portion such as is termed] xSylp thereof, intermixed with [sinews, or tendons, such as are termed] Eaqab. (TA.) And xabaAYibu Almatonayoni The flesh of the two corresponding portions extending along the two sides of the backbone. (TA.) [Hence,] laHomuhu xabaAYibu His flesh is dissundered, or cut in pieces. (TA.) ― -b3- See also xubRapN, in two places. ― -b4- Also The wool of a vaniIR [or sheep in its third year]; (S, L;) which is better than that termed Eaqiyqap, i. e. the wool of a jacaE [or sheep in or before its second year], and cleaner, and more abundant: (ISk, S:) so accord. to most of the leading lexicologists; though said in the K to be a mistake of J, for janiybapN. (TA.)

xaboxabapN xbxbh xbxbp
xaboxabapN [by rule an inf. n. of R. Q. 1:] Laxness, flaccidity, or flabbiness; and a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like: (S:) or laxness, flaccidity, or flabbiness, of a thing in a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like; (TA;) as also xaboxaAbN↓. (JK, K, TA.) [See also R. Q. 2.]

xaboxaAbN xbxAb
xaboxaAbN: see what next precedes.

xaAbRN xAb
xaAbRN, (S, K, TA,) in one copy of the K xaAbRapN, [as in the CK,] but the former is the more correct, (TA,) Relationship; (S, K;) and affinity, syn. SihorN: (S:) pl. xawaAbRu. (S, K.) You say, liI mino fulaAnK xawaAbRu [I have ties of relationship, or affinity, to such a one]. (S.)

maxabRapN mxbh mxbp
maxabRapN: see xubRapN: ＝ -A2- and see also xibRapN.

muxaAbRN mxAb
muxaAbRN, as though from xaAbRa↓, One who acts treacherously towards another, and takes him unawares. (TA.)

1 xabaOahu c
1. xabaOahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
xabaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xaboCN, (S, Msb,) He hid, or concealed, it; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as also xbROhu↓, [but app. in an intensive sense, or applying to a number of things,] (K,) inf. n. taxobiYapN; (TA;) and AxtbOhu↓. (K.) ― -b2- He kept it, preserved it, guarded it, or took care of it. and xbROhu↓ he did so much; and well, or carefully. (Msb.) [He laid it up; stored it, or reposited it, in a place of safety.]

2 xabRaAa
2: see 1, in two places. [Hence, xbRO jaAriyapF He kept a girl carefully concealed from view: see the pass. part. n., below.]

3 xaAbaOotuhu maA kacaA c
3. xaAbaOotuhu maA kacaA, (K,) inf. n. muxaAbaOapN, (TK,) I proposed to him as an enigma, What is such a thing? syn. HaAjayotuhu. (K. [See also 8.])

8 AxtbO c
8. AxtbO It was, or became, hidden, or concealed: (Mgh:) he hid, or concealed, himself. (S.) ＝ -A2- It is also trans.: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] AxtbO lahu xabiyoYFA↓ He expressed a thing enigmatically to him, and then asked him respecting it. (IDrd, K. [See also 3.])

xaboCN xbC
xaboCN (S, Msb, K) and xiboCN↓ (TA) and xuboOapN↓, of the measure fuEolapN from AlxbO [or rather AlxaboCu], like gurofapN and quboDapN from Algarofu and AlqaboDu, (Har p. 426,) and xabiIoCN↓ (S, K) and xabiyoYapN↓, (K,) of which last the pl. is xabaAyaA, (TA,) A thing that is hidden, or concealed, (S, * Msb, K,) and absent, or unseen. (K.) [Hence,] xaboCu AlsRamaMCi The rain. (Th, S, K.) And xaboCu AlOaroDi The plants, or herbage. (S, K.) And AlOaroDi xabaAyaA↓ The seed which the sower has hidden in the earth: or what God has hidden in the mines of the earth. (TA, from a trad.) AlRaciI yuxoriju AlxaboCa fiI AlsRamewaAti waAlOaroDi, in the Kur [xxvii. 25], is held by Az to mean Who knoweth what is unseen in the heavens and the earth; agreeably with an explanation of AlxaboCu by Fr. (TA.)

xiboCN xbC
xiboCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

xaboOapN c
xaboOapN A daughter; syn. binotN. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlnRabotu is put for Albinotu.]) Hence the prov., xaboOapN xayorN mino yafaEapi sawoCK [A daughter is better than a grown-up boy of evil deeds]. (TA.) [In Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 438, the first word in this prov. is written xubaOap, and followed by SidoqK.] Aboo-Zeyd Sa'eed Ibn-Ows El-Ansáree entitled one of his books ktAb xbOp because he commenced it by mentioning xbOp in the sense of bnt, quoting the foregoing prov. in confirmation thereof. (TA.)

xuboOapN c
xuboOapN: see xaboCN.

AimoraOapN xubaOapN c
AimoraOapN xubaOapN A woman who shows herself and then hides herself: (S, O, TA:) [like qubaEapN:] or a woman who keeps to her house, or tent. (K.)

xibaMCN xbMC
xibaMCN A well-known kind of structure; (K;) [i. e.] a kind of tent, (Mgh, TA,) made of wool, (Mgh, Msb,) or of camels' fur, or sometimes of [goats'] hair, sometimes upon two poles, or three; what is above this kind being termed bayotN: (Msb:) or a tent having one pole; that which has more than one pole being termed byt: (AZ, TA in art. rbE:) [or] also applied to a byt [or tent] of any kind: (Towsheeh, TA voce bayotN, q. v.:) pl. OaxobiYapN, (TA,) or OaxobiyapN: (Msb:) it is from xabaOahu “ he hid it, ” or “ concealed it: ” (Mgh:) or it belongs to art. xbI: (K:) most of the lexicologists hold that its radical letters are xbI: some, that they are xbw: IDrd asserts that they are xbO. (TA:) [See also art. xbI.] ＝ -A2- A mark made with a hot iron upon some secret part of an excellent she-camel: pl. OaxobiYapN. (Lth, K.)

xabiIoCN xbIC xbyC xbY
xabiIoCN: see xaboCN: and see also 8.

xabiyoYapN c
xabiyoYapN, and its pl. xabaAyaA: see xabNCN, in two places.

kayodN xaAbiYN c
kayodN xaAbiYN An artifice, or a stratagem, resulting in disappointment; i. q. xaAYibN; (AHei, K;) formed [from the latter] by transposition. (AHei.)

xaAbiYapN c
xaAbiYapN, as sometimes pronounced, (Msb,) or xaAbiyapN, with the C suppressed, (S, Msb, K,) because of frequent usage, (Msb,) i. q. HubRN [q. v.]; (S, K;) i. e. A large jar: pl. xwAbI [i. e. xawaAbiYu, or xawaAbK]: (TA:) from xabaOahu “ he hid it, ” or “ concealed it. ” (S, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] binotu AlxaAbiyapi (assumed tropical:) Wine. (Har p. 365.)

maxobaON c
maxobaON A place, or chamber, for hiding or concealing [anything]; a secret place or chamber: pl. maxaAbiYu. (MA.)

jaAriyapN muxabRaOapN c
jaAriyapN muxabRaOapN; so in the [S and] O, and in some of the correct copies of the K; in other copies of the K muxobaOapN; (TA;) [and thus in the CK;] A girl that is [kept in the house, or tent,] concealed from view; or that conceals herself; (S;) that is kept behind, or within, the curtain; (K, TA;) not going forth: or (TA) that is not yet married. (Lth, K, TA.)

muxotabiYN c
muxotabiYN One who conceals himself in order that he may see without the knowledge of him who is seen. (Mgh.)

1 xabata cikoruhu c
1. xabata cikoruhu The mention of him, or it, was, or became, concealed: (L:) [app. meaning he, or it, was, or became, obscure; or of no reputation, or repute.] ＝ -A2- xabuva, accord. to Z, i. q. xabuva [q. v.]: occurring in a trad. (TA.) [See xabiytN.]

4 Axbt OxAb Oxbt Oxbtt Axbt
4. Axbt He became in what is termed xabotN [q. v.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And, (S, Msb, K, TA,) [hence, or] from xabotN, (Ksh and Bd in xi. 25, and TA,) or from xabata cikoruhu, (L,) inf. n. UixobaAtN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) He (a man, Msb, TA) was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (S, Msb, K, TA,) in heart, (Msb,) and obedient, (TA,) lilRehi to God. (S, TA.) And in like manner, in the Kur [xi. 25], (TA,) waOaxobatuwA UilaI rabRihimo means (tropical:) And who have become lowly, humble, or submissive, [and obedient,] to their Lord; or have lowered, humbled, or abased, themselves to their Lord; or have trusted to their Lord: (A, * TA:) for the Arabs put UilaI in the place of li. (TA.)

xabotN xAb xb xbA xbt
xabotN A low, or depressed, tract of ground: (TA:) or a low, or depressed, (S,) or concealed and low, (TA,) tract of ground, in which is sand: (S, TA:) or a wide, or spacious, low tract of ground: (IAar, A, K:) or a plain, or soft, tract of ground in a [stony tract such as is termed] HarRap: (TA:) and a wide bottom, or bed, or interior, of a valley: (A:) or a deep valley, easy to be walked or ridden through, extended [to a great length], and in which grow varieties of the EiDaAh: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxobaAtN (K) and [of mult.] xubuwtN: (A, K:) it is a genuine Arabic word. (TA.)

fiyhi xabotapN fyh xbth fyh xbtp
fiyhi xabotapN (tropical:) In him is lowliness, humility, or submissiveness. (S, TA.)

xabiytN xbyt
xabiytN A thing that is contemptible, or despicable; (K, TA;) bad, corrupt, abominable, vile, base, or disapproved; [&c.;] (TA;) and [thus] i. q. xabiyvN. (As, K.) The Jew of Kheyber says,
yanofaEu AlTRayRibu Alqaliylu mina AlrRizo
qi walaA yanofaEu Alkaviyru Alxabiytu
[The lawful, but small, supply of the means of subsistence is beneficial, but the large and unlawful is not beneficial]. (TA.) Kh asked As respecting Alxbyt in this verse; and the latter replied that the poet meant Alxabiyv; the former word being of the dial. of Kheyber: but Kh rejoined, “ If so, the poet would have said Alktyr: it behooves you only to say that the people of Kheyber change v into t in some words: ” AM thinks that Alxbyt in this verse is a mistranscription for Alxatiyt, which means the thing that is “ contemptible and bad, ” and is syn. with Alxasiys. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a man; meaning as above; or Bad, corrupt, vitious, or depraved. (TA.)

muxobitN mxbt
muxobitN (assumed tropical:) Still; motionless: as also muxobiTN. (TA in art. xmd.)

1 xabuva xbv
1. xabuva, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
xabuva
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xabaAvapN, (S,) or xubovN, the former being a simple subst., (Msb,) or both, (Mgh, K, [the latter word erroneously written in the CK xabov,]) and xabaAviyapN, (K,) said of a thing, (S, Mgh, Msb,) It was, or became, xabiyv [q. v., meaning bad, &c.]; contr. of TaAba. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [Hence,] xabuvato raAYiHatuhu (tropical:) [Its, or his, odour was, or became, bad, foul, or abominable]. (A.) And xabuva TaEomuhu (tropical:) [Its taste was, or became, bad, foul, abominable, or nauseous]. (A.) And xabuvato nafosuhu (tropical:) His soul [or stomach] became heavy; (TA;) it heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato: (A and TA in the present art., and S and K in art. gvI: [see also macirato nafosuhu, in art. mcr:]) a phrase forbidden by Mohammad to be used; as though he disliked the word xubovN. (TA.) One says of certain food, taxobuvu Eanohu AlnRafosu (tropical:) [The soul, or stomach, becomes heavy, or heaves, or becomes agitated by a tendency to vomit, in consequence of it]. (TA.) ― -b2- xabuva, (S, A, K,) inf. n. xubovN, (S, K,) said of a man, signifies [in like manner] He was, or became, xabiyv, (S, A, K,) meaning bad, corrupt, base, or abominable; wicked, deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning. (S, K, TA. [See also 4.]) [Hence,] xabuva bihaA (tropical:) He committed adultery, or fornication, with her. (A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b3- [It is also said of a venomous reptile and the like, meaning It was, or became, malignant, or noxious; impure, unclean, foul, or filthy.]

2 hecaA mimRaA yuxabRivu AlnRafosa c
2. hecaA mimRaA yuxabRivu AlnRafosa, (TA,) or yuxobivu↓, Alnfs, (so in a copy of the A, [but the former I believe to be the right,]) This is of the things that cause the soul [or stomach] to become heavy, or to heave, or become agitated by a tendency to vomit. (TA.)

4 Axbv Oxbv Axbv xbv
4. Axbv He (a man) was, or became, characterized by xubov (Msb, TA) and XarR (Msb) [meaning badness, wickedness, deceit, &c.: see also xabuva]. ― -b2- He had bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends, and a bad, wicked, or deceitful, family: (L:) or his companions, or friends, became bad, wicked, or deceitful: (S in art. fls:) or he took to himself bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends (S, L, K) or connexions or assistants. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Axbvhu He taught him to be bad, wicked, or deceitful: and rendered him bad, corrupt, vitious, or depraved. (S.) ― -b2- See also 2.

5: see what next follows.

6 tHAbv tHAbv
6. tHAbv (A, TA) He made a show of being, or pretended to be, bad, wicked, or deceitful. (TA.) And you say also txbRv↓ [either in the same sense, or as meaning He affected, or endeavoured, to be bad, wicked, or deceitful; or to do that which was xabiyv, or bad, &c.]. (A, TA.)

10 Astxbv Astxbv
10. Astxbv [He deemed, or esteemed, xabiyv, i. e. bad, &c.]. kaAnati AlEarabu tasotaxobivu mivola AlHayRapi waAlEaqorabi [The Arabs used to deem impure, unclean, foul, or filthy, such as the serpent and the scorpion]. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He deemed bad, or corrupt, a word, or a dialectic variant. (A, TA.)

xubovN xbv
xubovN an inf. n. of xabuva: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [used as a simple subst., it means Any of the qualities denoted by the epithet xabiyvN, q. v., i. e. badness, &c.:] and xibRiyvaI↓ signifies the same: (K:) or this is a subst. from Oaxobva meaning “ he had a bad, wicked, or deceitful, family; ” (TA;) and signifies the state of having bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends or connexions: (L:) xaAbivapN↓, also, is syn. with
[xubovN, and so is] xabaAvapN↓, (K,) [for] this last is another inf. n. of xabuva, like xubovN, (S, Mgh, K,) or it is a simple subst. (Msb.) [Hence,] the first particularly signifies (tropical:) Adultery, or fornication. (K, TA.) See also xabiyvN, in three places.

xabavN xbv
xabavN The dross of iron, (S, TA,) and of silver, when they are molten. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] layosa AlUiboriyzu kaAlxabavi [lit. Pure gold is not like dross]; meaning (tropical:) the good is not like the bad. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Adulterating alloy in gold and iron &c. (Har p. 135.) ― -b3- A thing wherein is no good. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Excrement, or ordure: impurity, or filth. (Mgh in art. ql, and TA.) Hence the saying in a trad., UicaA balaga AlmaMCu qulRatayoni lamo yaHomilo xabavFA [explained in art. AHl]. (Mgh ubi suprà, and TA.)

yaA xubavu yA xbv
yaA xubavu: see xabiyvN.

yaA xibovapu yA xbvh yA xbvp
yaA xibovapu: see xabyvN. ＝ -A2- xibovapN with respect to a slave signifies (assumed tropical:) Unlawful capture; capture from a people whom it is unlawful to make slaves, (Mgh, * K, TA,) by reason of a treaty, or league, made with them, (Mgh, TA,) or of some sacred, or inviolable, right, originally belonging to them. (TA.) You say of a slave, laA xibovapa fiyhi mino UibaAqK walaA sariqapK (tropical:) [There is no unlawful capture in his case, from having run away, nor from having been stolen]. (A.) ― -b2- fulaAnN lixibovap is like the saying lizinoyapK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is the offspring of adultery, or fornication]. (S.) And wulida fulaAnN lixibovapK means (tropical:) Such a one was born spuriously. (A, * L.)

xabaAvi xbAv
xabaAvi: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xabiyvN xbyv
xabiyvN contr. of TayRibN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to objects of the senses and to those of the intellect; (Kull p. 177;) to sustenance, or victuals, and to offspring, and men, and to other things: (TA:) Bad; corrupt: (Msb, TA:) disapproved, hated, or abominable; (Msb, TA;) this accord. to IAar, being its primary signification: (TA:) or so in respect of taste, and of odour: (Mgh:) [nasty, nauseous, loathsome, or disgusting:] impure, unclean, foul, or filthy: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) unlawful; (Mgh, Msb;) applied in this sense to certain food: and, applied to certain beverage, injurious: (TA:) applied to medicine such as is forbidden in a certain trad., it means either impure and unlawful, such as wine &c., or nauseous to the taste: (IAth, TA:) you say that a thing is xabiyv in taste, [and in odour,] and in colour: and you apply this epithet to adultery, or fornication; and to property unlawfully acquired; and to blood, and to the like things which God has forbidden: (TA:) also to such things as garlic and onions (Msb, TA) and leeks, (TA,) which are disagreeable in taste and odour: (TA:) and to such things as the serpent and the scorpion: (Msb:) applied to language, it means (assumed tropical:) opprobrious, or of a reviling nature; (TA;) and (tropical:) bad or corrupt [in respect of authority; or of a bad dialect]: (A, TA:) applied to religion, (assumed tropical:) infidel, or of the nature of infidelity: (TA:) applied to a man, bad, corrupt, base, or abominable; wicked, deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; (S, K, TA;) as also xaAbivN↓: (K:) and an adulterer, or a fornicator: (Msb:) and a blamer, or censurer: or a slanderer, or calumniator: (Har p. 611:) [and, applied to a venomous reptile and the like, malignant, or noxious; as well as impure, unclean, foul, or filthy:] the fem. is xabiyvapN: (Msb:) the pl. masc. is xibaAvN (A, TA) and xubuvN, for which it is allowable to say xubovN↓, accord. to the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) and xubavaMCu, (S, A, Msb, TA,) like XurafaMCu [pl. of XariyfN], (Msb,) and OaxobaAvN, like OaXaraAfN [another pl. of XariyfN], (Msb, MF, TA,) and xabavapN, (Kr, Msb, MF, TA,) like DaEafapN pl. of DaEiyfN, (Msb, MF, TA,) two instances of which the like can scarcely be found, (Msb,) or is not found among sound words, for saraApN pl. of sariIRN is an unsound word, (MF, TA,) and xubuwvN, (AZ, TA,) which is also extr., (TA,) [and xabaAvaI, (like as HazaAnaI is a pl. of HaziynN,) applied in the A, in art. xnv, to xanaAvaI, pl. of xunovaI,] and xabiyvuwna [applied only to rational beings]: (Mgh:) and the pl. fem., i. e. of xabiyvapN, is xabaAYivu (Msb, TA) and xabiyvaAtN. (Mgh.) AlXRajarapu Alxabiyvapu, mentioned in the Kur [xiv. 31], (TA,) means The colocynth: or the kaXuwv, (K; TA,) which is a certain plant that clings to the branches of trees and has no root in the earth; (S and K in art. kXv;) [a species of cuscuta, or dodder;] or yellow Euruwq that cling to trees: (TA in the present art.:) also occurring in a trad., as meaning the garlic-plant; and the onion; and the leek; because of their disagreeable taste and odour. (IAth, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the slain at Bedr, OuloquwA fiI qaliybK xabiyvK muxobivK↓ They were cast into a well corrupt, and corrupting what fell into it. (TA.) xabiyvN muxobivN↓, (S, L,) or xabiyvN and muxobivN↓, (K,) and xaAbivN↓ (TA) and maxobavaAnN↓, (S, L, K,) applied to a man, signify One who takes to himself bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends (S, L, K, TA) or connexions or assistants: (TA:) or maxobavaAnu↓, as a determinate noun, [without the article Al] is only used in calling to, or addressing, a person: (K:) you say, yaA maxobavaAnu; (S;) fem. maxobavaAnapu↓: and to a man and woman together, yA maxobavaAnu: (L, TA:) and in the phrase xabiyvN muxobivN↓, the former word signifies bad, wicked, or deceitful, in himself; and the latter, having bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends and assistants. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) One says also, yaAxubavu↓, meaning yA xabiyvu [O bad or wicked or deceitful man!]; and to a woman, yaAxabaAvi↓, (S, K,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, (S,) and yA xabiyvapu. (K [accord. to SM: so in all the copies in his hands; but not found by him in any other lexicon: not in the CK, nor in my MS. copy of the K.]) xabaAvi↓ also occurs, in a saying of El-Hasan, addressed to the present world, AldRunoyaA. (L.) And yaA xibovapu↓ was said by El-Hajjáj to Anas, as meaning yA xabiyvu: and is also used as meaning O [thou of] bad, wicked, or deceitful, qualities or dispositions! [app. addressed to a woman, as the context seems to show; and agreeably with an assertion in Ham p. 810, that xibovpN is sometimes used in speaking of an old woman]. (L, TA.) xabiyvu AlnRafosi means (tropical:) Having the soul [or stomach] heavy, [or heaving, or agitated by a tendency to vomit,] and in a disagreeable state. (TA.) And maxobavaAnN↓ applied to a lie occurs in a trad, as meaning xabiyvN app. in an intensive sense [i. e. Very abominable]. (TA.) In the saying, OaEuwdu biQllRehi, (Mgh,) or AallRehumRa UinRiI OaEuwdu bika, (Msb, * K, * TA,) mina Alxubuvi waAlxbaAYivi, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or waAlxabaAYivi mina Alxubovi↓, (Msb, K, TA,) a form of words which Mohammad directed his followers to pronounce on entering a privy, or place of retirement for the relief of nature, because devils are in such a place, (Mgh, TA,) Alxubuv is pl. of Alxabiyv, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and so is Alxubov accord. to the dial. of Temeem, (Msb, TA,) and AlxabaAYiv is pl. of Alxabiyvap; (Mgh, TA;;) and the meaning is, I seek protection by God, or O God, I seek protection by Thee, from the male devils and the female devils, (IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) of the genii and of mankind: (Mgh:) or, reading Alxubov↓, [as a subst,] from infidelity and the devils: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or, [so reading, and regarding AlxbAYv as pl. of Alxabiyvapu↓ used as a subst.,] from infidelity and acts of disobedience: (Msb, TA:) or, from wicked, or unrighteous, conduct, such as adultery and the like, and culpable actions and evil qualities or dispositions: El-Khattábee asserts that the reading Alxubov, with the b quiescent, is a mistake of the relaters of traditions; but En-Nawawee rejects this assertion. (TA.)

xabaAvapN: see xubovN.

xabiyvapN xbyv xbyvh xbyvp
xabiyvapN fem. of the epithet xabiyvN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, [used as a subst.,] A bad, wicked, or deceitful, quality or disposition; and a culpable action: pl. xabaAYivu. (L, TA.) [Hence,] OumRu AlxabaAYivi (assumed tropical:) [The mother of bad qualities &c.; meaning] wine. (T in art. Am.) See also xabiyvN, last sentence. ― -b3- AlxabaAYivu also signifies Those things which the Arabs deemed foul, or filthy, or unclean, and which they did not eat; such as vipers, and scorpions, and the brS [i. e. either baroS or buroS], and the waral, and beetles, and the rat, or mouse. (L.)

xibRiyvN, applied to a man, (TA,) signifies kaviyru Alxubovi [i. e. Very bad or wicked or deceitful; or much addicted to adultery or fornication]: pl. xibRiyvuwna. (K.)

xaAbivN: see xabiyvN, in two places.

xaAbivapN: see xubovN.

Oaxobavu c
Oaxobavu [compar. and superl. of xabiyvN]: pl. OaxaAbivu. (TA.) You say, humo OaxaAbivu AlnRaAsi [They are the worst, or the most wicked or deceitful, of men]. (TA.) And huwa mina AlOaxaAbivi [He is of the worst, &c., of men]. (A, TA.) And hiIa
Oaxobavu AlRugatayoni (tropical:) It is the worse, or more corrupt, [in respect of authority,] of the two words, or dialectic variants. (A, TA.) ― -b2- AlOaxobavaAni Urine and dung (S, A, Msb, K) of a human being: (S, Msb, K:) or vomit and human ordure or thin human ordure: (Fr, TA:) or fetor of the mouth, and sleeplessness: or sleeplessness, and disquietude of mind by reason of grief. (K.) It is said in a trad., laA yuSalRiI AlrRajulu wuhuwa yudaAfiEu AlOaxobavayoni [The man shall not pray while he is striving to suppress the urine and ordure]. (TA.)

waqaEa fiI waAdiI tuxubRiva wqE fy wAdy txbv
waqaEa fiI waAdiI tuxubRiva, (K, * TA,) in which the last word, also pronounced tuxubRava, is imperfectly decl., (TA,) is similar to wqE fI wAdI tuxuyRiba [and means He fell into a state of things that was bad, corrupt, disapproved, &c.]. (K, TA.)

muxobivo mxbv
muxobivo One who teaches others to be bad, wicked, or deceitful: and some allow it to be applied to one who attributes, or imputes, to others what is bad, wicked, or the like. (TA.) ― -b2- See also xabiyvN, in four places.

maxobavapN mxbvh mxbvp
maxobavapN A cause of evil or corruption: (S, K:) pl. maxaAbivu. (TA.) So in the saying of 'Antarah,
nubRiYotu EamorFA gayora XaAkiri niEomatiI
waAlkuforu maxobavapN linafosi AlmunoEimi
[I have been told that 'Amr is not thankful for my beneficence: and ingratitude is a cause of evil to the soul of the benefactor]. (S.) One says also, fiyhi maxaAbivu jamRapN [In him, or it, are many causes of evil or corruption]. (A.) And TaEaAmN maxobavapN (tropical:) Food that is a cause of heaviness to the soul [or stomach]; or of heaving, or becoming agitated by a tendency to vomit: or that is unlawful. (TA.)

maxobavaAnN mxbvAn
maxobavaAnN and maxobavaAnu and maxobavaAnapu: see xabiyvN, in four places.

1. xabura, aor.
xabura
, (K,) inf. n. xubuwrN; (TA;) and Axtbr↓, and txbRr↓; (K;) He knew; or had, or possessed, knowledge; biXaIoCK [of a thing; generally meaning, with respect to its internal, or real, state]. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- xabarahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
xabura
, (Msb, MS,) inf. n. xaborN; (Msb, MS; *) and xabirahu, [aor.
xabara
,] (A,) inf. n. xabarN; (TA;) and Axtbirhu↓, and txbRrhu↓; (TA;) He knew it; syn. Ealimahu; (S, A, Msb;) [generally meaning, with respect to its internal, or real, state; like xabura bihi: see xuborN, its simple subst., as distinguished from its inf. n.] You say, mino Oayona xabarota hacaA AlOamora, (so in a copy of the S,) or xabirota, (so in another copy of the S, and so in the A, where it is expressly said to be with kesr,) Whence knewest thou this thing? (S, A. *) ― -b2- And xabarahu, (S, K,) aor.
xabura
, (S,) inf. n. xuborN and xiborapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and Axtbrhu↓ [which is the more common in this sense]; (S, Msb, K;) He tried, made trial of, made experiment of, tested, proved, assayed, proved by trial or experiment or experience him, or it. (S, Msb, K.) Hence the phrase, (S,) laOaxoburanRa xabaraka, (S, K,) in some good lexicons xuboraka, (TA, [and so in the CK, but this I think to be a mistake, suggested by the explanation, which is not literal,]) i. q. laOaEolamanRa Eilomaka [which properly signifies I will assuredly know thy knowledge, or what thou knowest, but here means, as is shown by the manner in which the phrase that it explains is mentioned in the S, I will assuredly try, prove, or test, thy state, and so know what thou knowest]. (S, K.) [Hence, also,] the saying of Abu-dDardà, wajadotu AlnRaAsa Auxoburo taqolihimo, (S,) or taqolihi, (A, K,) I found the people to be persons of whom it is said thus: [Try, prove, or test, them, or him, and thou wilt hate them, or him:] i. e. there is not one [of them] but his conduct is hated when it is tried, or proved, or tested: (K:) or when thou triest, provest, or testest, them, thou wilt hate them: the imperative form being used, but the meaning being that of an enunciative: (S, A, L, B:) [wajadotu is a verb of the kind called OafoEaAlu Alquluwbi, which govern two objective complements; therefore Auxoburo taqolihimo and Auxoburo taqolihi are for maqoliyRiyna Einoda Alxiborapi and maqoliyRFA End Alxbrp.] ＝ -A3- xabara AlOaroDa, [and, as appears from a passage in the L, xbRrhA↓, (see xaborN,)] He furrowed, or ploughed, the land for sowing. (Msb.) ＝ -A4- xabara AlTRaEaAma, (K,) aor.
xabura
, inf. n. xaborN, (TA,) He made the food greasy; or put grease to it. (K, TA.) ＝ -A5- xabira It (a place) was, or became, what is termed xaboraMC: (S:) or abounded with sidor [or lote-trees]. (TA.) ― -b2- And xabirati AlOaroDu, aor.
xabara
, (K,) inf. n. xabarN, (TA,) The land, or ground, abounded with xabaAr [app. meaning soft soil: see 3]. (K.) ＝ -A6- xbrt, [probably xaburato, like gazurato &c.,] inf. n. xubuwrN, (tropical:) She (a camel) abounded with milk. (Lh, TA. [See xaborN.])

3 xaAobara
3: xAbrhu, (TA,) inf. n. maxaAbarapN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) [He made a contract, or bargain, with him to till and sow and cultivate land for a share of its produce:] the inf. n. signifies i. q. muzaAraEapN [i. e. the making a contract, or bargain, with another to cultivate land for a share of its produce], (AO, Lh, S, A, IAth, Mgh, Msb,) for somewhat of its produce, (S, Msb,) or for a third or a quarter, (AO, Mgh,) or for a determined share, such as a third or a quarter or some other portion, (IAth,) or for half or the like: (so in some copies of the K and in the TA:) or the tilling the ground for half or the like: (so in other copies of the K:) and i. q. muWaAkarapN: (K:) and xiborN↓ is syn. with muxaAbarapN: (S, K:) it is a forbidden practice: (A, Mgh, TA:) it is from xabiyrN signifying “ a tiller, or cultivator, of land: ” (S, Mgh:) or from xabara “ he furrowed, or ploughed (land) for sowing; ” whence xabiyrN also: (Msb:) or from xabirati AlOaroDu “ the land abounded with xabaAr: ” or from [the fortress of] xayobar, because the Prophet made it to remain in the possession of its inhabitants for half of its revenue; and therefore it was said, xaAbarahumo. (TA.)

4 Axbrhu Oxbr Oxbrh Axbrh Axbrp xbr
4. Axbrhu, [inf. n. UixobaArN;] (S, A, Msb, K;) and xbRrhu↓, (S, A, K,) inf. n. taxobiyrN; (K;) are syn. [as signifying He informed him, told him, or acquainted him]. (S, A, K.) You say, Oaxobarotuhu bikacaA, (S, Msb,) [and Eano kcA,] and xabRarotuhu↓, (S,) [I informed him, or told him, of such a thing; or acquainted him with such a thing; or made him to know the internal, or real, state of such a thing.] And Axbrhu xubuwrapF↓, i. e. OanobaOahu maA Einodahu [He informed him, or told him, of what he had, or knew]. (K. [Whether it be meant that Axbr is doubly trans. without a particle, in this instance, like OaEolama, or whether xbwrp be a quasi-inf. n, is not explained.]) One says also, tuxobiru Eano majohuwlihi maroMtuhu (tropical:) [His aspect acquaints one with his unknown state or qualities]. (A.) [And Axbr Eanohu He predicated of him, or it.] ＝ -A2- Oaxobarotu AllRiqoHap (tropical:) I found the milch camel to be abounding with milk. (K. [See 1, last sentence.])

Astxbrhu (A, K) and txbRrhu↓ (K) He asked, or sought, or desired, of him information, or news, or tidings: (A, * K:) or he asked him respecting news, or tidings, and desired that he should inform him thereof. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, by way of comparison thereto, (S,) (tropical:) A she-camel abounding with milk; (S, K;) as also xiborN↓, (K,) and maxobuwrapN↓ [naAqapN]. (TA.)

xuborN (S, A, K) and xiborN↓ (K) and xaborN↓, an inf. n., (Msb,) and xabarN↓, also an inf. n., (TA,) and xuborapN↓ and xiborapN↓ and maxobarapN↓, (K,) Knowledge, syn. EilomN, (S, A, Msb, K,) biXaIoCK [of a thing]:
(A, K:) or, accord. to some, xubozN signifies knowledge of the secret internal state: and xibozapN↓ and xubozapN↓ signify knowledge of the external and internal state; or, as some say, of secret internal circumstances or properties; but this necessarily involves acquaintance with external things. (TA.) You say, liI bihi xuborN and xiborapN↓ [&c.] I have knowledge of it. (TA.) And maA liI bihi xuborN [&c.] I have not knowledge of it. (A.) ― -b2- See also xiborapN. ＝ -A2- And see xabiyrN: ＝ -A3- and xuborapN.

xiborN xbr
xiborN: see xuborN: ＝ -A2- and see also 3: ＝ -A3- and see xaborN, in two places.

xabarN xbr
xabarN [originally] an inf. n. of xabirahu: see xuborN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Information; a piece of information; a notification; intelligence; an announcement; news; tidings; a piece of news; an account; a narration, or narrative; a story; syn. nabaON; (T, K;) that comes to one from a person of whom he asks it: (TA:) or xabarN and nabaON are not synonymous; for, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, the latter relates to a thing of great importance: and accord. to the leading authorities in lexicology and the science of conventional language, the former signifies properly, and in its common acceptation, what is related from another or others: to which authors on the Arabic language add, that it may be true or false: (MF:) or what is related from another or others, and talked of: (Msb:) pl. OaxobaArN, (S, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. OaxaAbiyru. (K.) ― -b3- By the relaters of traditions, it is used as syn. with HadiyvN [signifying A tradition; or narrative relating, or describing, a saying or an action &c. of Mohammad]: (TA:) or this latter term is applied to what comes from the Prophet; and xabarN, to what comes from another than the Prophet; or from him or another; and OavarN, to what comes from a Companion of the Prophet; but it may also be applied to a saying of the Prophet. (Kull p. 152.) ― -b4- [In grammar, as correlative of mubotadaON, An enunciative: and as correlative of AisomN, the predicate of the non-attributive verb kaAna and the like, and of kaAda &c.] ― -b5- Also A man's state, or case; AlOamoru AlRaciI huwa Ealyohi. (Har p. 20.)

xabirN xbr
xabirN: see xabiyrN, in two places. ＝ -A2- See also xaborN. ― -b2- xabirapN, or OaroDN xabirapN; and mawoDiEN xabirN, and xabirN alone: see xuborN.

(TA.) ― -b3- What one buys for his family; as also xuborN↓: (K:) accord. to some, (TA,) flesh-meat (K, TA) which one buys for his family. (TA.) ― -b4- Food, (K, TA,) consisting of flesh-meat and other kinds. (TA.) ― -b5- A thing brought forward or offered [for entertainment]. (Lh, K.) So in the saying, AijotamaEuwA EalaI xuboratihi [They congregated over what he had brought forward, or offered, for their entertainment]. (Lh.) ― -b6- A mess of crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth, large, (K, TA,) and greasy. (TA.) ― -b7- A bowl in which are bread and flesh-meat for four or five [persons]. (K.) ― -b8- Food which the traveller carries in his journey, (K,) and provides for himself. (TA.) ― -b9- Seasoning, condiment, or savoury food; as also xabiyrN↓: whence the saying, OataAnaA bixubozapK walamo yaOotinaA bixuborapK [He brought us a cake of bread, but he brought us not any seasoning]. (TA.) ― -b10- Hence, by the Karaj, whose land is adjacent to 'Irák el-'Ajam, applied to A date; and by some of them pronounced xubolapN. (TA.)

xaboraMCu, (Lth, S, K,) and OaroDN xaboraMCu, (S,) and xabirapN↓, (Lth, K, [in the CK xaborap,]) or OaroDN xabirapN, (S,) A plain, or level, tract of land, that produces sidor [or lote-trees]: (S, K:) or a tract abounding with trees, in the lower part of a meadow, in which water remains until the hot season, and in which grow trees of the kinds called sidor and OaraAk, with abundant herbage around them: (Lth:) the pl. of xaboraMCu is xabaAraI and xabaArK and xaboraAwaAtN (S, K) and xibaArN; (K;) and the pl. of xabirapN is xabirN↓; (TA;) [or this is neither a pl. nor a quasi-pl. n.: it may be a coll. gen. n.: but it is probably only an epithet, of which xabirapN is the fem.; for] one says also mawoDiEN xabirN↓, (S, TA,) meaning a place abounding with sidor. (TA.) ― -b2- xaboraMCu also signifies A place where water collects and stagnates: (TA:) or where water collects and stagnates at the roots of trees of the kind called sidor: (K, TA:) or a round low tract of level ground in which water collects. (TA.) It is said in a prov., mano tajanRaba AlxabaAra Oamina AlEivaAra [He who avoids soft ground in which the feet sink will be secure from stumbling]. Alxabuwru The lion. (K.)

Xhd:) or possessing knowledge of matters of information, news, tidings, accounts, narratives, or stories; of what is termed xabarN; (K;) or of what are termed OaxobaAr; (TA;) as also xaAbirN↓ and xabirN↓, (K,) which last is thought by ISd to be a possessive [as distinguished from a verbal] epithet, (TA,) [or it is from xabira, a form which ISd may not have known,] and xuborN↓, (K,) which is an intensive epithet: (TA:) also informed; possessing information. (TA.) You say, OanaA bihi xabiyrN I have knowledge of it. (A.) And [hence] Alxabiyru is a name of God, meaning He who knoweth what hath been and what is or will be: (TA:) or He who well knoweth the internal qualities of things. (Sharh Et-Tirmidhee.) ― -b2- Also Possessing knowledge of God, (K, TA,) by being acquainted with his names and his attributes. (TA.) ― -b3- A lawyer; one skilled in the law, or practical religion. (TA.) ― -b4- A head, or chief. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A tiller, or cultivator, of land. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- Fur, or soft hair, syn. wabarN, (S, K,) of camels, and (tropical:) of the wild ass. (TA.) ― -b2- Hair that has fallen: and with p, a portion thereof. (K.) [See also xabiyrapN below.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Plants, or herbage; (S, K, TA;) fresh herbage: (K, TA:) likened to the wabar of camels, because growing like the latter: and seed-produce. (TA.) It is said in a trad., nasotaxolibu Alxabiyra (tropical:) We cut (S, TA) with the reaping-hook, (TA,) and eat, the plants, or herbage. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Froth, or foam: (TA:) or the froth, or foam, of the mouths of camels. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A4- Seasoned, or made savoury. (TA.) ― -b2- See also xuborapN.

Kheyber is mutanaAcarap [i. e. a fever “ against which people warn one another, ” because it is generally fatal]. (TA.) [See also xaAsirN.]

(A, TA.) And xabaza AlbaEiyru, (TK,) inf. n. xabozN, (S, K,) (tropical:) The camel beat the ground with his fore foot, (S, * K, * TA,) or, as in some lexicons, with his fore feet. (TA.) xubozN xbz
xubozN a word of well-known meaning; (K;) [Bread;] that which is eaten. (S.) It is said in a prov., kulRu OadaApi Alxubozi EinodiI gayoruhu [All the apparatus of bread is in my possession except it, namely, the bread itself]: the origin of which was this: a company of men demanded hospitality of a certain man; and when they sat down, he threw down a [piece of leather such as is called] niToE, and put upon it a mill-stone, and adjusted its pivot, and covered it [with the upper stone]: and the presence of his apparatus made the company to wonder: then he took the handle of the mill, (haAdiI AlrRaHaI,) and began to turn it: whereupon they said to him, What dost thou? and he answered in the words of this proverb. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlxulRapu xubozu AlUibili (tropical:) [Sweet herbage is the bread of camels: and AlHamoDu faAkihatuhaA, or AaHomuhaA, sour herbage is their fruit, or flesh-meat]. (A, TA.)

xibaAzapN xbAz xbAzh xbAzp

xubaAzaI xbAz xbAzI xbAzy xbAzyy

xabRaAzN xbAz
xabRaAzN A maker of bread; one whose office it is to make bread: (TA:) a baker; syn. furoniIRN. (Msb in art. frn.)

xubRaAzN xbAz
xubRaAzN (IDrd, S, K) and xubRaAzapN↓, (K,) [or the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un.,] and xubaAzaI↓ (IDrd, S, K) [which last is the most common form] and xubRaAzaI↓, (K,) or when with teshdeed the I is elided, (IDrd,) and xubRayozN↓, (K,) [Malva, or mallow;] a certain plant, well known, (S, K, TA,) of the leguminous kind, having broad leaves and a round fruit; [whence perhaps its name;] accord. to the Minháj, a species of the maluwxiyRapN [corchorus olitorious, or Jew's mallow]: or, as some say, the mlwxyRp is the garden-kind, and the xbAzI is the wild kind: some also say that the baqolap yahuwdiyRap [sonchus, or sow-thistle,] is one of the species of xbAzI; and there is a kind thereof that turns with the sun. 10. AstxbS Dayofuhumo Their guest asked for, or demanded, a mess of xabiyS [q. v.]. (A, TA.)

xabiySN xbyS
xabiySN Mixed; syn. maxobuwSN. (TA.) ― -b2- A kind of food, (Msb, TA,) sweet, (TA,) well known, (S, Msb, TA,) made of dates and clarified butter, (A, K, TA,) mixed together: (TA:) [Golius adds, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, “ aut amylo et defruto; ” app. meaning, or of starch and of new wine of which half or a third part has been boiled away: and one kind, called xabiySN muramRalN, was made with coarse flour: (see jariyXN:)] of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) xabiySapN is a more particular term [signifying a mess of xabiyS]. 1 xabaTa xbT
1. xabaTa, aor.
xabiTa
, (Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. xaboTN, (Msb, TA, &c.,) He struck, or beat, (Msb, TA,) anything: (TA:) or he struck, or beat, it, or him, vehemently: (M, K, TA:) or xaboTN signifies a camel's striking, or beating, a thing with his fore foot: (T, TA:) or in the cases of beasts, (dawaAbR, [generally meaning horses and mules and asses,]) the striking, or beating, with the fore feet; not with the hind feet: and in the case of the camel, with the fore foot and the hind foot: or vehement treading; or of the fore feet of beasts (dwAbR): (TA:) or, accord. to the Keshsháf, the act of striking, or beating, in a way
that is not right: or, as some say, the going, or journeying, upon what is not the middle, or main part, of the road, or what is not the main road, or upon a road not open to view: or continuous, or consecutive, striking, or beating, in different ways: and afterwards tropically applied to any (tropical:) beating, or striking, that is not approved: or originally, the striking, or beating, with the fore foot or the hind foot, and the like: (MF, TA:) with the fore feet or legs, it is like ramoHN with the hind feet or legs. (TA.) You say, of a camel, xabaTa AlOaroDa, (Msb,) or xabaTa AlOaroDa biyadihi, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He struck, or beat, the ground with his fore foot: (S, Msb:) or he struck, or beat, vehemently the ground with his fore foot; and txbRT↓ and AxtbT↓ signify the same: (K:) it is said in the O that xabaTahu signifies he struck him with his fore foot, or hand, and prostrated him, as also txbRThu↓: and AxtbT↓, said of a camel, is syn. with xabaTa: and in the T, that birijolihi taxabRaTaniI↓ is syn, with xabaTaniI. (TA.) Hence the trad., laA taxobiTuwA xaboTa Aljamali [lit. Ye shall not beat the ground as the camel does with his fore foot in rising]; meant to forbid a man's putting forward his foot in rising from prostration [in prayer]. (TA.) And xabaTahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies also He trod him, or it, vehemently, (K, TA,) as the camel does with his fore foot. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) fulaAnN yaxobiTu xaboTa EaXowaMCa (S, * TA) (tropical:) [Such a one goes at random, in a headstrong and reckless manner,] like the weak-sighted she-camel that beats the ground with her fore feet (taxobiTu) as she goes along, not guarding herself from anything. (S, TA.) It is a prov., applied to him who turns away from a thing as though he were not cognizant of it: or to him who is continually falling into a thing. (Har p. 239.) Zuheyr says,
raOayotu AlmanaAyaA xaboTa EaXowaMCa mano tuSibo
tumitohu wamano tuxoTiYo yuEamRaro fayahorami
I saw the fates [treading mankind] like the treading of the weak-sighted she-camel; whom they smote, him they killed: and whom they missed, he was made to continue in life so that he lived to extreme old age. (TA, and EM p. 132.) In like manner you say, fulaAnN yaxobiTu fiI EamoyaMCa (tropical:) Such a one undertakes what he undertakes with ignorance. (TA.) And xabaTa Oamorahu EalaI gayori baSyrapK (assumed tropical:) [He prosecuted his affair without mental perception, or without certainty]. (S in art. EXw, q. v.) And yaxobiTu fiI AlZRalaAmi (tropical:) He goes in the night without a lamp, and so becomes confounded and perplexed, and unable to see his right course, and errs from the way, and perchance may fall into a well. (TA.) And xabaTa AllRayola, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He went, or journeyed, in the night without direction. (K, TA.) And baAta yaxobiTu AlZRalomaMCa (tropical:) [He passed the night traversing the darkness without direction]. (TA.) xaboTN is said to signify (assumed tropical:) The act of journeying, or going, without direction: or upon what is not the middle, or main part, of the road, or what is not the main road. (TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] xabaTahu (tropical:) He asked of him a benefit, or favour, without any tie of relationship; (K, * TA;) as also AxtbThu↓: (IB, K:) or this is from xaboTu waraqi AlXRajari [explained in what follows]: (Har p. 425:) or the latter, [or both,] he came to him seeking his beneficence without any such tie: (S:) or he came to him seeking a gift; because he who does so must beat the ground with his feet: (IF:) and you also say, maEoruwfahu AxtbT↓. (Aboo-Málik, TA.) [The latter verb is the more common. See also 10.] ― -b4- And (tropical:) He conferred a benefit upon him without there having been any acquaintance between them, (S, K, TA,) and without there being anything to draw them near, and without there being any relationship: (TA:) and xabaTahu bixayori signifies the same: (TA:) or he bestowed on him a benefit, (K, TA,) being asked: (TA:) and you say also, bixayorK AxtbThu↓: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) and xabaTa fiyhimo bixayorK signifies (assumed tropical:) He benefited them. (TA.) 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh says, (S, TA,) praising El-Hárith Ibn-AbeeShemir, (TA,)
wafiI kulRi HaIRK qado xabaTota biniEomapK
(assumed tropical:) [And upon every tribe thou hast conferred benefit, app. meaning without being related to them]: (S, TA:) but it is said in a marginal note to the S, that xabaTRa would be better; and so it is accord. to one relation: in the L, however, it is said that xabatRa would be more agreeable with analogy. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, xabaTotu AlrRajula, inf. n. xaboTN, signifies (assumed tropical:) I held loving communion, commerce, or intercourse, with the man. (TA.) ― -b5- [In respect of the places which I have given to the abovementioned significations of asking and conferring a benefit, I have followed the opinion of IF; but it is said in the TA, and, I think, with greater probability, that they are from what here next follows.] ― -b6- xabaTa Alwaraqa mina AlXRajari, aor.
xabiTa
, (Msb,) inf. n. xaboTN, (Lth, T, Msb,) He made the leaves to fall from the trees: (Msb:) or he beat the leaves of the trees, (Lth, T,) meaning large trees of the kind called TaloH, [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera,] with a staff, or stick, (Lth,) so that they fell off, or became scattered, (Lth, T,) after which he gave them as food to camels; (Lth;) refrainfrom injuring thereby the trunks and branches of the trees: (T:) and lahu xabaTFA AxtbT↓ signifies the same as xabaTa. (TA.) And xabaTa AlXRajarapa, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S,) He beat the tree with a staff, or stick, in order that its leaves might fall off: (S:) or he bound the tree, and then made its leaves to fall, (K, TA,) by beating it with a staff, or stick, to give them as food to camels and other beasts. (TA.) The leaves are stored up for the camels; and in wintertime are bruised, or broken up, for them, and moistened with water, and given to them as fodder. (Har p. 218.) Mohammad was asked, Does AlgaboT [i. e. “ the wishing for a blessing on the condition that it shall not become transferred from its possessor ”] injure [its author]? and he answered, laA UilRaA kamaA yaDurRu AlEiDaAha AlxaboTu [No, save as the beating off the leaves injures the trees called 'idáh]; i. e., it only diminishes, without annulling, its author's recompense, like the beating off the leaves of the 'idáh, without cutting them down and extirpating them; for the leaves will grow again. (TA.) [See also art. gbT.] ― -b7- Hence, (A, TA,) xabaTa Alqawoma bisayofihi (tropical:) He struck the people with his sword. (A, K, TA.) ― -b8- xabaTahu AlXRayoTaAnu (tropical:) The devil touched him with a hurt, (K, TA,) so as to corrupt him, or disorder him, and render him insane; (TA;) as also txbRThu↓: (K, TA:) or the latter, [which is the more common,] the devil corrupted him, or disordered him: (S, Mgh, Msb: *) lit., struck him: (Mgh, Msb:) or prostrated him, and sported with him: or trampled upon him, and prostrated him. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 276], laA yaquwmuwna UilRaA kamaA yaquwmu QlRaciI yataxabRaTuhu↓ AlXRayoTaAnu mina QlomasRi (tropical:) [They shall not rise save as he riseth whom the devil prostrateth by reason of possession, or insanity]; i. e., as he who is affected by diabolical possession rises, in his state of possession, when he is prostrated, and falls: or it means, whom the devil corrupts, or disorders, by rendering him insane. (K, * TA.) [You say also, of a drug, AlEaqola xbRT↓ (assumed tropical:) It disordered the intellect: see the act. part. n., below.] ― -b9- xabaTa also signifies (assumed tropical:) He (a man) threw himself down (S, L, K) where he was, (S, L,) to sleep, (S, K,) or and slept. (L.) And (assumed tropical:) He (a man) slept. (A' Obeyd, TA.) In the K, qaAma is erroneously put for naAma. (TA.) ― -b10- xabaTa EalaI AlbaAbi He knocked upon the door, or at the door. (TA.) ― -b11- xabaTa AlEiroqu The vein beat, or pulsated. (TA.)

1 xatamahu xtm xtmh xtmp

xatima
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xatomN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and xitaAmN, (Lh, K, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, xataAm,] i. q. TabaEahu [He sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed, it]: (Msb, K:) or he put the xaAtam [or signet] upon it: (Mgh:) namely, a thing, (S, Mgh,) or a writing or book and the like: and xatama Ealayohi signifies the same [or he put a seal, or the impression of a signet, upon it]. (Msb.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, xatomN and TaboEN signify The impressing a thing with the engraving of the signet and stamp: and the former [as is indicated, but not plainly expressed, as distinguished from the latter,] is tropically used, sometimes, as meaning the securing oneself from a thing, and protecting [oneself] from it; in consideration of protection by means of sealing upon writings and doors: and sometimes as meaning the producing an impression, or effect, upon a thing from another thing; in consideration of the impress produced [by the signet]: and sometimes it is used as relating to (assumed tropical:) the reaching the end [of a thing]: (TA:) or the primary signification of xatomN is the act of covering over [a thing]: (Az, TA:) accord. to Zj, the proper meaning of xatomN and TaboEN is the covering over a thing, and securing oneself from a thing's entering it: some say that the former signifies the concealing a notification of a thing, [as] by putting one's fingers over it, by way of guarding oneself thereby. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, xatomu AlXRahaAdapi [The sealing of the testimony]; which is thus described by El-Hulwánee: the witness, when he wrote his name upon a SakR [q. v.], caused his written name to be beneath a piece of lead, [i. e. covered it with a piece of lead,] and put upon it the impress of his signet, in order that there might be no falsification of it or substitution for it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- As to xatomu AlOaEonaAqi [The sealing of the necks], the case is related, in the “Risáleh Yoosufeeyeh,” to have been this: 'Omar sent Ibn-Honeyf to seal the Euluwj [or unbelievers] of the Sawád; and he sealed five hundred thousand of them, in classes; that is, he marked them twelve dirhems, and twenty-four, and forty-eight; tying a thong upon the neck of each, and putting upon the knot a seal of lead. (Mgh.) ― -b4- xatomN also signifies The protecting what is in a writing by marking [or stamping] a piece of clay [upon it, or by means of a seal of any kind]. (TA.) ― -b5- And you say, of a man, xatama Ealayoka baAbahu [He sealed his door against thee]; meaning (tropical:) he turned away from thee, avoided thee, or shunned thee. (TA.) ― -b6- And xatama laka baAbahu [He sealed for thee his door]; meaning (tropical:) he preferred thee to others. (TA.) ― -b7- xatama EalaI qalobihi [which may be rendered He sealed his heart] means (tropical:) he made him to be such that he understood not, and such that nothing proceeded from him; or he made his heart, or mind, to be such that it understood not, &c. (K, TA.) xatama QllRehu EalaI quluwbihimo, in the Kur [ii. 6], is like the phrase in the same [xvi. 110 and xlvii. 18] TabaEa QllRehu EalaI quluwbihimo: (TA:) it points to what God has made to be usually the case when a man has ended in believing what is false and in committing that which is forbidden, so that he turns not his face to the truth; this occasioning, as its result, his becoming inured to the approval of acts of disobedience, so that he is as though this habit were impressed upon his heart: the assertion of ElJubbáee, that it means God hath put a seal upon their hearts, as a sign, to the angels, of their infidelity, is nought: (Er-Rághib, TA:) Alxatomu is explained by IAar as meaning the preventing of the heart from believing. (L in art. xdE.) [See also TabaEa.] ― -b8- xatama AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. xatomN, also signifies [as indicated above] (assumed tropical:) He reached the end of the thing. (K.) And AlXRaIoCa Aixotatamotu↓ (assumed tropical:) [I ended, or finished, the thing,] contr. of AifotataHotuhu. (S, TA.) You say, xatama AlquroMna (assumed tropical:) He reached the end of the Kur-án [in reciting it]; (S, Er-Rághib;) [he recited the whole of the Kur-án;] he completed [the recital of] the Kur- án: (Mgh:) [and] he retained in his memory the last portion of the Kur-án; meaning he retained the whole of it in his memory. (Msb.) It is said of Suleymán El-Aamash, kaAna yaqoraOu xatomFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He used to recite the whole of the Kur-án; at one time, according to the reading of Ibn-Mes'ood; at another time, from the edition of 'Othmán. (Mgh.) ― -b9- You say also, xatama QllRehu lahu bixayorK (assumed tropical:) [May God make his end to be good]. (S.) ― -b10- xatama Albacora (assumed tropical:) He covered over the sown seed: (Az, TA:) or xatamuwA EalaI Albacori (assumed tropical:) they turned up the earth over the sown seed, and then watered it: (Et-Táïfee, TA:) or xatama AlzRaroEa, (JK, K, TA,) aor.

[Mmiyna (or Amen) is] the seal, or stamp, and the mark, [of the Lord of the beings of the whole world upon his servants the believers,] which removes from them accidents, and causes of mischief; for the seal of the writing protects it, and precludes those who look from [seeing] what is within it. ,] inf. n. xadoEN, (Bd in ii. 8,) He hid it, or concealed it; (TA;) as also AxdEh↓, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. UixodaAEN. (TA.) ― -b2-

, inf. n. xadoEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and xidoEN, (AZ, S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) and xadiyEapN, (TA,) or this [also] is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) like xidaAEN, [which is also an inf. n. of 3,] and like xudNEapN, (TA,) He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; syn. xatalahu; (S, Mgh, K;) and desired to do to him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, without his knowing whence it proceeded: (S, K:) or he dissembled [or acted deceitfully] with him; pretended to him the contrary of what he concealed: (TA:) or he made him to resign, or relinquish, the object that he had in view, by pretending to him something the contrary of what he concealed: (Er-Rághib, B:) and xAdEhu↓, (S, TA,) inf. n. muxaAdaEapN (S) [and xidaAEN], signifies the same; (S, * TA;) as also AxtdEhu↓; and txdREhu↓; and xdREhu↓, inf. n. taxodiyEN: (TA:) or this last signifies he deceived him, deluded him, beguiled him, circumvented him, or outwitted him, much: (KL:) [and of another of these verbs we find the following various explanations:] xAdEhu↓ is syn. with kaAyadahu [which has the first of the meanings assigned in this sentence to xadaEahu; or signifies he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention; he deceived him, &c., being deceived, &c., by him; and this latter meaning, if not each meaning, may be intended here by kAydh; for Bd says, (in ii. 8,) that muxaAdaEap is between two]: (TA:) or it signifies he strove, endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him; (AAF, L;) [agreeably with what is said by Kemál Páshá Zádeh, (as I find in a marginal note in a copy of the MS, and also in the Kull p. 178,) that one says of a man xAdE when he has not attained his desire, and xadaEa when he has attained his desire;] for many a verb of the measure faAEala relates to one only; as in the instances of EaAqabotu AllRiSRa and TaAraqotu AlnRaEola: (L:) or it signifies, [like xadaEahu,] he pretended to him something different from that which was in his mind. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 8], QllReha waQlRaciyna MmanuwA yuxaAdiEuwna↓, (TA,) meaning They pretend, to God and to those who have believed, something different from that which is in their minds, by concealing unbelief and pretending belief; for when they do thus to the believers, they do thus to God: (K:) and again, [in iv. 141], QllReha wahuwa xaAdiEuhumo yuxaAdiEuwna↓ [They strive, endeavour, or desire, to deceive God, or] they think that they deceive God, but He is [their deceiver, i. e.,] the requiter, to them, of their xidaAE [or deceit, &c.]: (TA:) or the meaning is [they deceive] the friends of God: (S:) and [agreeably with this last rendering, and that given in the K,] Aboo-Hayáh reads, in the former passage, yaxodaEuwna QllReha: (TA:) [which passage continues thus:] UilRaA Oanofusahumo wamaA yuxaAdiEuwna↓ [but they do not deceive any save themselves]; i. e., the re- sult of their xidaAE [or deceit] does not befall any save themselves: (K:) here, again, Aboo-Hayáh reads yaxodaEuwna: (TA:) Muärrik reads wamaA yaxadRiEuwna↓, meaning yaxotadiEuwna. (K.) Accord. to IAar, AlxadoEu signifies manoEu AlHaqRi [meaning The preventing from discovering, or accepting, the truth]. (L.) [“ He deceived him, ” or the like, seems to be generally regarded as the primary signification of xadaEahu, for it occupies the first place in all the lexicons to which I have access: but Bd says (in ii. 8) that this meaning is from xadaEa said of the DabRi, and that the primary signification of xadoEN is the act of “ concealing: ” the action of the DbR, however, as will appear in what follows, implies, and originates from, a desire of deceit; and so, often, does the act of concealing.] ― -b4- [Hence, app.,] xadaEotuhu I gained the mastery over him. xaAdiEN [Deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, outwitting, or the like;] act. part. n. of xadaEahu; as also xaduwEN↓; (Msb;) or [rather] this latter is an intensive epithet, signifying one who deceives, &c., much, or often; or very deceitful, &c.; or a great deceiver, &c.; (Mgh, K;) and xadRaAEu↓, (Msb, TA,) and xadiEN↓, and xayodaEN↓; (TA;) [but these three are also intensive epithets, like xaduwEN;] and xudaEapN↓ signifies one who deceives, &c., other men; (S;) or [rather] this last is syn. with xaduwEN as explained above, (K,) or xadRaAEN: (Mgh:) [the pl. of xaAdiEapN, fem. of xaAdiEN, is xawaAdiEu:] and the pl. of xaduwEN↓ is xuduEN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] DabRN xAdiEN A [lizard of the kind called] DbR that deceives, beguiles, or circumvents; (Z, TA;) as also xadiEN↓. (S, K.) ― -b3- And dahorN xaAdiEN and xudaEapN↓ (assumed tropical:) [Deceiving, or varying, and very deceitful, or very variable, fortune, or time]. (TA.) [Whence, or] because of its variableness, (TA,) AlxudaEapu↓ is (tropical:) a name for Fortune, or time. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And fulaAnN xaAdiEu AlrRaOoIi (tropical:) Such a one remains not steadily in one opinion. (TA.) ― -b5- And xuluqN xaAdiEN (tropical:) A varying, or variable, disposition. (S, K, TA.) ― -b6- And suwqN xaAdiEapN (tropical:) A market varying, or variable, in its state; (S, A, O, K;) at one time being brisk, and at another time dull, in respect of traffic: (A, TA:) or a market dull in respect of traffic: or a market in which one cannot obtain a thing because of its dearness. (TA.) xaAdiEN also signifies (tropical:) Anything unsaleable, or difficult of sale, and in little demand. (TA.) And accord. to Fr, the Benoo-Asad use the epithet muxaAdiEu↓ [perhaps a mistake for xaAdiEN] in the sense of (tropical:) High, or dear, applied to a price. (TA.) ― -b7- And TariyqN xaAdiEN (tropical:) A road that appears at one time and disappears at another; as also xaduwEN↓: (K:) a road which one does not know: (TA:) a road deviating from the right course; (TA;) as also xayodaEN↓; (S, K, TA;) which one does not know. (S, TA.) And maMCN xaAdiEN (tropical:) A water to which one does not know the way. (TA.) ― -b8- [Hence also,] sinuwna xawaAdiEu (tropical:) Years in which is little good; bad years: (Sh, TA:) and sinuwna xadRaAEapN↓ (tropical:) (tropical:) years in which is little increase: (S, K, TA:) from xadaEa said of rain, or of spittle; and therefore doubly tropical: (TA:) or, as some say, years in which is much rain, and in which the produce is little. (Sgh.) xaAdiEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Corrupt, or bad; applied to food and other things. (TA.) And you say, diynaArN xaAdiEN (assumed tropical:) A deficient, or defective, deenár. (S.) And rajulN xaAdiEN (tropical:) A man who brings evil upon others. (TA.)

(K.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) AlxayodaEu is also applied to (tropical:) The mirage; (S, K, TA;) accord. to some. (S.) You say, garRahumu AlxayodaEu (tropical:) The mirage deceived them. (TA.) ― -b4- [For the same reason,] it is also applied to (assumed tropical:) The cat. (IB.) ― -b5- And from the former of the last two meanings is derived the phrase (TA) guwlN xayodaEN (S, K, TA) (tropical:) (tropical:) A very deceitful, or guileful, ghool; (K, TA;) so that it is doubly tropical. (TA.) ― -b6- TariyqN xayodaEN: see xaAdiEN; in the latter part of the paragraph.

OaxodaEu c
OaxodaEu [More, and most, deceitful, deluding, guileful, outwitting, or the like]. [Hence,] OaxodaEu mino DabRK [More deceitful, or guileful, than a dabb]; a prov.; (S, K;) applied to a person over whom one has not power, by reason of deceit, or guile. (IAar.) They said also, UinRaka laOaxodiEu mino DabRK HaraXotuhu [Verily thou art more deceitful, or guileful, than a dabb that I have hunted]. (AZ, AAF, O.) [See xidaAEN.] ＝ -A2- AlOaxodaEu [app. Each of the two branches of the occipital artery which are distributed upon the occiput;] a certain vein, (S, K,) one of a pair of veins, called the OaxodaEaAni, (S, Mgh, Msb,) in the cupping-place (Mgh, Msb) of the neck, (Mgh,) or in the place [of the application] of the two cupping-instruments; being a branch from the wariyd [or carotid artery]; (S, K;) sometimes the scarification [for cupping] happens to be upon one of them, and the patient consequently is exhausted by loss of blood: (S:) the AxdEAn are two concealed veins in the place of the cupping of the neck: Lh says, they are two veins in the neck: some say that they are the wadajaAni, q. v.: (TA:) the pl. is OaxaAdiEu. (K.) ― -b2- fulaAnN Xadiydu AlOaxodaEi means Such a one is strong in the place of the AxdE. (As, S, O.) ― -b3- It also means (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is] a person who resists; unyielding; uncomplying. (TA.) And layRinu AlOaxodaEu (assumed tropical:) One who does not resist; yielding; complying. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, lawaI fulaAnN OaxodaEahu (tropical:) Such a one turned away, or
aside, and behaved proudly, or haughtily. (TA.) And sawRaI OaxodaEahu (tropical:) He relinquished pride, or haughtiness. (TA.) And to him who is proud, one says, laOuqiymanRa OaxodaEayoka, meaning (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly dispel thy pride. (Ham p. 432.)

(JK, K,) upon blackness; (K;) such whiteness resembling the xadamap, (JK, TA,) or being likened to xadam, or anklets: (TA:) or blackness upon whiteness: &c. (K.) [See Oaxodamu: and see also xadamapN.]

xadamapN A thong, (JK, S, K,) plaited, (TA,) thick and strong, like a ring, (JK, K,) which is fastened upon the pastern of a camel, (JK, S, K,) and to which is attached the sariyHap [or thong] of the naEol [or leathern shoe with which the foot is sometimes protected], (S,) or to which are attached the saraAYiH [or thongs] of the nEl: (K:) [it is the n. un. of xadamN↓: and its pl. is xidaAmN; as below: in the TA, said to be tropical; but this is pro-
bably a mistake: the other significations here following are all tropical:] accord. to AA, [the pl.] xidaAmN signifies shackles, or hobbles; syn. quyuwdN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) (tropical:) i. q. xaloxaAlN [meaning An anklet]; (JK, S, Mgh, K;) because sometimes made of thongs, with gold and silver affixed thereon: (S:) pl. xidaAmN, (S,) and [coll. gen. n.] xadamN↓. (Ham p. 612.) kaQlomamohuwrapK UiHodaI xadamatayohaA is a prov. [meaning (assumed tropical:) Like her who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]. (JK, TA. [See also mahomuwrapN.]) ― -b3- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) A ring of white a little above the hoof of a horse &c.] You say of a horse, lahu xadamataAni mino xilaAfK, meaning (assumed tropical:) He has a whiteness [or rather a ring of white a little above the hoof] in his fore leg [or right fore leg] and another in his left fore leg [probably a mistake of a copyist for his left kind leg]. (TA in art. xlf.) [The coll. gen. n. xadamN↓ is used in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as stated by Freytag, in the sense of (assumed tropical:) A place where the colour differs, like an anklet, on the foot: and a whiteness on the foot of a bull, surrounding it like a circle: and xidaAmN as meaning whiteness: or, as some say, streaks (“striæ”). See also xudomapN.] ― -b4- [Hence, also,] (assumed tropical:) The place where each foot comes forth from the trousers. (TA.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The shank; (K;) because it is the place of the xadamap, i. e. the anklet: (TA:) pl. xidaAmN and [coll. gen. n.] xadamN↓. (K.) Hence, in a trad. of Selmán, kaAna EalaI HimaArK waEalayohi saraAwiylu waxadamatAhu tucabocibaAni [He was upon an ass, and upon him were trousers, and his shanks were dangling]: or, as some say, the meaning here is, the parts from which his two feet came forth, of the trousers. (TA.) And one says, Oabodati AlHarobu Eano xidaAmi AlmuxadRaraAti (tropical:) [The war made apparent the shanks, or the anklets, of the girls that had been kept behind the curtains]; meaning the war became vehement. (A, TA.) ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) A ring of people; (S, K;) a compact ring thereof: likened to the thong described in the first sentence of this paragraph. (TA.) Hence the saying of Khálid Ibn-El-Weleed, in a letter that he wrote to the Satraps of Persia, (TA,) AlHamodu lilRehi AlRaciI faDRa xadamatakumo, meaning [Praise be to God,] who hath dispersed, or broken up, your congregation: (S, * K, * TA:) for when the thong above mentioned is broken, or parted, the saraAYiH [or thongs of the leathern shoe] become loosed, and the shoe falls off: so says IAth, and A'Obeyd says the like. (TA.)

xidonN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and xadiynN↓ (S, K) A friend: (S, TA:) or a secret, or private, friend; a friend in secrecy or privacy: (Mgh, Msb, and Ksh and Bd in iv. 29:) or a companion, or an associate, who converses, or talks, with one: (M, TA:) or [simply] a companion, or an associate: (K:) but accord. to Er-Rághib, mostly used as meaning an amorous companion or associate; a companion, or an associate, affected with sensual appetency: (TA:) the former is applied alike to the male and the female: (Ksh and Bd in v. 7:) and ↓the latter signifies also one who is thy friend, &c., (mano yuxaAdinuka, K,) and who is with thee, (TA,) in every affair, or case, open and secret: (K:) pl. (of the former, S, Mgh, Msb) OaxodaAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) and [of the latter] xudanaMCu. (TA.) Hence, xidonu AljaAriyapi [The friend, &c., of the girl]: (S:) or he who converses, or talks, with the girl. (JK.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 29], walaA mutRaxicaAti OaxodaAnK, (S,) meaning [Nor taking to themselves] friends [or associates] to commit fornication with them in secret. (Jel.) AlEulaI xadiynu↓ is a metaphorical expression, used by a poet, [meaning (tropical:) Lover of eminence,] like EaXiyqu AlEulaI. (TA.)

xudanapN xdn xdnh xdnp
xudanapN One who associates with men as their xidon [or friend, or secret friend, &c.,] (yuxaAdinu AlnRaAsa) much. (S, K.)

xadiynN xd xdyn
xadiynN: see xidonN, in three places.

Oaxodanu Having OaxodaAn [or friends, or secret friends, &c.]. (TA.)

xacorafato, said of a [wild] she-ass, She hastened, sped, or went quickly, and threw out her legs. (TA.) And, said of camels, They threw the pebbles with their feet by reason of quickness. (K.) ＝ -A2- xacorafahu He cut off his (a man's) extremities with a sword. (K.) ― -b2- He sharpened it; namely, a sword. (K.) ― -b3- He filled it; namely, a vessel. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)
