xacorafapN inf. n. of Q. 1. ＝ -A2- Also Roundness of the legs of an animal, or quadruped. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A piece of a garment or cloth. (TA.)

xicoraAfN c
xicoraAfN A certain plant of the spring, which dries up when it feels the [heat of] summer: (Lth, K:) or a species of the [kind called] HamoD, (AHn, S, K,) having a small leaf, and rising to the height of a cubit: (AHn:) the latter is said by Az to be the correct explanation: the former he disapproves: (TA:) n. un. with p. (S.)

xucoruwfN c
xucoruwfN [A kind of whirling plaything;] a thing which a boy turns round by means of a thread, or string, in his hands, causing it to make a sound such as is termed dawiIR: (S, K:) or a small piece of wood, or a slit, or split, reed or cane, in the middle of which is cut a notch, and which is then tied with a thread, or string, which being pulled, it turns round, and is heard to make a sound such as is termed Hafiyf: boys play with it; and it is also called xarRaArapN: (Lth, TA: [in the latter of which, in art. xr, the xrRArp is said to be a piece of wood like the half of a sandal, tied with a thread or string, which, being put in motion, draws along the piece of wood and causes it to make a sound:]) or a small, round, piece of skin, attached to which are two connected threads or strings, which being pulled by a boy, with his fingers, it turns round, causing a sound to be heard such as is termed dawiIR: (EM p. 43:) pl. xacaAriyfu. (S.) Imra-el-Keys likens to it a swift horse: (S:) and it is applied as an epithet to a horse; (Lth;) meaning Swift in his running, (Lth, K, TA,) or in going. (TA.) And one says, tarakati AlsRuyuwfu raOosahu xacaAriyfa, meaning (assumed tropical:) The swords made his head to be pieces, each piece like the xcrwf. (S, K.) ― -b2- Clay kneaded, and made like sugar, (yuEomalu XabiyhFA biAlsRukRari, in the CK yuEomalu mnhu XabiyhFA biAlsRukRuri, [the latter reading evidently wrong, and the former I think doubtful,]) with which boys play. (K.) ― -b3- The piece of wood that is put [app. as a handle] in the hole of the upper millstone. (TA.) ― -b4- A herd of camels: and one separate therefrom. (K.) ― -b5- Lightning gleaming, or shining brightly, in the clouds, and separate therefrom. (K.) ― -b6- Anything scattered from, or of, a thing. (L, O, K.) ― -b7- The xacaAriyf of the hawodaj are The pieces of wood (saqaAYif) with which the hwdj is made of a square form. (K.) [See also daAmigapN.]

rajulN mutaxacorifN c
rajulN mutaxacorifN A man of good natural disposition. (TA.)

1. xacafa, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
xacifa
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. xacofN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) trans. without a particle, (Msb,) and by means of bi, (S,) He threw a pebble, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or a datestone, (Mgh, K,) or the like, (Mgh, Msb, K,) with the fingers; (S;) or by taking it between his two fore fingers; (Mgh, K;) or with the extremity of the thumb and that of the fore finger, (Mgh, Msb,) by putting the extremity of the thumb upon that of the fore finger [and then jerking the latter forward]; (Mgh;) or with a mixocafap of wood. (Lth, K.) The doing this was forbidden by Mohammad, because game cannot be taken thereby, nor an enemy defeated, but a tooth may be broken, and an eye put out. (TA.) HaSaI Alxacofi [properly] Pebbles that are thrown [in the manner described above], (Msb,) is used as meaning (tropical:) small pebbles. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xacafa bibawolihi He emitted his urine and then stopped it. (TA.) ― -b3- And xacofu AlnRuTofapi The emitting of the sperma genitale into the midst of the womb. (TA.) ― -b4- And xacafa bihaA, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He broke wind with a sound. (TA.) ― -b5- And Alxacofu The hastening, speeding, or going quickly, of camels. (TA. [See also xacafaAnN.]) ― -b6- And The act of cutting, or cutting off. (Kr, TA.)

6: [taxaAcafaA app. signifies They vied with each other in throwing in the manner described in the first sentence above. ― -b2- And hence,] EayonaAhu taxaAcafataA biAldRamoEi (tropical:) i. q. AsrtA [app. a mistranscription for OajorataAhu, i. e. His eyes shed tears]: so in the A. (TA.)

xacafaAnN A certain pace, or manner of going, of camels. ('Eyn, T, K. [See also 1, last sentence but one.])

xacuwfN c
xacuwfN A horse or the like (Lth) quick in pace. (Lth, K.) ― -b2- A she-ass that throws the pebbles by reason of her quickness: (S, K:) or whose navel is near to the ground by reason of her fatness: (K:) or so fat that, if a pebble is thrown at her with the fingers, or with two fore fingers, or with the extremity of the thumb and that of the fore finger, it sinks into her fat: (Z:) and that raises her legs to the side of her belly: (TA:) pl. xucufN. (As, TA.)

AlxacRaAfapu (assumed tropical:) The anus; syn. AlAisotu; (TA;) as also Almixocafapu↓. (K.)

mixocafapN c
mixocafapN A kind of sling; syn. miqolaAEN: (S, K:) or a thing with which one throws: (S:) or it signifies also a wooden instrument with which one throws in the manner termed xacofN: (K:) or a thing into which stones are put, and with which they are thrown at birds &c., like a miqolaAE. (ISd.) [In the TA in art. dv, it is said (in my opinion erroneously) to signify a bullet.] ― -b2- See also AlxacRaAfapu.

1. xacalahu, (S, Msb, K,) and xacala Eanohu, (Msb, K,) aor.
xacula
, (JK, Msb,) inf. n. xicolaAnN (JK, S, K) and xacolN, (JK, Msb, * K,) or xicolaAnN↓ is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and Axclhu↓; (TA;) He abstained from, or neglected, aiding him, or assisting him; (JK, * S, Msb, K;) and held back from him: (Msb:) and xacalahu he left, forsook, or deserted, him: (MA:) and, accord. to AZ, xacala Eanohu, aor.
xacula
, inf. n. xucuwlN, he left him, and held back from going with him. (T in art. tlw.) And xicolaAnN↓ signifies God's failing to preserve a man; accord. to Az, from an evil action; so that he falls into it. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 154], wa Uino yaxoculokumo famano caA QlRaciI yanoSurukumo mino baEodihi [But if He fail to aid you, or to preserve you, then who is he that will aid you after Him?]: here 'Obeyd Ibn-'Omeyr read yuxodilokumo↓, with damm to the I and kesr to the c. (TA.) ― -b2- And xacala He (a gazelle) held back from going with the herd; or remained behind the herd. (As, S.) And xacalato She (a gazelle, &c., K, as, for instance, a [wild] cow, TA) held back from going with her female companions, and remained alone: or held back, or remained behind, not overtaking [the others]: (K:) or you say, of a female gazelle, and of a [wild] cow, taxoculu SawaAHibaAtihaA She holds back from going with her female companions, or remains behind them, with her young one, in the place of pasturage: or remains alone with him; as A'Obeyd says, on the authority of As. (T, TA.) And xacalato She (a wild animal, S, O, or a gazelle, K) remained attending to her young one [when the rest of the herd had gone]; (S, O, K;) said by some to be inverted [as to the meaning], because she is [not the one that leaves, but] the one that is left; (S;) as also txAclt↓, (S, K,) and Axclt↓. (K.) ― -b3- A poet says, (namely, 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, TA,) describing a horse,
fahowa kaAldRalowi bikafRi AlmusotaqiI
xacalato Eanohu AlEaraAqiI faQnojacamo
meaning [And he is, or was, like the bucket in the hand of the drawer of water,] of which the cross pieces of wood have become separated from it [so that it has become severed from the wellrope]. (S.)

2. xcRlhu, inf. n. taxociylN, He incited him, or induced him, to abstain from, or to neglect, aiding him, or assisting him; and hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him, from aiding his companion, or assisting him. (T, TA.) And xcRl Eanohu OaSoHaAbahu, inf. n. as above, He incited, or induced, his companions to abstain from, or to neglect, aiding him, or assisting him. (S.) ― -b2- He induced him to be cowardly and weak-hearted, and to abstain from fighting. (Msb.)

(T.)

6. txAclwA They abstained from, or neglected, aiding, or assisting, one another: (S:) i. q. tdAbrwA [which has the foregoing signification accord. to the TA, but properly means they turned their backs, one upon another]: (K:) they left, forsook, or deserted, one another in trouble. (MA.) [And, accord. to Freytag's Lex., They fled from fight, or battle.] ― -b2- txAclt rijolaAhu (said of an old man, TA) His legs became weak (S, K, TA) in consequence of some evil affection. (TA.) ― -b3- And txAcl He was, or became, behind. (KL.) ― -b4- See also 1.

7: [AnxclwA, accord. to Freytag's Lex., They were destitute of aid, or assistance: they fled.]

xicolaAnN c

xaAcilN c
xaAcilN Abstaining from, or neglecting, the rendering of aid, or assistance. (S, K.) ― -b2- And Any one leaving, forsaking, or deserting. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and xacuwlN↓, (T, K,) A female gazelle, and a [wild] cow, holding back from going with her female companions, or remaining behind them, with her young one, in the place of pasturage: or remaining alone with him: (T:) or a female gazelle, &c., (K,) as, for instance, a [wild] cow, (TA,) holding back from going with her female companions, and remaining alone: or holding back, or remaining behind, not overtaking [the others]: (K:) or the latter signifies a female gazelle that has left, forsaken, or deserted, her young ones. (EM p. 60.) ― -b4- And the former, A female gazelle remaining attending to her young one; as also muxocilN↓. (K. [See 1.]) ― -b5- Also Routed, defeated, or put to flight. (IAar, K.)

muxocilN c
muxocilN: see the next preceding paragraph.

maxocuwlN c

, (K,) inf. n. xacomN, (JK, S, TA,) He cut it, or cut it off: (S, K:) or he did so quickly: (JK, Z, TA:) and xcRmhu↓ and txcRmhu↓ signify the same: (K:) or ↓the second, inf. n. taxociymN, he cut it in pieces; (S, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned;) and so ↓the third. xacama
, (K,) inf. n. xacomN, (TK, [as indicated in the K by its being said that the verb is like samiEa,]) It became cut, or cut off; as also txcRm↓: (K:) [or] the latter is quasi-pass. of xacRamahu [and therefore signifies it became cut in pieces]. xacama
, (K,) inf. n. xacamN (S, TA) [and app. xacamaAnN, q. v. infrà]; or xacama, [so in the JK, which may be also correct, agreeably with the primary signification of this verb, though the aor. is there said to be
xacama
, which may perhaps be a mistranscription for
xacima
,] inf. n. xacomN [there mentioned in two places] and xacamN; (JK;) (tropical:) He was quick (JK, S, K, TA) in pace, or rate of going; (JK, S, TA;) as also Axcm↓. (JK. [But this last may be erroneously taken from the phrase marRa muxocimFA, there immediately following; for this phrase may be mistranscribed for marRa yaxocamu, which I find in the TA.]) ― -b2- [And hence,] xacamN signifies also (assumed tropical:) [The being liberal, or bountiful; (see the part. n. xacimN;) or] the giving a gift, or making a present. 4: see 1, in the latter part. ＝ -A2- Axcm AlnRaEola He repaired the [thong called] XisoE of the sandal. (AA, TA.) [Here, as in many other instances, the A has a privative effect: see xacimati AlnRaEolu, above.]

8. AixotacaAmN, [accord. to some, seems to signify The cutting off a thing for oneself:] accord. to some, Tiybu AlnRafosi [as meaning the being pleased, content, or willing: see xacimN]. (Ham p. 703, q. v.)

xacimN A cutting, or sharp, sword; (K;) as also xacuwmN↓ (JK, K) and mixocamN↓; (JK, T, S, ISd, TA;) the last erroneously said in the K to be like muEaZRamN. (TA.) One of the swords of Mo- hammad was named Almixocamu↓: it was formerly the sword of El-Hárith El-Ghassánee. (TA.) ― -b2- A garment, or piece of cloth, altogether, or wholly, old and worn out. (TA.) [And in like manner, accord. to Freytag (who does not name his authority), xacuwmN↓, applied to a scabbard of a sword, Lacerated and worn by use.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Quick, or swift of pace, applied to a horse; (JK, S;) and so xacuwmN↓, applied to an ostrich. (S.) ― -b4- [And hence.] (tropical:) A man (JK, S) liberal, or bountiful, (S, K,) in giving; (S;) pleased, content, or willing, (JK, K, TA,) to be liberal or bountiful; plenteous in gifts: (TA:) pl. xacimuwna: (JK, K:) it has no broken pl. (TA.)

xacomapN A snatching away; a snatch: and a stroke, or blow. (TA.) ― -b2- A certain mark (simapN) of camels: (JK, K:) an Islámee term: (K:) a certain mark of sheep or goats, (JK, T, TA,) being a slit across the ear, (T, TA,) which leaves the ear dried up. (JK, T, TA. [See xacomaMCu.]) ― -b3- Also, [or xicomapN, q. v.,] A space, or period, syn. saAEapN, (K,) [of the night, or of the day:] and xadomapN [or xidomapN] is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

xicomapN c
xicomapN [like jicomapN] A piece cut off of a garment. (JK. [See also xucaAmapN.]) A portion cut off from property. (JK.) A portion of the night. (JK. [See also xacomapN.]) ― -b2- A company of men. (JK. [But perhaps this may be a mistake for xadamapN.])

xacomaMCu c
xacomaMCu A sheep or goat, (XaApN, JK, K,) or a she-goat, (S,) having the mark in the ear termed xacomapN; (JK;) [i. e.] having the ear slit across, without its being separated: (S, K:) or a ewe having the extremity of her ear cut off. (T, TA.)

xacamaAnN c
xacamaAnN [app. an inf. n. of xacima] Quickness of pace, or of rate of going. (TA.)

xacuwmN c
xacuwmN: see xacimN, in three places.

OucunN xaciymN c
OucunN xaciymN An ear cut, or cut off: (K:) pl. xucumN. (TA.)

xucaAmapN c
xucaAmapN A piece cut off. (JK, K. [See also xicomapN.])

mixocamN c
mixocamN: see xacimN, in two places.

1 xarRa xr
1. xarRa, (S, A, K,) aor.
xarira
(S, M, K) and
xarura
, (M, K,) [the latter of which is anomalous,] inf. n. xariyrN, (S, A, Msb, K,) It (water) sounded; [i. e., murmured; rumbled; or gurgled;] (S, A, Msb, K;) as also xaroxara↓, (A,) inf. n. xaroxarapN: (TA:) or xarRa, aor.
xarira
, (IAar, T,) inf. n. xarRN, (IAar,) it (water) ran vehemently [so as to make a noise: as used in the present day, it ran, flowed, or trickled down; and leaked, or oozed, out: and also it ran so as to make a murmuring, or similar, sound]: (IAar, T:) and xurRa it was made to run: (TA: but the subject of this verb is not mentioned.) And xarRato, (A, K,) aor.
xarira
and
xarura
, (K,) inf. n. xariyrN, It (the wind, AlrRiyHu) sounded; [i. e., murmured; rumbled; or rustled;] (A, K;) among reeds or canes; as also xaroxarato↓, (A,) inf. n. as above: (TA:) or the latter signifies
it made a quick xariyr [or rustling] among reeds or canes or the like. (Lth.) Also It (an eagle, EuqaAb) made a rustling (Hafiyf) with its wings, in flying. (Lth, K.) And xarRa, (S,) inf. n. xariyrN, (K,) He (a man sleeping) snored, or made a sound in breathing; (S, K, * TA;) as also xaroxara↓, (S,) inf. n. xaroxarapN: (S, K:) and the latter, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) has the same signification when said of a leopard (K, * TA) in his sleep; (TA;) as also the former, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and when said of a cat; (K, * TA;) as also the former, (TA,) inf. n. xuruwrN (so in the CK and in a MS. copy of the K, but in the text of the K in the TA, xaruwrN,) and xariyrN; (TA;) [i. e. he made a loud purring in his sleep;] and it is likewise significant of the sound, or sounds, made by a person suffering strangulation. (S, TA: but of the verb applied in this last manner, only the inf. n., xaroxarapN, is mentioned.) And xarRa, aor.
xarura
, It (a stone) made a sound in its descent. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xarRa, aor.
xarira
(S, A, Msb, K) and
xarura
, (K,) the latter of which is anomalous, (TA,) inf. n. xuruwrN (S, K) and xarRN, (K,) He, or it, fell, or fell down: (S, A, Msb, K:) originally, he, or it, fell, making a sound to be heard at the same time: afterwards used in the sense of falling absolutely: you say xarRa AlbinaMCu The building fell down: (TA:) and xarRa lilRehi saAjidFA He fell down prostrating himself to God: (S, A, * TA:) or xarRa signifies He, or it, fell from a high to a low place: (K, TA:) so in the Kur [xxii. 32], fakaOanRamaA xarRamina AlsRamaMCi [He is as though he fell from the shy]. (A, * TA.) And xarRuwA liOacoqaAnihimo, inf. n. xuruwrN, [They fell down prostrate, with their chins to the ground: see the Kur xvii. 108 and 109:] (A:) [whence the saying,] EaSafato riyHu faxarRati AlOaXojaAru liloOacoqaAni (tropical:) [A wind blew violently, so that the trees fell, or bent themselves, down to the ground]. (A.) ― -b3- You say also, xarRa, (TA,) inf. n. xarRN, (K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He died: (K, TA:) because a man, when he dies, falls down. (TA.) In the Kur xxxiv. 13, it may mean (assumed tropical:) He died, or he fell down. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (xarRa) He stumbled after going right. (TA.) ― -b5- And xarRato xaTaAyaAhu (assumed tropical:) His sins fell; [or fell from him; q. d. fell to the ground;] went away; or departed. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- And xarRa mina Aljabali, inf. n. xuruwrN, He, (a man,) and it, (a stone, &c.,) rolled down from the mountain. (TA.) ― -b7- And AlOaEoraAbu yaxirRuwna mina AlbawaAdiI AlquraI (tropical:) The Arabs of the desert come down, or descend, from the deserts to the towns or villages. (A.) ― -b8- And xarRuwA EalayonaA, (TA,) inf. n. xarRN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) They came upon us suddenly, or unawares, from a place unknown. (K, * TA.) ― -b9- And xarRuwA (assumed tropical:) They came from one town, or country, or the like, to another. (TA.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) They passed along, or away, or by. (TA.) ― -b11- xararota Eano yadayoka, or mino yadayoki, is a metonymical phrase, well known, meaning (tropical:) Mayest thou be confounded and stupified by shame; or, so as to be speechless and motionless: xrrt [properly] signifying saqaTota. OaxoraAtN, [also pl. of xurotN↓, (see xubonN,)] in the formation of which the p of the sing. seems to have been considered as elided, also signifies The loops of a [leathern water-bag such as is called] mazaAdap: it is said in the T that in the mzAdp are its AxrAt, the loops between which is the qaSabap [commonly signifying cane, or reed, but here app. meaning the mouth, which has the form of a short cylinder, and is in the middle of the upper part of the mzAdp, between the two loops, these being at the two upper corners], whereby [app. referring to the AxrAt] it is carried [and suspended on the side of a camel, counterpoised by another mzAdp on the other side of the camel]: and AM adds that one says [also] OaxoraAbu AlmazaAdapi, sing. xurobapN [q. v.]; and in like manner, xurobapu AlOucuni [“ the bore of the ear ”]; with b: and gulaAmN Oaxorabu AlOucunayoni [“ a boy having his ears pierced, or bored ”]: he says, also, that the xurotap, with t, is [the hole] in the iron of the faOos, and [the eye] of the needle; and the xurobap, with b, is in the skin: and AA says that xurotapN signifies the eye of the [kind of needle called] Xagiyzap, i. e. the misalRap: (TA:) and Lth says that it signifies a round hole. (TA in art. Hrt.)

AlxaraAtaAni AlxrAtAn
AlxaraAtaAni Two stars, (K,) of the stars of the Lion, two whips' lengths apart, [(see sawoTN,) in] the two shoulder-blades of the Lion, (TA,) also called zuborapu AlOasadi, (K,) [composing the Eleventh Mansion of the Moon: (see zuborapN: and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:)] the word is mentioned here in the K, as though it were of the measure faEaAlaAni; but accord. to Kr and others, it is dual of xaraApN, belonging to art. xrw, in which it is again mentioned in the K: (TA:) accord. to ISd, however, only the dual form is known, and the radical t and the augmentative t [by which latter is meant p] are in the dual alike: (TA in art. xrw:) Zj asked Th respecting the xrAtAn, and he answered, IAar says that they are two stars, of those of the Lion; and Aboo-Nasr, the companion of As, says that they are two stars in the zbrp of the Lion, i. e. in the middle thereof; but in my opinion they are two stars after [i. e. to the eastward of] the jabohap and the qalob: Zj disapproved of this, and replied, I say that they are two stars in that part of the breast which is the stabbing-place, derived from xurotu AlUiborapi, “ the eye of the needle: ” but Th rejoined, that this was an error, because the word is the dual of xaraApN; and he cited some verses in which a poet speaks of certain stars in the Lion, and, among them, of AlxaraApu. (MF, TA.)

1. xaraja, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
xaruja
, (L,) inf. n. xuruwjN and maxorajN, (S, Msb, K,) He, or it, went, came, passed, or got, out, or forth; issued, emanated, proceeded, went, or departed; contr. of daxala; (TA;) mina AlmawoDiEi [from the place]. (Msb.) One says, xaraja maxorajFA HasanFA [He, or it, went, came, passed, or got, out, or forth, &c., well: and it turned out well]. (S.) [And xaraja mino TaAEatihi: see TaAYiEN, in art. TwE. When xaraja means It was disbursed, or expended, the inf. n. is xarojN.] xaraja bihi [lit. He went out, &c., with him, or it]: see 4. (TA.) yawomu Alxuruwji [The day of going forth] means the day of the Eiyd [or festival]. (A, TA, from a trad.) And [as used in the Kur l. 41] The day when men shall come forth from their graves; (TA;) a name of the day of resurrection. (AO, K.) ― -b2- [(assumed tropical:) It became excluded by a definition or a rule or the like, or by a portion thereof.] manoSuwbN EalaI Alxuruwji is a phrase of the Basree grammarians, said of the objective complement of a verb, meaning (assumed tropical:) Put in the accus. case as being out of the predicament of the subject and that of the attribute. (TA.) ― -b3- xaraja mino OamorK (assumed tropical:) [He got out of, escaped from, extricated himself from, evaded, or became quit of, affair, or a state]. (ISh, TA in art. nks.) [And xarajamino HaAlK UilaI HaAlK (assumed tropical:) He passed from one state to another state. And xaraja mino diynihi (assumed tropical:) He quitted, or forsook, his religion. And xaraja mino dayonihi, and mn maraDihi, (assumed tropical:) He became quit of his debt, and of his disease.] And xaraja UilaI fulaAnK mino dayonihi (assumed tropical:) He paid such a one his debt: a phrase used in law. (TA.) [And xaraja EalaI AlsRuloTaAni, and Eano Oamori AlsRuloTaAni, (assumed tropical:) He rebelled against the Sultán.] And xarajato EalaI xiloqapi Aljamali (tropical:) [She became formed like the he-camel]; said of a she-camel that is termed muxotarajapN↓. (S, A, K.) And xaraja UilaI AlbacaMCa (assumed tropical:) [He became foul, or obscene, in his language]. (L and K in art. xnc.) And xaraja fiI AlEilomi waAlSRinaAEapi, inf. n. xuruwjN, (tropical:) He was, or became, conspicuous in science and art. (A, TA. [See also 5.]) ― -b4- maA OaHosana xuruwjahaA, said of a cloud (saHaAbap), (tropical:) How good is its first rising from the horizon! (A.) [You say also, xaraja AlsRaHaAbu, inf. n. xuruwjN, meaning (assumed tropical:) The clouds became extended, or expanded: see xarojN.] And xarajati AlsRamaMCu (tropical:) The sky became clear, after having been cloudy. (T, A.)

EalaI hecaA xarRajuwA qawola kacaA (assumed tropical:) According to this meaning &c. they have resolved, explained, or rendered, such a saying, is a phrase of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons &c.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He educated, disciplined, or trained, well a youth: and in like manner, a horse [and a camel; for muxarRajN, as is indicated in the K voce mudarRabN, applied to a camel, is syn. with muWadRabN]. (IAar.) You say, xrRjhu fiI AlOadabi, (S, A, * K,) inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He educated, disciplined, or trained, him well in polite accomplishments; i. e. a teacher, his pupil. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [He, or it, rendered a thing Oaxoraj, i. e. of two colours, white and black: &c.] You say, AlnRujuwmu tuxarRiju AllRawona The stars render the colour [of a thing, such as an expanse of water,] a mixture of black and white, by reason of its blackness and their whiteness. (TA.) And xrRj AllRawoHa, (A, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He (a boy, A) wrote upon part of the tablet and left part of it without writing. (A, * K.) And xrRj kitaAbFA (tropical:) He wrote a book leaving [blank] the places [of the titles] of the sections and chapters. (A.) And xrRj AlEamala, (A, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He made the work to be of different kinds. (A, K, * TA.) And xrRjti AlrRaAEiyapu AlmaroEaI, inf. n. as above, The pasturing animals ate part of the pasture and left part. (S, * A, K, * TA. [See also 4.]) And OaroDN fiyhaA taxoriyjN: and EaAmN fiyhi taxoriyjN, and EAm cuw taxoriyjK: see Oaxoraju.

3. AlmuxaArajapu i. q. AlmunaAhadapu biAlOaSaAbiEi, (S, TA,) i. e. (TA) One person's putting forth as many of his fingers as he pleases, and the other's doing the like: (K, TA:) [or the playing at the game called morra; micare digitis: see xariyjN. You say, xArjhu He played with him at the game of morra. See also 6.] ― -b2- xaArajahumo, [inf. n. as above,] He contributed with them to the expenses of a journey or an expedition against an enemy, sharing equally with each of them; like naAhadahumo. (L in art. nhd.) ― -b3- And xArjhu He made an agreement with him, namely, his slave, that he (the latter) should pay him a certain import at the expiration of every month; (Mgh, L, TA;) the slave being left at liberty to work: (L, TA:) in which case the slave is termed EabodN maxaArajN↓. (Mgh, L, TA.)

4 Axrjhu Oxrj Oxrjh Axrjh Axrjp xrj
4. Axrjhu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. [UixoraAjN and] bihi, (S, K,) He made, or caused, him, or it, to go, come, pass, or get, out, or forth; to issue, emanate, proceed, or depart: [he put, cast, or thrust, him, or it, out, or forth; expelled, ejected, or dislodged, him, or it: he took, led, drew, or pulled, him, or it, out, or forth: he gave it forth: he, or it, produced it:] as also bihi xaraja↓: [but it should be observed that this latter properly and generally denotes accompaniment, like cahaba bihi; and may be literally rendered he went, came, passed, or got, out, or forth, with him, or it:] and Axtrj↓, also, is syn. with Oaxoraja; as in the saying, in a trad., faQxotaraja tamaraAtK mino qirobapK [And he took forth, or took forth for himself (accord. to a property of many erbs of this form), some dates from a water-skin]: (TA:) [so, too, is Astxrj↓; as meaning he took, led, drew, or pulled, out, or forth: but this generally implies some degree of effort, or labour; as does also Axtrj↓; and likewise, desire: i. e. it means he sought, or endeavoured, to make a thing come forth: the former is also syn. with OabodaEahu (q. v.) and OaHodavahu: and both of them signify, and so does Axrj in many instances, he drew out, or forth; extracted; educed; produced; elicited; fetched out by labour or art; got out; or extorted: this is what is meant by its being said that] AlAisotixoraAju↓ is syn. with AlAisotinobaATu, (S, K,) and so is AlAixotiraAju↓. (K.) OaxorijoniI maxoraja SidoqK, in the Kur xvii. 82, means Cause Thou me to go forth from Mekkeh in a good, or an agreeable, manner, so that I may not turn my heart [or affections] towards it: (Jel: [see also various similar explanations in Bd:]) or mxrj is here a n. of place, or, accord. to the more approved opinion, of time. (TA.) ― -b2- Axrj maA fiI Sadorihi (assumed tropical:) [He vented that which was in his bosom, or mind]. (TA in art. srH.) ― -b3- [Axrj said of a definition or a rule or the like, or of a portion thereof, means (assumed tropical:) It excluded something.] ― -b4- Axrjhu mina AlOamori (assumed tropical:) [He excluded him from participation in the affair]. (TA in art. HDn, &c.) ＝ -A2- Axrj [intrans.] He paid his xaraAj; (K;) i. e. his land-tax, and poll-tax. (TA.) ＝ -A3- He hunted ostriches such as are termed xurojN, (K, TA, [in the CK Alxaraja is erroneously put for Alxuroja,]) pl. of Oaxoraju. (TA.) ― -b2- He married to a woman of brown complexion, white intermixed with black, whose parents were, one, white, and the other, black. (T, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He passed a year of fruitfulness and sterility, (K, TA,) or half fruitful and half sterile. (TA.) ― -b4- Axrjti AlrRaAEiyapu (tropical:) The pasturing animals ate part of the pasture and left part. (K, TA. [See also 2.])

[of mult.] xirajapN (S, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OaxoraAjN. (TA.)

xarojapN [n. un. of 1: pl. xarajaAtN]. You say, maA xaraja UilRaA xarojapF waAHidapF He went not, or came not, out, or forth, save once: and maA Oakovara xarajaAtika How many are thy goings, or comings, out, or forth! (A.)

xaraAjN xrAj
xaraAjN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and xarojN↓, (S, Msb, K,) both also written with damm, [i. e. xuraAjN↓ and xurojN↓,] (K,) but the former mode of writing them is that which more commonly obtains, (TA,) i. q. UitaAwapN; (S, K;) A tax, or tribute, which is taken from the property of people; an impost, or a certain amount of the property of people, which is given forth yearly; a tax upon lands &c.: (TA:) or the revenue, or gain, derived from land, (A, Mgh, Msb,) or from a slave, (Mgh,) or also from a slave: (A:) and then applied to the land-tax, which is taken by the Sultán: (A, Mgh:) and the poll-tax paid by the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government: (A, Mgh, Msb:) or xaraAjN signifies especially a land-tax: and xarojN↓, a poll-tax: (IAar:) or the former also signifies the poll-tax paid by the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government: it is a term which was applied to a yearly land-tax which 'Omar imposed upon the people of the Sawád [of El-'Irák]: then, to the landtax which the people of a land taken by convention agreed to pay; and their lands were termed xaraAjiyRapN: accord. to Bd, it is a name for the proceeds of land: and has then been used to signify the profits arising from possessions; such as the revenue derived from the increase of lands, and from slaves and animals: accord. to Er-Ráfi'ee, its primary signification is an impost which the master requires to be paid him by his slave: accord. to Zj, xarojN↓ is an [obsolete] inf. n.: and xaraAjN, a name for that which comes forth: and he also explains the latter word by faIoCN: and xarojN↓, by DariybapN and jizoyapN: (TA:) the pl. (of xaraAjN, L, TA) is OaxoraAjN and OaxaAriyju [a pl. pl.] and OaxorijapN. (S, K.) AlxaraAju biAlDRamaAni, a saying ascribed to Mohammad, (K, TA,) occurring in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, of disputed authority, but affirmed by several authors to be genuine, means, accord. to most of the lawyers, (TA,) The revenue derived from the slave is the property of the purchaser because of the responsibility which he has borne for him: (A, * Mgh, * K, TA:) for one purchases a slave, and imposes upon him the task of producing a revenue for a time, and then may discover in him a fault which the seller had concealed; wherefore he has a right to return him and to receive back the price; but the revenue which he had required the slave to produce is his lawful property, because he had been responsible for him; and if he had perished, part of his property had perished: (K, * TA:) in a similar manner IAth explains it, as relating to a male or female slave or to other property. (TA.) ― -b2- xarojN↓ and xaraAjN as used in the Kur xxiii. 74 mean A recompense, or reward. (Fr.) Some, for xarojFA↓, in this instance, read xaraAjFA. (TA.) ― -b3- And xaraAjN is also used as meaning (tropical:) The taste of fruit; this being likened to the xrAj of lands &c. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See also xariyjN, in five places.

(K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Suppleness of the joints: (IDrd, K:) and softness, yieldingness, flaccidity, flabbiness, laxness, or fragility, (S, K,) in a thing. (S.) [See xaruEa.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Cowardice; and weakness, or feebleness, and languor, or languidness; in a man. (TA.) [See also xariEa.]

xariEN xrE
xariEN (S, K) and xariyEN↓ (K) Weak, or infirm; (S, K;) applied to a man: (S:) anything weak; and soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, or fragile: (O:) also the former, applied to a young camel,
weak; or, as some say, small, that is [or may be] raised, or lifted: and, applied to a branch, soft, tender, or supple. (TA.)

xiroEapN xrE xrEh xrEp
xiroEapN a subst. from AixotaraEa AlXRaIoCa signifying Airotajalahu [&c.; app. meaning A thing done, or produced, without premeditation; &c.; like bidoEapN from AibotadaEahu, a syn. of AixotaraEahu, q. v.]. (TA.)

xaruwEN xrwE
xaruwEN: see xariyEN.

xirowEN xrwE
xirowEN Any weak, bending plant, of whatever kind it be: (As, S:) any plant weak, or fragile, (qaSiyf,) and sappy, whether it be a tree or a herb: (TA:) a plant weak by reason of its softness, or tenderness, and sappiness. (Sgh.) [See also xariEN.] ― -b2- Hence, as some say, (TA,) [The ricinus communis; common palma Christi; or castor-oil-plant;] a certain plant, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (S,) soft, tender, or pliant, (Msb,) not serving for pasturage, (K,) bearing a berry resembling sparrows' eggs, called AlsRimosimu AlhinodiIRu; accord to Ibn-Jezleh, the best thereof is that called AlbaHoriIRu; it has the property of loosening phlegm, and it is useful for counteracting the colic and palsy and the [disease in the face called] laqowap, the dose extending to a mivoqaAl. (TA.) The word is of the measure fiEowalN; (Msb;) and J says [in the S] that there is no other word of the same measure except EitowadN, which is the name of a certain valley; but to this have been added cirowadN, the name of a certain mountain; and EitowarN, the name of a certain valley, and not a mistranscription of EitowadN; and jidowalN, a dial. var. of jadowalN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also] AimoraOapN xirowaEapN A beautiful, and soft, or tender, woman: and [the pl.] xaraAwiyEu, applied to women, signifies [the same, or merely] beautiful. (TA.) ― -b4- And xirowaEN is likewise applied to youth, or youthfulness, and to life, meaning (tropical:) Soft, or delicate. (TA.)

xariyEN xryE
xariyEN: see xariEN. ― -b2- Anything that quickly breaks. (TA.) ― -b3- Soft; applied to a lip (Xafap): (TA:) and pendulous; applied to the lip of a camel. (S, K. *) ― -b4- Applied to a woman, (S, Msb, K, TA,) Youthful, and soft, tender, or delicate: or beautiful: (TA:) or that walks with an affected bending of the body, and with softness, or delicacy: (Msb:) or that affects a bending of the body by reason of softness, or delicacy; (As, S, K;) as also xiriyEapN and xaruwEN↓: (Ibn-' Abbád, K:) or (assumed tropical:) vitious; or immoral; or an adulteress; or a fornicatress; (S, K;) but this explanation is disallowed by As: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) that does not repel the hand of a feeler, or toucher; as though she were gentle, or mild, (tanoxariEu,) to him; as also with p: or hard, or (assumed tropical:) impudent, not caring for what is said or done, and inordinately brisk, lively, or sprightly: pl. xuruwEN and xaraAYiEu and xurRaEN. (TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) One who induces, or is an object of, suspicion; because such a person fears, and is therefore as though he were weak. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, [as a subst.,] A branch; because of its softness, or tenderness, and its bending. (TA.)

xaraAEapN a dial. var. of xalaAEapN, which is syn. with daEaArapN [i.e. Vice, or immorality; or vitious, or immoral, conduct; &c.]. (S.)

XaApN maxoruwEapN c
XaApN maxoruwEapN A sheep, or goat, having the mark termed xaraEN [q. v.] in the ear. (K.)

xaroEabN xrEb
xaroEabN (K) and xaroEabapN↓ (TA) and xuroEuwbN↓ and xuroEuwbapN↓ (K) A branch, or twig, until a year old; or of a year's growth: or fresh, or juicy, and tall: (K, TA:) or (TA) soft, or tender, and of recent growth, (K, TA,) that has not yet become hard: (TA:) or xuroEuwbN↓ [is an epithet, and] signifies a bending branch or twig. (S.) [Compare xariEN, and xirowaEN, and xariyEN.] ― -b2- Also, [i. e. all the words above,] (K,) or xaroEabapN↓ [only], (TA,) A young woman of goodly make, soft, or tender: (K:) or a young woman large in body, and of goodly make: or soft, or tender, and pliant: (TA:) or fair, tender, or pliant, fat, large in body, fleshy, with small, or delicate, bones: (K:) or fair: (TA:) or soft, or pliant, in the waist, and tall: (As, TA:) or large in the body, and fleshy: (TA:) or xuroEuwbapN↓ and xaroEabapN↓ signify a girl slender in the bones, (S, TA,) having much flesh, (TA,) and soft, or tender: (S, TA:) or a young woman of goodly stature, resembling a twig (xuroEuwbapi) of a year's growth. (Lth, TA.) And xaroEabN signifies A soft, or tender, body. (TA.) And A tall and fleshy man. (K.)

xaroEabapN xrEbh xrEbp
xaroEabapN: see above, in three places.

xuroEuwbN: see xaroEabN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A tall and well-made camel: (S:) or a tall and large she-camel: and one having much milk. (K.)

xuroEuwbapN: see xaroEabN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A piece of a gourd, and of a cucumber, and of fat; as in the L &c.: in the K written xucoEuwbapN. (TA.)

, He (a man, TA) was, or became, fond of, or addicted to, the eating of xurofap, (K,) i. e. gathered, or plucked, fruit (S, K, TA) of the palm-tree. (TA.) ＝ -A5- xarifa, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.

2. xrRfhu, inf. n. taxoriyfN, He attributed to him xaraf, (K, TA,) i. e. [dotage; or] a corrupt, an unsound, or a disordered, state of intellect. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

3. xArfhu, (K,) inf. n. muxaArafapN and xiraAfN, (TA,) He bargained, or made an engagement, with him, for work, for the xariyf [or autumn]; (K;) from Alxariyfu, like AlmuXaAharapu from AlXRahoru; (O, TA;) as also EaAmalahu muxaArafapF (S, TA) and xiraAfFA: and so AisotaOojarahu muxaArafapF and xiraAfFA [He hired him, or took him as a hired man or a hireling, for the autumn]. (Lh, TA.)

4. Axrf, said of the palm-tree, It attained, or nearly attained, the time for its fruit to be cut off. (JK, K.) ― -b2- And, said of a people, or party, They entered upon the [season called] xariyf. (S, K.) See also 1. ― -b3- Axrft, said of a ewe, or she-goat, She brought forth in the [season called] xryf. (S, K.) ― -b4- Said of a she-camel, She brought forth in the like of the time [of the year] in which she became pregnant (S, K) in the preceding year: so says El-Umawee: (S:) [or, so applied, it means the same as when said of a ewe or she-goat; for] the epithet applied to her in this case is muxorifN↓; (S, K;) but this is more correctly explained as signifying, applied to a she-camel and to a ewe or she-goat, that brings forth in the xryf. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, said of curap [or millet], It became very tall. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- Axrfhu naxolapF He assigned to him a palm-tree of which he should cut, or gather, the fruit. (Lth, K.) ＝ -A3- Also, (said of anxiety, JK, or of time,
or fortune, TA,) It corrupted him, or disordered him; (K, TA;) [app., in his intellect; or caused him to dote; as is indicated in the JK;] namely, an old man. (JK.)

xrifN Corrupted, unsound, or disordered, in his intellect, (S, Msb, K,) in consequence of old age; doting: (S, Msb:) fem. with p. (TA.)

xurufN A time of going forth of camels, (Nh,) or of men, (O, K,) to the [herbage of the season called] xariyf: so in the saying of El-Járood, yaA rasuwla QllRehi qado Ealimota maA yakofiynaA mina AlZRahori cawodN naOotiI EalayohinRa fiI xurufK [O Apostle of God, verily thou knowest that a number such as is termed cwd, of camels for riding or carriage, whereon we come in a time of going forth &c., is not sufficient for us]. (Nh, O, K.)

xurofapN Gathered, or plucked, fruits; (S, Mgh, K;) and particularly of the palm-tree: (TA:) and xuraAfapN↓ signifies the same. (Mgh, K, TA. [See also xariyfN.]) It is said in a trad., AltRamoru xurofapu AlSRaAYimi [Dates are the gathered fruit of the faster]; (S, TA;) because breaking the fast upon them is approved: and in another, AlnRaxolapu xurofapu AlSRaAYimi, meaning The palm-tree is that of which the fruit is eaten by the faster. (TA.) See also maxorafN, last sentence.

xarofaI The jlbAn, (i. e. julubRaAn, or julobaAn, &c., accord. to different copies of the K, [see art. jlb,]) a well-known grain or seed, (AHn, K,) of the kind called qaTaAniIR [i. e. pulse]: (AHn:) an arabicized word, from xarobaI, (AHn, K,) which is Persian; also called xulRarN. (AHn.)

xarofiIRN xrf xrfI xrfy

xarafaIRN and xarofiIRN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Msb,) and xirofiIRN↓, (K,) Of, or relating to, the season called xariyf; (S, Msb, K;) and applied to the rain of that season; (JK;) rel. ns. from Alxariyfu; (S, Msb, K;) irregularly formed. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- The first also signifies The increase (nitaAj) [of sheep and goats] in the end of the [season called] qayoZ. (Aboo-Nasr, TA voce SafariIRN, q. v.)

xaraAfN xrAf xrwf
xaraAfN and xiraAfN↓ The time of the gathering, or plucking, of fruits: (Ks, K:) like HaSaAdN and HiSaAdN [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also inf. ns. of xarafa in the first of the senses explained above. (K.)

xiraAfN xrAf xrwf
xiraAfN: see the next preceding paragraph: and see maxorafN, last sentence.

xaruwfN xrwf
xaruwfN A lamb; syn. HamalN [q. v.]: (S, Msb:) or the male young one of the sheep-kind: or such as has pastured, and become strong: (Lth, K:) younger than the jacaE: (Lth, TA:) so called because it depastures from this place and this: (Msb, TA: [see 1:]) fem. with p: (K:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OaxorifapN and (of mult., TA) xirofaAnN. (Msb, K, TA.) The latter pl. is sometimes used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Young and ignorant persons; like as kibaAXN is used as meaning aged and learned persons. (TA.) And hence the prov., kaQloxaruwfi OayonamaA QtRakaOa EalaI SuwfK [Like the lamb: wherever he reclines, he reclines upon wool]: (JK, TA: but in the latter, AtRkI:) applied to him who leads a soft and delicate life. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (sometimes, S,) A colt; the male offspring of a mare; when he has attained the age of six months, or seven months; (S, K;) a meaning assigned to it by As, in the “ Book of the Horse; ” but unknown to Abu-l-Ghowth: (S:) or, until a year old: (ISk, K:) it is said by some to be applied to a horse: in the L it is said that the xrwf of horses is such as is brought forth in the [season called] xariyf: but Khálid Ibn-Jebeleh says that it means such as pastures upon the [herbage of the season called] xariyf: and Suh thinks that it is an epithet applied to a horse, and any beast, as meaning that depastures the trees and herbage. (TA.)

xariyfN xryf
xariyfN Fresh ripe dates, (K, TA,) or fruits [in general], (S, TA,) gathered, or plucked; (S, K, TA;) as also maxoruwfN↓. (S, TA. See also maxorafN, last sentence. [And see xurofapN.]) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Fresh milk; milk recently drawn from the udder. (Hr, TA.) ― -b3- Palm-trees (naxolN) whereof the quantity of the fruit that is upon them is computed by conjecture. (K. [See also xaraAYifu, voce xariyfapN.]) ― -b4- [The autumn;] one of the divisions of the year, (S, Mgh,) the division (Msb) [consisting of] three months between the end of the qayoZ [or summer] and the beginning of the XitaMC [or winter], (Lth, K, *) in which the fruits are gathered. (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b5- And hence, (Mgh, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A year: (Mgh, K, TA:) so in the saying, mano SaAma yawomFA fiI sabiyli QllRehi baAEadahu QllRehu mina AlnRaAri OarobaEiyna xariyfFA Oawo saboEiyna, i. e. [Whoso fasteth a day in the way of God, God will remove him from the fire of Hell] to the distance of a journey of forty years, or seventy. (Mgh: and similar exs. are given in the TA, from three trads.: see also an ex. voce UinRa.) ― -b6- Also The rain of the season so called: (S, K:) or the rain, (JK,) or the first of the rain, (K,) in the beginning of the XitaMC [or winter], (JK, K,) which comes at the time of the cutting off of the fruit of the palmtrees: then follows the wasomiIR, at the coming in of the winter; then, the rabiyE; then, the Sayof; and then, the Hamiym: so says As: El-Ghanawee says that the xryf is between the [auroral] rising of AlXRiEoraI [or Sirius, which commenced, in central Arabia, about the epoch of the Flight, on the 13th of July, O. S.,] and the [auroral] setting of AlEaroquwataAni [or AlfarogaAni, the 26th and 27th of the Mansions of the Moon, commencing, in the same region and period, on the 8th and 21st of Sept., O. S., and continuing thirteen days]: El-Ghowr and Rekeeyeh [? (imperfectly written)] and El- Hijáz are all rained upon by the xryf; but Nejd is not: AZ says, the first rain is the wasomiIR; the follows the XatawiIR; then, the dafaYiIR; then, the Sayof; then, the Hamiym; then, the xariyf: and therefore the year is made to consist of six seasons: accord. to AHn, [who seems in this matter to differ from most others,] Alxryf is not originally the name of the division of the year; but the name of the rain of the qayoZ [or summer]; and then the season was named thereby. (TA.) [See also nawoCN.] ― -b7- [Also The herbage of the season so called, or of the rain so called; like as rabiyEN signifies the “ herbage of the season, or of the rain, so called. ” So in the phrase used by Khálid Ibn-Jebeleh (in explaining the word xaruwf), maA raEaI Alxariyfa Such as pastures upon the xryf.] ― -b8- Also, accord. to AA, (TA,) A rivulet, streamlet, or small channel for irrigation. (JK, K, TA.)

xuraAfapN xrAfh xrAfp xrwf
xuraAfapN i. q. xurofapN, q. v. (Mgh, K.) ― -b2- Hence xuraAfaAtN meaning Stories that are deemed pretty: similar to fukaAhapN from faAkihapN: (Mgh:) [or] xuraAfapu was the name of a man, (S, Mgh, K,) of [the tribe of] 'Odhrah, (S, K,) whom the Jinn (or Genii) fascinated, (S, Mgh, K,) as the Arabs assert, (Mgh,) and carried off, (TA,) and who related what he had seen, (S, Mgh, K,) of them, when he returned, (Mgh,) and they pronounced him a liar, and said, (S, Mgh, K,) of a thing that was impossible, (Mgh,) Hadiyvu xuraAfapa [a story of Khuráfeh]: (S, Mgh, K:) but it is related of the Prophet, that he said, xuraAfapu HaqRN, (S, Mgh,) meaning What Khuráfeh relates [as heard] from the Jinn [is true]: (Mgh:) the r is without teshdeed; and the article Al is not prefixed, because the word is determinate [by itself], unless one mean thereby xuraAfaAtN as signifying fictictious night-stories: (S:) or xuraAfapN signifies a fictitious story that is deemed pretty: (Lth, K:) [and OaxaAriyfu↓ app. signifies the same as xuraAfaAtN, as though its sing. were OuxoruwfapN, like as OasaATiyru and OaHaAdiyvu, which have similar meanings, are pls. of which the sings. are said to be OasoTuwrapN and OuHoduwvapN:] see 1, last signification.

xaruwfapN xrwf xrwfh xrwfp
xaruwfapN: see what next follows.

xariyfapN xryf xryfh xryfp
xariyfapN and xaruwfapN↓ A palm-tree (naxolapN) of which a man gathers, or plucks, the fruit for himself and his household; as also maxorafN↓: (AHn:) or a palm-tree which one takes for the picking up of its fresh ripe dates: (Sh, O, K:) or the latter signifies a palm-tree of which the fruit is cut off; being of the measure faEuwlapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: and the former is said to signify one that is set apart for its fruit that is [to be] gathered, or plucked: (TA:) or a selected palm-tree: (JK:) and its pl. is xaraAYifu: (JK, TA:) or xaraAYifu signifies palmtrees whereof the quantity of the fruit that is upon them is computed by conjecture. (AZ, S, K. [See also xariyfN.]) Also, the former, [A palm-tree set in the manner described in the following explanation:] one's digging, for a palm-tree, in a water-course, or channel of a torrent, in which are pebbles, until reaching hard ground, and then filling up the hollow with sand, and setting the palm-tree therein. (O, K.)

xaArifN xArf
xaArifN A keeper, or watcher, of palm-tree: (K:) pl. xurRaAfN. (TA.)

OaxaAriyfu c
OaxaAriyfu: see xuraAfapN; and see 1, last signification.

maxorafN mxrf
maxorafN The place of the gathering, or plucking, or cutting off, of fruit. (Msb.) A place of abode of a people, or party, during their xariyf. (TA. [It is there added, “ as though formed from OaxorafuwA, by the rejection of the augmentative letter: ” but it is rather to be regarded as regularly formed, from xarafuwA: see 1.]) ― -b2- Also A garden; (Mgh, TA;) and so maxorafapN↓: (S, K:) or a garden of palm-trees; as also maxorifN↓ and maxorafapN↓: (TA:) a single palm-tree: or a few palm-trees, up to ten; more than these being termed a busotaAn or a Hadiyqap: (El-Harbee, TA:) see also xariyfapN: or a small collection of palmtrees, six or seven, which a man purchases for the fruit that is [to be] gathered, or plucked: or any collection of palm-trees: (L, TA:) or a walled garden of palm-trees: (IAth, TA:) or palm-trees [absolutely]: (Mgh:) and an avenue between two rows of palm-trees, such that one may gather, or pluck, the fruit from whichever of them he will; (K;) as also maxorafapN↓: (Sh, K:) and, (S, Mgh, K,) as also maxorafapN↓, (S, K,) a road, (S, Mgh, K,) such as is conspicuous, clear, or open: (K:) pl. maxaArifu. (Mgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., EaAYidu AlmariyDi EalaI maxaArifi AljanRapi HatRaI yarojiEa, i. e. The visitor of the sick is as though he were in the gardens of Paradise until he returns: or upon the palm-trees of Paradise; gathering, or plucking, their fruits: or upon the roads of Paradise: (Mgh, * TA:) or, as some relate it, AljnRpi ElI maxorafapi↓. (TA. [See also another explanation, and other readings in what follows.]) And it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, AlnRaEami tarakotukumo EalaI maxorafapi↓, (S,) or turikotumo, (TA,) i. e. [I have left you, or ye have been left,] upon a conspicuous road, like the road of the camels, (As, S, * TA,) which they have trodden with their feet so that it has become plainly apparent. (As, TA.) ― -b3- Also Gathered, or plucked, fruit of palm-trees: (As, A 'Obeyd, IAmb, K:) a correct meaning, though IKt says that the proper word in this sense is only maxoruwfN: it is like maXorabN and maToEamN and marokabN as meaning maXoruwbN and TaEaAmN maOokuwlN and marokuwbN; and may signify fresh ripe dates gathered or plucked: (IAmb, TA:) pl. as above. (As, &c.) So in the former of the two trads. mentioned above accord. to As and A 'Obeyd: (TA:) and this interpretation is corroborated by another reading, i. e., ElI AljnRpi xurofapi↓: (Mgh:) another reading is, fiI AljnRpi xiraAfi↓: [see xaraAfN:] and another, lahu fiI AljanRapi xariyfN↓, i. e. [The visitor of the sick shall have] gathered fruits in Paradise. (TA.)

mixorafN The thing in which fruits are gathered; (S, Har p. 374;) called by the Arabs xaAfapN: (Har ib.:) a [basket of the kind called] mikotal, (Msb,) or zinobiyl, of small size, in which the best fresh ripe dates are gathered: (O, K:) pl. maxaArifu. (A, TA.) One says, xarajuwA UilaI AlmaxaArifi bAlmaxaArifi, i. e. They went forth to the gardens with the baskets (zubul) [for gathering fruit]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) The basket (znbyl) in which the importunate beggar puts his food. (Har ubi suprà.)

And you say, EayoXN muxarofajN A plentiful life. (S.) ― -b2- Also The best of food, or of meat and drink; and so xarofajN↓ and xuraAfijN↓. (Er-Riyáshee.)

1 xaraqahu Oxrq xrq xrqh xrqp
1. xaraqahu, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
xariqa
(Mgh, Msb, K) and
xaruqa
, (K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) inf. n. xaroqN, (S, Mgh, Msb, KL,) He made a hole in it, perforated it, pierced it, or bored it; (Msb, * KL;) syn. jaAbahu [in this sense, as well as in another to be explained below], (K, [in the CK, erroneously, jACa bhi,]) and vaqabahu: (TA:) and he cut it [so as to make a hole or a slit in it]: (Msb:) and he rent it, or tore it. (JK, K, KL.) You say, xaraqa Alvawoba, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) aor.
xariqa
[and
xaruqa
], inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) He [made a hole in, or] rent, or tore, the garment, or piece of cloth; (JK, K;) and AlxufRa [the boot]; and the like. (Mgh.) And xaraqa AlSRaxorapa He made a hole in the rock; syn. jaAbahu. (A in art. jwb.) [And xaraqa AlHaAYiTa He made a hole in, or through, the wall: see xaroqN, below.] And xaraqahu biAlmivoqabi He made a hole in it or through it, perforated it, pierced it, or bored it, with a drill or the like; syn. vaqabahu. (Msb in art. vqb.) xaraqa AlsRafiynapa [He made a hole in the ship], in the Kur xviii. 70, means that he did so by taking out, from the ship, with an axe, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) a plank, (Jel,) or two planks. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xaraqa AlOaroDa, (JK, S, Msb,) or AlmafaAzapa, (Mgh, K, *) (tropical:) He traversed, crossed, or cut through by journeying, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the earth, or land, (JK, S, Msb,) or the desert; (Mgh, K;) syn. qaTaEahaA; (JK, Mgh, K; *) or jaAbahaA; (S, Msb;) so as to reach the furthest part thereof. (Mgh, TA.) [See also 8.] It is said in the Kur [xvii. 39], UinRaka lano taxoriqa AlOaroDa, meaning, For thou shalt not reach the extremities of the earth: or, accord. to Az, thou shalt not traverse the earth in length and breadth: (TA:) or it means thou shalt not bore through the earth, (Jel, TA,) so as to reach the end thereof: (Jel:) or thou shalt not make a hole in the earth by thy vehement treading: (Ksh, Bd:) accord. to one reading, ln taxoruqa. (Ksh, TA.) ― -b3- [And xaraqati AlrRiyHu (assumed tropical:) The wind passed along: and (assumed tropical:) blew: for] the inf. n. xaroqN signifies (assumed tropical:) the passing of the wind: and (assumed tropical:) the blowing thereof. (KL.) [See also 7 and 8.] ― -b4- xaraqa Alkaciba (tropical:) He forged, or feigned, the lie; as also Axtrqhu↓. (K, TA.) It is said in the Kur vi. 100, waxaraquwA lahu baniyna wabanaAtK, i. e. (tropical:) And they have feigned Him to have, or falsely attributed to Him, sons and daughters. (Ksh, Bd, Jel. [See also 2.]) And xaraqa [alone, the object being understood], (K,) inf. n. as above, (KL,) signifies (tropical:) He lied; told a lie: (K, KL, TA:) and txrRq↓ (tropical:) he forged, or feigned, a lie. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- xariqati AlXRaApu, aor.
xaraqa
, inf. n. xaraqN, The sheep had in its ear a xaroq, i. e. a round hole or perforation. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- xariqa fiI Albayoti, aor.
xaraqa
, (JK, K,) inf. n. xuruwqN, (JK,) or
xaraqN; (TK;) and xaraqa, inf. n. xuruwqN; (K;) He remained in the house, or tent, not quitting it. (JK, * K.) ― -b2- And xariqa, aor.
xaraqa
, inf. n. xaraqN, said of a gazelle, or young gazelle, (Msb, K, TA,) when hunted, (TA,) or when overtaken by the dog, (IAar,) It was frightened, (Msb, K, TA, [in the CK, Aano yaEoraqa is erroneously put for Oano yaforaqa,]) so as to be unable to go away, (Msb,) or so as to be unable to rise, (K, TA,) and clave to the ground: (IAar, TA:) and in like manner said of a bird, (Msb, K,) it became frightened, (K,) or impatient, (TA,) so as to be unable to fly away. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (Msb,) the same verb, (S, Msb, K,) with the same aor., (Msb, K,) and the same inf. n., (S, Msb, K,) said of a man, (Msb,) He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or he became bereft of his reason or intellect, because of fear, or of shame: (S, Msb, K:) or he was confounded, perplexed, or amazed, [for yatahayRaba in the CK, I read yabohata, as in other copies of the K and in the TA,] opening his eyes, and looking: (K, TA:) and he remained confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of anxiety, or of hardship, or distress. (TA.) waqaEa faxariqa [He fell down and clave to the ground], occurring in a trad, means he fell down dead. (TA.) ＝ -A4- xariqa, aor.
xaraqa
, (JK, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xaraqN; (S, Msb, K; *) and xaruqa, aor.
xaruqa
, (JK, K,) [of which xuroqN, said in the S and Msb to be a simple subst., may be the inf. n., like as HusonN is of Hasona;] He was rough, ungentle, clumsy, or awkward, (S, Msb, K,) in doing, or making, a thing: (Msb:) and he was unskilful in work, and in the management of affairs: and he was foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding: (K:) or he was ignorant: (JK:) or the latter verb signifies he knew not his work with his hand, or his handicraft. (Msb.) And xaruqa biAlXRaIoCi He was ignorant of the thing, (K, TA,) and did it not well. (TA.)

2 xrRqh Oxrq xrq xrqh xrqp
2. xrRqh, (S, Msb,) inf. n. taxoriyqN, (Msb, K,) is similar to xaraqahu, but has an intensive signification; [He made holes in it; perforated it, pierced it, or bored it, in several, or many, places: he cut it so as to make holes or slits in it:] (Msb:) he rent it, or tore it, much, or in several, or many, places: (K, TA:) namely, a garment, (S, TA,) &c. (TA.) ― -b2- And xrRq, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He lied much. (K, TA.) Aboo-Jaafar and Náfi' read, [in the Kur vi. 100,] waxarRaquwA lahu baniyna wabanaAtK (assumed tropical:) [And they have very falsely attributed to Him sons and daughters]. (TA. [See also 1.])

4 Axrqhu Oxrq Oxrqh Axrqh Axrqp xrq
4. Axrqhu He (a man, S) caused him to be confounded, or perplexed, so that he was unable to see his right course; or caused him to be bereft of his reason, or intellect. (S, K.)

5 txrRq Oxrq txrq xrq
5. txrRq quasi-pass. of xarRaqa; [thus signifying It had holes made in it; became perforated, pierced, or bored, in several, or many, places: it became cut so as to have holes or slits made in it: it became rent, or torn, much, or in several, or many, places:] (S, * K:) as also Anxrq↓; (K;) [or rather the latter, as is indicated in the S, is quasi-pass. of xaraqa, and thus signifies it had a hole made in it; became perforated, pierced, or bored: it became cut so as to have a hole or slit made in it: it became rent, or torn:] and Axrwrq↓ signifies the same [as the former or as the latter]: all said of a garment [&c.]: (S:) and Anxrq↓ signifies also it became wide, or expanded. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] txrRq fiI AlsRaxaMCi (tropical:) He took a wide, or an ample, range, or was profuse, in liberality, bounty, or munificence; syn. twsRE. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- And see what next follows, in two places.

7 Uinoxaraqa
7: see 5, in two places. ― -b2- Anxrqti AlrRiyHu (tropical:) The wind blew [app. in any manner, (see munoxaraq,) or] irregularly; not in one uniform manner: (TA:) [and txrRft↓ app. signifies the same: for you say,] baladN waAsiEN tanoxariqu bihi AlrRiyaAHu [(assumed tropical:) A wide country in which the winds blow, or blow irregularly]: (El-Muärrij, TA:) and fiyhaA AlrRiyaAHu OaroDN waAsiEapN tataxarRaqu↓ [app. meaning, in like manner, (assumed tropical:) A wide land in which the winds blow, &c.]. (S, K.)

8 Axtrq Oxtrq Axtrq Qxtrq
8. Axtrq (tropical:) He, or it, passed through, or over, or across. (Mgh, K, * TA.) [See also 1, in the former half of the paragraph.] (tropical:) He traversed, or crossed, (Mgh, TA,) a desert, (Mgh,) or a land, (TA,) not following a road. (Mgh, TA.) [(assumed tropical:) He travelled a road: see an ex. voce vugorapN.] (tropical:) He made a mosque, (Mgh, TA,) and a house, (TA,) to be his way, or thoroughfare. (Mgh, TA.) Hence, Axtrq AlHijora (assumed tropical:) He entered into the midst of the Hijor [q. v.], without going around the HaTiym. (Mgh.) And Alxayolu taxotariqu maAbayona AlquraI waAlOaroDi (tropical:) The horses, or horsemen, pass through the midst of the intervening spaces of the towns, or villages, and the land. (TA.) And Aixotaraqotu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) I stepped into the midst of the people, or party. (TA.) And AlrRayHu taxotariqu AlOaXojaAra (assumed tropical:) [The wind passes, or blows, through the trees.] (JK.) AixotiraAqu AlrRiyaAHi signifies (assumed tropical:) The passing [or blowing] of the winds. (S.) [See also 1, in the middle of the paragraph; and see 7.] ― -b2- Axtrq Alkaciba: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

xaroqN Oxrq xrq xrqp
xaroqN, originally an inf. n., of 1: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) A hole, or perforation, (Mgh, Msb, KL,) in a garment, (S, TA,) and in a wall, (Msb, TA,) &c.: (Msb:) and a round hole, or perforation, in the ear of a sheep: (S, Msb:) pl. xuruwqN. (S, Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying, AitRasaEa Alxaroqu EalaI AlrRaAqiEi [The hole was, or became, wide to the patcher]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A part that has a hole made in it, or that is rent, or torn, of, or from, a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A desert; and so maxoraqN↓: (K:) or the former, a desert far extending, (JK, TA,) whether level or not level: and ↓the latter, a wide desert in which the winds [blow, or] blow irregularly: (TA:) and the former, (El-Muärrij, K,) as also xaroqaMCN↓, (K,) signifies likewise a wide land, (K,) or a wide country, (El-Muärrij,) in which the winds [blow, or] blow irregularly: (El-Muärrij, K: [see 7:]) ISh says, the space between El-Basrah and Hafr Abee-Moosà is a xaroq, and that between En-Nibáj and Dareeyeh is a xaroq: (TA:) pl. xuruwqN. (K.) You say also xawoqaMCu mafaAzapN xaroqaMCu↓ A farextending desert. (TA.) And qaTaEonaA Uilayokumo OaroDFA xaroqaMCa↓ and xaruwqFA↓ [We have traversed, in journeying to you, a wide land, or a wide land in which the winds blow, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain plant, resembling the qusoT [q. v.], (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) having leaves. (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád.)

xuroqN Oxrq xrq xrqp
xuroqN a subst. from xariqa, (S, Msb,) [or perhaps inf. n. of xaruqa as syn. with xariqa, (see 1, last two sentences,)] and xuruqN↓, (TA,) Roughness, ungentleness, clumsiness, or awkwardness; contr. of rifoqN; (JK, S, * Mgh, Msb, * K, TA;) in doing, or making, a thing: (Msb:) unskilfulness in work, and in the management of affairs: foolishness; stupidity; or unsoundness, or deficiency, in intellect or understanding; as also xuroqapN↓: (K:) and ignorance. (TA.) [Hence,] nawomapu Alxuroqi The sleep of [the time of morning called] the DuHaI. (Har p. 223. [See also HumoqN and xuluqN.]) ＝ -A2- The first of these words is also pl. of Oaxoraqu and of [its fem.] xaroqaMCu. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also The she-camel's vulva. (JK.)

xiroqN Oxrq xrq xrqp
xiroqN and xirRiyqN↓ (tropical:) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (S, K;) as also mixoraAqN↓: (IAar, K:) or ↓the second signifies very liberal or bountiful &c.: (K: [so in a later part of the art.:]) or this and the first signify one who takes a wide, or an ample, range, or is profuse, in liberality or bounty &c.: (TA:) or a youth, or young man, (JK,) excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, and the like; or clever, or ingenious; with liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity, (Lth, JK, K,) and courage: (Lth, JK:) and a goodly youth or young man, [for AlfatiIRu in the CK, I read AlfataI, as in other copies of the K,] of generous disposition: (K:) the pl. (of xiroqN, TA) is OaxoraAqN [a pl. of pauc.] (K) and xuraAqN, or xurRaAqN, (accord. to different copies of the K, [both anomalous, and perhaps it is xiraAqN, agreeably with analogy,]) and xuruwqN; (K;) and the pl. of xirRiyqN↓ is xirRiyquwna; no broken pl. of it having been heard. (T, TA.) One says also, AlkafRi biAlnRawaAli huwa mataxarRiqu↓ (tropical:) [He has a liberal hand, largely beneficent]. (TA.) And AlkRfRi biAlnRawaAli huwa maxoruwqu↓ (tropical:) He is liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous. (TA. [But see maxoruwqN below.]) ― -b2- xiroqN is also applied to a spear, meaning (assumed tropical:) Highly esteemed or prized; excellent; or rare. (TA.)

xaruqN Oxrq xrq xrqp
xaruqN: see Oaxoraqu.

xariqN Oxrq xrq xrqp
xariqN [part. n. of xariqa, q. v.:] A young gazelle weak in the legs, (K, TA,) cleaving to the ground, and not rising: (TA:) a gazelle, or young gazelle, (K, TA,) when hunted, (TA,) frightened, so as to be unable to rise: (K, TA:) and in like manner a bird (K, TA) frightened, (K,) or
impatient, (TA,) so as to be unable to fly away: (K, TA:) fem. with p. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] A man (Msb) confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or bereft of his reason or intellect, by reason of fear, or of shame: (S, Msb, K:) or confounded, perplexed, or amazed, opening his eyes, and looking. (K, TA.) See also Oaxoraqu. ＝ -A2- Also Ashes: because they remain [cleaving to the ground] while the people thereof go away. (K.)

xuruqN Oxrq xrq xrqp

xuroqapN: see xuroqN.

xiroqapN A piece, (S, Msb, K,) or piece torn off, (TA,) of a garment, or of cloth; [a rag;] pl. xiraqN. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [A ragged, patched, garment: and particularly one worn by a devotee; also called muraqRaEapN, q. v.: but this is probably postclassical. Hence, OaSoHaAbu Alxiraqi The devotees.] ― -b3- (tropical:) A portion of a swarm of locusts, (K, TA,) less than a rijol; as also HizoqapN. (TA.)

xaruwqN xrq xrwq
xaruwqN: see the next paragraph: ― -b2- and see also xaroqN.

xariyqN xryq
xariyqN A womb rent by the fœtus, and that consequently does not conceive (K, TA) afterwards; (TA;) [of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN;] as also mutaxarRiqapN↓. (K.) ― -b2- And A she-camel whose womb has been rent. (JK.) Applied to a well (biYor), it signifies AlRatiI kusira jibolatuhaAEani AlmaMCi: (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, K:) [in the CK jabalatuhA: neither of these readings affords an admissible meaning: the right reading I believe to be jiyluhaA; and the meaning, Of which the side, or lateral part, is broken, from the water upwards:] pl. xaraAYiqu (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, K, TA) and xuruqN, (Ibn-' Abbád, K, TA, [the latter erroneously written in the CK xuruwoqN,]) like safaAYinu and sufonN. (TA.) ― -b3- A channel of water that is not deep, and not without trees. (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b4- The place of expanding of a valley, where it ends. (JK, K.) ― -b5- A low, or depressed, tract of land, containing herbage: pl. xuruqN. (S, K.) One says, mararotu bixariyqK mina AlOaroDi bayona masoHaAwayoni [I passed by a low tract of land, containing herbage, between two plain tracts containing small pebbles and without herbage]. (Fr, S.) ― -b6- Hard ground. (A, TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A violent wind; (A, TA;) as also riyHN xaroqaMCu↓: (S, K:) the latter signifies (tropical:) a wind that blows violently: or, that does not continue to blow in the same direction: (TA:) or the former signifies (tropical:) a cold wind that blows violently; (S, K;) as also xaruwqN↓: (K:) [it is an epithet; for] one says riyHN xariyqN which is anomalous, as by rule one should say xariyqapN: (S:) it is [also] one of the names for (tropical:) a cold wind that blows violently; (JK, T, TA;) as though it perforated, or rent; the agent [riyHN] being unused: (T, TA:) and (as some say, TA) it signifies also (assumed tropical:) a gentle, soft, wind; thus bearing two contr. meanings: or that returns, and [then] continues its course: (K:) or, as in the L, does not continue its course: (TA:) or that blows long. (K.)

xurRaqN A certain bird, (JK, IDrd, K,) smaller than the qunobur [or lark], (JK,) that cleaves to the ground: (IDrd:) or a kind of sparrow: (K:) so says AHát, in the “ Book of Birds: ” (TA:) pl. xaraAriqu. (JK, IDrd, K.)

xirRiyqN xryq
xirRiyqN: see xiroqN, in three places.

xaAriqN [act. part. n. of xaraqa]. ― -b2- [And hence,] sayofN xaAriqN A sharp, or cutting, sword: pl. xuruqN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] OamorN xaAriqN liloEaAdapi (assumed tropical:) [An event breaking through, or infringing, the usual course of nature]. (KT, in a definition of muEojizapN, q. v.) ― -b4- [In the present day, xaAriqN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Profound, or penetrating, in learning or science.]

Oaxoraqu c
Oaxoraqu and [its fem.] xaroqaMCu have for their pl. xuroqN. (K.) ― -b2- The fem., applied to a ewe, signifies Having her ear perforated (S, Mgh, Msb, K) with a round hole. (S, Msb.) And, applied to an ear, Perforated, or bored. (TA.) ― -b3- And the masc., applied to a camel, That puts his manosim [or toe] upon the ground before [the sole of] his xufR [or foot]: the doing of which is a result of generous quality. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And the fem., applied to a she-camel, That does not retread (laA tataEaAhadu), in the L lA ttEhRd,) [with her hind feet] the places of her [fore] feet (JK, L, K) upon the ground: mentioned by Ibn- 'Abbád and Z. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, (Mgh, Msb,) Rough, ungentle, clumsy, or awkward, (JK, S, Msb,) in doing, or making, a thing: (Msb:) unskilful in work [and in the management of affairs (see xariqa]; as also xariqN↓ and xaruqN↓: (K:) or foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding: (Mgh, K:) ignorant: (TA:) not knowing his work with his hand, or his handicraft: (Msb:) fem. as above. (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, &c.) It is said in a prov., (JK, S,) laA taEodamu AlxaroqaMCu EilRapF [The stupid woman is not in want of an excuse]: (JK, S, K:) used in forbidding excuses: (K:) i. e., excuses are many: the stupid woman is skilled in making them: how then must be the clever? (S, K:) applied to every one who excuses himself being able. (K in art. El.) ― -b5- xaroqaMCu applied to a desert, and to a land: see xaroqN, in three places. ― -b6- And applied to a wind: see xariyqN. ― -b7- Hence, riHolapN xaroqMCu (assumed tropical:) A hard journey. (Har p. 177.)

maxoraqN mxrq
maxoraqN: see xaroqN, in two places. ― -b2- maxoraqu HawoDK A stone that is at the Euqor [or hinder part] of a watering-trough, for the purpose of their [standing upon it, and] drawing forth the water from it, [i. e. the trough,] when they will. (K.)

maxoriqN, though unheard by us, is the sing. of maxaAriqu signifying The orifices of the body; such as the mouth and the nose and the ears and the anus and the like. (Mgh.)

muxoraqN [pass. part. n. of 4; Confounded, &c.: and hence,] silent. (JK: but there written without the vowel of the r.)

gayoru muxoriqK, applied to a road, means [That does not cause one to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or] in which one is not confounded, or perplexed, so as to be unable to see his right course. (IAar in TA: but the latter word is there written without the vowel of the r.)

mixoraAqN mxrAq
mixoraAqN A kerchief twisted for the purpose of beating therewith: (JK, S:) a genuine Arabic word: (S:) or a thing made of twisted rags, with which boys play: (TA:) or a twisted kerchief, or an inflated [skin such as is termed] ziqR, or the like, with which boys play, beating one another therewith: so called because it rends (yaxoriqu) the air when they make use of it: (Ham p. 702:) pl. maxaAriyqu. (S, TA.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says,
kaOanRa suyuwfanaA minRaA waminohumo
maxaAriyqN biOayodiI laA EibiynaA
[As though our swords, ours and theirs, were kerchiefs twisted for beating therewith, in the hands of players]: (S:) or mxAryq in this verse [written with tenween by poetic license] is the pl. of mixoraAqN signifying a wooden sword with which boys play: the poet means, we cared not for the smiting with the swords, like as the players care not for the smiting with the mxAryq. (EM p. 198.) [See also another ex., in a verse cited voce xariyjN.] 'Alee is related, in a trad., to have said that the lightning is the maxaAriyq of the angels; (S, TA;) meaning thereby the instruments with which the angels chide and drive the clouds. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A garment, or piece of cloth. (JK. [But this I find not elsewhere.]) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A sword [in the ordinary sense of the word]: so in the A and O and L: in the K, AlsRayRidu is erroneously put for AlsRayofu. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A man goodly in body, or person, whether tall or not tall. (JK, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) One who falls not into a case without escaping, or extricating himself, therefrom. (Sh, TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) One who exercises art in the management of affairs. (K.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A wild bull: (As, K:) so called because he traverses far-extending districts: (As, TA:) or because the dogs pursue him and he escapes from them: said in the A to be called mixoraAqu AlmafaAzapi. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A man who engages in wars, or fights, and is active therein. (S, K.) ― -b9- See also xiroqN.

maxoruwqN mxrwq
maxoruwqN (tropical:) One who is denied good, or prosperity; into whose hand wealth falls not. (K, TA.) And maxoruwqu AlkafRi (assumed tropical:) A man who gains not, or gets not, anything. (JK.) See also xiroqN.

muxoraworiqN mxrwrq
muxoraworiqN One who goes round about camels, [meaning who has them within the compass of his rule and care,] (JK, K, TA,) and urges them against their will, (TA,) and is active, and exercises art in his management [of them]: (JK, K, TA:) mentioned by Sgh on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

muxotaraqN mxtrq
muxotaraqN (assumed tropical:) A passage, or place of passing. (S. [See xawoxapN, in two places.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] baladN baEiydu Almuxotaraqi (assumed tropical:) [A country, or district, wide to
traverse; lit., far extending in respect of the place of passing]. (TA.) ― -b3- muxotaraqu AlrRiyaAHi (assumed tropical:) A place in which the winds blow: (K:) and AlrRiyHi munoxaraqu↓ (assumed tropical:) a place in which the wind blows [in any manner, or irregularly: see 7]. (S.)

mutaxarRiqu mtxrq
mutaxarRiqu: see the last paragraph in this art.: and see also xariyqN: ― -b2- and xiroqN.

munoxaraqN mnxrq
munoxaraqN: see muxotaraqN.

munoxariqN mnxrq
munoxariqN [Having a hole made in it, &c.: see its verb]. rajulN munoxariqu AlsRirobaAli A man having his clothing rent, or torn, (JK, K,) by long travel; as also AlsRirobaAl mutaxarRiqu↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Quick, or swift. (Ham p. 42.)

1 xaramahu xrm xrmh xrmp
1. xaramahu, aor.
xarima
, inf.n. xaromN, He perforated, or pierced, it; namely, a thing. (Msb.) [And so xazamahu. (Mgh in art. xzm.)] ― -b2- And He cut it, or cut it off. (Msb.) You say, maA xaramotu minohu XayoYFA I did not diminish, and did not cut off, from it, or him, anything. (S.) And maA xarama mina AlHadiyvi HarofFA He did not diminish [from the narrative, or tradition, a letter, or a word]. (TA.) And xarama fulaAnFA, (K,) aor, and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He slit the partition between the nostrils of such a one: (K:) or xaromN signifies the mutilating (qaToE) of the nose: (JK:) or mutilation (qaToE) in the partition between the nostrils and in the naAXirataAni [or two alœ], or in the extremity of the Oaronabap [or lobule of the nose]; not amounting to what is termed jadoEN; (Lth, TA;) and the epithet is Oaxoramu↓, fem. xaromaMCu: (Lth, JK, TA:) and the like in the lip; or in the upper part of the fuwq [app. meaning the front edge of the lobe, which at its termination above forms a crena,] of the ear: (Lth, TA: [see Oaxoramu, as relating to the ear:]) accord. to Sh, it is both in the nose and in the ear; but in the nose, it is the mutilation (qTE) of the fore part of the nostril of a man, and the Oaronabap [or lobule of the nose], after the mutilation of the upper part of this, so as to reach the interior of the nose; and the epithet applied to the man is Oaxoramu↓. (TA.) And xaramahu, inf. n. as above, also signifies He hit, or hurt, his xaworamap [q. v.]. (TA.) You say also, xarama Alxurozapa, (K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] Alxarazapa,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n.; (TA;) and xrRmhA↓, (K,) inf.n. taxoriymN; (TA;) He cracked, or tore without separating, the suture, or seam, of a skin; syn. faSamahaA: (K, TA, in the CK qaSamahA:) or xaramotu Alxaroza, aor. and inf. n. as above, i. q. OavoOayotuhu [meaning I spoiled the sewing of the skin, or hide; as when one uses a thick instrument for sewing or perforating, and a thin thong; or as when one rends two stitch-holes into one]. (S.) [And xaramahu sayolN app. A torrent cut into it, or trenched it; namely, the ground, or the side of a mountain: see xaromN.] And xaramatohu xawaArimu↓ [lit. Cutting-off events cut him off]; meaning (assumed tropical:) he died: like as one says, XaEabatohu XaEuwbu. (TA. [See also 8.]) ― -b3- xarama AlqiroTaAsa He hit the target with his arrow without perforating it. (TA.) ― -b4- maA xarama Eani AlTRariyqi He (a guide) did not turn aside from the way. (JK, S.) ＝ -A2- xarima, (S, K,) aor.
xarama
, (K,) inf. n. xaramN, (S,) said of a man, (S, K,) He had the partition between his nostrils cut, or mutilated: or the extremity of his nose, but not to the extent denoted by the term jadoEN: the epithet applied to the man in this case is Oaxoramu↓: (S:) or he had the partition between his nostrils slit; i. e. wataratuhu taxarRamato↓. (K.) ＝ -A3- xaruma, aor.
xaruma
, He cared not for what he did nor for what was said to him. (K.)

2 xarRama
2: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] DaroEN fiyhi taxoriymN An udder in which are incisions [or crackings of the skin]; and so fyh taXoriymN. (TA.)

5 txrRmt wataratuhu txrmt wtrth txrmt wtrtp
5. txrRmt wataratuhu: see 1, last sentence but one. txrRmt Alxurozapu (K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] xaramahaA,) The suture, or seam, of a skin cracked, or became torn without separating; quasi-pass. of xaramahaA [q. v.]. (K, TA.) Anxrm↓ [in like manner] signifies It became slit; said of the bore of the ear. (S.) And you say also, txrRm AlzRanodu [The wooden instrument for producing fire cracked, or split]. (TA.) Hence the phrase, OaraAka yataxarRamu zanoduka, mentioned by IAar, meaning (assumed tropical:) I see thee to have no good in thee: for when the znd cracks, or splits, (UicaA taxarRama,) one cannot produce fire by mean of it, and there is no good in it. (TA.) [Hence likewise,] txrRm zanoduhu means also (tropical:) His anger became appeased: [or,] accord. to the S, txrRm zabaduhu has this meaning: and accord. to the A, txrRm Oanofuhu has the same meaning. (TA.) Accord. to IAar, (TA,) jaMCanaA fulaAnN yataxarRamu zabaduhu means (tropical:) Such a one came to us doing to us that which was wrongful, or injurious, and foolish, or stupid. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8, in two places. ＝ -A3- txrRm also signifies He followed, or adopted, the religion of the xurRamiyRap. (S, K, TA: in the CK, the maxorimiyRap.)

7 Anxrm Onxrm Anxrm Qnxrm
7. Anxrm It became cut, or cut off. (Msb.) See also 5. Said of a writing, or book, it means It became deficient; part of it went. (TA.) And said of a generation, It went away; came to an end. (TA.) See also Oaxoramu.

8 Aixotaramahumu AldRahoru Axtrmhm Aldhr
8. Aixotaramahumu AldRahoru Time, or fortune, cut them off; and extirpated them; as also taxarRamahumo↓: (S:) or destroyed them by its calamities. (Msb.) And Aixotaramatohumu AlmaniyRapu and taxarRamatohumo↓ Death, or the decree of death, cut them off; and extirpated them. (K.) And Aixoaramatohu AlmaniyRapu Death, or the decree of death, [cut him off, or] took him away, (JK, K, TA,) mino bayoni OaSoHaAbihi [from amidst his companions. (TA. [A phrase similar to xaramatohu xawaArimu: see 1.]) And Auxoturima EanRaA (JK, * K,) [He was cut off from us by death;] he was taken away [from us by death]; (JK;) he died, (K, TA,) and went away [from us]. (TA.) Accord. to some, AixotirAmN [as an inf. n. of Auxoturima] signifies The dying suddenly. (Har p. 123.)
