xuromN xrm
xuromN The place of the bore, or perforation, of a thing. (Msb.) The eye of a needle. (TA.) ― -b2- See also maxorimN.

xaramapN xrm xrmh xrmp
xaramapN The place of perforation of the ear: (S:) or the place of slitting, of the nose, in the partition between the nostrils [and in either of the alœ, as appears from what here follows]. (K.) It is said in a trad., fiI AlxaramaAti AlvRalaAvi mina AlOanof AldRiyapu, by AlxrmAt being app. meant AlmaxoruwmaAt↓, i. e. [In the case of the mutilation of] the two alœ and the partition between the nostrils [the blood-wit, or fine for homicide, shall be paid]. (TA.)

xuromaAnN xrm xrmAn
xuromaAnN A lie, or falsehood. (S, K.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN biAlxuromaAni (S, TA) i. e. [Such a one uttered] that which was a lie. (TA.)

xariymN xrym
xariymN One who cares not for what he does nor for what is said to him. (K.)

AlxurRamiyRapu Alxrmyh Alxrmyp
AlxurRamiyRapu The sect who held the doctrine of the transmigration of the soul, and allowed general license: (S, K, TA:) they were in the time of El-Moatasim: their sheykh, Bábak [El-Khurramee, i. e. of Khurram, in Persia], was then slain, and they scattered themselves in the countries; and there remains of them a remnant in the mountains of Syria. (TA.)

xurRaAmN xrAm
xurRaAmN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Young men (TA) such as follow the licentious ways of the xurRamiyRap [so I render mutaxarRimuwna↓] in acts of disobedience. (K, TA.) [See what next follows.]

xaArimN xArm
xaArimN [act. part. n. of xarama: fem. with p; and pl. of the latter xawaArimu]. One says, xaramatohu xawaArimu [explained above]: see 1. (TA.) ― -b2- Corrupting; acting corruptly; doing evil, or mischief. (K.) [See xurRaAmN, which is probably a pl. thereof.] ― -b3- Neglecting; or leaving undone [what ought to be done]. (K.) ＝ -A2- Cold, as an epithet (K.) ― -b2- A cold wind: (K:) so accord. to A'Obeyd: but accord. to Kr, [xaAzimN,] with zAI. (TA.)

xaworamN xwrm
xaworamN: see what next follows.

xaworamapN xwrmh xwrmp
xaworamapN The end, or tip, of the nose (JK, S) of a man: (S:) or the fore part of the nose: or the part between the nostrils. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (JK, K,) as being likened thereto, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A rock in which are holes; (JK, K;) n. un. of xaworamN↓: (K:) [or] the latter has this signification. (S. [But this seems to be a mistake.])

Oaxoramu c
Oaxoramu [Having the nose mutilated in any of the manners explained in the first paragraph of this art.]: fem. xaromaMCu: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- And Having the ear perforated, when it is not slit:
(S:) or having the ear slit after it has been pierced: (S and Msb* and TA in art. xrb:) and muxarRamN↓, likewise, signifies having the ear slit; as also Oaxorabu and muxarRabN. (TA in that art.) And the fem., applied to a she-goat, Having her ear slit crosswise. (K. [See also xacomaMCu.]) Also, the fem., applied to an ear, Slit, or perforated, or mutilated. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A pool of water left by a torrent; because one part thereof passes a way (yanoxarimu↓) to another: pl. xuromN. (TA.) ― -b2- And the fem. also signifies Any hill, or rising ground, sloping down into a [hollow such as is termed] wahodap; (K;) and so the masc.: (TA:) or any [hill such as is termed] Oakamap having a side whereby it cannot be ascended. (K.) ＝ -A3- Oaxoramu Alkatifi The extremity of the spine of the scapula: (S:) or a notch, or small hollowed place, [app. the glenoid cavity,] at the extremity of the spine of the scapula, (JK, T, TA,) next the socket: (T, TA:) pl. OaxaArimu: (JK, T, TA:) or OaxoramaA Alkatifayoni, in the K miswritten Mxiru maA fiI Alkatiafayoni, signifies the heads of the two scapulæ, next the upper arms: (K, * TA:) or the two extremities, or edges, of the lower portion of the two scapulæ, which surround, or border, the kuEoburap [app. here meaning the thick part next to the inferior angle] of the scapula: and AlOaxoramu the end of the spine [of the scapula]. (K, * TA. [In the K is here added, accord. to different copies, Hayovu yanoxadiEu, as in the TA; or Hyv yanoxadimu, as in the CK; or Hyv yanoxacimu: the right reading seems to be Hayovu yanoxarimu, where it forms a kind of cleft; app. meaning where it forms the glenoid cavity. In the CK, for munoqaTaEu AlEayori, is erroneously put munoqaTiEu AlEayoni; and w is erroneously prefixed to the former noun.]) ― -b2- AlOaxoramaAni Two cleft bones at the extremity of the interior of the upper part of the inside of the mouth. (K.) ＝ -A4- Oaxoramu AlrRaOoIi (tropical:) A man weak in judgment. (JK, TA.)

maxorimN mxrm
maxorimN The end of a prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain: pl. maxaArimu: (S:) or maxorimu jabalK signifies the prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain: [like xaromN:] and maxorimu sayolK, the extremity of a torrent: (K: [accord. to the TK, of a sword; for mxrm Alsyf is there put in the place of mxrm Alsiyl:]) pl. as above: (TA:) and maxorimu OakamapK and AkmpK xuromu↓ signify the place where a hill such as is termed Akmp ends. (K.) Also A [road such as is termed] vaniyRap, between two mountains: (TA:) [or the pl.] maxaArimu signifies the mouths of [mountain-roads such as are termed] fijaAj: (S:) or roads in rugged tracts: (Skr, K:) or roads in mountains, and in sands. (IAth, TA.) [Hence,] yamiynN caAtu maxaArima (tropical:) An oath in which are ways of evasion. (S, TA.) And laA xayora fiI yamiynK laA maxaArima lahaA (tropical:) There is no good in an oath that has not ways of evasion: from maxorimN signifying “ a vaniyRap between two mountains. ” (TA.) And hecihi yamiynN qado TalaEato fiI AlmaxaArimi (tropical:) [This is an oath that has come forth in expressions that admit of ways of evasion]: said of an oath that affords a way [or rather ways] of evasion to the utterer thereof. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- [The pl.] AlmaxaArimu [or maxaArimu AllRayoli] also signifies The first portions of the night. (K.) It occurs in an instance in which some read AlmaHaArimu [pl. of maHoramN, q. v.]. (TA.)

maxoruwmaAtN: see xaramapN.

mutaxarRimuwna mtxrmwn
mutaxarRimuwna: see xurRaAmN.

xironaAbataAni xrnAbtAn
xironaAbataAni: see xinRaAbataAni, in art. xnb.

xurapu AlfaOosi, as in the Tekmileh, on the authority of Fr; in the K and accord. to Sgh, AlfaOosi xurowapu↓, which is a mistake; (TA;) The xurot [q. v. in art. xrt] of the fOs: pl. xuraAtN; (Fr, Sgh, K, TA;) like as vubapN has for its pl. vubaAtN. (TA.)

AlxaraAtaAni AlxrAtAn
AlxaraAtaAni Two stars, (K,) mentioned [and described] in art. xrt, (TA,) each of which is [said to be] called xaraApN: (K:) accord. to ISd, only the dual form of the word is known; and the radical t and the augmentative t [by which latter is meant p] are in the dual alike: (TA:) but Kr and others say that it is dual of xaraApN, and belongs to this art. (TA in art. xrt.)

xurowapN xrwh xrwp
xurowapN: see the first paragraph in this art.

xazRN A certain kind of cloth, (S, A, K,) well known, (K, TA,) woven of wool and silk: (TA:) and also a kind of cloth entirely of silk; and this is the kind which one is forbidden to ride upon and to sit upon; not the former kind, which is allowable, and was sometimes worn by companions of the Prophet and by the next succeeding generation, as IAth has ascertained: (TA:) derived from xuzazN, (K, TA,) accord. to some: (TA:) or it is the name of a certain beast [thought by Golius to be the beaver]: and afterwards applied to the cloth made of its fur: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. xuzuwzN. (S, A, Msb, K.) [Golius seems to derive it from the Persian qazo, meaning raw silk; and assigns to it also the meaning of a coarser kind of spun silk.] xuzuwzN wabuzuwzN signifies Good cloths, or stuffs, or garments. (A in art. bz.)

xuzazN xzz
xuzazN The male of the Oaronab [or hare]: (S, A, Msb, K:) or the offspring of the Arnb: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxizRapN (K) and [of mult.] xizRaAnN. (S, Msb, K.) Hence the saying, masRuhu masRu Alxuzazi [The feel of him, or it, is like the feel of the male, or young, hare]. (A, TA.)

xazRaAzN xzAz
xazRaAzN A seller of xazR. (TA.)

1. xazirati AlEyonu, aor.
xazara
, (Msb,) inf. n. xazarN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) The eye was, or became, narrow and small: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or it contracted its sight, naturally: (K:) or xazira, aor.
xazara
, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) signifies he (a man) was as though he looked from the outer angle of the eye: (S, A: *) or he looked as though on one side: or he opened and closed his eyes; (K;) or, his eye: (M:) or he had a distortion (HawalN) of one of his eyes: (K:) [or he had eyes looking towards his nose; or, looking sideways; (see Oaxozaru;) or, looking towards their outer angles; (see xuzorapN;) see also 2, and 6, and Q. Q. 1.] ＝ -A2- xazarahu, aor.
xazura
, (TA,) inf. n. xazorN, (K,) He looked at him from the outer angle of the eye; (K, * TA;) as one does in pride, and in light estimation of the object at which he looks. (MF.) A poet says,
laA taxozuri Alqawoma XazorFA Eano muEaAraDapK
[Look not thou at the people from the outer angle of the eye, askew, sideways]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- xazara [as an intrans. v.] He affected, or pretended, to be cunning; i. e. intelligent, or sagacious; or intelligent with a mixture of craft and forecast; syn. tadaAhaI. (IAar, K. [See also 2.]) ＝ -A4- Also He fled. (K.)

You say, xzRr Eayonayohi He (an old man) narrowed his eyes; contracted his eyelids as though they were sewed together; to collect the light: when a young man does so, yatadaAhaI bicelika [i. e. he affects, or pretends, thereby, to be cunning; i. e. intelligent, or sagacious; or intelligent with a mixture of craft and forecast]. xazarN [commonly known only as inf. n. of xazira or xazirati AlEayonu]: see xaziyrN.

xaziru AlEayoni: see Oaxozaru.

xaziyrapN xzyrh xzyrp

(TA.) ― -b2- xanaAziyru also signifies A well-known disease; (S;) [scrofula; or glandular swellings in the neck;] ulcers, (K,) or hard ulcers, (S,) which arise in the neck: (S, K:) or ganglions, or hard or nodous lumps beneath the skin, in the neck, and in soft parts, such as the armpits; but most frequently in the neck. bilaAduhumo bilaAdu AlxayozuraAni
[Their lands are the lands of the kheyzurán]: it is a kind of plant with pliable and smooth twigs: (ISd:) or a kind of tree, (S,) the roots of the qanaA [by which are app. meant the canes of which spear-shafts are made]: (S, Msb:) pl. xayaAziru. (S.) ― -b2- Reed, or reeds; cane, or canes. (S, K.) ― -b3- And hence, Musical reeds or pipes. (TA.) ― -b4- Spears: (IAar, K:) because of their pliableness: (TA:) [or because commonly made of canes:] pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- Any pliable twig or rod; (Mbr, K;) any piece of wood that is pliable. (AHeyth.) [Often applied in the present day to the osier; as well as to the rattan: n. un. with p.] ― -b6- The rod which kings hold in their hands, and with which they amuse themselves (yataEabRavuwna) and make signs. (Ham p. 710.) ― -b7- The pole with which a ship, or boat, is pushed or propelled, (Mbr, K,) when pliable, or bending; as also xayozaArapN↓. (Mbr, TA.) ― -b8- Also, (AO, Msb, K,) and with p, (S, TA,) The sukRaAn (S, Msb, K) of a ship, (K,) i. e. its kawoval [meaning the rudder]: (TA:) or, accord. to 'Amr Ibn-Bahr, the lijaAm [lit. the bridle and bit, app. meaning the tiller] of a ship, by means of which the sukRaAn, which is the canab, is directed. (TA: [but instead of AltI bhA yqwm AlsRukRAnu whw fI Alcnb, I read AlcI bh yuqawRamu AlsRukRaAnu whwAlcRanabu.]) En-Nábighah says, describing the Euphrates in the time of its increase, or fulness,
yaZalRu mino xawfihi AlmalRaAHu muEotaSimFA
biAloxayozuraAnapi baEoda AlOayoni waAlnRajadi
[By reason of his fear, the sailor becomes in a state of cleaving, or laying fast hold, upon the xyzrAnp, (which may here mean the pole above mentioned, or the rudder, or the tiller,) after fatigue and distress]. (S, TA.) In a trad. it is said that the devil, when he had been commanded by Noah to go forth from the ark, mounted upon the xyzrAn of the ark, i. e. its sukRaAn. (TA.)

(assumed tropical:) he is a person whom one may not hope to overcome]: (IAar, K:) or (assumed tropical:) he is bold and skilful. (K.)

(S.) ― -b2- And hence, Aixotazalotu AlwadiyEapa (assumed tropical:) I was unfaithful in respect of the trust, or deposit; even if meaning I refused to restore it: because the doing so is a cutting off, for one's self, of the property of the owner. , (Mgh, K,) inf. n. xazomN, (JK, TA,) He pierced it, or perforated it; (JK, Mgh, K;) namely, a thing of any kind: for instance, the nose of a camel, for the [ring called] xizaAmap [to which the rein is attached]: and the letter of a Kádee to another Kádee; for such a letter is pierced for the siHaMCap [or strip of paper with which it is bound], and is then sealed [upon this strip]; and when this is done, the letter is said to be maxozuwmN↓. You say, xazama AlbaEiyra, aor. as above, (Mgh, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) He pierced the nose of the camel (Mgh, Msb) for the xizaAmap: (Mgh:) or xazama AlbaEiyra (S, K) biAlxizaAmapi, (S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) he put the xzAmp in the side of the nostril, (K,) or in the partition between the nostrils, (S,) [but the former is the more common practice,] of the camel; (S, K;) as also xzRmhu↓; (K;) [or] this signifies the doing so much, or often. (TA.) [Hence,] xazama Oanofahu (assumed tropical:) He brought him under, or into, subjection; rendered him submissive, tractable, or manageable. (TA.) 3. xAzmhu, (S,) or xAzimhu AlTRariyqa, (K,) inf. n. muxaAzamapN (S in art. xSr) [and xizaAmN], He (a man, S) took a different way from his (another's) until they both met in one place: (S, K:) the doing so is also termed muxaASarapN: (S in art. xSr, and TA:) it is as though it were a rivalling, or imitating, in travelling. (TA.) Ibn-Fesweh says,
UicaA huwa naHRaAhaA Eani AlqaSodi xaAzamato
bihi Aljawora HatRaI tasotaqiymu DuHaI Algadi
i. e. When he turns her, meaning his she-camel, from the right way, she pursues with him a way different from the wrong, so that she overcomes him, and takes the right way, in the early daytime of the morrow. (TA.) muxaAzamapN also signifies The act of rivalling, or imitating. (JK, TA.) And one says, laqiytuhu xizaAmFA (JK, TA) and maxaAzamapF, (JK,) meaning I met him face to face: (TA:) or suddenly, or unexpectedly, and face to face. (JK.)

(Bd in iv. 118; &c.) xusoraAnN is also attributed to an action, as well as to a man: (B, TA:) you say, (but in this case the verb is used tropically, A,) xasirato tijaAratuhu (tropical:) [His traffic was losing; or an occasion of loss]; (A, B;) opposed
to rabiHato. (A.) It is also used in relation to personal acquisitions; such as health, and safety, and intellect, and faith, and the recompense or reward of obedience [to God], which God has declared [Kur xxii. 11 and xxxix. 17] to be manifest xusoraAn, (B,) since there is none like it. (Bd.) For instance, you say, xasira Eaqolahu, and maAlahu, He lost his intellect, and his property. (IAar.) [In a phrase of this kind, the noun which immediately follows the verb may be considered as put in the accus. case on account of the rejection of a prep., namely fiI: for] it is said that xasira is never used otherwise than intransitively: though this has been contradicted, on the ground of the following phrase in the Kur [xxii. 11], xasira QldRunoyaA wa QloMxirapa [He hath lost, or he loseth, the things of the present life and of the latter life]; and the like; as QlRaciyna xasiruwA Oanofusahumo wa Oaholiyhimo [Who shall have lost themselves, or their own souls, and their families, or their wives; Kur xxxix. 17 and xlii. 44]; (MF, TA;) i. e., themselves, or their own souls, by their having erred, and their families by their having caused them to err, or by being separated from them for ever; (Bd;) or by being themselves made to remain for ever in Hell, and by their not gaining access to the Huwr prepared in Paradise [as wives] for the believers: (Jel:) or the meaning is, accord. to Fr, who shall be deceived of their own souls, &c.: or, accord. to others, who shall have destroyed their own souls, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- Also [He experienced, or saw, that he was loser; or] his having lost became manifest to him: so in the Kur xl. [78 and] last verse. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (with all the forms of the inf. n. above mentioned, K,) He erred; went astray; deviated from, or lost, or missed, the right way: or he became lost; he perished; or he died: syn. xasifa
, (JK, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xasofN, (JK,) or xusuwfN, (S, K,) or both; (Msb;) [and Anxsf↓;] It (a place) sank, (JK, Msb,) or went away, into the ground, or earth, (S, Msb, K,) with what was upon it. (JK.) You say, AlOaroDu Anxsf↓, [and xasafat,] The ground sank [into the earth] with what was upon it. (TA.) And bihi AlOaroDu Anxsft↓, (JK,) or bh AlArD Anxsf↓, and xusifa bh AlArD, (TA,) and xasafato, (Msb in art. swx,) The ground sank with him, or it: (JK:) or the ground, or earth, [swallowed up him, or it; or] took and enclosed him, or it. (TA.) And AlbiYoru Anxsft↓ The well [sank and collapsed; or] went away into the earth with its casing of stones and wood. (Mgh.) And xasafa fiI AlOaroDi and xusifa bihi [He, or it, sank into the ground, or earth, and became swallowed up, or enclosed, or concealed, therein]. (S.) It is said in the Kur [xxviii. 82], accord. to one reading, laxusifa binaA [We had been swallowed up by the earth]: (S:) accord. to another reading, (that of 'Abd-Allah, S, i. e. Ibn-Mes'ood, TA,) bnA laQnoxusifa↓, (S, K,) in the pass. form; (K;) [meaning the same;] like as one says, AunoTuliqa bnA. (S.) You say also, xasafato Eayonu AlmaMCi The spring of water sank, or went away, into the earth. (Msb, K. *) And AlEayonu Anxsft↓ The eye sank, or became depressed, in the head; syn. gaArato; (Msb in art. gwr;) [and so xasafat, inf. n. xusuwfN; for] xusuwfu AlEayoni signifies The eye's going away into the head: (S:) or Anxsft↓ signifies its black, or part surrounded by the white, disappeared in the head: (Mgh:) or this last, (K,) as quasi-pass. of the trans. v. xasafa, (TA,) (tropical:) it (the eye) became blind; as also Oaxosafat↓; (K, TA;) and [in like manner] xasafat (assumed tropical:) it (the eye) lost its light [or sight]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] xasafa Alqamaru, inf. n. xusuwfN; (S, Msb, K;) and xusifa; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) The moon [suffered eclipse, or became eclipsed, or] lost its light, or part of its light; (Msb;) i. q. kasafa: (S, * Msb, * K:) and xasafati AlXRamosu and kasafat both signify the same [i. e. the sun suffered eclipse, &c.]: (Mgh:) or one says kasafat of the sun, and xasafa of the moon, (Th, S, Msb, K,) accord. to the more approved usage: (Th, S, Msb:) or, in the common conventional language, Alkusuwfu is the partial loss of the light of the sun, and Alxusuwfu is the total loss of the light thereof: (AHát, Msb:) or Alxswf is the partial loss of the light of the sun, and Alkswf is the total loss thereof, (K, TA,) accord. to AHát: (TA:) Alxswf often occurs in the trads., as said of the sun; though the term commonly known in the classical language is Alkswf [in this case]: and it is said in a trad., UinRa AlXRamosa wa Alqamara laAyaxosifaAni limawoti OaHadK Oawo liHayaAtihi [Verily the sun and the moon suffer not eclipse for the death of any one or for his life]; predominance being in this instance attributed to the moon, as being masc., over the sun, which is fem. (IAth.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. xasofN, (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) became defective or deficient; suffered loss or diminution. (K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (the body) became lean, or emaciated. (TA.) And xasafato, said of camels and of sheep or goats, (tropical:) They became lean, or emaciated. (TA. [This meaning is there indicated, but not clearly expressed. See xasofapN. Accord. to the KL, the inf. n. xasofN signifies The being vile, abject, or contemptible: and also the being lean, or emaciated: and hence Golius, on that authority, has rendered the verb as meaning vilis et macer fuit.]) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) It (the colour, or complexion, of a person) became altered, or altered for the worse. (TA.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) It (a thing, K, as, for instance, a roof, TA) became pierced with a hole, or rent; (K, TA;) as also Anxsf↓. (TA.) ― -b7- And, xasafat, said of a she-camel, (tropical:) She, after yielding abundant milk, soon stopped [its flow] in winter. (K, TA.) ― -b8- And, said of a well, It was, or became, such as is termed xasiyfN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b9- And xasafa, said of a man, (tropical:) He recovered from a disease. (IDrd, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- xasafa, (JK, Msb, TA,) aor.

xasifa
, inf. n. xasofN, (TA,) (tropical:) He put out, or blinded, the eye of such a one, (K, * TA,) so that the black, or part surrounded by the white, disappeared in the head. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A well (biYorN) dug in stones, so that it yields an abundant and unceasing flow of water; (S, K;) as also xasiyfapN and xasuwfN↓ and maxosuwfapN↓; (K;) or, as some say, xasiyfN only: (TA:) or this signifies a well pierced through its mountain [or rock] to the water beneath so that it never becomes exhausted; (JK, TA;) as also maxosuwfapN↓: (JK:) or a well dug so as to reach an unceasing, or a copious, source of water: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxosifapN (JK, K) and [of mult.] xusufN. (S, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A she-camel that yields abundant milk, but soon stops [its flow] in winter. (K, TA.) [And] with p, (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that yields abundant milk. (JK.) ― -b4- See also xasofN. ― -b5- EayonN xasiyfapN (Mgh, K, TA) and xaAsifapN↓ (JK, Mgh) (tropical:) An eye put out, or blinded; (JK, K, TA;) of which the black, or part surrounded by the white, has disappeared in the head. (JK, Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- AlxasiyfaAn, thus correctly written, as in the L, and so in the Nawádir of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, and in the Tedhkireh of Aboo-'Alee El-Hejeree, who asserts that the n is the n of the dual, and in one dial. with damm, [so that the word is written AlxasiyfaAni and AlxasiyfaAnu,] and on whose authority is mentioned the saying humaA xaliylaAnu, with damm to the n, [so that each is a dual in form, though not in signification,] but in the O and the K AlxayosafaAnu↓, [in the CK AlxiysafaAnu,] with fet-h to the s, and [AlxayosufaAnu↓,] with damm to that letter, (TA,) Bad dates: (O, K:) so in the Nawádir and Tedhkireh above mentioned: (TA:) or a palm-tree that bears a small quantity of fruit, and of which the unripe dates turn bad. (O, K.)

xasaA, (JK, K, * and TA in art. zkw,) without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; and in like manner zakaA, which is coupled with the former, is without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; (TA in that art.;) [but each has Al prefixed to it in the K;] accord. to Fr, some make it quasi-coordinate to fatFI [i. e. with tenween, and masc.]; some, to zfr [app. meaning the proper name zufaru i. e. without tenween, and masc.]; and some, to sakoraI [app. meaning without tenween, and fem.]: (TA:) a word that is said in playing with walnuts; (JK;) An odd number: (Lth, Fr, K, TA:) and zkA signifies an even number: (Lth, Fr, TA:) accord. to IB, its final letter is hemzeh, for one says, yuxaAsiYu meaning yuqaAmiru [he contends in a game of hazard]; but it is pronounced without C to assimilate it to zkA: (TA:) the pl. is OaxaAsK, (K, TA,) accord. to the M, maxaAsK, like masaAwK, (TA, [but the former pl. occurs in a verse cited in the TA,]) which is anomalous. (K.) One says, xasFA Oawo zakFA, [so in my copies of the S, with tenween,] i. e. Odd or even? (S:) [or xasaA Oawo zakaA, as shown above:] and some say, xasaA zakaA, like xamosapa EaXara. (IB, TA.) And it is said in a trad., maA OadoriI kamo HadRavaniI OabiI Eino rasuwli QllRehi SalRaI QllRehu Ealayohi wa salRama OaxosaA Oamo zakaA, or OaxosFA Oamo zakFA, [for the vowel-signs are not written in my original,] meaning farodFA Oamo zawojFA [i. e. I know not how many times my father told me, from the Apostle of God, God bless and save him; whether an odd or an even number: or, perhaps, once or twice]. (TA.)

(Zj, K.) ― -b2- And hence the saying in a trad., xuXRuwA bayona kalaAmikumo laA Uileha UilRaA QllRehu, meaning, (assumed tropical:) Introduce ye, or insert ye, in your speech the words There is no deity but God. R. Q. 2. taxaXoxaXa: see xaXRa fiyhi. ＝ -A2- Also It made a sound (S, K) such as is described below, voce xaXoxaXapN. (S.) 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh says,
taxaXoxaXa OabodaAnu AlHadiydi Ealayohimu
yabosa AlHaSaAdi januwbu kamaA xaXoxaXatu↓
[The short coats of mail of iron rustled upon them, like as when a south wind has caused to rustle the dry reaped corn]. (S.)

xuXaAXN: see xiXaAXN; for the former, in three places.

xiXaAXN c
xiXaAXN The wooden thing that is inserted in the bone of the nose of the camel, (S, A, K,) to which the nose-rein is tied, in order that he may be quickly submissive: (TA:) the burap is of brass, (S, TA,) or of silver; (TA;) and the xizaAmap is of hair: (S:) or the thing that is put in the nose; and the brp is the thing that is put in the flesh: (Lh:) or what is in the bone, when it is wood, or a stick; and the EiraAn is what is in the flesh, above the nose: (As:) a wooden thing, or stick, that is put in the bone of the nose of the camel: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb:) pl. OaxiXRapN. (A, Msb.) [Hence the saying,] jaEala AlxiXaAXa fiI Oanofihi waqaAdahu UilaI AlTRaAEapi biEunofihi (tropical:) [He put the xXAX in his nose, and drew him to obedience by his violence]. (A, TA.) [And hence, also,] it signifies gaDabN, (IAar, K,) as used in the saying, HarRaka xiXaAXahu, [lit., He put in motion his xiXaAX: meaning, (assumed tropical:) he roused, or excited, his anger; or] he made him angry. (IAar.) ＝ -A2- AlxiXaAXu, and AlxaXaAXu↓, (S, K,) the latter form being sometimes used, (S,) which indicates that the former is the more chaste, but, accord. to MF, several authorities say the contrary, (TA,) and AlxuXaAXu↓, (K,) or AlOaroDi xaXaAXu↓, (A 'Obeyd, Msb,) and xiXaAXu AlOaroDi, (Msb,) The creeping things of the earth: n. un. with p, which is syn. with AlHaXarapu and AlhaAmRapu: (Msb:) the HaXaraAt (A' Obeyd, S, K) of the earth, (A' Obeyd, K,) and its hawaAmR, and [other] creeping things, (A 'Obeyd,) such as sparrows and the like: (A 'Obeyd, K: *) or xiXaAXu AlOaroDi, and AlTRayori, signify the small ones of beasts or creeping things [of the earth], and of birds: (A:) IAar is related to have said that it is xiXoxaAXN↓, contr. to what is said by the lexicologists in general: and these things are said to have their appellation from their entering into the earth and concealing themselves; but this assertion is not valid: (ISd:) in a trad., for mn xXAX AlArD, one relation substitutes mino xaXiyXihaA↓, which has the same meaning: and some say that it is xuXayoX↓, a contracted dim. of xXAX; or xuXayRiX↓, without contraction: (TA:) and AlxaXaAXu↓ signifies the bad [meaning ignoble] kinds of birds; this being with fet-h only: (As:) or birds that do not prey: (IAar, TA voce EuqaAbN:) xiXaAXN, with kesr, also signifies the serpent of the mountain; which does not suffer one to survive; and the OafoEaI is the serpent of the plain; (El-Fak'asee, K;) which like wise does not suffer one to survive: (K:) or a great and abominable vuEobaAn: or a serpent like the Oaroqam, but smaller: or a small, tawny serpent, smaller than the Arqm: (TA:) or a white serpent, which seldom hurts, between the HufRaAv and the Arqm: (Aboo-Kheyreh:) or such as is light, or active, and small in the head, of serpents: explained also as signifying the serpent, without restriction: (TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) such as has no power of defence, [maA laA difaAEa lahu, as in the CK and a MS copy of the K, for which we find in some copies of the K, and in the TA, mA lA dimaAga lahu such as has no brains, which is doubtless a mistake,] of beasts or creeping things of the earth, and of birds, (K,) such as the ostrich, and the [bustard called] HubaAraI, and the karawaAn [or stonecurlew], and [the bird called] mulaAEibu ZilRihi, and the [harmless kinds of] serpent: (TA:) or what is small in the head, and slender, of beasts or creeping things: and the kite; and [the bird called] mulaAEibu ZilRihi: (Aboo-Muslim:) the pl. is xXRMC [app. xuXRaMCu, originally xuXaXaMCu, unless a mistake for OaxiXRaMCu, originally OaxoXiXaMCu]. (TA.)

xaXiyXN c
xaXiyXN, and xuXayoXN, and xuXayRiXN: see xiXaAXN.

xuXRaMCN c
xuXRaMCN The bone which is protuberant behind the ear, (S, Msb, K,) and which is thin, and bare of hair: (TA:) originally xuXaXaMCu, (S, Msb, K,) of the measure fuEalaMCu; (S;) [but masc., and perfectly decl., as being quasi-coordinate to quroTaAsN, whereas the original is fem., and imperfectly decl.; (see quwabaMCu;)] like quwobaMCN, which is originally quwabaMCu; (S, Msb;) and these two words are the only instances of their kind: (ISk, Msb:) dual xuXaXaAwaAn. (S, K.)

xaXoxaXapN c
xaXoxaXapN The [clashing, clattering, chinking, jingling, rattling, or rustling,] sound of arms, or weapons, (S, A, * K,) and the like; (S;) as also XaxoXaxapN, but this latter is a dial. var. of weak authority: (TA:) and of any dry or hard thing rubbing against another such thing: (K:) accord. to IDrd, such [sound or thing (for his words are ambiguous)] is termed xaXoxaAXN↓: (TA:) and the [rustling] sound of a new garment or piece of cloth, when it is put in motion; as also naXonaXapN: (IAar:) and [a confused sound] such as is heard to proceed from the inside of an animal on its being hit by an arrow: (JK in art. xXf:) and a motion having a sound like the sound of arms, or weapons; (TA;) or an audible motion. (Mgh in art. xXf.)

xaXoxaAXN c
xaXoxaAXN A company: (ISd, TA:) or a numerous company of men: (Az, TA:) or a company (S, K) in, (K,) or having upon them, (S,) arms, or weapons, and coats of mail. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also xaXoxaXapN. ＝ -A3- Also A certain plant, (S, Msb,) well known; (S, Msb, K;) [namely, the poppy;] which is of several species; (K;) i. e., four; (TA;) yusotaAniIRN [or garden-poppy,] (K,) which is the white, and this is the most fit for eating, and the best thereof is the fresh and heavy; (TA;) and manovuwrN, (K,) which is the wild Egyptian; (TA;) and muqarRanN, [app. the horned poppy,] (K,) the produce of which has an elongated extremity like the horn of the bull; (TA;) and zubodiIRN, [app. the spattling poppy,] (K,) which is known by the name of blbs [a word which I have not been able to find elsewhere]: (TA:) every one of these is soporiferous, and produces torpidness, and cools: (K:) used as a suppository, it produces sleep: and the integument [of the capsule] has a stronger power of producing sleep than the seeds: (TA:) [or rather the seeds have no narcotic power:] from half a drachm of the integument, with cold water, as a draught, taken early in the morning, and the like at sleep, has a wonderful effect in stopping a looseness characterized by a mixture of humours and by blood, when accompanied by heat and inflammation: (K:) it is wonderful also that its solid part confines, and its juice relaxes: and when the root, or lower part, is taken with water, [and boiled] so that the water is reduced to half its quantity, it is beneficial as a remedy for diseases of the liver arising from thick humour: so says the author of the Minháj: (TA:) the n. un. is with
p: (Msb:) and the pl. is xaXaAxiXu [app. a mistake for xaXaAxiyXu]. (TA.) [See also OafoyuwnN.]

xiXoxaAXN c
xiXoxaAXN: see xiXaAXN.

maxoXuwXN c
maxoXuwXN A camel having a xiXaAX put in his nose; as also xaXN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

1 xaXaba c
1. xaXaba, (S, K,) aor.
xaXiba
, (K,) inf. n. xaXobN, (TA,) He mixed a thing (S, K) with (bi) another thing. (S.) ― -b2- And He picked out, chose out, or selected, a thing: the verb thus having two contr. significations. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He polished a sword, (S, K,) by laying on it a broad and smooth spearhead and rubbing it therewith: so accord. to ElAhmar, who relates that an Arab of the desert said to him, I said to a sword-polisher, “ Hast thou finished my sword? ” and he answered, naEamo UilRaA OanRiI lamo OaxoXibohu [Yes, except that I have not polished it]. (S.) And [or, as in the TA, “ or ”] He sharpened it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And He forged a sword: (K:) or fashioned it with the file, without polishing it: (TA:) or he made it imperfectly, not thoroughly, or not well: (A:) thus, again, the verb has two contr. significations: (K:) also he thus made an arrow: (A:) or he shaped out a bow, (AHn, K,) and an arrow, (TA,) [in a rough manner, or] by the first operation, (AHn, K, TA,) without perfecting it, or making it smooth, or even. (TA.) You say of a sword, before it has been filed, maA OaHosana maA xuXiba [How well has it been forged!]: and in like manner one says of an arrow, when it has been filed, before the safan [with which it is smoothed] has been applied to it. (Skr, on a verse of Sakhr, cited below, voce xaXiybapN.) ― -b3- [Hence,] xaXaba AlXRiEora, (ISk, S, A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (A,) (tropical:) He said, spoke, or uttered, the poetry (ISk, S, A, K) as it came, (ISk, S,) [unpolished, and unstudied,] without affecting nicety, or refinement, therein, (ISk, S, A, K,) and without study, or labour: (A, K:) Jereer did thus, and Farezdak trimmed his verses; but the verses of Jereer thus produced are better than the trimmed verses of Farezdak: (A, TA:) and AxtXbhu↓ signifies the same. (A, K.) You say also, humo yaxoXibuwna AlkalaAma waAlEamala (tropical:) [They say, speak, or utter, words, and do work, without affecting nicety, or refinement, and without study, or labour]: (A:) or imperfectly, or not thoroughly; inelegantly, or not well. (TA.) And AitRaxaca AlsRayofa xaXabFA: see 8.

5 txXRb c
5. txXRb: see 8. ＝ -A2- txXRbti AlUibilu The camels ate thick branches: (K:) or ate dry herbage. (S.) And tataxaXRabu EiydaAna AlXRajari They take with the mouth, and eat, the branches of the trees. (TA.)
