8. AxtXb AlsRayofi signifies AitRaxacahu xaXobFA↓; He took the sword without choosing the best by taking it from this place or that; (L, TA;) as also tHXRbhu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end.

12 AxXwXb c
12. AxXwXb He [a man or a camel (see xaXibN)] was, or became, tall, and gross, rude, or coarse, with bones uncovered by flesh, and hard, or hardy. (K.) He (an ostrich) was, or became, rough, or coarse. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became hard, or hardy, and rough, or coarse, in his religion, clothing, food, and in all respects. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) He employed himself in work, and in walking barefoot, in order that his body might become thick, gross, or coarse. (S, TA.) And AxXwXb fiI EayoXihi (assumed tropical:) He endured with patience a life of hardship, or difficulty: or he subjected himself to a life of hardship, or difficulty, in order to render himself the more able to bear it. (K, TA.) AixoXawoXibuwA is thus used in a trad. of 'Omar: (S, TA:) or, as some relate it, the word is [AjXwXbwA,] with j; or, accord. to some, AxXwXnwA, with x and n. (TA.)

rajulN qiXobN xiXobN c
rajulN qiXobN xiXobN A man in whom is no good: (S, K:) or with whom is no good: (TA:) [in some copies of the K, xiXobN wa qiXobN; but this, as is said in the TA, is incorrect:] xiXobN being an imitative sequent to qiXobN. (S, TA.)

xaXabN c
xaXabN [Wood, such as is used in carpentry and the like; timber;] thick wood: (A, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. xaXabapN [signifying a piece of wood or timber]: (Msb:) the pl. of the latter, (S, Msb, *) or of the former, (K,) is xaXabN, (S, K, [i. e., accord. to the K, the pl. is the same as the sing., but properly speaking, as said above, this is a coll. gen. n.,]) and xuXubN and xuXobN (S, Msb, K) and xuXobaAnN, (S, K,) [which last is agreeable with analogy as pl. of xaXabN,] or xuXobaAnN is pl. of xuXobN, and xuXobN is pl. of xaXabapN. (JK.) The hypocrites are described in a trad. as xuXubN biAllRayoli SuxubN biAlnRahaAri Like timbers, or pieces of wood, in the night; [clamorous in the day;] meaning that they pass the night in sleep, without prayer. (TA.) ― -b2- maAlN xaXabN (assumed tropical:) Cattle that are lean, or emaciated, syn. hazolaI, (K,) in consequence of their feeding upon dry herbage. (TA.) [And it seems that xaXabN↓ signifies the same: for I find in the TA, and in a copy of the A which I believe to have been used by the author of the TA, mentioned as tropical, maAlN xaXabN waHaTibN jazolN, app. meaning that maAlN xaXibN and HaTibN signify jazolN; but jazolN, I think, is here evidently a mistranscription for hazolaI; as HaTibN is explained in the S and K as signifying “ very lean or meagre. ”]

xaXibN c
xaXibN Rough, or coarse; as also OaxoXabuxaXiybN↓: (K:) the former applied in this sense to a male ostrich: (S:) and both signify anything gross, or big, and rough, or coarse; (A 'Obeyd, S;) as also xaXiybN↓: (TA:) and the first, (K,) applied to a man and to a camel, (TA,) tall, and gross, rude, or coarse, with bones uncovered by flesh, and hard, or hardy, and strong; (K, * TA;) as also xaXiybN↓ and xaXiybiIRN↓: (K:) or these three signify, or signify also, dry, or rigid, or tough: (Kr, ISd:) and xaXibN, a man hard, or hardy, strong, and vigorous, in body: (A, TA:) and the same, (JK,) or xaXiybN↓, (TA,) a man whose bones are uncovered by flesh, and whose sinews are apparent; (JK, TA;) hard, or hardy, and strong: (JK:) and the last, a gross, big, or coarse, camel: (S, TA:) a camel gross, coarse, or rude, in make, and ugly: (TA:) and a horse thick, or big, in the bones. (Ham p. 207.) See also xaXabN. And see OaxoXabu, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Life in which one is not dainty, nice, or scrupulous. (K.)

xaXobapN c
xaXobapN The first filing of a sword, before the polishing. (TA.)

xuXobaAnN c
xuXobaAnN: see OaxoXabu.

xaXaAbN c
xaXaAbN: see OaxoXabu.

xuXaAbN c
xuXaAbN, from the Persian xuwXo Mbo, [The beverage properly called in Arabic] nabiyc. (TA.)

xaXiybN c
xaXiybN and maxoXuwbN↓ Mixed. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, (K,) or both, (TA,) Picked out, chosen, or selected: (K, TA:) both words thus having two contr. significations. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former (S, K) and latter, (K,) A sword polished: (S, K: *) this is [said to be] the prevailing signification: (TA:) or both signify a sharpened sword. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- And the former, (As, S, K,) or both, (JK, A,) A sword of which the forging is commenced; thus [again] having two contr. significations: (S:) or forged, (K, * TA,) or fashioned with the file, but not yet polished: (As, TA:) or newly made: (TA:) or imperfectly, not thoroughly, or not well, wrought; (JK, A;) and thus both words applied to an arrow: (A:) or the former, (S, K,) or both, (TA,) applied to an arrow, (S, K,) and to a bow, (K,) shaped out (S, K) [in a rough manner,] by the first operation, (S, TA,) not yet perfected, or made smooth, or even: (TA:) pl. of the former (accord. to the TA as applied to a bow [but I see no reason for this restriction]) xuXubN and xaXaAYibu. (K.) lamo yunaqRaHo maxoXuwbN↓ [Rough hewn, not yet trimmed,] is a prov., mentioned by Meyd and Z. (MF, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] XiEorN xaXiybN and maxoXuwbN↓ (tropical:) Poetry said, spoken, or uttered, as it has come to the speaker, [unpolished, and unstudied,] without his affecting nicety, or refinement, therein, and without study, or labour. (A, * TA.) And jaMCa bilmaxoXuwbi↓ (tropical:) [He said, or uttered, that which came to him, as it came, unpolished, and unstudied]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also xaXiybN voce xaXibN, in three places. ― -b5- It also signifies Bad, corrupt, or vile. (K.)

xaXiybapN c
xaXiybapN The natural quality [of the metal] of a sword, (Skr on the verse here following, S, TA,) before the making thereof is completed: (Skr:) or its blade, or iron: (A:) or its edge: or its polish. (JK.) Sakhr says,
waSaArimN OuxoliSato xaXiybatuhu
OaboyaDu mahowN fiI matonihi zubadu
And a sharp sword of which the natural quality [of the metal] before the completion of the making thereof has been refined, [white, or a sword,] thin in the two edges or sides, having [in its broad side] diversified marks. (Skr.)

xaXiybiIRN c
xaXiybiIRN: see xaXibN.

xaXRaAbN c
xaXRaAbN: see what next follows.

xaXRaAbapN c
xaXRaAbapN [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is xaXRaAbN↓,] Sellers of xaXab [i. e. wood, or timber]. (TA.) ― -b2- Fighters with staves. ＝ -A2- Accord. to ElHejeree, xXAbp [so in the TA, without any syll. sign,] signifies A slender [implement of the kind called] mTrq [i. e. miToraq, q. v.,] which the polisher, when he has finished the polishing of a sword, passes over it, in consequence of which the scabbard does not alter its state. (TA.)

xaAXibN c
xaAXibN: see muxotaXibN.

OaxoXabu c
OaxoXabu: see xaXibN. Also A great mountain: (A:) or a rugged, or rough, and great mountain; (S, K;) and so jabalN xaXibN↓: or such as is not to be ascended: (TA:) an elevated place, rugged, with rough stones: (JK:) a tract of the kind termed qufR, rugged and stony: (TA:) pl. OaxaAXibu, (A, TA,) because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it: and the fem. xaXobaMCu is also sometimes used in the same sense; or as syn. with gayoDapN [i. e. a thicket, &c.]; but the former meaning is better known: and this [likewise] is thought to be rather a subst. than an epithet, because of the pl., mentioned above: (TA:) and xuXobaAnN↓ [also seems to be a pl. of OaxoXabu, or of xaXibN; for it is said that it] signifies rugged, or rough, mountains, neither great nor small: (K:) and rugged ground. (TA in art. cnb.) xaXobaMCu also signifies Hard land or ground; (K, * TA;) land, or ground, in which are stones and pebbles and earth or clay. (IAmb, TA.) And OaroDN xaXaAbN↓ (K, TA) Hard land or ground, like xaXobaMCu, (TA,) that flows with the least rain. (K, TA.) And OakamapN xaXobaMCu (S, TA) A hill of which the stones are scattered, but near together. (TA.) And jabohapN xaXobaMCu A displeasing forehead; as also xaXibapN↓: (TA:) or a displeasing, rigid forehead; (JK, S, K; *) not even. (JK.) And OaxoXabu Aljabohapi A man having a displeasing and rigid forehead. (TA.)

bayotN muxaXRabN c
bayotN muxaXRabN [so in the present day, but written in the TA without any syll. sign,] A house having xaXab [i. e. wood, or timber, employed in its construction]. (TA.)

maxoXuwbN c
maxoXuwbN: see xaXiybN, in four places. ― -b2- It is applied to a horse, by El-Aashà; (S, TA;) meaning Of mixed pedigree: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or not broken; not well trained; from what next follows; and thus used only by El-Aashà. (IKh, TA.) ― -b3- jafonapN maxoXuwbapN A wooden bowl imperfectly made. (IKh, TA.) ― -b4- TaEaAmN maxoXuwbN [Food imperfectly prepared; i. e.], if flesh-meat, not thoroughly cooked; and if not flesh-meat, (but grain, TA,) without any seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (K, * TA.)

muxotaXibN c
muxotaXibN One who eats what he can; as also xaAXibN↓. (JK.)

1 xaXarahu c
1. xaXarahu, aor.
xaXira
, (S, K,) inf. n. xaXorN, (S,) He picked it, (Lh, S, K,) namely, a collection of goods, or commodities, (Lh,) removing from it what was bad. (Lh, S, K.) ― -b2- And xaXara, aor. (and inf. n., TA) as above, He left upon the table refuse of food: thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also xaXarahu He rendered it (a thing) bad, or vile. (TA.)

xuXaArN c
xuXaArN (K) and xuXaArapN↓ (S, A, K) The bad part or parts [or the refuse] (Lh, S, K) of goods, or commodities, (Lh,) or of anything. (S, K.) And the latter, The worst kind, syn. XiyS, of lates. (A.) ― -b2- What contains no lubR [or heart], of barley. (A, K.) ― -b3- And the latter, The refuse of food remaining upon a table; that in which is no good. (S, A, K. *) ― -b4- Also the latter, (S, A, K,) and the former, (K,) and xuXRaArN↓, (IAar,) (tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (IAar, S, A, K;) as also xaAXirN↓, accord. to the K, but correctly xaAXirapN↓, as related by AA from IAar. (TA.) El-Hotei-ah says,
wabaAEa baniyhi baEoDuhumo bixuXaArapF
wabiEota licuboyaAna AlEalaMCa bimaAliki
[And some of them have sold their sons for the refuse of mankind; but] thou hast purchased eminence for Dhubyán with Málik: in the S we find bimaAlikaA [with thy property]: but it is correctly as above: Málik was a son of 'Oyeyneh Ibn- Hisn: the Benoo-'Ámir slew him: wherefore 'Oyeyneh made war upon them, and obtained his blood-revenge, and spoil: and to this event El- Hotei-ah refers in the verse above. (IB, TA.)

xuXaArapN c
xuXaArapN: see the paragraph next preceding.

xuXRaArN c
xuXRaArN: see the paragraph next preceding.

xaAXirN c
xaAXirN: see the paragraph next preceding.

xaAXirapN c
xaAXirapN: see the paragraph next preceding.

1 xaXaEa c
1. xaXaEa, aor.
xaXaEa
, inf. n. xuXuwEN, He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; (S, Msb, K;) as also AxtXE↓ (S, K) and txXRE↓; (Abu-lFet-h, Ham pp. 24 and 127;) xuXuwEN being syn. with xuDuwEN: (S, Msb, K:) or xXwE is nearly the same as xDwE: (Lth, K:) or the former is mostly used as meaning in the voice; and the latter, in the necks: (Msb:) or the latter is in the body; and the former is in the voice and in the eyes: (K:) or, as we read in the 'Eyn, the former is nearly the same as the latter, except that the latter is in the body, and signifies the acknowledging of humility and submission, and the former is in the voice and in the eyes; and the like is said in the Nh [and in the Msb in art. xDE]. (TA.) You say, xaXaEati AlOaSowaAtu The voices were [or shall be (as in the Kur xx. 107]) still and low: (Msb:) or low: or, as some say, still. (TA.) And xaXaEa bibaSarihi He lowered his eye. (S.) And AxtXE↓ and txXRE↓ He cast his eye towards the ground, and lowered his voice. (TA.) Lth says that you say, fulaAnN AxtXE↓, but not AxtXE bibaSarihi. (TA.) And xaXaEa baSaruhu His eye became contracted. (TA.) And xaXaEato duwnahu AlOaboSaAru (tropical:) [meaning The eyes were cast down before him, or it]. (TA.) xuXuwEN also signifies The being, or becoming, still: and the abasing oneself; or lowering oneself. (K, TA.) And AxtXE↓, He lowered, or stooped, or bent down, his breast. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He feared; for instance, in prayer: (TA:) or xaXaEa fiI SalaAtihi and fiI duEaAYihi signifies He applied himself with his heart to [or in] his prayer, and his supplication. (Msb.) ― -b3- xaXaEati AlkawaAkibu, (Aboo-'Adnán,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) The stars approached to the place of setting; (Aboo-'Adnán;) or approached to setting: (K:) or sank, and nearly disappeared in their setting-place. (Aboo- Sálih El-Kilábee.) [The corresponding phrase in Hebrew, occurring in Gen. xxxvii. 9, probably has the same meaning.] ― -b4- xaXaEati AlXRamosu (tropical:) The sun became eclipsed. (TA.) ― -b5- xaXaEa AlsRanaAmu (tropical:) The hump for the most part went away; (O, K;) i. e. the hump of the camel: (TA:) or became lean; its fat going away, and its height becoming lowered. (L.) ― -b6- fulaAnN jicolN HikaAkN xaXaEati Eanohu AlOubanu is a saying of the Arabs, explained in art. Hk. (TA in that art.) ― -b7- xaXaEa Alwaraqu (tropical:) The leaves withered. (TA.) ― -b8- xaXaEati AlOaroDu (tropical:) The earth, or land, dried up, not being rained upon. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xaXaEa fulaAnN xaraAXiIRN Sadorihi Such a one ejected the viscous saliva [or phlegm of his chest]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And xaXaEato xaraAXiIRN Sarihi The viscous saliva [or phlegm of his chest] became ejected. (O, K.) The verb is thus intrans., as well as trans. (O.)

5 txXRE c
5. txXRE He lowered, humbled, or abased, himself: (Lth, K:) or he constrained himself to be, or to become, lowly, humble, or submissive; or to be so, or to become so, in voice, or in the eyes. (S.) See also 1, in two places.

6 txAXE c
6. txAXE [He feigned lowliness, humility, or submissiveness, in demeanour, or in voice, or in the eyes]. (TA in art. mwt; &c.)

8 UixotaXaEa
8: see 1, in four places.

xuXoEapN c
xuXoEapN A low hill: (S:) or a hill cleaving to the ground: (IAar, K:) and a piece of rugged ground: (IDrd, K:) or [elevated ground such as is termed] qufR that is for the most part soft, i. e. neither stone nor clay: (Lth:) and a rock growing in the sea: (TA:) pl. xuXaEN. (K.) It is said in a trad., kaAnati AlOaroDu xuXoEapF EalaI AlmaMCi vumRa duHiyato [The earth was a low hill, &c., upon the water: then it was spread out]: (S:) but this trad. is variously related. (TA.)

xaAXiEN c
xaAXiEN Lowly, humble, or submissive, (K, TA,) and still: (TA:) [or so in the voice and in the eyes: (see 1:)] pl. xaAXiEuwna and xuXRaEN; the latter also signifying men lowering, humbling, or abasing, themselves: or constraining themselves to be, or to become, lowly, humble, or submissive; or to be so, or to become so, in voice, or in the eyes: or casting their eyes towards the ground, and lowering their voices. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur
[lxviii. 43, and lxx. 44], accord. to different readings, xaAXiEapF OaboSaAruhumo and xaAXiEFA OaboSaAruhumo [Having their eyes cast down]: the accus. case being used as denotative of state. (Zj, TA.) ― -b2- Bowing; or bending down the head and body. (K.) ― -b3- Fearing. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A camel's foot (xufRN) cleaving to the ground. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A wall that has cracked, and given notice of its falling, and [then] become even with the ground. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A herb dried up, and falling down upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b7- Applied to a place, (S, K,) and, with p, to a balodap [or portion of country], (S,) (tropical:) Overspread with dust, [in the CK AlmuEanobaru is erroneously put for AlmugabRaru,] and having in it no place of alighting, or of abiding: (S, K:) and to land (OaroDN), meaning of which the wind raises the surface, by reason of its softness, so as to efface its traces, or tracks: (L:) or in this case it is with p, as in the Kur xli. 39, and means altered (mutagayRirap [probably a mistranscription for mutagabRirap overspread with dust]), and having its herbage broken in pieces: (Zj, * TA:) or dried up, and containing no herbage: (Jel:) or containing no green herbage: or low, or depressed, and still: (TA:) and, without p, applied to a place, to which one finds not his way: (Sgh, K:) pl. xuXRaEN. (TA.)

1 xaXafa c
1. xaXafa, aor.
xaXifa
(S, Sgh, L, K) and
xaXufa
, (L, K,) inf. n. xaXofN, (S,) He, or it, made a sound, (L, K,) or what is termed HisR [i. e. a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound], (S,) and an audible motion: (S, L:) said of a man: and said also of snow, as meaning it caused one to hear a [sound such as is termed] xaXofap in walking [upon it]; as is the case in intense cold. (S.) And xaXafa, aor.
xaXifa
, inf. n. xuXuwfN, said of snow, It was rough, so that it caused one to hear a xaXofap in walking [upon it]: and in like manner said of ice; i. e. it was soft, or yielding [to the feet, crackling], or easily broken. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Katámee, (TA,)
UicaA kabRada AlnRajomu AlsRamaMCa biXatowapK
EalaIHiyna harRa Alkalobu wAlvRaloju xaAXifu
[When the asterism of the Pleiades culminates in winter, at the time when the dog whines by reason of the cold, and the snow causes one to hear a slight sound in walking upon it]: (S:) or, accord. to IB, the right reading is, bisuHorapK [a little before daybreak, or in the last third of the night]: (TA:) Hyn is here mansoob because ElI is made to be redundant, and because it is prefixed to a verbal proposition: (S:) this is the more approved way in a case of this kind, when the verb commencing the proposition is a pret.; but some say ElI Hiyni. (I 'Ak p. 199.) ― -b2- xaXafa said of water, It froze. (K.) ― -b3- Said of cold, It was, or became, intense. (K.) ― -b4- xaXafa iI AlsRayori, (K,) inf. n. xaXafaAnN, (JK,) He hastened, made haste, or sped, [app. so as to cause a slight sound to be heard,] in going, journeying, or pace. (JK, * K.) And marRa yaxoXifu He passed along hastening. (TA.) ― -b5- xaXafa, (S, K,) aor.
xaXufa
(S, TA) and
xaXifa
, (TA,) inf. n. xuXuwfN (S, K) and xaXafaAnN, (K,) He went away in, or into, the land, or country. (S, K.) And xaXafa fulaAnN Such a one journeyed away, went away, or departed, or became hidden or concealed, syn. tagayRaba, (K, TA,) in the land, or country. (TA.) ― -b6- xaXafa fiI AlXRaIoCi (aor.
xaXifa
, TA,) He entered into the thing; as also AnxXf↓. (K.) ― -b7- xaXafa, inf. n. xaXafaAnN, He (a man) went, or travelled, by night. (K.) ― -b8- And He was bold, or daring, in night-journeying: or he went about, or round about, by night; (L, K, TK; but in the first and second, only the inf. n. is mentioned in this case;) and journeyed much by night. (L.) And xaXafa biAlqawomi, aor.
xaXifa
, said of a guide of the way, He went about, or round about, by night, and hastened, or sped, with the party: (JK:) or xaXafa bihimo, inf. n. xaXaAfapN, he (a guide of the way) acted with a penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, with them [in conducting them]; as also xXRf↓, inf. n. taxoXiyfN. (K, * TA.) ― -b9- xaXafato biwaladihaA She (a woman) cast forth her child [from the womb]. (K.) And xuXifa bihi He, or it, was cast, or thrown; as also xufiXa bh, and HufiXa bh. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xaXafa raOosahu biAlHajari He (a man, S) broke his head with the stone. (S, K.)

2 xaXRafa
2: see 1.

3 xAXf c
3. xAXf, (K,) inf. n. muxaAXafapN, (JK, TA,) It (an arrow) caused a [sound such as is termed] HaXofap to be heard on its hitting the object aimed at: (K, * TA:) or it (an arrow) caused a [confused sound such as is termed] xaXoxaXap to be heard from the inside of the animal hit thereby. (JK.) ― -b2- xAXf fiI AlXRarRi, and UilaI AlXRarRi, He hastened in doing, and to do, evil, or mischief. (TA.) ― -b3- xAXf fiI cimRatihi He hastened in breaking, or violating, his compact, covenant, or promise of protection or safeguard, or of security or safety. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- xAXf AlUibila layolatahu He went, or kept pace, with the camels during his night; syn. saAyarahaA. (K.)

7 UinoxaXafa
7: see 1.

xuXofN c
xuXofN: see xaXofapN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and xiXofN: ＝ -A3- and xaAXifN.

xuXofN c
xuXofN: see what next follows.

xiXofN c
xiXofN (As, JK, IDrd, Msb, K) and xuXofN↓ and xaXofN↓, (K,) the second of which is said by MF to be the most common, and then the first, (TA,) [but this is a mistake, for the first is the only form commonly occurring,] The young one of the gazelle; (JK, Msb;) applied to the male and the female; (Msb;) or the female is termed xXfp [i. e. xiXofapN and xiXofapi and xaXofapN]: (K:) or the young one of the gazelle in the first stage after its birth: (K:) or after it is termed TalFA; for it is called by the latter appellation when just born: (As, TA: [see XaSarN:]) or after it is termed jadaAyap: (TA:) or when it first walks: or she that flees, or goes away, from, or of, (mino,) her young ones: (K: [a strange (as well as an ambiguous) explanation, seeing that the fem. is said in the K to be with p:] pl. xuXuwfN, (Msb,) or xiXafapN. (K.)

xaXafN c
xaXafN and xaXiyfN↓ Rough snow, (JK, K,) that causes one to hear a [sound such as is termed] xaXofap in walking [upon it]: (TA:) and (in like manner, TA) ice that is soft, or yielding [to the feet, crackling], or easily broken: (K:) or the latter signifies [simply] snow. (S.) One says, OaSabaHa AlmaMCu xaXiyfFA↓ [The water became ice such as was soft, &c.]. (JK, TA.) [See also xaAXifN.]

xaXofapN c
xaXofapN (JK, S, K) and xaXafapN↓ (Mgh, K) and xaXofN↓ (K) A sound: (K:) or such as is termed HisRN; (S;) [i. e.] a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound: (JK:) and a motion: (JK, S, K:) or a low, faint, gentle, or soft, HisR: or the first signifies the sound of the creeping of serpents; and the sound of the hyena: (K:) or a sound that is not loud, or vehement; (A 'Obeyd;) and so ↓the second: (Mgh:) or a single sound; so accord. to Fr: (Az, TA:) and ↓the last signifies the sound of a sword falling upon flesh, and upon a weapon or weapons: and the sound of feet, such as is not loud, or vehement. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the first, A [tract of high ground such as is termed] qufR that is mostly soft. (L, K.)

xaXafapN c
xaXafapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

xaXuwfN c
xaXuwfN A quick, or swift, man. (S.) ― -b2- One going away, or who goes away, into the land, or country; as also xaXiyfN↓ and xaAXifN↓. (K.) ― -b3- One entering, or who enters, into a thing; as also xaXiyfN↓ and xaAXifN↓ and mixXafN↓. (K.) One who enters into affairs (K, TA) and fears not, or dreads not; as also mixoXafN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Also and xaAXifN↓ and xaAXifapN↓ sings. of xuXRafN, which signifies Camels that journey by night: (S:) or, accord. to IB, the sing. of this pl. is xaAXifN only: and the pl. of xuXuwfN is xuXRafN [a mistranscription for xuXufN]. (L.) ― -b5- See also mixoXafN: ― -b6- and the paragraph here next following.

xaXiyfN c
xaXiyfN: see xaXafN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and xaXuwfN also, in two places. ― -b2- Also A sharp, or penetrating, sword; and so xaAXifN↓ and xaXuwfN↓: (K:) or, applied to a sword, i. q. xaXiybN [q. v.]. (JK.) ― -b3- And Water that runs in a [watercourse such as is termed] baToHaMC, beneath the pebbles, two or three days, and then goes away. (TA.)

AlxaXRaAfu c
AlxaXRaAfu: see mixoXafN. ― -b2- OumRu xaXRaAfK Calamity, or misfortune; (JK, K;) as also xaXRaAfN, without OumR. (TA.)

xuXRaAfN c
xuXRaAfN A certain nocturnal flying thing; (Msb;) the xufRaAX [or bat], (S, K, Msb,) that flies by night: so says El-Fárábee, in section X: (Msb:) formed by transposition from the latter word, which is the more chaste: (Sgh, Msb, TA:) or rather so called because of its xafaXaAn, i. e. its going about, or round about, by
night: (Lth, TA:) or a certain flying thing, having two small eyes: (TA:) as some say, (S,) and thus also says El-Fárábee, (Msb,) the xuTRaAf [or swallow]: (S, Msb, TA:) he who says xufRaAXN derives its name from the smallness of its eyes. (Lth, TA.)

xaAXifN c
xaAXifN [act. part. n. of 1; fem. with p]: see 1. ― -b2- Water freezing, or in a state of congelation, and so xaXofN↓. (TA.) [See xaXafN.] ― -b3- See also xaXuwfN, in four places: ― -b4- and see xaXiyfN. ― -b5- Also A boy light, or active, and brisk, lively, or sprightly; like xaAsifN. (TA in art. xsf.)

OaxaAXifu c
OaxaAXifu Hard tracts of land: with s, it signifies such as are soft. (Fr, K.)

maxoXafN c
maxoXafN A place of ice; (Sgh, K;) [an icehouse;] this is the meaning of the term by which Lth explains it, namely, yaxadaAn, (Sgh, TA,) [or yaxodaAno,] which is Persian, and which the author of the L has mistranscribed najoraAn, adding thereto AlcI yjrI Elyh AlbAb. (TA.)

ZaboyapN muxoXifN c
ZaboyapN muxoXifN A she-gazelle having a xiXof. (Sgh, K.)

mixoXafN c
mixoXafN: see xaXuwfN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A guide of the way (Lth, JK, K) who travels, or goes about, with people by night: (Lth, JK:) or who acts with a penetrative energy, and with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness. (K.) A man (AA, S) bold, or daring, (AA, S, K,) to encounter the night, (S,) or to encounter the terror of the night, (AA,) or in night-journeying: (K:) or who goes about, or round about, by night; as also xaXuwfN↓: (K:) or this last, one who fears not by night: (JK:) or who goes away boldly in the night or in any case. (AA, IB.) ― -b3- AlmixoXafu The lion; (K;) because of his boldness in going about: (TA:) and so AlxaXRaAfu↓. (JK.)

1 xaXamahu c
1. xaXamahu, (S, K,) aor.
xaXima
, (K,) inf. n. xaXomN, (JK, S,) He broke his xayoXuwmN [q. v.]. (JK, S, K.) ＝ -A2- xaXima, aor.
xaXama
, inf. n. xaXamN, (K, TA,) agreeably with rule, (TA, [accord. to the CK xaXomN,]) and xuXuwmN, (K,) which is irreg., (TA,) He (a man, TA) was, or became, wide in the nose. (K.) ― -b2- And It (the nose) became altered for the worse in odour, or stinking, by reason of a disease therein; (K, TA;) i. e., by reason of a stoppage therein, affecting the passage of the breath, and preventing respiration: or had one of its three bones broken. (TA.) ― -b3- And xaXima, (JK, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
xaXama
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. xaXomN, (JK, Mgh, and so in some copies of the K,) or xaXamN, (S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) and xuXaAmN, (K, [but mentioned in the JK as though a simple subst.,]) said of a man, (S, * Msb, K,) He became affected with a certain disease in the nose, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb,) which stopped the passage of the breath; (JK;) or which caused it to become altered for the worse in odour, or stinking; (Zj, Mgh;) or which rendered it corrupt, or unsound, so that the person could not smell: (Msb:) or his [cartilages of the nose called the] xayaAXiym [pl. of xayoXuwmN q. v.] delapsed, (K, TA,) and the passage of his breath became stopped. (TA.) ― -b4- And xaXima, (JK, Msb, K,) aor.
xaXama
, (K,) inf. n. xaXamN; (TA;) and AxXm↓; (JK, K;) and xXRm↓, (S, JM, TA,) inf. n. taxoXiymN; (JM;) for which last, the K erroneously substitutes txXRm↓; (TA;) It (flesh-meat) became altered for the worse in odour, or stinking: (S, * Msb, K:) or became very stinking; stank much. (JK.)

2 xXRmhu AlXRaraAbu c
2. xXRmhu AlXRaraAbu, inf. n. taxoXiymN, The odour of the wine rose into his xayoXuwm, and intoxicated him: (M, K:) or the odour of the wine rose into his xyXwm, and became infused in his brain, and so dispelled his reason. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

4 OaxoXama
4: see 1, last sentence.

5 txXRm c
5. txXRm His reason became dispelled by the rising of the odour of wine into his xayoXuwm and its becoming infused in his brain. (T, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence.

xaXomN c
xaXomN The nose: [see also xayoXuwmN:] and the mucus that flows from it. (TA, from a trad.: and the latter signification is mentioned in the TA voce salata; as well as in the present article.) ― -b2- [In modern Arabic, it signifies The mouth: and hence, a spout.] ＝ -A2- In Persian, it signifies Anger: and this meaning is with probability deducible from the literal root of this art.; for he who is angry raises his nose and makes it pointed. (TA.)

xuXomapN c
xuXomapN [Intoxication produced by the odour of wine rising into the xayoXuwm;] a subst. from xaXRamahu AlXRaraAbu. (K.)

xaXimN c
xaXimN, applied to flesh-meat, [Stinking: (see 1, last sentence:) or] stinking much. (JK.)

xuXaAmN c
xuXaAmN A certain disease in the nose, and a stoppage of the passage of the breath [therein]. (JK. [See also 1.]) ＝ -A2- A man having a large nose: (S:) [or] a large nose; (Zj, JK, K;) and so though not elevated, or prominent. (Zj, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A mountain having a thick prominence: (S:) or a long mountain, (AA, JK, TA,) having a prominence, (AA, TA,) or having a thick prominence: (TA:) or a great mountain. (K.) ― -b3- And AlxuXaAmu The lion: (JK, K:) because of the greatness of his nose. (TA.)

xuXaAmapN c
xuXaAmapN Refuse; anything remaining after the good has been picked out. (JK.)

xayoXuwmN c
xayoXuwmN The extreme, or most remote, [meaning innermost,] part of the nose: (S, Msb:) or the interior of the nose: (MA:) or the upper part of the interior of the nose: and the bone of the nose: (KL:) or the part that is above the nuxorap [which here seems to mean the end, or tip, or flexible part,] of the nose, of the bone thereof: and what is beneath this [is] of [the thin cartilages called] the xaXaArim of the head: (M, K:) and the nose [altogether] (Msb, KL) is so called by some: (Msb:) the word is of the measure fayoEuwlN: (Msb, TA:) and its pl. is xayaAXiym: (Msb:) which [also] signifies certain cartilages in the extreme [or inmost] part of the nose, between it and the brain: or certain ducts, (Euruwq, [meaning, or including, the air-passages, see juXRapN, and naxara, &c.,]) in the interior (baATin M, or baTon K) of the nose. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the pl. signifies also (tropical:) Prominences, or projecting parts, of mountains. (JK, S, TA.) ― -b3- And the sing., [as a coll. gen. n.,] Small, thin, black things, resembling flesh; and morbose nodes; upon a bone. (TA.)

OaxoXamu c
OaxoXamu Wide in the nose: (K:) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b2- And, so applied, Having a certain disease in the nose, (S, Msb,) whereby it is rendered corrupt, or unsound, so that he cannot smell: (Msb:) or whose xayoXuwmN has a fetid odour; (Mgh, Msb;) from xaXima said of flesh-meat, explained above: (Msb:) or that cannot smell anything, (JK, Az, Mgh, K, TA,) whether sweet or stinking, (Az, Mgh, TA,) by reason of a stoppage in his xayaAXiym, from having one of the three bones broken: (TA:) and maxoXuwmN↓ [in like manner] signifies having his nose altered for the worse in odour, or stinking, his nose altered for the worse in affecting the passage of the breath, and preventing respiration; or having one of its three bones broken: (TA:) fem. of the former xaXomaMCu. (Msb.) ― -b3- And, applied to the nose, Altered for the worse in odour, or stinking, by reason of a disease therein, (K, TA,) i. e., by a stoppage therein, affecting the passage of the breath, and preventing respiration: or having one of its three bones broken. (TA.)

muxaXRamN c
muxaXRamN Intoxicated; as also maxoXuwmN↓ and mutaxaXRimN↓: (K:) or much intoxicated. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Broken in pieces. (TA.)

maxoXuwmN c
maxoXuwmN: see OaxoXamu: ― -b2- and see also muxaXRamN.

mutaxaXRimN c
mutaxaXRimN: see muxaXRamN.

1 xaXuna c
1. xaXuna, aor
xaXuna
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xuXuwnapN and xuXonapN (S, Msb, K, KL) and xaXaAnapN (CK, TA, but omitted in some copies of the K) and xaXonN and maxoXanapN, (K,) It was, or became, rough, harsh, or coarse; (K, * KL, PS;) contr. of laAna, (S, K,) or of naEuma; (Msb;) as also txXRn↓. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa cuw xaXonapK and xuXuwnapK (K) and maxoXanapK (TA) (tropical:) He is difficult, refractory, or stubborn; not to be coped with. (K, TA. [See also xaXinN.]) And xaXuna Ealayohi Sadorihi and Elyh Sdrh AxXwXn↓ (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, angry with him. (Sh, TA.) See also 3.

2 xaXRana
2: [xXRnhu He made it rough, harsh, or coarse. ― -b2- Hence,] xXRn Sadorahu, inf. n. taxoXiynN, (tropical:) He exasperated him; made him to be affected with wrath, or rage. (S, K, TA.) A poet says,
waxaXRanato SadorFA jayobuhu laka naASiHu
[explained in art. jyb]. (S.)

3 xAXnhu c
3. xAXnhu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. muxaAXanapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was rough, harsh, or coarse, to him; syn. Ealayohi xaXuna↓; in speech, and in action; (M, TA;)
[he acted towards him, or with him, roughly, harshly, or coarsely;] contr. of laAyanahu. (S, K.)

5 taxaXRana
5: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 12.

10 AstxXnhu c
10. AstxXnhu He found it [or esteemed it] rough, harsh, or coarse. (K.) ＝ -A2- Hence, in a trad. of 'Alee, making mention of pious men of learning, QsotalaAnuwA maA QsotaxoXana Almutorafuwna (assumed tropical:) [And they esteemed, or esteem, soft, or smooth, what those leading a life of ease and plenty esteemed, or esteem, rough, harsh, or coarse]. (TA.) And AstxXn AlmaqaAma fiI maHalRi kacaA (assumed tropical:) [He esteemed unpleasant, or uncomfortable, the remaining in such a place of abode]. (TA in art. bXE.)

12 AxXwXn c
12. AxXwXn (JK, S, K) and txXRn↓ (K) It was, or became, very rough, harsh, or coarse: (S, K:) or (K.) he wore rough, harsh, or coarse, clothes: (JK, K:) or the former signifies also he accustomed himself to the wearing of such clothes: (S:) or each, he ate rough, harsh, or coarse, food: (TA:) or the former, (JK,) or each, (K,) (assumed tropical:) he said what was rough, harsh, or coarse: (JK, K, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he lived a rough, or coarse, life. (K.) The former verb is more intensive in all its senses (K, TA) than xaXuna and txXRn, because of the repetition of the medial radical and the addition of the w; and the same is the case of every verb of this class, as AEXwXb and the like, as is indicated in the S. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

xaXinN c
xaXinN Rough, harsh, or coarse; (S, * Msb, * K, KL, PS;) applied to a thing (S, Msb, K) of any kind; (K;) as also OaxoXanu↓: (S, Msb, K:) in relation to a stone, they seldom or never say otherwise than OaxoXanu: (Msb:) the fem. of the former is with p; (Msb, K;) and the pl. is xuXunN, (Msb,) [also said to be a pl. by poetic license of OaxoXanu, for xuXonN, as will be seen below,] or xiXaAnN, (K,) which is applied in the sense explained above to land [or lands]: (TA:) the fem. of OaxoXanu↓ is xaXonaMCu; (K;) and the pl. is xuXonN. (S.) You say OaroDN xaXinapN Rough, or rugged, ground or land. (Msb.) And OaroDN xXonaMCu↓ Rugged ground or land, (JK, TA,) in which are stones and sand. (TA.) And mulaMCapN xaXonaMCu↓ [A wrapper for the body] in which is roughness, harshness, or coarseness, either from newness or from make. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A strong man. (Msb.) And huwa xaXinu AljaAnibi and OaxoXanuhu↓ (tropical:) He is difficult, refractory, or stubborn; not to be coped with. (K, TA. [See also 1.]) And EaAXa EayoXFA xaXinFA (assumed tropical:) He lived a rough, or coarse, life. (K.) See also OaxoXanu.

xuXayonaMCu c
xuXayonaMCu [dim. of xaXonaMCu] A certain small herb, or leguminous plant, green, found in meadows, and plains; so called because of its roughness, or harshness, or coarseness. (TA.) See also xaXnaMCu at the end of the next paragraph.

OaxoXanu c
OaxoXanu, and its fem. xaXonaMCu: see xaXinN, in five places. You say also katiybapN xaXonaMCu (tropical:) [An army, or a portion thereof, bristling with weapons: or] having many weapons: (JK, S, K, TA:) [and in like manner, jayoXN xaXinN↓, occurring in the TA in art. xms:] and maEoXarN xuXonN and xuXunN; the latter allowable in poetry: (S: [it is there implied that this has a similar meaning:]) or the last signifies (assumed tropical:) [a company of men] who resist harm, or injury. (Ham p. 5.) And OuvofiyRapN xaXonaMCu (assumed tropical:) A great number [of people]. (S in art. vafI.) ― -b2- Also, (K, TA,) or OuxayoXinu↓, (JK,) (tropical:) A man whose state, or condition, is discommended. (JK, K, TA. [See also muxaXRanapN.]) And the fem., (assumed tropical:) A she-camel lean, or emaciated. (JK, K.) And sanapN xaXonaMCu (assumed tropical:) A year of drought or distress. (JK.) ― -b3- A rájiz says,
mino yavoribiyRaAtK xuXoni
meaning [Of the fabric of Yethrib,] new [unfeathered arrows]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- xaXonaMCu also signifies A certain green herb, or leguminous plant, (A Hn, JK, K,) having short leaves, (JK,) that spreads upon the ground, (AHn,) rough to the feel, but soft in the mouth, viscous like purslane; (AHn, K;) its blossom is yellow, and it is eaten [by men], and is like wise a pasture: (AHn:) also called xuXayonaMCu↓. (TA.)

OuxayoXinu c
OuxayoXinu dim. of OaxoXanu as syn. with xaXinN. (TA.) OuxayoXinu fiI caAti QllRehi is a phrase occurring in a trad. [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) Somewhat rough or coarse in clothing, or in mode of living, for the sake, or to obtain the approbation, of God]. (S, TA.) See also OaxoXanu.

muxaXRanapN c
muxaXRanapN A she-camel whose Tiroq [or condition in respect of fatness] is discommended. (JK, K. [See also OaxoXanu.])

1 xaXati AlnRaxolapu c
1. xaXati AlnRaxolapu, aor. taxoXuw, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. aXowN, (JK, TA,) The palm-tree bore dates such as are termed xaXow, i. e. HaXaf: (JK, S, K:) so says El-Umawee, (S,) or IAar. (TA.)

xaXFA c
xaXFA Black wheat. (IAar, K, * TA.)

xaXowN c
xaXowN Dates such as are termed HaXaf: (JK, S, K:) so says El-Umawee, (S,) or IAar, who adds, i. e., of which the lower portion has become bad and rotten, while in its place: he says that it is of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab. (TA.)

1 xaXiIa c
1. xaXiIa, aor. yaxoXaI, inf. n. xaXoyapN (JK, S, M, Msb, K) and xaXoIN (JK, M, K) and xiXoIN (Sgh, K) [the second and third erroneously written in the CK xaXFA and (by indication) xiXFA] and xaXaApN (M, K) and xaXoyaAnN, (JK, M, K,) though it has been said that the only instances of this kind are XanoMnN and layRaAnN, [see the former of these two,] but in one copy of the M found written xiXoyaAnN, (TA,) and maxoXaApN (JK, M, K) and maxoXiyapN, (M, K,) He feared; syn. xaAfa: (JK, S, M, Msb, K:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, he dreaded; or feared with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, or awe. (TA.) You say, xaXiyahu He feared him, or it; [or he dreaded him, or it; i. e. feared him, or it, with reverence, &c.;] as also txXRAhu↓. (K.) [And xaXiIa minohu, meaning the same: or He feared, or dreaded, what might happen to him from him, or it. And xaXiIa Ealayohi XayoYFA He feared, or dreaded, for him a thing.] And faEalotu celika xaXaApa Oano yakuwna kacaA [I did that in fear, or dread, that such a thing might happen]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- xaXayotuhu also signifies Hope. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And the saying of Ibn-'Abbás to 'Omar, laqado Oakovarota mina AldRuEaMCi biAlmawoti HatRaI xaXiytu Oano yakuwna celika Oasohala laka Einoda nuzuwlihi, is explained as meaning [Verily thou hast prayed much for death, so that] I hope [that it may be easier to thee when it happens]. (TA.) ― -b3- And sometimes xaXiytu means Ealimotu [I knew, or know]. (Msb.) So it is said to mean in the saying of the poet.
walaqado xaXiytu biOa mano tabiEa AlhudaI
skana AljinaAna maEa AlnRabiIRi muHamRadi
[And I know assuredly that he who follows the right direction shall dwell in the gardens of Paradise with the Prophet Mohammad]: (S, TA:) or the meaning may be, I hope. (TA.) ― -b4- In the saying in the Kur [xviii. 79], faxaXiynaA Oano yurohiqahumaA TugoyaAnFA wakuforFA, the meaning is said, by Akh, to be And we disapproved [that he should make excessive disobedience, and ingratitude, to come upon them twain]; (S;) and so says Zj, explaining it as the saying of El-Khidr: or, accord. to Fr, the meaning is, and we knew. (TA. [See also Oazohaqa.]) ＝ -A2- xaAXaAniI faxaXayotuhu: see 3.

2 xXRAhu c
2. xXRAhu, inf. n. taxoXiyapN, He frightened him, or made him to fear; (S, K;) [or he made him to dread; or to fear with reverence, &c.; (see 1;)] biAlOamori [with the thing, or event]. (TA.) One says, xaXRi cuWaAlapa biAlHibaAlapi, meaning [Frighten thou] the wolf [with the snare]. (S. [See art. cOl.]) And laqado kunotu wamaA OuxaXRaI biAlcRiYobi [Verily I used to be in a state when I was not frightened by the wolf]: a prov. (JK, TA.)

3 xaAoXaIa
3: xaAXaAniI faxaXayotuhu↓, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) aor. of the latter OaxoXiyhi, (A'Obeyd, S,) [I vied with him in fear or dread, and] I was more fearful [or dreading] than he. (A 'Obeyed, S, K.) ― -b2- xaAXaI fulaAnFA, (JK, TA,) inf. n. muxaAXaApN, (TA,) He left, forsook, relinquished, or abandoned, such a one, being left, &c., by him. (JK, TA.) ― -b3- xAXI bihimo He guarded himself against them in an extraordinary degree, and was cautious, or wary, (JK, TA,) and therefore turned away, or withdrew. (TA.)

5 taxaXRaIa
5: see 1, second sentence.

xaXK c
xaXK: see what next follows.

xaXoyaAnu c
xaXoyaAnu Fearful, or fearing; (S, Msb, TA;) [or dreading; i. e. fearing with reverence, &c.: (see 1:)] as also xaAXK↓ and xaXK↓: (K:) fem. xaXoyaA, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, xaXoyaMCu,]) like gaDobaI fem, of gaDobaAnu, (Msb,) accord. to rule, (TA,) and xaXoyaAnapN, mentioned by El-
arzookee, and thought by MF to be of the dial. of Asad; (TA;) or this signifies a wo man who fears, or dreads, (taxoXaI,) everything; (JK, TA;) so in the Tekmileh: (TA:) pl. xaXaAyaA, (K,) pluralized in a similar manner to epithets significant of diseases, like HayaATaI &c., because AlxaXoyap is like a disease. (TA.)

xaXaMCN c
xaXaMCN Land such as is termed jahaAdN [i. e. hard; or having no herbage; or hard, and having no herbage; or level; or rugged, &c.]. (JK, Sgh, K.)

xaXiIRN c
xaXiIRN Dry; (As, JK, S, K;) like HaXiIRN; (As, S;) applied to herbage; (As, S;) or to herbs and trees: (JK:) or dry and rotten. (IAar, TA.) A rájiz says, (S,) namely, Sakhr, (TA,)
samRu caraAriyHa riTaAbK waxaXiIo
[Poison of moist cantharides, and dry]; (S, TA;) meaning waxaXiIRK, suppressing one of the two Is by poetic license. (IB, TA.)

xaAXK c
xaAXK: see xaXoyaAnu.

OaxoXaI c
OaxoXaI meaning More [and most] fearful, or feared, [or dreaded,] (S, K,) is anomalous, (K,) being from the pass. [verb, like its syn. Oaxowafu]. (TA.) You say, hecaA AlmakaAnu OaxoXaI mino caAka This place is more fearful, or feared, [or dreaded,] than that. (S, K. *)

maxaAXK c
maxaAXK [pl. of maxoXaApN, originally maxoXayapN,] Causes of fear [or dread]; syn. maxaAwifu [pl. of maxaAfapN: like which, maxoXaApN is also an inf. n.]. (Har p. 138.)

1 xaSRahu biAlXRaIoCi c
1. xaSRahu biAlXRaIoCi, (S, K,) or bikacaA, (A, Msb,) aor.
xaSuSa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. xaSRN (K) and xuSuwSN (S, Msb, K) and xaSuwSN (TA) and xaSuwSiyRapN and xuSuwSiyRapN, (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) of which last two the former is the more chaste, (S, TA,) and is the form mentioned in the Fs and its Exposi tions, and the I in it is said to be the relative I, and the I which is characteristic of an inf. n., whereas in the latter it is said to be a characteristic of intensiveness, but MF thinks that this requires consideration, because the I is also said to be, and by some more commonly, without teshdeed, as in karaAhiyapN and EalaAniyapN, (TA,) and xiSRiySaI, (S, K,) like mikRiyvaI, which is said to be the only other instance of this measure, (TA,) [but some others might be added, as dilRiylaI and fixRiyraI and qitRiytaI,] and xiSRiySaMCu, (IAar, Kr, K,) [like mikRiyvaMCu,] the former of which last two [each of which has an intensive signification] is the chaste, and com monly known, form, (TA,) and xuSRiyRapN, or xiSRiyRapN, or xaSiyRapN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) written by Sgh with damm, (TA,) and taxiSRapN, (Ibn-' Abbád, K,) or, as some say, xaSuwSiyRapN and xiSRiyRapN [or xuSRiyRapN or xaSRiyRapN] are each a quasi-inf. n., as also xaASRapN, (TA,) He distinguished him particularly, peculiarly, or specially, i. e., above, or from, or exclusively of, others, by the thing, or by such a thing; he particularized him, or particularly or peculiarly or specially characterized him, thereby; syn. faDRalahu (A, K, TA) duwna gayorihi, and mayRazahu; (TA;) he appropriated, or assigned, [the thing or] such a thing, or made it to belong, to him alone, or in particular, or peculiarly, or specially, exclusively of others; (Msb;) and bihi AxtSRhu↓ signifies the same; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also AxSRhu↓, (A, [but for this I know not any other authority,]) and xSRShu↓; (A;) or this last has an intensive signification. (Msb.) You say, xaSRahu biAluwdRi He distinguished him &c. by love, or affection; or favoured him in preference to another, or others, thereby. (K, TA.) As to the saying of AZ,
Uini QmoraON xaSRaniI EamodFA mawadRatahu
EalaI AltRanaAniI laEinodiI gayoru makofuwri
[If a man distinguish me above, or from, or exclusively of, others, purposely, by his love, or because of his love of me, notwithstanding distance of each from the other, it will not be disacknowledged with me,] the meaning is, xaSRaniI bimawadRatihi; or it may be xaSRaniI limawadRatihi UiyRaAIa [in the TA bimawadRatihi, which is evidently a mistranscription]; for, says ISd, we have not heard xaSRahu [or rather xaSRa] doubly transitive. (TA.) And [hence] xaSRahu bikacaA also signifies He gave him such a thing in large quantity, or abundantly. (TA.) [You say also, xaSRahu biAlcRikori He distinguished, &c., or singled out, him, or it, by mention: or he particularized, peculiarized, or specified, him, or it, thereby; he particularly, peculiarly, or specially, mentioned him, or it. And xaSRahu, alone, He pointed particularly, or peculiarly, to him, or it, in what he said; or he meant particularly, or peculiarly, him, or it. And xaSRa minohu kacaA He distinguished, particularized, peculiarized, or specified, thereof such a thing: and he distinguished therefrom such a thing; he particularly, peculiarly, or specially, excepted therefrom such a thing.] You also say, xaSRahu linafosihi (TA) and linafosihi AxtSRhu↓ (T, A, TA) [He appropriated, or took, or chose, him, or it, particularly, or specially, to, or for, himself; as also xaSRa bihi nafosahu and bihi nafosahu AxtSR↓]. And fulaAnFA huwa yasotaxiSRu↓ and yasotaxoliSuhu (A, TA) [He appropriates such a one purely to himself, exclusively of any partner; (see the latter verb;)] he chooses such a one for himself; he appropriates him to himself as his particular, or special, intimate; (TA in art. xlS;) both signify the same. (S and K in art. xlS.) [And AxtSRhu↓ He treated him, or behaved towards him, with partiality; was partial towards him: a signification implied by the first explanation in this art.: and in this sense it is often used.] ＝ -A2- xaSRa, aor.
xaSuSa
, [contr. to general rule, by which it should be

[vii. 21 and xx. 119], waTafiqaA yaxoSifaAni EalayohimaA mino waraqi AljanRapi; and yaxiSRifaAni↓, originally yaxotaSifaAni, by some pronounced yaxaSRifaAni↓, (S, TA,) and by some, yaxoSRifaAni↓, with two quiescent letters together; (TA; [but this appears to be incorrect; see 8 in art. xSm;]) and yuxoSifaAni↓, from OaxoSafa; and yuxaSRifaAni↓, from xaSRafa; (Ksh and Bd in vii. 21, and TA;) thus accord. to different readings; i. e. OaxoDaru c
OaxoDaru [Green; verdant;] of the colour termed xuDRaAraI; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also xaDirN↓ (Msb, K) and xaDiyrN↓ and xaDuwrN↓ and yaxoDuwrN↓ and yaxoDiyrN↓: (K, TA: the last two written in the CK taxoDuwrN and taxoDiyrN:) applied to a horse, [and to a camel, (see xuDorapN,) and to an ass, and sometimes to a bird, and to a garment of the kind called kisaMC, and the like, and to various other things, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or dingy ash-colour; or dark dust-colour;] of a dust-colour intermixed with duhomap [i. e. blackness or deep ash-colour]; which is the same as dayozajN; (S;) in horses being distinguished as OaxoDaru Oadogamu and OaxoDaru OaToHalu and OaxoDaru Oaworaqu: (TA: [see the latter epithet in each of these cases:]) applied to a man, [and to other things,] tawny, or brownish: (S:) [and blackish: and of a blackish hue inclining to green:] and black; (S, K;) black-complexioned: (TA:) [and intensely black: it is said in the Msb, art. Htm, that AlOaxoDaru is, with the Arabs, Oasowadu; which may mean either that green is, with the Arabs, termed Aswd, or that AlAxDr is, with the Arabs, black: but the truth is, that each of the epithets OaxoDaru and Oasowadu is sometimes used for the other: see what here follows, and see Oasowadu: in Har p. 495, it is erroneously said, on the authority of Er-Rázee, that the Aswd is not termed by the Arabs AxDr, although the AxDr is termed by them Aswd because of its intense xuDorap and riIR:] the fem. is xaDoraMCu: and the pl. is xuDorN. (Msb, TA.) You say XajarapN xaDoraMCu A green, and fresh, or juicy, tree. (TA.) And maMCN OaxoDaru Water inclining to a green colour, by reason of its clearness. (TA.) And OaxoDaru Aljilodapi [lit. Tawny of skin:] meaning (assumed tropical:) of pure race; because the complexions of the Arabs are tawny; (S;) of genuine Arab race: (IB:) as in the saying of El-Lahabee, (S, TA,) El-Fadl Ibn-'Abbás, (TA,)
waOanaA AlOaxoDaru mano yaEorifuniI
OaxoDaru Aljilodapi fiI bayoti AlEarabo
[And I am the tawny: who knows me? the tawny of skin (or pure of race), of the family that comprises the nobility of the Arabs]. (S, IB.) And fulaAnN OaxoDaru AlqafaA [lit. Such a one is blackish, or black, in the back of the neck:] meaning (tropical:) such a one is the son of a black woman: (Az, A:) or (tropical:) one who is slapped on the back of his neck: (A:) or (tropical:) a freedman, or an emancipated slave. (TA.) And OaxoDaru AlbaToni (tropical:) A weaver: (A, TA:) because his belly, being stuck close to his loom, becomes blackened by it. (TA.) And OaxoDaru AlnRawaAjici (tropical:) An eater of onions and leeks: or a tiller, or cultivator, of the ground; because he eats herbs, or leguminous plants. (A.) And humo xuDoru AlmanaAkibi [lit. They are green in the shoulders, from carrying the produce of their land:] meaning (tropical:) they are in a state of great plenty. (K, TA.) And [hence, perhaps,] fulaAnN OaxoDaru (tropical:) Such a one possesses abundant xayor [or wealth, or prosperity]: (A, TA:) [or it may mean goodness: for] AlOaxoDaru, applied to a man, is an epithet of praise, whereby he may be likened to the sea, because it is described as green, or to the [rain or herbage called] rabiyE; in both cases meaning (assumed tropical:) liberal, or bountiful; and it is so applied because xuDorapN is of the colours of the Arabs: and it is also an epithet of dispraise, as meaning (assumed tropical:) black by reason of baseness, ignobleness, or meanness. (Ham p. 282.) And XaAbRN OaxoDaru (tropical:) A young man whose hair has begun to grow upon the sides of his face. (TA.) And katiybapN xaDoraMCu (tropical:) An army, or a troop of horse, overspread with the blackness of iron: (S, TA:) or a great army or troop of horse (K, TA) of which most of the men are clad in iron; like jaOowaMCu: (TA:) because of the xuDorap of the iron: (A:) [i. e.] because of the blackness thereof. (TA.) And AllRayolu OaxoDaru (tropical:) Night is black. (TA.) And [hence,] janRa Ealayohi OaxoDaru AljanaAHayoni (tropical:) Night [lit. the black-winged] veiled him, concealed him, or covered him with its darkness. (A.) mudohaAmRataAni, in the Kur [lv. 64, relating to two gardens of Paradise], is explained by xaDoraAwaAni because it means Inclining to blackness, by reason of abundance of moisture, or irrigation. (S.) ― -b2- AlOaxoDaru used as a subst.: see xuDaArapN. ― -b3- The fem. xaDoraMCu [is also used as a subst., and] signifies Gree herbs or leguminous plants; (Msb, K;) as also xuDaArapN↓: (K:) pl. xaDoraAwaAtN: by rule it should be xuDorN; but as the quality of a subst. predominates in it, it has a pl. like the pl. of a subst., like SaHoraAwaAtN pl. of SaHoraMCN: (Msb:) this pl. occurs in the saying (in a trad., TA) layosa fiI AlxaDoraAwaAti SadaqapN There is no poor-rate in the case of green herbs or leguminous plants; (Msb;) or fresh fruits and herbs or leguminous plants; (TA;) or fruits, such as the apple and the pear &c.; or herbs or leguminous plants, such as leeks and smallage and rue and the like; and xuDarN, pl. of xuDorapN, is sometimes substituted for it. (Mgh.) [Hence,] UiyRaAkumo waxaDoraMCu AldRimani, meaning (tropical:) Avoid ye the beautiful woman that is of bad origin: (S, A, Msb:) because what grows in a dimonap [or place which men have blackened by their cooking, and where their camels or other beasts have staled and dunged], though it may be beautiful and bright, does not bear fruit [because it is neglected, and left unwatered], (S, Msb,) and soon becomes corrupt, or bad. (Msb. [See also dimonapN: and see EuXobapN AldRaAri, in art. EXb.]) ― -b4- And AlxaDoraMCu, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, (TA,) (tropical:) The sky, or heaven; (S, A, K;) because of its greenness; like as the earth is called AlgaboraMCu. (TA.) You say, maA taHota AlxaDoraMCi Oakorahu minohu (tropical:) [There is not under the sky one more hateful than he]. (A.) ― -b5- And xaDoraMCu (tropical:) A bucket (A, K) with which water has been drawn long, so that it has become green or blackish &c. (HatRaI QxoDarRato). (K.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The congregated or collective body, and mass, or bulk, of a people. (S, K.) So in the saying, OabaAda QllRehu xaDoraMCahumo (assumed tropical:) [May God destroy the congregated or collective body, mass, or bulk, of them]: (S:) or this means, (tropical:) their stock (Xajarap) from which they have branched off; (A;) [for] xaDoraMCu signifies the origin of anything: (TA:) or, their life in this present world: (Fr, TA:) or, as some say, their enjoyment and plenty; (TA;) [for] xaDoraMCu signifies prosperity, and plenty, and enjoyment: (TA in a later part of this art.:) or the right reading is gaDoraMCahumo, meaning “their prosperity, and their pleasantness of life, or plenty and prosperity.” (S. [See art. gDr.]) ― -b7- Albaqolapu AlxaDoraMCu: see xaDirN. ― -b8- AlxuDoru, (T,) or AlxaDoraMCu, (K,) The domestic pigeons; (T, K;) so called although of various colours, because their predominant colour is wuroqap [or ash-colour], or xuDorap [meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]: the xuDor and the numor [or spotted with white and black, &c.,] are especially characterized by the faculty of rightly directing their course. (T, TA.) ― -b9- AlOaxaASiru [a pl. of AlOaxoDaru used as a subst.] (tropical:) Gold and flesh-meat and wine; as also AlOaHaAmirapu [as some explain this latter]. (A.) And Soft, or tender; applied to herbage, or seed-produce. (TA.) ― -b11- [Hence,] EiyXapN xaDoraMCu (assumed tropical:) A mode of life soft, or delicate, and plentiful and pleasant. (Har p. 639.) ― -b12- AlOaxoDaru is also the name of [A certain star, or asterism; most probably either a of Piscis Australis or ε of Pegasus, or some star or asterism nearly in a line with those two;] one of the three OanowaMC of the rain called Alxariyf; namely, the middle nawoC of those three AnwMC; the first being the nasoraAni; and the last, the foremost of the farogaAni: see nawoCN. 1. xaTRa, aor.
xaTuTa
, inf. n. xaTRN, He made [a line, or lines, or] a mark, EalaI AlOaroDi, upon the ground. (Msb.) You say, xaTRa AlzRaAjiru fiI AlOaroDi, aor. and inf. n. as above, The diviner made a line, or a mark, or lines, or marks, upon the ground, and then divined. (TA.) And AlzRaAjiru yaxuTRu biUiSobaEihi fiI AlrRamoli wayazojuru [The diviner makes lines, or marks, with his finger upon the sand, and divines]. (S.) Th says, on the authority of IAar, that Eilomu AlxaTRi is Eilomu AlrRamoli [or geomancy]: I 'Ab says that it is an ancient science, which men have relinquished: but Lth says that it is practised to the present time; [to which I may add, that it has not even now ceased; being still practised on sand and the like, and also on paper;] and they have conventional terms which they employ in it, and they elicit thereby the secret thoughts &c., and often hit upon the right therein: the diviner comes to a piece of soft ground, and he has a boy, with whom is a style; and the master makes many lines, or marks, in haste, that they may not be counted; then he returns, and obliterates leisurely lines, or marks, two by two; and if there remain two lines, or marks, they are a sign of success, and of the attainment of the thing wanted: while he obliterates, his boy says, for the sake of auguring well, AibonaIo EiyaAno OasoriEaA AlbayaAno [O two sons of 'Iyán (meaning two lines or marks), hasten ye the manifestation]: I 'Ab says that when he has obliterated the lines, or marks, and one remains, it is the sign of disappointment: and AZ and Lth relate the like of this. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-El-Hakam Es-Sulamee, traced up by him to its author, kaAna nabiIRN mina AlOanobiyaMCi yaxuTRu famano xaTRahu Ealima mivola Eilomihi [A prophet of the prophets used to practise geomancy; and he who matches his geomancy knows the like of his knowledge]. (TA.) You say also, when a man is meditating upon his affair, and considering what may be its issue, or result, fulaAnN yaxuTRu fiI AlOaroDi (tropical:) [Such a one makes lines, or marks, upon the ground]. (TA.) [See also nakata: and see St. John's Gospel, ch. viii. verses 6 and 8.] And xaTRa birijolihi AlOaroDa means (tropical:) He walked, or went along. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (Msb, K,) He wrote (S, Msb, K) a writing, or book, (Msb,) or a thing, (TA,) with the reed prepared for that purpose, (S, K,) or with some other thing; (K, TA;) [and so xTRT↓, for] taxoTiyTN is syn. with tasoTiyrN, or, as in the T, like tsTyr; whence the saying, xuTRiTato Ealayohi cunuwbuhu His sins were written [or registered] against him. (TA.) ― -b3- xaTRa AlxiTRapa, and xaTRahaA linafosihi: see 8; for the latter, in two places. ― -b4- [Hence,] xaTRa Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He prohibited it; or took it for himself; relating to anything. (K, TA.) ― -b5- xuTRu waHohuhu: or xaTRa: see 8. ― -b6- xaTRa AlgulaAmu: see 8. ― -b7- xaTaTotu biAlsRayofi wajohahu wawasaTahu (tropical:) [I cut, or clave, with the sword his face and his waist]. (TA.) And xaTRahu biAlsRayofi niSofayoni (tropical:) [He clave him, or it, in halves with the sword]. (TA.) And jaAraAhu famaA xaTRa gubaArahu (tropical:) He contended with him in running, and did not cleave his dust. (JK, S, * A, L.) ― -b8- xaTRa QllRehu nawoCahaA [God made its (a land's) rain-giving star or asterism (see nawoCN) to pass it over: or may God make &c.]: from xaTiyTapN signifying “ a land not rained upon between two lands that have been rained upon: ” (S, TA: *) it was said by I' Ab [in a tropical sense, by way of imprecation, with reference to a woman], when he was asked respecting a man who had put the affair of his wife in her own hand and she had in consequence divorced him by a triple sentence: (S:) accord. to one relation, it is xaTRaOa; the meaning being “ may he make its rain to miss it: ” (S, TA:) and accord. to another, xaTRaI↓, originally xaTRaTa, like taqaDRaI AlbaAziI: the former, or first, is the weaker, or weakest, in authority, of these relations. (TA. [See also 2 in art. xTO.])

2 xTROhu c
2. xTROhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taxoTiYapN and taxoTiIoCN, (S, K,) He said to him, OaxoTaOota [meaning Thou hast done wrong, or committed a mistake or an error]: (S, Msb, K:) or he pronounced him, or asserted him, to be doing wrong, or committing a mistake or an error. (Msb.) You say, Uino OaxoTaOotu faxaTRiYoniI [If I do wrong, &c., tell me that I have done so]. (S.) ― -b2- Also He made it to miss: so in the saying, xaTRaOa QllRehu nawoCahaA God made, or may God make, its [i. e. a land's] star, or asterism, to miss; so that the rain which the star or asterism should have brought did not, or shall not, fall upon it. (TA.) This was [also] said by I'Ab [in a tropical sense] with reference to a woman, as an imprecation, in disapproval of her conduct. (Mgh.) As some relate this saying, the verb is xaTRaI, (Mgh, TA,) and the meaning, God made, or may God make, its [rain-giving] star or asterism, to pass it over, and not send rain upon it: and in this case it may be, (TA,) or it is, (Mgh,) from xaTiyTapN, signifying “ a land not rained upon (Mgh, TA) between two lands that have been rained upon; ” (Mgh;) the verb being originally xaTRaTa, and the final T being changed into I. (Mgh, TA. [See art xT.]) nawoC is [here] the sing. of OanowaMCN meaning the “ Mansions of the Moon, ” also called the “ stars, or asterisms, of rain. ” (Mgh.) [See more in the first paragraph of art. xT: and see also 4 in the present art.] Accord. to Fr, xaTRaI AlsRahoma and xaTRaOahu are syn. [as meaning He made the arrow to pass over, or to miss, the mark]. (TA.) One says also, xuTRiYu Eanoka AlsRuwoCu [May evil be made to miss thee;] i. e. may evil be repelled from thee. (ISk.) And xaTRaOa Eanoka AlsRuwoCu [app. for taxaTRaOa↓] Evil missed thee, or may evil miss thee. (AZ.)

(TA.) See also 5. ＝ -A2- AxTOhu, (S, K,) which signifies, He [or it] missed, or failed of hitting, it [or him], (TA,) and txATOhu↓ (S, K) and txTROhu↓ (K) and lahu txTRO↓ (TA) [and xaTiYahu↓, as will be seen from what follows,] are syn. (S, K, TA.) [See also 2, last sentence.] You say, AxTO AlrRaAmiI AlgaraDa The archer, or thrower, missed the mark; or failed of hitting it. (TA.) And AxTOhu AlsRahomu The arrow [missed it, or him, or] passed beyond it, or him: and you may also say, OaxoTaAhu, suppressing the C (Msb.) And AxTO AlTRariyqa [He missed the way; or] he deviated from the way. (TA.) And AxTO nawoWuhu [(assumed tropical:) His star, or asterism, missed]; said of him who has sought an object of want and not succeeded in attaining it: (TA:) and to a person in this case one says, AxTO nawoWuka [(assumed tropical:) Thy star, or asterism, has missed]. (Mgh. [See also 2.]) And AxTOhu The right, or due, was, or became, [out of his reach,] or far from him. (Msb.) Owfà Ibn-Matar ElMázinee says,

xaTomN xTm
xaTomN The muzzle, i. e. the fore part of the nose and mouth, of a dAbRap [i. e. beast], (JK, S, Msb, K, TA,) whatever it be, (S, Msb,) as a dog, and a camel, but originally of a beast of prey, and of a sheep or goat: (TA:) or, of a beast of prey, i. q. xuroTuwmN: (IAar, TA:) or, as some say, of a beast of prey, [the lip, i. e.] what corresponds to the jaHofalap of the horse: (TA:) or of a camel, the nose. xuTomapN (tropical:) A prominent portion of a mountain. (S, TA.)

xiTomiIRN xTm xTmI xTmy
xiTomiIRN (JK, S, Msb, K) and xaTomiIRN, (Msb, K,) or, accord. to Az, the latter only, the former being incorrect, (TA,) but the former is the more common, (Msb,) [Althæa; the althæa officinalis of Linn.; i. e. marsh-mallow;] a certain plant (JK, K) with which, (S, TA,) or with a preparation of which, (JK,) the head is washed; (JK, S, TA;) a well-known preparation for washing the head: (Msb:) it is a dissolvent, suppurative, lenitive; good for dysury, and the stone, and sciatica, and ulcer of the bowels, and tremour, and for the suppuration of wounds, and the allaying of pain; and, with vinegar, for the [species of leprosy termed] bahaq; and for toothache, used as a gargle; and for the sting or bite of venomous reptiles and the like, and for burns; the mixing of its seed with water, or its bruised stem or root, causes it to congeal; and its mucilage, extracted by hot water, is beneficial to the sterile woman. (K.)

xiTaAmN xTAm
xiTaAmN [A kind of halter for a camel; a cord of which one end is fastened round the nose and jaws of a camel; accord. to J,] i. q. zimaAmN: (S:) [but the following explanations are more correct:] a certain thing well known; so called because [a portion of] it lies upon [or surrounds] the fore part of the nose and the nouth of the camel: (Msb:) or anything that is put upon the nose of the camel in order that he may be led thereby: (M, K:) or a cord, or rope, which is put upon the neck of the camel, and folded [for yusamRaI, in my copy of the work from which this is taken, I read yuvonaI, as in another explanation, below,] upon, or over, his nose: (Mgh:) or a cord, or rope, which is attached to an iron that surrounds the nose and jaws [of the camel]: (JK:) or any cord, or rope, that is suspended upon the throat of the camel and then tied upon, or over, his nose, whether of skin or of wool or of fibres of the palm-tree or of hemp: (ISh, TA:) but if of plaited leather, it is said to be called jariyrN: (TA:) or the xTAm of the camel is a cord, or rope, of fibres of the palm-tree, or of [goats'] hair, or of flax, at one end of which is put a ring, then the other end is tied to it, [i. e. to the rope, as the relative pronoun in the original shows, or to some part of it,] so that it becomes like a ring [or loop], then it is put upon the neck of the camel, and then it is folded upon, or over, his nose: what is put in the nose, [attached to a ring, or the like, therein,] and is slender, is termed zimaAmN: (IAth, TA:) pl. xuTumN. 2. xTRI He made to pass over: so in the saying, xaTRaI QllRehu nawoCahaA God made, or may God make, its (a land's) [rain-giving] star or asterism to pass it over, and not send rain upon it: (TA in art. xTO:) but in this case the verb is, (Mgh in that art.,) or may be, (TA ibid.,) originally xaTRaTa, the final T being changed into I. (Mgh and TA ibid. [See 2 in art. xTO.]) Accord. to Fr, xaTRaI AlsRahoma and xTO are syn. [as meaning He made the arrow to pass over, or to miss, the mark]. (TA in art. xTO.) 5. taxaTRayotuhu I stepped, or walked, over him, or it: (Msb:) or I passed over and beyond him, or it: (S:) or txTRI AlnRaAsa He went over the people, (rakibahumo,) and passed beyond them; and so AixotaTaAhumo↓. (K.) One says, taxaTRayotu riqaAba AlnRaAsi [I stepped over, walked over, passed over and beyond, or went over and passed beyond, the necks of the people]. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Friday, [of one who came too late to the Friday-prayers, as is shown in the TA in art. AnI,] raOaI rajulFA yataxaTRaI riqaAba AlnRaAsi He saw a man passing step by step [over the necks of the people who were already in their ranks in the mosque]. (TA. [See also Har p. 83.]) One says also, fulaAnN laA yataxaTRaI Eani AlTRunubi [Such a one will not step over, or beyond, or from, the tent-rope], meaning, will not go far from the tent for the purpose of voiding his excrement, by reason of his foulness and vileness and uncleanness. (TA.) And taxaTRayotu kacaA (S, TA) I passed over [to such a thing or place or person]: (TA:) one should not say taxaTRaOotu [in this sense], with C. (S, TA.) [Hence the following tropical phrases.] txTRAhu Almakoruwhu (tropical:) [What was disliked or hated, or evil, passed over him; not alighting upon him]. (TA.) And taxaTRayotu Uilayohi biAlmakoruwhi (tropical:) [I passed over others to him with that which was disliked or hated, or evil; i. q. tajaAwazotu]. (TA.) And txTRI EanRiI baSaruka (assumed tropical:) [Thine eye, or thy sight, passed me over]. (Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. tyh.) ― -b2- [Also (assumed tropical:) I overstepped it, or transgressed it; namely, a limit prescribed to me, &c.]

1 xafRa xf
1. xafRa, aor.
xafifa
, inf. n. xifRapN (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.) and xafRN (Msb, K) and xafRapN and taxawRufN, but this last belongs to art. xwf, (K,) contr. of vaqula [both properly and tropically]; (Msb;) properly, (TA,) It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, xafiyf [i. e. light] (JK, S, Msb, K, TA) of weight, (JK,) in body, or material substance. (TA.) Hence the saying of 'Atà, in a trad., xifRuwA EalaI AlOaroDi, meaning [Be ye, or bear ye, lightly upon the ground] in prostration: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or, as some relate it, xafRifuwA↓: i. e. prostrate yourselves [lightly upon the ground;] not heavily, so as to make marks, or impressions, upon your foreheads: and in another trad. it is said, UicaA sajadota fataxaAfRa↓ When thou prostratest thyself, put thy forehead upon the ground lightly: but A 'Obeyd says that some say fatujaAfi, [i. e. fatujaAfi EaDudayoka Eano janobayoka,] with j. (TA [See 3 in art. jfw.]) [Hence also,] xafRa AlmiyzaAnu The balance had one of its two scales light, so that it rose. (TA.) ― -b2- [Used tropically, it means (assumed tropical:) It, or he, was, or became, light in estimation, lightly esteemed, or of little account.] ― -b3- And (tropical:) He was, or became, xafiyf [i. e. light as meaning active, agile, &c.,] in work: (TA:) he was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; syn. naXiTa. (Msb and TA in art. nXT.) You say, xafRa fiI Eamalihi waxidomatihi (tropical:) He was, or became, [brisk, &c., or] obedient and submissive, in his work and his service: (TA:) and xafRa lahu fiI Alxidomapi (tropical:) [He was, or became, brisk, &c., to him in service], aor. yaxifRu, inf. n. xifRapN: (S:) and in like manner, xafRa lifulaAnK (tropical:) He was, or became, [promptly] obedient and submissive, to such a one. (TA.) [Hence,] xafafotu UilaI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [I was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, in behaviour to such a one]. (S in art. hX.) And xafRati AlOunovaI lilofaHoli (tropical:) The female was, or became, submissive to the male. (A, TA.) And xafRati AlOutunu liEayorihaA (tropical:) The she-asses obeyed their he-ass. (K, TA.) And xufRa UilaI AlEaduwRi, inf. n. xufuwfN, (assumed tropical:) He hastened to the enemy. (Msb.) And xafRa Alqawomu Eano waTanihimo, (K, * TA,) inf. n. xufuwfN, (TA,) (tropical:) The people, or party, removed, or departed, or journeyed, quickly from their home: or, as some say, simply removed, or departed, or journeyed, from it. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He was, or became, xafiyf [or light] in intellect, or understanding: (TA:) [and in conduct, or behaviour: generally meaning] (assumed tropical:) he was, or became, light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle; or light of intellect; lightwitted; syn. TaAXa: (Msb:) the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is xifRapN. (Msb and K &c. in art. TyX, and TA in the present art.) [But sometimes, when relating to the intellect, or understanding, it means, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, quick, acute, or sharp; and clever, or ingenious: see xafiyfN.] And you say of him whose hearing is good, fiI Oucunihi xifRapN (tropical:) [In his ear is quickness, acuteness, or sharpness, of hearing]. (TA in art. vql.) ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) He was, or became, flurried, agitated, or excited, by reason of fear, and by anger, or the like: see 10. ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, lighthearted, or cheerful; one whose company, or converse, was acceptable and cheering.] You say, xafRa fulaAnN EalaI Almaliki (assumed tropical:) Such a one was, or became, acceptable and cheering to the king. (TA.) ― -b7-
[(assumed tropical:) It (an action, or an affair, and a case, or the like,) was, or became, light, or easy: and it become alleviated.] You say, xafRato Ealayohi AlHarakapu (assumed tropical:) [Motion, or moving, was, or became, easy to him]; opposed to vaqulato. (TA.) And xafRato HaAluhu: see 4. ― -b8- [(assumed tropical:) It (a word) was light, or easy, of utterance: and in like manner said of a sound, (assumed tropical:) it was, or became, light to the ear; or slight. ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) It (food) was, or became, light to the stomach; easy of digestion. ― -b10- Said of the hair of the head, and of the beard, (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, light, thin, or scanty.] ― -b11- Said of a people, or company of men, (qawomN,) inf. n. xufuwfN, it means qalRuwA waqado xafRato zaHomatuhumo [i. e. (assumed tropical:) They became few in number, their crowding having diminished]. (S.) ― -b12- Said of rain, [&c.,] (assumed tropical:) It diminished; decreased; or was, or became, [light, or] deficient. (TA.) ― -b13- [Said of a blow, a disease, an affection of the mind, &c., It was, or became, light, slight, or inconsiderable.] ― -b14- xafRato manaAziluhumo minohumo wamaDawoA (assumed tropical:) [means Their abodes became clear of them, and they went away]. (K * and TA in art. Xwl.)

2 xfRfhu xff xffh xffp
2. xfRfhu He made it, or rendered it, xafiyf [i. e. light, both properly and tropically: the tropical significations are shown by the preceding paragraph, and by explanations of xafiyfN; and some by what here follows]: (Msb:) taxofiyfN is the contr. of tavoqiylN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, in the Kur [ii. 174], celika taxofiyfN mino rabRikumo (assumed tropical:) [That is an alleviation from your Lord]. (TA.) Hence also, in a trad. [respecting the estimates to be made by the collectors of the poor-rate], xafRifuwA AlxaroSa (assumed tropical:) [Make ye the conjectural computation of the quantity of the fruit upon palm-trees &c. light to the owners, or moderate;] go not to the utmost length in the xrS. (TA.) [And xfRf Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He made light, or alleviated, his burden, suffering, distress, uneasiness, or the like, by removing from him somewhat thereof; he alleviated him; he relieved him: see Kur iv. 32 and viii. 67 &c.] And xafRifuwA EalaI AlOaroDi: see 1; second sentence. [And xfRf fiI Eamalihi (assumed tropical:) He relaxed, or remitted, in his work.] ― -b3- [taxofiyfN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The making a word light, or easy, of utterance, by the suppression of hemzeh, or by its conversion into A or I or tavoqiylN; opposed to taHoqiyqN and taHoqiyqN: and by making a double consonant single; opposed to tavoqiylN and taXodiydN: and by making a movent consonant quiescent; opposed to tavoqiylN and taHoriykN: each of these changes in a word is said to be liltRaxofiyfi for the purpose of alleviating the utterance. Also, in like manner, (assumed tropical:) The making a sound light to the ear, or slight; opposed to tavoqiylN. And (assumed tropical:) The suppressing of hemzeh; opposed to taHoqiyqN.]

Hwc.) ― -b2- See also 10. ＝ -A2- He was, or became, unburdened, or unencumbered, or without anything that burdened him heavily: (Msb:) or he was, or became, little burdened or encumbered, in journeying, (JK, TA,) or in his residence at home. 10. AstxfRhu contr. of Aisotavoqalahu; (S, K, TA;) He deemed it, or him, xafiyf [i. e. light, properly and tropically]. (TA.) He found it light, or easy, to carry, (Bd in xvi. 82, and TA,) and to remove. (Bd ibid.) ― -b2- AstxfR bihi (assumed tropical:) He held him, or it, (namely, a man's right, or due, or just claim, Msb, TA,) in light, or little, estimation or account, or in contempt; he contemned, or despised, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b4- AstxfRhu also signifies (assumed tropical:) He demanded, or desired, his xifRap [i. e. briskness, or promptness]; as also minohu taxafRafa↓: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) it (a thing) incited him, or excited him, to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness; syn. AisotahaXRahu; (JK and K and TA in art. hX;) and OaTorabahu: (Har p. 139:) and (assumed tropical:) he incited him, or excited him, to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness, so as to induce him to follow him in his error: (TA:) [and simply] (tropical:) he excited him to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness; (Ksh and Bd and Jel in the Kur xxx. last verse;) flurried him, or disquieted him: (Ksh and Bd ibid.:) and (tropical:) it flurried him, so that he became unsteady; said of impatience; and of a lively emotion of the heart or mind; (TA;) and of fear; (MA;) and of anger: (T in art. (Msb.) And you say, AstxfR fulaAnFA Eano raOoyihi (assumed tropical:) He incited, or excited, such a one to ignorance, foolishness, or wrong conduct, and levity, or unsteadiness, so as to make him swerve from his right sentiment, opinion, or judgment; (Az, K, TA;) as also AstfzRhu En rOyh.
