xufRN xf
xufRN A boot; (KL, PS, &c.;) a certain thing that is worn (JK, S, Msb, K, TA) upon the foot: (TA:) pl. xifaAfN (S, L, Msb, K) and OaxofaAfN [which is a pl. of pauc.]. (L, TA.) Hence, rajaEa bixufRaIo HunayonK [He returned with the two boots of Honeyn]; a saying which originated thus: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) an Arab of the desert bargained with Honeyn the UisokaAf [or maker of shoes and boots], (K,) who was of the people of El-Heereh, (TA,) for a pair of boots, until he angered him, (K,) and Honeyn desired to anger the Arab: (TA:) so when the Arab of the desert departed, Honeyn took one of his two boots and threw it down in the way, and then he threw down the other in another place; and when the Arab passed by one of them, he said, “ How like is this to the boot of Honeyn! and if the other were with it, I would take it: ” and he went on: and when he came to the other, he repented of having left the former: and Honeyn had lain in wait for him: therefore when the Arab went away in search of the former [boot], Honeyn betook himself to the camel that he rode, and what was upon it, and went away therewith; and the Arab came, having with him nothing but a pair of boots; and it was said, (K,) i. e. his people said to him, (TA,) “ What hast thou brought from thy journey? ” and he answered, jiYotukumo bixufRaIo HunayonK [“ I have brought you the two boots of Honeyn ”]: and this became a prov., applied on the occasion of one's despairing of an object of want, and returning disappointed: (K:) thus the case is related by A 'Obeyd, and by most others after him. (TA.) Accord. to ISk, Honeyn was a strong man, who asserted his relationship to Asad Ibn-Háshim Ibn-'Abd-Menáf, and came to 'Abd-El-Muttalib, wearing a pair of red boots, [formerly distinctive of kings and men of high rank,] and said, “ O my paternal uncle, I am the son of Asad the son of Háshim the son of 'Abd-Menáf: ” but 'Abd-El-Muttalib said, “ No, by the garments of my father Háshim, I know not in thee the natural qualities of Háshim; therefore return thou: ” so he returned: and it was said, rajaEa HunayonN bixufRayohi [Honeyn returned with his pair of boots]. (O, K, &c.) As to the saying of the rájiz,
yaHomilu fiI saHoqK mina AlxifaAfi
tawaAdiyFA suwRiyna mino xilaAfi
he means thereby [He carries, in] a pastor's bag (kinof) made of the leg of a xufR [or boot, wooden implements to be tied upon the dugs of she-camels, made of different trees]. (S. See xilaAfN.) ― -b2- The foot (KL, PS) of the camel; (S, Msb, KL,
PS;) the whole (majomaE) of the firosin of the camel; (JK, K, TA;) of the male and of the female; corresponding to the HaAfir [or hoof] of the horse: (TA:) and sometimes of the ostrich, (K,) because resembling that of the camel: (TA:) but of no other than these two: (K:) of the masc. gender; whereas firosinN [its syn.] is fem.: (TA:) pl. OaxofaAfN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- [And hence, by a synecdoche, for cawaAtu xufRK,] (tropical:) Camels; coupled with HaAfirN as meaning horses, [and sometimes asses or mules], (Mgh, TA, *) and ZilofN [as meaning sheep or goats or other cloven-hoofed beasts]. (TA.) You say, maAlahu xufRN walaAHaAfirN walaA ZilofN (tropical:) [meaning He possesses not camels, nor horses or asses or mules, nor sheep or goats or other cloven-hoofed beasts]. (TA.) You say also, jaMCati AlUibilu EalaIxufRK waAHidK, meaning (tropical:) The camels came following one another, the head of each [except the first] being at the tail of the next [before it], whether tied together in a file or not. (L.) ― -b4- An aged camel: (K:) [and a weak camel:] or, as some say, a bulky camel: pl. OaxofaAfN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., yuHomaI mina AlOarAaki maA lamo tanalohu OaxofaAfu AlUibili [Of the trees called ArAk, what the aged and weak of camels cannot reach may be prohibited]: i. e. what is near, thereof, to the place of pasturage is not to be prohibited, but is to be left for the aged and weak camels, that cannot go far in search of pasture: (As, O, Msb:) or what camels cannot reach (Msb, TA) by means of their AxfAf, (Msb,) by walking thereto, (TA,) may be prohibited: (Msb, TA:) or it means, what camels cannot reach with their heads may be prohibited [to be shaken or beaten off for them]. (Mgh.) ― -b5- (tropical:) The sole, or part that touches the ground, of the foot of a man. (M, K, TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A tract of ground (S, A, O, L) more rugged, (S, O, L,) or longer, (A,) than such as is termed naEolN: (S, A, O, L:) or a rugged piece of ground. (K.)

xafaXN Smallness of the eye, (S, A, K,) or of the eyes, (Msb,) and weakness in the sight, by nature: (S, A, Msb, K:) or a natural narrowness in the eye: (TA:) and sometimes it is a disease: (S, Msb: *) or a corrupt state in the eyelids, (Kh, A, K,) and redness, which causes the eyes to become narrow, (Kh,) without pain, (Kh, A, K,) and without ulceration: (Kh:) and (so in the S and A and Msb, but in the K “ or ”) nyctalopia; or the seeing by night, (S, A, K,) but not by day: (S, K:) or the seeing by night more than by day: (Msb:) and in a cloudy day, but not in a clear one: (S, A, Msb, K:) and sometimes, (tropical:) the being affected with ophthalmia, or inflammation of the eye with pain and swelling. xafRaAqN [Flapping, or flapping much;] applied to a wing. (TA.) And applied to a bird, [because of the sound of its wings,] meaning Flying. (TA.) ― -b2- OaroDN xafRaAqapN A land in which the saraAbi [or mirage] quivers. (TA.) ― -b3- xafRaAqu Alqadami A man broad in the fore part of the foot: (S, K:) or broad in the under part, or sole, of the foot: (JK, TA:) or having the foot light upon the ground; not heavy, nor slow: (IAar, TA:) or quick in step, beating the ground much with the foot so that it makes a sound of flapping to be heard by reason of the vehemence of his tread. (Ham p. 173.) ― -b4- xafRaAqapu AlHaXaI A woman lank in the belly. (S, L, K, TA.)

xafRaAqapN fem. of xafRaAqN [q. v.]. ― -b2- [Hence,] AlxafRaAqapu The anus. (IDrd, K.)

xaAfiqN xAfq
xaAfiqN [act. part. n. of xafaqa in all its senses]. It is applied as an epithet to the saraAb [or mirage, as meaning Quivering]: and so xafuwqN↓ [but with an intensive signification]. (JK.) And [the fem. pls.] xawaAfiqu and xaAfiqaAtN are used as [substs.] signifying Banners, or standards, [because of their fluttering.] (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, Moving, or shaking, his head, or bending it [down, or nodding], when drowsy, or dozing. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] raOayotu fulaAnFA xaAfiqa AlEayoni (tropical:) I saw such a one with the eye cast down, and depressed in the head [as though drowsy]. (TA.) ― -b4- OayRaAmu AlxaAfiqaAti Certain days in which the stars [in great number] became scattered (tanaAvarato [in the CK, erroneously, tanASarato]), [causing a belief that the day of judgment was at hand, (see Kur lxxxii. 2,)] in the time of Abu-l-'Abbás and Aboo-Jaafar, (K, TA,) the 'Abbásees. (TA.) ― -b5- AlxaAfiqaAni is a term applied to The place of sunrise and the place of sunset, (AHeyth, JK, Mgh, K,) by the attribution of predominance to the latter; for AlxaAfiqu, meaning the disappearing, is applied to the place of sunset: (AHeyth, TA:) or the horizon (Oufuq) of the place of sunrise and that of the place of sunset; (S, K;) accord. to Lth (TA) and ISk, (S, TA,) because the night and the day for the most part pass away (yaxofiqaAni↓, so in the T and S, but in the K, erroneously, yaxotalifaAni, TA) between them, (T, TA,) or in them: (S, TA:) or the two [opposite] extremities of the heaven and the earth: (As, Sh, K:) or the end of the heaven and earth: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, K:) or two vacant spaces (hawaAMni) next to the two [opposite] sides of the earth: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) and xawaAfiqu AlsRamaMCi signifies The regions of the heaven from which issue the four [cardinal] winds. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, K.) One says, maAbayona AlxaAfiqayoni mivoluhu There is not between the place of sunrise and the place of sunset the like of him. (TA.) And OaloHaqahu QllRehu biAlxaAfiqi and biAlxawaAfiqi [May God remove him to the place of sunset and to the four cardinal regions of the heaven or earth]. (TA.) ― -b6- xaAfiqN also signifies A place void of, or unoccupied by, any one to cheer by his presence. (TA.)

xayofaqN, applied to a desert (falaApN), Wide, (S, K,) in which the saraAb [or mirage] quivers. (S.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse or mare, (JK, S, K, TA,) mostly to a female, (IDrd, TA,) and a she-camel, (IDrd, JK, K,) and a male ostrich, (IDrd, S, K,) Quick, or swift: (K:) or very quick or swift: (JK, S:) and xanofaqiyqN↓, (so in some copies of the K,) or xayofaqiyqN↓, (so in other copies of the K and in the JK and O, and so written by A'Obeyd,) each correct, the n in the former and the I in the latter augmentative, (MF, TA,) is applied to a she-camel and a male ostrich, (JK, K,) in the former sense, as is also xayofaqN, (JK,) or in the latter sense. (A'Obeyd, K.) Accord. to some, applied to a she-camel, it signifies Lean, or lank, in the belly; having little flesh. (TA.) And, applied to a woman, Long in the rufogaAni [app. here meaning the two inguinal creases], slender in the bones, and wide in step. (El-Kilábee, K.) Also, applied to a woman, Quick and bold; and so xanofaqiyqN↓: (TA:) or the latter, so applied, signifies light, active, or agile, and bold: and Sb says that the n in it is augmentative; deriving it from xafoqu AlrRiyHi [explained above: see 1]. (S.) ― -b3- Also i. q. daAhiyapN [meaning either A calamity, or, as an epithet, very cunning]; (AA, K;) and so xanofaqiyqN↓; which latter occurs in a verse, variously related, applied to a child brought forth by a woman who had been in labour a whole night; (S, K;) meaning dAhyp; or, as some explain it, in this instance, meaning imperfectly formed; (TA;) [and is also used as a corroborative of dAhyp; for] one says daAhiyapN xanofaqiyqN↓ [a great, or severe, calamity; or extremely cunning]. (S.)

(K.)

xayofaqiyqN xyfqyq
xayofaqiyqN: see xayofaqN: ＝ -A2- and see also xanofaqiyqN.

maxofaqN mxfq
maxofaqN A place, (TA,) or a level land, (As, TA,) in which the saraAb [or mirage] quivers. (As, TA.) [See also xifoqapN.] ― -b2- And [the pl.] maxaAfiqu signifies The places of setting [of stars]: and is used as [a sing.,] meaning the place of setting of a star. (Ham p. 152.) [See also xaAfiqN.]

maxofuwqN A man (T) having a fluttering, or palpitation, of the heart. (IDrd, * T, K. *) ― -b2- And Possessed, bereft of reason, or insane; syn. majonuwnN: (AA, K:) fem. with p. (AA.)

1 xafaA xf xfA
1. xafaA, (S, K,) aor. yaxofuw, (S,) inf. n. xafowN (S, K) and xufuwRN; (ISd, K;) and xafaI, aor. yaxofiI, inf. n. xFfoIN; (S, TA;) and xafiIa, aor. yaxofaI, inf. n. xafoIN; (Kr, TA;) said of lightning, It flashed, gleamed, or shone, (S, K, TA,) faintly, extending sideways in the adjacent tracts of cloud: when it flashes, gleams, or shines, a little, and then ceases, not extending sideways, it is termed wamiyDN; and when it cleaves the clouds, and extends high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left, it is termed EaqiyqapN: (S, TA:) accord. to A 'Obeyd, xafowN signifies the extending of lightning sideways in the tracts of the sky. (TA.) ― -b2- And xafaA, (K,) inf. n. xafowN, (TA,) It (a thing) appeared. (K, TA. [See also xafiIa, in art. xfI.])

xifowapN xfI xfwh xfwp
xifowapN i. q. xifoyapN, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, xafiyRap,]) an inf. n. of xafiytu lahu as syn. with Aixotafayotu, (K * and TA in art. xfI, q. v.,) the w and I being interchangeable. (TA.)

1 xafiIa xf xfI xfy xfyy
1. xafiIa, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaxofaI, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xafaMCN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) has two contr. significations: (Mgh, Msb:) It was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, [or hardly perceived or perceptible, by any of the senses, or only by the eye or ear, or by the mind; mostly] unapparent, or not apparent; (K;) [latent; obscure;] hidden, concealed, or covered; (Mgh, Msb;) [or unconspicuous; but also faint, or dim, to the sight; suppressed, or stifled, said of the voice; or low, faint, gentle, or soft, to the ear; and obscure to the mind, abstruse, recondite, occult, or covert; and secret, private, or clandestine:] and the contr., i. e. it appeared; it was, or became, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident; (Mgh, Msb;) [as also AstxfI↓: (see musotaxofK, below:)] or, accord. to some, the particle that connects it with its subject distinguishes one meaning from the other: (Msb:) you say, xafiI Ealayohi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) it (a thing, or an affair, Mgh) was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, [&c., by him;] unapparent, or not apparent, [or obscure, &c., to him;] (TA;) or hidden, or concealed, from him: (Mgh, Msb:) and xafiIa lahu it appeared to him; it was, or became, perceptible, apparent, open, &c., to him: [but see what follows:] (Mgh, Msb:) whence the sayings of Mohammad, [app. the Hanafee Imám,] referring to spoils, faxafiI lahumo Oano yacohabuwA bihaA wayakotumuwhaA Oahola AlXRiroki, i. e. It appeared [to them that they should go away with them, or take them away, and conceal them from the believers in a plurality of gods], and xafiIa lahumo Oano yuxorijuwhaA UilaI daAri AlUisolaAmi [It appeared to them that they should take them forth to the territory of El-Islám]: but this is said only in relation to that which appears from a state of concealment or from a hidden quarter. (Mgh.) [Hence,] bariHa AlxafaMCu The affair, or case, became manifest: (S, K:) or the state of concealment departed, or ceased; but the former explanation is better: or, as some say, AlxafaMCu↓ here signifies the secret; and the meaning is, the secret became apparent: (TA:) or, lit., the low ground became high and apparent; meaning (assumed tropical:) what was concealed became revealed. (Har pp. 133-4. [See also art. brH.]) [And EalaI xafaMCK means Covertly, secretly, privately, stealthily, or clandestinely. (See also what follows.)] ― -b2- xafiytu lahu, aor.
xafaIa
, (K,) inf. n. xufoyapN and xifoyapN (Msb, K) and xifowapN, (K,) the I and w being interchangeable, (TA,) signifies Aixotafayotu↓ [i. e. I made myself unapparent to him, lurked, or lay hid or in ambush, for him; cloaked, or disguised, myself to him; hid, or concealed, myself from him]: (K:) [for] AxtfI signifies he hid, or concealed, himself, (Fr, * El-Fárábee, JK, * Msb, K,) minohu from him; (TA;) as also AstxfI↓, (Fr, * JK, * Msb, K,) and AxfI↓, (IAar, K,) and txfRI↓ also is syn. with AxtfI [in this sense]: (Z, TA:) or you say, Aisotaxofayotu↓ minoka, meaning I hid, or concealed, myself from thee; but not Aixotafayotu↓: (IKt, Th, S, Msb:) or AxtfI↓ in the sense of xafiIa is not of high authority, nor is it disallowed, (Az, Msb, TA,) but AstxfI↓ is more usual. (Az, TA.) You say, faEalotuhu xufoyapF and xifoyapF [I did it covertly, secretly, privately, stealthily, or clandestinely]. (Msb) And qutila xfoyapF and xifowapF [He was slain covertly, secretly, &c.]. (JK.) And yaOokuluhu xifowapF [lit. He eats it covertly, &c.,] means he steals it. (K.) In the saying in the Kur [vii. 53], AudoEuw rabRakumo taDarRuEFA waxufoyapF, the meaning [of the last word] is, Submissively, devoting yourselves to his service: or, accord. to Zj, adhering to his service in your minds: or, accord. to Th, celebrating Him in your minds: or, accord. to Lh, in quietness, and stillness: (TA:) or secretly; and so in the similar passage in the Kur vi. 63. (Jel, and so Bd on this latter passage.) xufoyapN is from Oaxofayotu AlSRawota [explained below in this paragraph]: (JK:) the intrans. v. whereof is AxtfI↓ [signifying It (the voice) was, or became, suppressed, or stifled; or low, faint, gentle, or soft; like xafiIa, which is more common]. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A2- xafaAhu, aor. yaxofiyhi, (JK, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xafoIN (JK, Msb, * K) and xufiIRN, (K,) also has two contr. significations: (S, Msb, TA:) He made it perceptible, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: (JK, S, Msb, K:) and he hid, or concealed, or covered, it; (S, Msb, K; [in this latter sense, erroneously written in the CK xafRAhu;]) as also AxfAhu↓: (S, K:) or, accord. to some, this latter has the latter meaning; and the former verb has [only] the former meaning: but accord. to other, the reverse is the case: (Msb:) or, accord. to Aboo-' Alee El-Kálee, the former verb has the former meaning only; and ↓the latter verb has both meanings: (IB, TA:) ↓the latter is also explained as signifying he removed its xifaMC, i. e. its covering: (TA:) and the former, as meaning he made it to come forth from a state of concealment: (JK:) and he drew it forth; (K;) as also AxtfAhu↓. (S, Msb, K.) One says, xafaI AlmaTaru AlfaOora The rain made the rats, or mice, to come forth from their holes. (S.) It is said in the Kur [xx. 15], UinRa AlsRaAEapa MtiyapN OakaAdu OaxofiyhaA, (JK, TA,) or OuxofiyhaA↓, (JK, S, TA,) accord. to different readers: (TA:) the former means [Verily the hour of the resurrection is coming:] I am almost making it to appear: (JK, TA:) and the latter, I am almost removing that which conceals it: (S, IJ, TA:) or I almost conceal it: (JK, TA:) or, as Ubeí reads it, OakaAdu OuxofiyhaA mino nafoisI [I almost conceal it from Myself]: and Fr says [that the meaning is], I almost conceal it from Myself, and how then should I acquaint you therewith? (TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the flight [from Mekkeh], AxfI EanRaA xabaraka [written without the vowel-signs, so that it may be AixofiI or OaxofiI↓,] i. e. Conceal thou thine information from such as may ask thee respecting us. (TA.) And in another trad., kaAna yaxofiI Sawotahu biOaniynK, thus with fet-h to the I, meaning He used to make his voice perceptible [or audible, with moaning]. (TA.) And you say, AlSRawota Oaxofayotu↓ [meaning I suppressed, or stifled, the voice; or made it low, faint, gentle, or soft]. (Lth, JK, TA.) [And AlkalaAma AxfI↓ He uttered speech, or the speech, in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, tone; he spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner; lit. he made speech, or the speech, to be low, &c.] ＝ -A3- xafaI, aor. yaxofiI; and xafiIa, aor. yaxofiI; inf. n. of each xafoIN; said of lightning: see xafaA, in art. xfw.

(K.) [See also xafaMCN.]

(TA.) And [in the same phrase, accord. to some,] Low, or depressed, ground. (TA.)

OaxofiyapN. (Lth, JK, S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oaxofiyapu AlnRawori The calyxes of flowers: (K:) sing. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- And Oaxofiyapu AlkaraA [The coverings of drowsiness; meaning] the eyes. (K.)

xafiIRN xf xfI xfy xfyy
xafiIRN i. q. xaAfK↓; (S, K;) applied to a thing; (S;) i. e. Unperceived or imperceptible, [or hardly perceived or perceptible, by any of the senses, or only by the eye or ear, or by the mind; mostly] unapparent, or not apparent; (K;) [latent; obscure; hidden, or concealed; or unconspicuous; but also faint, or dim, to the sight; suppressed, or stifled, applied to the voice; or low, faint, gentle, or soft, to the ear; and obscure to the mind, abstruse, recondite, occult, or covert; and secret, private, or clandestine: see 1, first sentence:] pl. xafaAyaA. (S.) [You say najomN xafiIRN A dim star or asterism. And makaAnN xafiIRN An obscure, or a concealed, place. And SawotN xafiIRN A low, faint, gentle, or soft, voice or sound.] And AimoraOapN xafiyRapu AlSRawoti A woman having a low, faint, gentle, or soft, voice. (TA in art. xfD.) And some of the Arabs say, (Yaakoob, S,) UicaA Hasuna mina AlmaroOapi xafiyRaAhaA Hasuna saAYiruhaA, meaning [When] the voice and the foot-mark of the woman [are good, or pleasing, the rest, or the whole, of what pertains to her is good, or pleasing]: (Yaakoob, JK, S, K:) for when her voice is soft, or gentle, this indicates her being bashful, or shy; and when her foot-marks are near together, and firmly impressed, they indicate that she has [large] buttocks and haunches. (Yaakoob, S.) One says also, laqiytuhu xafiyRFA I met him covertly, secretly, privately, or clandestinely. (TA.) [And maXaI miXoyapF xafiyRapF He walked with a soft, or stealthy, gait.] ― -b2- Also One who secludes himself from [other] men; whose place is concealed from them. (TA.)

(JK, TA) ― -b2- And A tangled, or luxuriant, or dense, thicket, (JK, K, TA,) which the lion takes as his covert: (JK, TA:) or xafiyRap is the name of a certain place frequented by lions; (S, IB;) and is properly imperfectly decl., so that you say Ousuwdu xafiyRapa; but it may be perfectly decl. in poetry. (IB.) ＝ -A2- Also A slight taint, or infection, or a touch, or stroke, of insanity: so in the phrase bihi xafiyRapN In him is a slight taint, &c., of insanity. (Ibn-Menádhir, S, K. *)

And one says, huwa maA OadoriI OaIRu xaAfiyapa↓, (K and TA voce xaAlifap, q. v.,) or xaAfiyapK↓, (CK ibid.,) I know not what one of mankind he is. (K.) ― -b5- xaAfiI AlguraAbi: see the last sentence but one in the next paragraph.

xaAfiyapN contr. of EalaAniyapN [app. meaning that it signifies A state of being unapparent or not apparent, covert, secret, private, or clandestine: though explained in the TK (followed by Freytag) as an epithet applied to a man, meaning whose actions are always covert]. (TA.) xanojarN mivolu xaAfiyapi AlnRasori [A dagger like the xAfyp of the vulture], occurring in a trad., means a small xnjr. (TA.) One says also xaAfiyapu AlguraAbi [The xAfyp of the crow]: and the pl. is [sometimes expressed by using the coll. gen. n., saying] AlguraAbi xaAfiI↓. (S, TA.)

AlxaAfiyaMCu: see xaAfK.

2 xlRl OasonaAnahu c
2. xlRl OasonaAnahu, inf. n. taxoliylN, [He picked his teeth;] he extracted the remains of food between his teeth with a xilaAl [or toothpick]; (Msb, K, * in which latter the pass. form of the verb is mentioned;) and so txlRl↓, alone; (T, S, * O, TA;) but accord. to the K, you say, txllRehu [he extracted it], meaning the remains of food between the teeth. (TA.) ― -b2- xlRl AlXRaEara biAlmuXoTi [He separated the hair with the comb; he combed the hair]. (Mgh voce taXoriyHN.) ― -b3- xlRl liHoyatahu, (S, * Msb, K,) and OaSaAbiEahu, (S, * K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He made the water to flow into the interstices of his beard, (Msb, K,) and of his fingers or toes, (K,) in the ablution termed wuDuwoC; (S, TA;) and txlRl↓, alone, signifies the same. (S.) It (the former) is as though it were taken from taxalRalotu Alqawoma meaning “ I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people. ” (Msb.) Hence the trad., xalRiluwA OaSaAbiEakumo laA tuxalRalahaA naArN qaliylN buqoyaAhaA [Make ye the water to flow into the interstices of your fingers or toes, lest fire that shall spare little be made to flow into their interstices]. (TA.) ― -b4- xllRehu kilosFA He put SaAruwj [or kilos, i. e. quick lime, &c.,] into the interstices of its (a building's) stones. (TA in art. kls.) ― -b5- xlRl AlqivRaMCa, and AlbiTRiyxa, inf. n. as above, He investigated the state of the cucumbers, and the melons, or water-melons, so as to see every one that had not grown, and put another in its place. (AA, TA.) ― -b6- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- And see 1 again, last sentence. ＝ -A3- xlRl, inf. n. taxoliylN, said of wine and of other beverages, It became acid, or sour; and spoiled: (K:) or, said of XaraAb [i. e. wine and the like], (Mgh,) or of nabiyc [i. e. must and the like], (Msb,) or of expressed juice, (K,) it became vinegar; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as also AxtlR↓; (Lth, K;) but this is disallowed by Az; (TA;) and txlRl↓; but this is of the language of the lawyers; (Mgh;) or, said of nbyc, this last signifies it was made into vinegar: (Msb:) or xlRl, said of XrAb, signifies it spoiled, (JK, T,) and became vinegar. (T.) ＝ -A4- taxoliylN also signifies The making vinegar; (S;) and so AixotilaAlN↓; (K;) i. e. of the expressed juice of grapes and of dates. (TA.) You say, xlRl Alxamora, (K,) or AlXRaraAba, (Mgh,) or AlnRabiyc, inf. n. as above, (Msb,) the verb being trans. as well as intrans., (Mgh, Msb, K,) and AlnRabiyca txlRl↓, (TA,) He made the wine, or beverage, or must or the like, into vinegar. (Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) ＝ -A5- And xlRl Albusora He put the full-grown unripe dates in the sun, and then sprinkled them (naDaHahu, in some copies of the K nDjh,) with vinegar, and placed them in a jar: (K:) so in the M: and in like manner, other things than busor; as cucumbers, and cabbage, and baAcanojaAn [q. v.], and onions. (TA.) [Accord. to modern usage, the verb signifies He pickled.]

3. xAlRhu, (JK, Mgh, K,) inf. n. muxaAlRapN and xilaAlN (JK, S, K) and [quasi-inf. n.] xulRapN↓, (JK,) He acted, or associated, with him as a friend, or as a true, or sincere, friend. (JK, S, * Mgh, K.) laA bayoEN fiyhi walaA xilaAlN, in the Kur [xiv. 36], is said to mean [Wherein shall be no buying or selling] nor mutual befriending: or [and no friends, or true friends, for], as some say, xilaAlN is here pl. of xulRapN↓, like as jilaAlN is pl. of julRapN. (TA.)

4 OaxalRa c and OuxilRa
4. OaxalRa OuxilRa and OuxilRa bihi: see 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- OxalRa bihi He (a man) fell, or stopped, short in it; fell short of accomplishing it; fell short of doing what was requisite, or due, or what he ought to have done, in it, or with respect to it; or flagged, or was remiss, in it; namely, a thing; syn. qaSRara fiyhi; (Msb;) as, for instance, in belief, and in confession thereof, and in works: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 2:) he left it, neglected it, omitted it; or left it undone: (Har p. 402:) or i. q. OajoHafa bihi [app. as meaning he was near to falling short of accomplishing it, or of doing what was requisite in it; or was near to being remiss in it]; namely, a thing. (K.) ― -b3- He failed of fulfilling his compact with him, or his promise to him. (K.) ― -b4- He became absent, or he absented himself, from it; he left, abandoned, or quitted, it; namely, a place &c. (K.) You say, AxlR bimarokazihi He (a man, S, or a horseman, Mgh) left, abandoned, or quitted, his station (S, Mgh) which the commander had appointed him. (Mgh.) And AxlR bihimo He became absent, or he absented himself, from them. (JK.) ― -b5- AxlR AlwaAliI biAlvRuguwri The prefect made the frontiers to be kept by a small body of troops. (K.) ＝ -A2- OaxalRa Uilayohi: see 8. ＝ -A3- AxlRhu He made him, or caused him, to want, or be in need. (JK, S, K.) You say, maA OaxalRaka UilaI hecaA What has made thee, or caused thee, to want, or be in need of, this? (S.) And maA OaxalRaka QllRehu Uilayohi What has God made thee, or caused thee, to want, or be in need of? (Lh, K.) ＝ -A4- AxlR AlOibila: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A5- AxlRwA, (K,) inf. n. UixolaAlN, (TA,) Their camels pastured upon what is termed xulRap. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, AxlR said of a man signifies (assumed tropical:) Oaxaca mino qubulK [i. e. He took frontways]: opposed to OaHomaDa [and HamRaDa, q. v.], meaning Oaxaca mino duburK. (TA.) ＝ -A6- AxlRt AlnRaxolapu The palmtree produced bad fruit. (A' Obeyd, JK, S, K.) ― -b2- And The palm-tree produced dates such as are termed xalaAl: [like OabolaHat from balaHN:] thus it bears two contr. significations. (K.)

You say, taxalRalotu Alqawoma I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people. (S, M, Msb, K. *) And taxalRaluwA AldRiyaAra [They went through the midst of the houses]. (S in art. jws.) And txlRl AlrRamola He passed through the sands. (Az, TA.) And txlRl Alqaloba
(assumed tropical:) [It penetrated the heart]; said of admonition. (TA in art. bhm.) And txlRl AlAXRaIoCu The thing [i. e. anything] went, or passed, through. (JK, * S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, It intervened; said of a time &c. And hence the phrase mino gayori taxalRuli Without interruption.] ― -b3- And txlRl AlmaTaru The rain was confined to a particular place, or to particular places; was not general. (S, K.) ― -b4- See also 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b5- txlRl AlrRuTaba He sought out the fresh ripe dates in the interstices of the roots of the branches (M, K) after the cutting off of the racemes of fruit. (M.) And txlRl AlnRaxolapa He picked the dates that were among the roots of the branches of the palm-tree; as also takarRabahaA. (AHn, TA.) ― -b6- For other significations, see 2, in four places.

8. AxtlR [primarily signifies] It had interstices, breaks, chinks, or the like. (MA. [See xalalN.]) ― -b2- [And hence,] It was, or became, shaky, loose, lax, uncompact, disordered, unsound, corrupt, (Msb,) faulty, or defective, (KL, Msb,) [and weak, or infirm, (see xalalN and muxotalRN,)] said of a thing or an affair; (KL;) it became altered for the worse. (Msb.) [You say, AxtlR mizaAjuhu His constitution, or temperament, became in a corrupt or disordered state. And AxtlR alone He was, or became, disordered in temper; (see taHamRaDa;) but this seems to be from the same verb said of a camel; (see AxtlRt AlOibilu, below;) for the camel becomes disordered in his stomach by pasturing long upon xulRap, without shifting to HamoD. And AxtlR Eaqolahu His mind, or intellect, was, or became, unsound, or disordered.] And AxtlR Oamoruhu [His affair, or state, was, or became, unsound, corrupt, or disordered]; (S, voce AiDoTaraba;) i. e. waqaEa fiyhi Alxalalu. (JM.) ― -b3- He was, or became, lean, meagre, or emaciated; (KL;) and so AxtlR jisomuhu. (S.) See 1, first sentence. ― -b4- See also xalRa as syn. with OaxalRa or OuxilRa &c., near the beginning of the first paragraph. [Hence,] AxtlR Uilayohi He wanted it, or needed it; (S, Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (S, Msb;) as also Alyh OaxalRa↓: (TA:) whence the saying of Ibn-Mes'ood, Ealayokumo biAlEilomi faUinRa OaHadakumo laAyadoriI mataI yuxotalRu Uilayohi [Keep ye to the pursuit of knowledge, or science; for any one of you knows not, or will not know, when it will be wanted, or needed]; i. e., when men will want, or need, that [knowledge] which he possesses. (S.) You say also, AuxotulRa UilaI fulaAnK Such a one was wanted, or needed. (JK.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, in two places. ＝ -A3- AxtlRhu biAlrRumoHi, and biAlsRahomi: and yaxotalRu AlvRaworu Alkaloba biqaronihi: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- AxtlR also signifies He served together. (KL.) ― -b3- AuxotulRa said of herbage: see xulRapN, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A4- AxtlR AlmakaAnu The place had in it xulRap [q. v.]. (MA.) ― -b2- And AxtlRt AlUibilu The camels were confined in [pasturage such as is termed] xulRap. (K.)

xalRN xl
xalRN a word of well-known meaning, (S, Msb.) Vinegar; i. e. expressed juice of grapes (JK, Mgh, K) and of dates (JK) &c. (K) that has become acid, or sour: (JK, * Mgh, K:) so called because its sweet flavour has become altered for the worse (AixotalRa): (Msb:) a genuine Arabic word: (IDrd, K:) the best is that of wine: it is composed of two constituents (K) of subtile natures, (TA,) hot and cold, (K,) the cold being predominant: (TA:) and is good for the stomach; and for the gums, (K,) which it strengthens, when one rinses the mouth with it; (TA;) and for foul ulcers or sores; and for the itch; and for the bite, or sting, of venomous reptiles; and as an antidote for the eating of opium; and for burns; and for toothache; and its hot vapour is good for the dropsy, and for difficulty of hearing, and for ringing in the ears: (K: [various other properties &c. are assigned to it in the TA:]) xalRapN↓ signifies somewhat (lit. a portion) thereof; [being the n. un.:] (Aboo-Ziyád, K;) or it may be a dial. var. thereof, like as xamorapN is [said by some to be] of xamorN: (Aboo-Ziyád, TA:) see also xalRapN: the pl. is xuluwlN [meaning sorts, or kinds, of vinegar]. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., niEoma AlUidaAmu AlxalRu [Excellent, or most excellent, is the seasoning, vinegar!]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OumRu AlxalRi [The mother of vinegar; meaning] wine. (JK, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also the saying,] maA fulaAnN bixalRK walaA xamorK, (A'Obeyd, JK, S,) or maA lahu xalRN walaA xamorN, (K,) or maA Einoda fulaAnK xalRN walaA xamorN, (S, in art. xmr,) Such a one, or he, possesses neither good nor evil: (A'Obeyd, JK, S, K:) [or neither evil nor good: for] AA says that some of the Arabs make Alxamoru to be good, and AlxalRu to be evil; [and thus the latter is explained in one place, in this art., in the K;] and some of them make Alxmr to be evil, and AlxlR to be good. (Har p. 153.) ＝ -A2- I. q. HamoDN [i. e. A kind of plants in which is saltness: or salt and bitter plants: or salt, or sour, plants or trees: &c.: opposed to xulRapN]. (K.) A poet says,
layosato mina AlxalRi walaA AlximaATi
[She is not, or they are not, of the plants or trees called xlR, nor of the kind called xmAT (pl. of xamoTN)]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A road in sands: (S:) or a road passing through sands: or a road between two tracts of sand: (K:) or a road passing through heaped-up sands: (JK, K:) masc. and fem. [like TariyqN]: (S, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxolRN and [of mult.] xilaAlN. (K.) One says HayRapu xalRK [A serpent of a road in sands, &c.]; like as one says OafoEaI SariymapK. (S.) ― -b2- An oblong tract of sand. (Ham p. 709.) ― -b3- ― -b4- A vein in the neck (JK, K) and in the back, (K,) communicating with the head. (JK, TA.) ― -b5- A slit, or rent, in a garment, or piece of cloth. (K.) ＝ -A4- An old and worn-out garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, S, K, TA,) in which are streaks: (TA:) [or so vawobN xalRN:] and xaloxalN↓ and xaloxalN↓, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, K,) signify old and worn out, (JK,) or thin, (K,) like halohalN and halohaAlN. (TA.) ― -b2- A bird having no feathers: (JK:) or having few feathers. (K.) ― -b3- A man (JK, S) lean, meagre, or emaciated; (JK, S, K;) as also xaliylN↓ (K) [a meaning said in the TA to be tropical] and maxoluwlN↓ and muxotalRN↓: (TA:) or light in body: (IDrd, TA:) and [the fem.] xalRapN, applied to a woman, light (K, TA) in body, lean, or spare: (TA:) the pl. of xalRN is xuluwlN. (JK.) Also Fat: thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) and so maxoluwlN↓. (TA.) It is applied to a man and a camel. (TA.) Accord. to the K, it also signifies A [young camel such as is termed] faSiyl: (TA:) but it means such as is lean, or emaciated: (TA:) and so maxoluwlN↓, applied to a fSyl as an epithet, for a reason mentioned above, in an explanation of the phrase xalRa AlfaSiyla. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Also i. q. Aibonu maxaADK [i. e. A male camel in his second year]; (JK, K;) and so xalRapN↓; which is also applied to the female: (As, S, K:) and i. q. Aibonu labuwnK [i. e. a male camel in, or entering upon, his third year]; and in like manner xalRapN↓ is applied to the female; (JK;) or, as in the M, to a she-camel; (TA;) and, as some say, (JK,) a large she-camel: (JK, TA:) and Aibonu AlxalRapi↓ signifies the same as Aibonu AllRabuwni (T in art. bnI) or Aibonu maxaADK [or Abn AlmaxaADi]. (TA in that art.) You say, OataAhumo biquroSK kaOanRahu firosinu xalRapK↓, (S, TA,) or kaOanRahu xufRu xalRapK, (JK,) [They brought them a round cake of bread as though it were the foot of a camel in its second, or third, year,] meaning small. (JK. [In the TA, meaning samiynap (i. e. fat); but this seems to be a mistranscription.]) ＝ -A5- A cautery. (TA.)

xalRapN A road between two roads. (TA.) ― -b2- A hole, perforation, or bore, that penetrates, or passes through, a thing, and is small: or, in a general sense: (K:) or a gap, or breach, in a booth of reeds or canes. (T, TA.) [See also xalalN.] ― -b3- [And hence,] The gap that is left by a person who has died: (As, T, S, TA:) or the place, of a man, that is left vacant after his death. (K.) One says, of him who has lost a person by death, AallRehumRa Qxolufo EalaI Oaholihi bixayorK waQsodudo xalRatahu, i. e. [O God, supply to his family, with that which is good, the place of him whom they have lost,] and fill up the gap which he has left by his death. (As, T, S, * TA.) ― -b4- And The interval, or inter-
vening space, between the piercer, or thruster, and the pierced, or thrust: whence the saying, raqaEa xalRapa AlfaArisi, explained in art. rqE. (O and K and TA in that art.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] Want, or a want: poverty; (S, Msb, K;) need, straitness, or difficulty. (Lh, K.) One says, bihi xalRapN XadiydapN He has pressing, or severe, need or straitness or difficulty. (Lh, TA.) And sadRa QllRehu xalRatahu May God supply his want. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., AlxalRapu tadoEuw UilaI AlsRalRapi Want invites to theft. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- I. q. xaSolapN; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) both signify A property, quality, nature, or disposition: and a habit, or custom: (KL, PS, TK:) [and app. also a practice, or an action:] in a man: (TA: [see the latter word:]) pl. xilaAlN. (JK, Mgh, Msb, K.) One says, fulaAnN xalRatuhu HasanapN [Such a one, his nature, or disposition, is good]. (IDrd, TA.) And hence, xayoru xilaAli AlSRaAYimi AlsRiwaAku [The best of the habits, or customs, of the faster is the use of the tooth-stick]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also xulRapN. ＝ -A3- An isolated tract of sand, (Fr, K,) separate from other sands. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. haDobapN [which signifies An elevated tract of sand: but more commonly a hill; or a spreading mountain; &c.]. (JK, TA.) ＝ -A4- Wine, (K,) in a general sense: (TA:) or acid, or sour, wine: (S, K:) or wine altered for the worse, (K, TA,) in flavour, (TA,) without acidity, or sourness: (K, TA:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] xalRN↓. (K.) ― -b2- See also xalRN, first sentence. ＝ -A5- And see this last word near the end of the paragraph, in four places.

xulRapN an inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] of xaAlRahu, q. v.: (JK:) True, or sincere, friendship, love, or affection; as also xuluwlapN↓ and xulaAlapN↓ and xalaAlapN↓ and xilaAlapN↓: (S:) or all these signify a particular true or sincere friendship, or love, or affection, in which is no unsoundness, or defect, and which may be chaste and may be vitious: (K: [in which all are said to be substs., except xulRapN, as though this were properly speaking an inf. n., though having a pl., as shown below:]) [and sometimes simply friendship: see an ex. in a verse cited voce maroHabN, in art. rHb:] or xulRapN and xalRapN↓, (Msb,) or xilRN↓ and xilRapN↓, each with kesr, (K,) signify true, or sincere, friendship, or love, or affection, (Msb, K,) and brotherly conduct: the last two as used in the phrases, Uinahu lakariymu AlxilRi↓ and AlxilRapi↓ [Verily he is generous in respect of true, or sincere, friendship, &c.]: (K:) the pl. of xulRapN in the sense explained above is xilaAlN. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also xaliylN, in three places. ＝ -A2- A kind of plants or herbage [or trees]; (JK, S, Msb, K;) namely, the sweet kind thereof; (S, K;) not HamoD: (JK:) or any pasture, or herbage, that is not HamoD; all pasture, or herbage, consisting of HamoD and xulRap, and HamoD being such as has in it saltness [or sourness]: (TA:) the [kind of plant, or tree, called] Earofaj; and every tree that remains in winter: (JK:) accord. to Lh, it is [applied to certain kinds] of trees &c.: accord. to IAar, peculiarly of trees: but accord. to A'Obeyd, [shrubs, i. e.] not including any great trees: (TA:) and a certain thorny tree: also a place of growth, and a place in which is a collection, of [the plants, or trees, called] Earofaj: (K:) and any land not containing [the kind of plants, or herbage, or trees, called] HamoD; (AHn, K;) even though containing no plants, or herbage: (AHn, TA:) the pl. is xulalN: (K:) one says OaroDN xulRapN and OaraDuwna xulalN: ISh says that OaroDN xalRapN and xulalu AlOaroDi mean land, and lands, in which is no HamoD, sometimes containing [thorny trees such as are called] EiDaAh, and sometimes not containing such; and that xulRapN is also applied to land in which are no trees nor any herbage: (TA:) some say that xulRapN, as meaning the pasture, or herbage, which is the contrary of HamoD, has for a pl. xilaAlN, and then, from xilaAl is formed the pl. OaxilRapN: and some say that this last means herbage that is cut (waQjotuzR AuxotulR↓ [in which the latter verb seems to be an explicative adjunct to the former]) while green. (Ham p. 662, q. v.) They say that the xulRap is the bread of camels, and the HamoD is their fruit, (JK, T, Sudot;, TA,) or their flesh-meat, (S, TA,) or their xabiyS. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, by way of comparison, it is applied to (tropical:) Ease, or repose; freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; or tranquillity; and ampleness of circumstances: and HamoD, to evil, and war: (T, TA:) and the former, to life: and the latter, to death. (Ham p. 315.) ― -b3- Also Acid, or sour, leaven or ferment. (IAar, TA.)

OaxilRapN, (K,) i. e. pl. of xilaAlN. (TA.)

xalalN An interstice, an interspace or intervening space, a break, a breach, a chink, or a gap, between two things; (JK, S, Msb, K;) pl. xilaAlN: (JK, S, Msb:) and particularly the places, (K,) or interstices, (S,) of the clouds, from which the rain issues; as also xilaAlN↓; (S, K;) both occurring in this sense, accord. to different readings, in the Kur xxiv. 43 and xxx. 47: (S, TA:) the latter may be [grammatically] a sing. [syn. with the former], or it may be pl. of the former: (MF, TA:) and AldRaAri xilaAlu↓ signifies what is around the limits of the house; (JK, K;) or around the walls thereof; thus in the M; (TA;) and what is between the chambers thereof. (K.) You say, daxalotu bayona xalali Alqawomi and xilaAlihimo↓ [I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people]. (S, Msb.) And huwa xalalahumo and xilaAlahumo↓ (M, K) and xalaAlahumo↓ (K [but in the CK these words are with damm to the second l]) He is amid them. (M, K.) And buyuwti AlHRI jusonaA xilaAla↓, and duwri Alqawomi xilaAla↓, i. e. [We went, or went to and fro, or went round about, &c.,] amid the tents of the tribe, and in the midst of the houses of the people; like a phrase in the Kur xvii. 5. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] Shakiness, looseness, laxness, or want of compactness, and disorder, or want of order, of a thing; (Msb;) unsoundness, or corruptness, (S, Msb, *) in an affair or a thing, (S,) or of a thing; (Msb;) [a flaw in a thing;] defect, imperfection, or deficiency; (Ham p. 300;) weakness, or infirmity, in an affair, (JK, K, TA,) as though some place thereof were left uncompact, or unsound, (TA,) and in war, (JK,) and in men: (JK, K: *) and (tropical:) unsettledness in an opinion. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Alxalalu The night. (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád.)

(TA.) ― -b3- AltRaxoliyTu fiI AlOamori signifies The creating confusion, or disorder, (AlUifosaAdu,) in the affair, or case. (S.) And you say, huwa fiI taxoliyTK fiI Oamorihi [and mino Amrh, He is in a state of confusion, or disorder, in, or with respect to, his affair, or case]. (TA.) [And xlRT Ealayohi AlOamori He rendered the affair, or state, or case, confused, or disordered, or perplexed, to him. And xlRT bayona Alqawomi He created confusion, or disorder, or disturbance, among the people, or company of men.]

3 xAlThu xAlT xAlTh xAlTp
3. xAlThu, inf. n. muxaAlaTapN (S, Mgh, K) and xilaATN, (S, K,) It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, or intermingled, with it; it became incorporated, or blended, with it; syn. maAzajahu; (Mgh, K;) and xaAmarahu; (S, A, K, all in art. xmr;) [as, for instance,] water with milk. (A in art. xmr, and Mgh in the present art.) xilaATN in relation to camels, and men, and beasts, also signifies Their being mixed together. (K.) A poet says,
yaxorujona mino buEokuwkapi AlxilaATi
[They come forth from the crowding and dust (of the beasts) occasioned by the being mixed together]. (Th, TA.) And it is said in a trad., laA xilaATa walaA wiraATa (S, Mgh,) There shall be no putting together what is separate, nor separating what is put together, from fear of the poor-rate: (S:) for the Prophet made it incumbent on a person having possessed forty sheep or goats a whole year to give one sheep or goat; and so on one having possessed more thereof to the number of a hundred and twenty, to give one sheep or goat; but if they exceeded a hundred and twenty by one, two sheep or goats were to be given of them: (Az, TA:) i. e. there shall be no putting together what is separate; as, for instance, when three persons possess a hundred and twenty sheep or goats, every one of them having forty, they not having been partners for a whole year, and it being incumbent on every one of them to give a sheep or goat; and when the collector of the poorrate comes to them, they put them together, assigning them to one pastor, in order that they may not be obliged to give for them more than one sheep or goat: (K, * TA:) accord. to IAth, this is termed UixolaATN [app. a mistake for xilaATN]: nor shall there be any separating of what is put together; i. e., when there are two partners, each of them having a hundred and one sheep or goats, for which together they are bound to give three sheep or goats; and when the collector of the poorrate comes to them, they separate their sheep or goats, so that each of them shall not have to give more than one sheep or goat: [see also art. wrT:] (TA:) or xlAT signifies a man's mixing his sheep or goats when they are eighty in number with those of another which are forty in number, both together being bound to give two sheep or goats while they are separate, in order that one [only] may be taken: and wrAT, a man's giving to another the half of his sheep or goats when they are forty in number, in order that the collector of the poor-rate may not take anything: (Mgh:) or xlAT is, when there are, between two partners, a hundred and twenty sheep or goats, one of them having eighty and the other forty, and the collector of the poor-rate has taken two of these sheep or goats, the former partner's restoring to the latter the third of a sheep or goat; so that the former has had to give a sheep or goat and a third; and the latter, two thirds of one: and if the collector have taken, from the hundred and twenty, one sheep or goat, the former partner's restoring to the latter one third [in some copies of the K, erroneously, two thirds] of a sheep or goat; so that the former has had to give two thirds of a sheep or goat; and the latter, one third of one: (ISd, K, * TA:) and wrAT is deceiving, and acting dishonestly: (ISd, L, TA:) in the place of wrAT, we find, accord. to one relation, XinaAq, followed by fiI AlSRadaqapi. (TA.) ― -b2- El- 'Ajjáj contended with Homeyd El-Arkat in two poems of the metre termed rajaz ending with T, and Homeyd said, AlxilaATa yaA OabaA AlXRaEovaMCi, i. e. [Beware thou of mixing; or] do not thou mix my Ourojuwzap with thine [O father of her with the shaggy hair]; to which El-'Ajjáj replied, AlfijaAju OawosaEu mino celika yaA Qbona OaxiI [The roads are wider than to require my doing that, O son of my brother]. (AO, S.) ― -b3- xAlT AlcRiYobu Alganama [lit. signifying The wolf mixed with the sheep, or goats,] means (tropical:) the wolf fell upon the sheep, or goats: (K, TA:) the inf. n. is xilaATN. (TA.) ― -b4- xAlThA, (Az, Msb, K,) inf. n. xilaATN and muxaAlaTapN, (Az, Msb,) (tropical:) He had carnal intercourse with her; (Az, Mgh, * Msb, K;) i. e., a man with his wife, (Az, Msb,) or with a woman: (K:) the lawyers say, xAlThA muxaAlaTapa AlAizodiwaAji: (Msb:) Th explains the inf. n. xilaATN by rafavN, q. v. (TA.) Also, in like manner, with the same inf. ns., (tropical:) a stallion-camel with the female. (Lth, K, TA.) [See also 4.] IAar explains xilaATN in relation to camels as signifying (assumed tropical:) A man's coming to the nightly resting-place of another's camels, and taking thence a male camel, and making him to cover his she-camel without his owner's knowledge. (TA.) ― -b5- xAlThu AlsRahomu (assumed tropical:) [The arrow penetrated into him]. (TA.) ― -b6- xAlThu AlXRayobu [Hoariness, or whiteness, became intermixed in his hair]. (S and K in art. wxT; &c.) ― -b7- xAlThu AldRaMCu (tropical:) The disease infected, or pervaded, him; [as though commingling with him;] syn. xaAmarahu: (Sh, K:) or infected, or pervaded, his inside. (Lth, S.) ― -b8- xaAlaTa qalobahu hamRN EaZiymN (tropical:) [Great anxiety, or disquietude of mind, infected, or pervaded, his heart]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., warajaEa AlXRayoTaAnu yalotamisu AlxilaATa (tropical:) And the devil returned seeking to infect (yuxaAliT) the heart of the man praying by suggesting what was vain. (TA.) ― -b9- Alxamoru tuxaAliTu AlEaqola (tropical:) [Wine infects the intellect]. (S and K in art. xmr.) And xuwliTa fiI Eaqolihi, inf. n. xilaATN, (tropical:) [He became infected, corrupted, disordered, or confused, in his intellect.] (S, K.) And xuwliTa Eaqoluhu, and Eaqoluhu AixotalaTa↓, (tropical:) His intellect became corrupted, or disordered; (TA; [in which only the latter phrase is thus explained, though both are mentioned;]) and so AixotalaTa↓ alone: (S, K:) and nafosuhu AixotalaTato↓ (assumed tropical:) [His soul, or stomach, became disordered]: (S and K in art. xvr:) and OaxolaTa↓, said of a man, signifies the same as AxtlT. (TA.) ― -b10- xAlT Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) He mixed with the people, or company of men, in familiar, or social, inter-
course; conversed with them; or became intimate with them; or mixed with them in, or entered with them into, their affairs; syn. daAxalahumo; as also xalaTahumo↓, inf. n. xaloTN; (TA;) and xaliTa↓, like fariHa, is used in a similar manner, in the sense of xaAlaTa: (IAar, TA:) and you say also AxtlT↓ biAlnRaAsi (assumed tropical:) [he mixed, or associated, or conversed, with men]. (TA.) And xaAlaTotu fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) I mixed with such a one in familiar, or social, intercourse; conversed with him; or became intimate with him; syn. xaAmarotuhu, (A in art. xmr,) and EaAXarotuhu. (S, Msb, K, all in art. EXr.) And xAlThu fiI Oamori (assumed tropical:) [He mixed, or joined, with him in an affair]. (Mgh.) And hence xAlThu signifies (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, copartner with him; he shared with him. (Mgh.) xaAlaTahumo also signifies xaAlafahumo [evidently a mistranscription, for HaAlafahumo (assumed tropical:) He entered into a confederacy, league, compact, or covenant, with them]. (TA.) And you say also xAlT AlOumuwra (assumed tropical:) [He mixed in, engaged in, or entered into, affairs]. (S, K.)

8 AxtlT OxtlT AxtlT QxtlT
8. AxtlT It was, or became, mixed, mingled, commingled, incorporated or blended together, (S, * Msb, K,) or put together. (Msb.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, confused, confounded, indiscriminate, promiscuous, without order, disordered, or perplexed.] ― -b2- AxtlT AllRayolu biAltRuraAbi (assumed tropical:) [The night became confused, or confounded, with the dust, or earth]: (AZ, K:) and AlHaAbilu biAlnRaAbili (K) (assumed tropical:) the setter of the snare with the shooter of arrows; or the warp with the woof: (TA:) and AlmaroEaI biAlhamali (assumed tropical:) [the place of pasturage with the camels left to pasture by themselves]: (AZ, K:) and AlxaAviru biAlzRubaAdi (as in some copies of the K and in the TA) (assumed tropical:) the thick milk with the butter that had become bad, or spoiled, in the churning; or, as some say, with the thin milk; (TA;) or biAlzRabRaAdi (as in other copies of the K and in the TA) with the herb [so called], which, when it falls into the raAYib [or milk that is thick, and fit for churning, &c.], is with difficulty separated from it: (TA:) [but see art. zbd:] proverbs, alluding to the dubiousness and confusedness of an affair or a case: (K:) or the first, to the dubiousness of an affair or case; and the second, to its confusedness; and the third is applied when a people's affair or case is confused or perplexed to them; and the last relates to the confusedness of truth with falsity; and to a people whose affair or case is dubious to them, so that they do not decide upon anything. (TA.) ― -b3- [AxtlT AlZRalaAmu (assumed tropical:) The darkness, or the beginning of night, became confused, is a phrase of frequent occurrence. And so AixotilaATu AlZRalaAmi (assumed tropical:) The confusedness of the darkness, &c.] ― -b4- AxtlT Ealayohimo Oamoruhumo (assumed tropical:) [Their affair, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to them]. (S.) ― -b5- See also 3, in four places, near the end of the paragraph: and see 6. ― -b6- Said of a camel, (tropical:) He became fat; (ISh, K;) his fat and flesh becoming mixed together. (ISh.) ― -b7- Said of a horse: see 4, last sentence.

xiloTN xlT
xiloTN Anything that mixes, mingles, commingles, or becomes incorporated or blended, with a thing; an admixture; (K, TA;) any kind of mixture; as a medicinal mixture; and the like: pl. OaxolaATN. (TA.) ― -b2- A kind of [mixed] perfume, (S, * Msb,) well known: (Msb:) pl. as above. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- [Sing. of AxlAT in the term] OaxolaATu AlUinosaAni The four humours of man, (K, TA,) which are the constituents of his composition; (TA;) namely, AlmirRataAni [the black bile and the yellow bile] and Albalogamu [the phlegm] and AldRamu [the blood]. (TA in art. mzj.) ― -b4- Mixed dates of various sorts: pl. as above. (K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A man who mixes with others, and manifests love to them; (TA;) and xiloTapN a woman who does so: (K, * TA:) and the former, (IAar, TA,) or xaloTN↓, (K,) or this signifies [simply] muxaAliTN, [see 3,] and is an inf. n. used in that sense, (TA,) and xaliTN↓, (Lth, K,) and xuluTN↓, (K,) which is mentioned by Sb and explained by Seer, (TA,) (tropical:) a man who mixes with others, (K, TA,) and manifests love to them, (TA,) and behaves in a blandishing manner to them, and one who casts his women and goods among men; (K, TA;) and xaliTapN↓ in like manner, applied to a female. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A man of mixed race: or a bastard. (As.) You say rajulN xiloTN miloTN (assumed tropical:) A man of mixed race: (K, * TA:) or of faulty race: (O, TA:) or miloTN signifies one whose race and father are unknown. (As, TA.) And OaxolaATN mina AlnRaAsi (assumed tropical:) A medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people; or of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff, thereof; (K, * TA;) as also xaliyTN↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) and xulRayoTaI↓, (K,) and xulayoTaI↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) to these (lahunRa [in the CK lahum]) there is no sing.: (K, TA:) but xaliyTN is also a sing., and has pls., as will be seen below. (TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) Stupid; foolish; having little sense; (IAar, K;) as also xaliTN↓: (IAar, Sgh, K:) pl. of the former OaxolaATN; (IAar, TA;) with which xuluTN↓ is syn. (TA.) ― -b8- A crooked bow, and arrow; (K;) an arrow of which the wood has grown crookedly, and which ceases not to be crooked even if it have been straightened; (S;) as also xiliTN↓, applied to either of these. (K.) And in like manner, (assumed tropical:) a man; he being likened to such an arrow: and (assumed tropical:) a people, or company of men. (TA.)

xaliyTN xlyT
xaliyTN [Mixed; mingled; incorporated, or blended: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; like qatiylN &c. And hence,] (K,) or EalafN xaliyTN, (S, TA,) [The kind of trefoil called] qatR and cut straw (S, TA) mixed together: (TA:) or clay mixed with cut straw: (K, TA:) or with qatR. (K.) Also, (K,) or labanN xaliyTN, (TA,) Sweet milk mixed with sour or such as bites the tongue. (K, TA.) Also, (K,) or samonN xaliyTN, (TA,) Clarified butter in which are fat and flesh-meat. (K, TA.) [Hence also,] it is said in a trad. respecting [the beverage called] nabiyc, (TA,) nuhiIa Eani AlxaliyTayoni (S, K) fiI AlOanobicapi (S) or Oano yunobacaA (K) [Two sorts of things mixed together are forbidden in the beverages of the kind called nbyc, or that nbyc should be made of them]; i. e. it is forbidden to mix together [for making nbyc] two sorts of things; (S, TA;) meaning dried dates and raisins; (S, Mgh, K;) or fresh grapes and fresh ripe dates; (S;) or dried dates and full-grown unripe dates, (T, Mgh, K,) thoroughly cooked by fire; (Mgh;) or fresh grapes and raisins; (T, K;) and the like; because such nbyc quickly alters, and becomes intoxicating: (K:) and some hold that nbyc so made is forbidden even if it do not intoxicate. (TA.) ― -b2- See also OaxolaATN mina AlnRaAsi, voce xiloTN. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) One who mixes much with men: (Msb, TA:) [see also mixolaATN:] (assumed tropical:) one who mixes with others in familiar, or social, intercourse; or becomes intimate with them; or mixes with them in, or enters with them into, their affairs; syn. with muxaAliTN↓; (S, K;) like as nadiymN is syn. with munaAdimN, and jaliysN with mujaAlisN: (S:) pl. xulaTaMCu (S, Msb, K) and xuluTN: (S, K:) it sometimes has
these pls., but is itself both sing. and pl.: (S, TA:) and as a pl. signifies (assumed tropical:) a people, or company of men, whose affair, or case, or state, is one: (K, TA:) it occurs frequently in the poems of the Arabs because they used to assemble in the days of the fresh herbage, sundry tribes of them congregating in one place, and familiar intercourse took place between them, and when they separated and returned to their homes, it grieved them: (S, TA:) or, accord. to some, it relates only to partnership: (TA:) it signifies (assumed tropical:) a partner, copartner, or sharer; (Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) as, for instance, in merchandise, and sheep or goats: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) one who has mixed his property with that of his copartner: (Bd in xxxviii. 23:) or (assumed tropical:) one who shares in merchandise, or in a debt, or in commerce, or in neighbourship: (Ibn- 'Arafeh, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a sharer in the rights of possession, or property; such as water, and a road: (K:) the pl. is xulaTaMCu; (Mgh, TA;) occurring in the Kur xxxviii. 23: (TA:) and the sing. also signifies (assumed tropical:) a neighbour; syn. jaArN [which has also other significations here assigned to xaliyTN]; (TA;) and mujaAwirN: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) a husband: and (assumed tropical:) the son of a paternal uncle: (K:) and [the pl.] xuluTN is also explained by IAar as (assumed tropical:) i. q. mawaAlK [pl. of mawolFI, which has several of the significations here assigned to xaliyTN]: and as signifying also (assumed tropical:) neighbours of sincere friendly conduct. (TA.) It is said in a trad. (K, TA) respecting [the right termed] AlXRufoEap, (TA,) AlXRariyku OawolaI mina AlxaliyTu OawolaI mina AljaAri (assumed tropical:) The sharer in what is not divided is more deserving than the sharer in the rights of possession, or property; [and the sharer in the rights of possession, or property, is more deserving than the neighbour:] (K, TA:) [or the trad. is as follows:] AlxaliyTu mina AlXRariyki waAlXRariyku OaHaqRu mina AljaAri OaHaqRu mino gayorihi (assumed tropical:) the sharer in the thing itself that is sold has more right than the sharer in the rights thereof; and the sharer in the rights thereof has more right than the adjoining neighbour; and the adjoining neighbour has more right than another: or the meaning here is, he between whom and thyself are acts of receiving and giving, and affairs of debt and credit; not the sharer, or partner. (Mgh.) And in another trad., maA kaAna mino xaliyTayoni faUUinRahumaA yataraAjaEaAni bayonahumaA biAlsRawiyRapi (assumed tropical:) Whatever two copartners there be that have not divided the beasts [belonging to them], they shall make claim for restitution, one of the other, with equality; i. e., if they be copartners in camels for which it is incumbent to give sheep or goats, and the camels be found in the possession of one of them, and the poor-rate for them be taken from him, he shall make a claim for restitution [of what he has given above his own share] upon his copartner, with equality: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, K, TA:) the two persons are not xaliyTaAni unless they be such as drive back their beasts to the nightly resting-place, and drive them forth in the morning to the pasturage, and water them, together, and have their stallions mixed together, and have been copartners for a year; and if so, they give the poor-rate as one: otherwise, they are not xlyTAn; and they give the poor-rate as two: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, TA:) the trad. applies, for instance, to the case of two copartners who have mixed their property together; one of them having forty bulls or cows or of both kinds; and the other, thirty; and the collector of the poor-rates takes from the forty a musinRap [q. v.], and from the thirty a tabiyE [q. v.]; then the giver of the msnRp makes a claim for restitution of three sevenths thereof upon his copartner; and the giver of the tbyE, of four sevenths thereof upon his copartner; for it is incumbent to give the beasts of these two ages [the msnRp and the tbyE] when the property is not divided, as though it were the property of one: and the saying bAlsRwyp shows that if the collector of the poor-rate wrong one of them, and take from him more than the law imposes upon him, he cannot make a claim for restitution thereof upon his copartner, who is only responsible to him for the value of what falls upon him in particular, of what is incumbent by the law: and the making claim for [just] restitution, by one upon the other, shows that the partnership holds good notwithstanding the distinction of the things which compose the possessions, with such as hold this to be the case. (IAth, TA.)

1. xalaEahu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
xalaEa
, (TA,) inf. n. xaloEN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He pulled it off; syn. nazaEahu; (Mgh, Msb;) or stripped it off; or took it off; (TA;) or put it, or threw it, or cast it, off from him; (IAth;) namely, his garment, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb,) Eano badanihi from his body; (Mgh;) and his sandal, (S, Mgh, Msb,) Eano rijolihi from his foot; (Mgh;) &c.; (Msb, TA;) [as also AxtlEhu↓, as appears from its being said that] AixotilaAEN is syn. with xaloEN: (TA:) accord. to some, xaloEN is syn. with nazoEN; but accord. to Lth, (TA,) the former is like the latter, except that the former is a somewhat leisurely action. (K, TA.) The phrase in the Kur [xx. 12], faQxolaEo naEolayoka is said to be used in its proper sense, [And do thou pull off, or put off, thy sandals,] because his sandals were of the skin of a dead ass: or, as the Soofees say, it is a command to stay; like as you say to him whom you desire to stay, “ Pull off thy garment and thy boots, ” and the like; and is tropical: (TA:) or, accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) make thy heart vacant from [care for] family and property. (Bd.) ― -b2- xalaEa Ealayohi, (B, TA,) and xalaEa Ealayohi xiloEapK↓, (S, TA,) [He took off from himself, and bestowed upon him, a garment: and hence,] he bestowed upon him, or gave him, a garment; [generally meaning, a robe of honour;] the meaning of giving being inferred from the connective ElI, not from the verb alone. (B, TA.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad. respecting 'Othmán, UinRa QllReha sayuqamRiSuka qamiySFA wa UinRaka tulaASu EalaI xaloEihi, (L,) meaning (tropical:) Verily God will invest thee with the apparel of the office of Khaleefeh, (K and TA in art. qmS,) and thou wilt be urged with enticement, and solicited, to divest thyself of it. (TA in art. lwS.) ― -b4- xalaEa Alfarasu EicaArahu (assumed tropical:) The horse threw off his head-stall, or halter, and wandered about at random. (Mgh.) ― -b5- [And hence,] xalaEa EicaArahu [said of a man,] (tropical:) (tropical:) He threw off from himself his EcAr, [meaning restraint,] and acted in a wrongful and evil manner towards others, with none to repress him. (TA.) ― -b6-
xalaEa OawoSaAlahu He removed its AwSAl [meaning the bones so called, as is indicated by the context]. (TA.) ― -b7- xalaEa maAla SaAHibihi (tropical:) [He took away the property of his companion]; said of a person gambling with another. (A, TA.) ― -b8- xalaEa qaloba AlnRaAZiri Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) [It drew away the heart of the beholder towards it]; said of the best of property. (Aboo-Sa'eed.) ― -b9- xalaEa qayodahu (tropical:) [He took off his shackles; or] he released him from his shackles: and in like manner, xalaEa daAbRatahu, and xlREhaA↓, he released his beast from its shackles. (TA.) ― -b10- xalaEa AlrRiboqapa Eano Eunuqihi (tropical:) He annulled his compact, or covenant. (TA.) ― -b11- xalaEa yadFA mino TaAEapK (tropical:) He [threw off his allegiance, or] forsook obedience to his Sultán, and acted in a wrongful and evil manner towards him: (TA:) obedience being likened to a garment which a man puts off, or throws off, from him. (IAth, TA.) ― -b12- yuxolaEu AlmayRitu [for yuxolaEu Alkafanu Eani AlmayRiti, like xalaEa AldRaAbRapa (mentioned above) for xalaEa qayoda AldRaAbRapi,] The corpse shall have its grave-clothes pulled off from it. (Mgh.) ― -b13- [In like manner you say,] xalaEotu AlwaAliI Eano Eamalihi (tropical:) I removed the ruler, or governor, or the like, from his office; or deposed him. (Msb.) And xuliEa AlwaAliI (tropical:) [The ruler, or governor, or the like, was divested of his authority; or] was removed from his office; or was deposed; (S, TA;) and so AlEaAmilu [the agent, or the exactor of the poor-rates]; and Alxaliyfapu [the Khaleefeh]. (TA.) And xalaEa qaAYidahu (tropical:) [He divested his leader of his authority; or removed him from his office; or dismissed him]. (S, TA.) But IF says, This is scarcely, or never, said, except of an inferior who forsakes, or relinquishes, his superior; so that [xalaEahu signifies, in a case of this kind, (tropical:) He threw off his allegiance to him; or forsook obedience to him; like another phrase, mentioned above; and] one does not say, [or seldom says,] xalaEa AlOamiyru waAliyahu EalaI baladi kacaA [as meaning (assumed tropical:) The prince deposed his ruler over such a province, or the like]; but only, [or rather,] Eazalahu. (TA.) ― -b14- xalaEa QmoraOatahu, (Az, S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. xuloEN, with damm, (S, K, *) or this is a simple subst., (Az, Mgh, Msb,) and the inf. n. is xaloEN, (Az, Msb, TA,) and some add xilaAEN; (TA;) and xAlEhA↓, (Az, TA,) inf. n. muxaAlaEapN; (K;) [and xilaAEN seems to be another inf. n. of this latter verb, rather than of the former;] (tropical:) He divorced his wife (Az, Mgh, Msb, K) for a ransom given by her, (Msb,) or for her property given by her as a ransom to release herself from him, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or for a gift, or a compensation, from her, (K, accord. to different copies; some having bibacolK; and others, bibabadalK;) or from another: (K:) because the wife is [as] a garment to the husband, and the husband to the wife, (Az, Mgh, Msb, TA,) as is said in the Kur ii. 183: (Az, TA:) [it is also said that] taxaAluEN↓ is syn. with xuloEN: (K:) [but see 6, below:] and AixolaEohaA, occurring in a trad., is explained as signifying Divorce thou her, and quit her. (TA.) ― -b15- xalaEahu Oaholuhu (tropical:) [His family cast him off, repudiated him, or renounced him;] so that if he committed a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, they should not be prosecuted for it. (S, TA.) In the Time of Ignorance, when one said, (K, TA,) proclaiming in the fair, or festival, (TA,) yaA OayRuhaA AlnRaAsu hecaA QbonaI qado xalaEotuhu, (K, * TA,) meaning [O men, this, my son, I cast off, repudiate, or renounce, him, or] I declare myself to be clear of him; so that if he commit a crime, or an offence rendering him liable to punishment, I am not responsible; and if a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, be committed against him, I will not pursue [for redress, or retaliation]; (TA;) he was not punished afterwards for any such act committed by him: (K, TA:) this was when the person doing so feared some foul action or treachery from his son: and in like manner, they said, UinRaA qado xalaEonaA fulaAnFA [Verily we cast off, &c., such a one]. (TA.) In like manner, also, xalaEuwhu, inf. n. xaloEN, signifies (tropical:) [They cast him off, repudiated him, or renounced him, or] they declared themselves to be clear of him; meaning a confederate; so that they should not be punished for a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, committed by him, nor should he be punished for such an act committed by them. (IAth, L.) In the same sense the verb is used in the saying, naxolaEu wanatoruku mano yafojuruka [We repudiate, or renounce, or] we declare ourselves clear of, and forsake, him who disobeys, or opposes, Thee: (Mgh, TA:) or naxolaEu wanahojuru mano yakofuruka we hate, and [repudiate, or renounce, or] declare ourselves clear of, [and forsake,] him who denies, or disacknowledges, thy favour, or who is ungrateful, or unthankful, for it. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- xaluEa, aor.
xaluEa
, (K,) inf. n. xalaAEapN, (S, * TA,) (tropical:) He became cast off, repudiated, or renounced, by his family; (SaAra xaliyEFA; TA; i. e. xalaEahu Oaholuhu; S, TA;) so that if he committed a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, they were not prosecuted for it: (S, K, TA:) he became alienated or estranged [from his family]; syn. tabaAEada: (TA:) [he became vitious, or immoral; notorious for drinking and play; a gambler; or the like: see xalaAEapN, below; and see xaliyEN.] ＝ -A3- xuliEa He became affected with what is termed xaAliEN, i. e., a twisting of the EuroquwbN [or hock-tendon]. (K.)

(Msb.) ― -b2- xAlE QmoraOatahu: see 1. ― -b3- xAlEhu (tropical:) He contended with him in a game of hazard: because he who does so takes away the property of his companion. (TA.)

(tropical:) [He was, or became, loose in the joints; or] he shook his shoulder-joints and his arms, and made signs with them: (TA:) and taxoliyEN↓ also signifies a certain manner of walking, (so in some copies of the K, and in the TA,) in which one shakes his shoulder-joints and his arms, and makes signs with them: (TA:) or the walking of him whose buttocks are apart, or parted. (CK, and so in a MS. copy of the K.) [See also taxalRaja.] ― -b4- txlRE fiI AlXRaraAbi (assumed tropical:) He persisted in the drinking of intoxicating beverage, (K, * TA,) or became intoxicated, so that his joints became lax, or loose. 6. txAlEwA (tropical:) They annulled, dissolved, or broke, the confederacy, league, compact, or covenant, that was between them. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- taxaAlaEaA (tropical:) They divorced themselves, namely, a husband and his wife, for a gift, or a compensation, (bibacolK, or bibadalK, accord. to different copies of the S,) from the wife to the husband. (S.) See also xalaEa QmoraOatahu.

7. AnxlE It became pulled off, stripped off, taken off, or removed, from its place; it became displaced. (Mgh.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- Hence, AinoxalaEa qinaAEu qalobihi mino XidRapi AlfazaEi (tropical:) [He became as though] the integument of his heart became pulled off, in consequence of violence of fear, or fright. (Mgh.) And hence also, AinoxalaEa fuWaAdu AlrRajuli (tropical:) [The heart of the man became removed from its place; meaning] the man became frightened. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [AnxlE AlEuDowu, or AlEaZomu, The limb, or the bone, became dislocated. See Ainoxaraja. ― -b4- AnxlE Eano Eamalihi (tropical:) He (a ruler, or governor, or the like,) became removed from his office; became deposed. See 1.] ― -b5- AnxlE mino maAlihi (tropical:) He became stripped of his property, like as a man is stripped of his garment. (TA.)

8. AixotalaEato (S, Mgh, K) mino zawojihaA, (Mgh,) (tropical:) She became divorced from her husband (S, Mgh, K) for a gift, or a compensation, from her, (S, K, accord. to different copies; some having bibacolK; and others, bibabadK;) or from another, (K,) or for her property given by her as a ransom to release her from him. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AxtlEhu: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AxtlEwhu (tropical:) They took his property: (K, TA:) from the "Nawá- dir el-Aaráb." (TA.)

xaloEN Flesh-meat cooked with seeds that are used for seasoning, then put into a receptacle of skin, (S, K, *) which is called qarofN: (S:) or flesh-meat cut into strips or oblong pieces, and dried, or salted, and dried in the sun, roasted, (K, TA,) and, as Lth says, (TA,) put into a receptacle with its melted grease: (K, * TA:) or flesh-meat having its bones pulled out, then cooked, and seasoned with seeds, and put into a skin, and
used as provision for travelling: (Z, TA:) and xaliyEN↓, also, signifies flesh-meat of which the bones have been pulled out, and which is seasoned with seeds, and laid up (yurofaEu) [for future use]: (TA:) and xawolaEN↓, flesh-meat which is boiled in vinegar, and then carried in journeys. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A state of dislocation of the joint, of the arm or hand, or of the leg or foot; its becoming displaced, without separation; as also xalaEN↓. (TA.)

xuloEN xlE xlEp
xuloEN [accord. to the S, and app. accord. to the K, and inf. n., (see xalaEa QmoraOatahu,) or] a simple subst., signifying (tropical:) The act of divorcing a wife (Az, Mgh, Msb) for a ransom given by her, (Msb,) or for her property given by her as a ransom to release her from her husband, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or for a gift, or a compensation, from her; or from another: (K: see 1:) IAth says that it annuls the return to the wife unless by means of a new contract: accord. to EshSháfi'ee, there is a difference of opinion respecting it; whether it be an annulment of the marriage, or a divorcement: [if the latter, it is not irrevocable unless preceded by two divorcements:] sometimes it is called by the latter term. (TA.) [See also xuloEapN.]

xalaEN xlE xlEp
xalaEN: see xaloEN.

xuloEapN A state of divorcement [for a ransom given by the wife, or for her property given by her as a ransom to release her from her husband, or] for a gift, or a compensation, from the wife, (S, * K,) or from another. (K.) [See 8: and see also xuloEN.] You say, waqaEato bayonahumaA AlxuloEapu [Divorcement, or] separation, [for a ransom, &c. or] for [a gift, or] a compensation, took place between them two. (TK.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) The best, or choice part, of property, or of camels or the like; (Aboo-Sa'eed, S Sgh, K;) so called because it takes away the heart of him who looks at it; (Aboo-Sa'eed;) as also xiloEapN↓. (Aboo-Sa'eed, Sgh, K.) ＝ -A3- (assumed tropical:) Weakness in a man. (TA.)

xiloEapN Any garment which one pulls off, or takes off, from himself: (TA:) and particularly, (TA,) a garment which is bestowed upon a man, [generally meaning a robe of honour,] (K, * TA,) whether it be put upon him or not: (TA:) or a gift, or free gift, [of any kind,] which a man bestows upon another: (Msb:) or a sewed garment: (KL:) pl. xilaEN. (Msb, TA.) You say, xalaEa Ealayohi xiloEapF [explained above]: see 1, near the beginning. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also xuloEapN.

xulaAEN xlAE
xulaAEN (assumed tropical:) An affection resembling what is termed xabalN [q. v.], (K, TA,) and insanity, or diabolical possession, (TA,) which befalls a man: (K, TA:) or weakness, and fear or fright: (TA:) and xawolaEN↓ and xayolaEN↓ [in like manner] signify (tropical:) fear, or fright, affecting the heart, (S, K, TA,) occasioning evil imagination, and weakness, (TA.) as though it were a touch of insanity, or of diabolical possession, (S, K, TA,) in a man, and in the heart. (S.)

xaliyEN xlyE
xaliyEN Pulled off; stripped, or taken, off; put, or thrown, or cast, off; i. q. maxoluwEN↓; applied [to a garment, and a sandal, or the like, or], accord. to some, to anything. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, used as a subst., A cast-off, or] an old, and wornout, garment. (K, TA.) You say, huwayakosuwhu mino xaliyEihi [He clothes him with some of his cast-off, or old, and worn-out, apparel]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also xaloEN. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A person whose property is won from him in a game of hazard; as also maxoluwEN↓. (L.) ― -b5- xaliyEu AlEicaAri (assumed tropical:) (assumed tropical:) A man who does and says what he pleases; not caring, nor fearing God nor the blame of men; like the beast that has no halter on its head. (Har p. 676.) Also applied to a woman in a state of estrangement [from her husband; lit., Having her headstall, or halter, pulled off, or thrown off; she being likened to a mare; meaning, (assumed tropical:) (assumed tropical:) without restraint]; having none to command or forbid her: [see 1:] incorrectly written xaliyEapu AlEicaAri; for xlyE is here of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: or you say xaliyfapN without mentioning the EcAr, from xalaEapN, like ZariyfapN and laTiyfapN [from ZaraAfapN and laTaAfapN]. (Mgh.) [See also xaAliEN.] ― -b6- xaliyEN is also applied to a Khaleefeh, and a prince or the like, meaning (tropical:) Divested of his authority; removed from his office; deposed; (L;) as also maxoluwEN↓: and it is a strange thing, noticed by Dmr and others, that every sixth is mxlwE. (TA.) ― -b7- Also (tropical:) A young man, (S,) or a son, (K,) and a confederate, (IAth, L,) cast off, repudiated, or renounced, (S, IAth, L, K,) by his family, (S,) or father, (K,) or confederates, (IAth, K,) so that if he commit a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, they, i. e. his family, or he, i. e. his father, or they, i. e. his confederates, shall not be prosecuted, or punished, for it; (S, IAth, L, K;) as also maxoluwEN↓: (K:) pl. of the former, xulaEaMCu: (K:) and (tropical:) a young man (K, TA) thus cast off by his family, (TA,) who commits, or has committed, many crimes, or offences rendering him liable to punishment; as also xawolaEN↓: (K, TA:) (assumed tropical:) one alienated or estranged [from his family]: (TA:) (tropical:) one who has broken off from his family, and disagreed with them, and wearied them by his wickedness and baseness and guile; (Mgh, K, * TA; *) as though he had thrown off his headstall or halter, [i. e., restraint,] and who does what he will; or because his family have cast him off, and declared themselves clear of him; (Mgh;) or because he has cast off his kinsfolk, and they have declared themselves clear of him; or because he is divested of religion and shame; (TA;) fem. with p: (K: [indicating that it is a part. n. of xaluEa; not of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, as is implied by some portions of the explanations here given:]) (assumed tropical:) bad, evil, wicked, or mischievous: (TA:) (tropical:) [vitious, or immoral: (see xalaAEapN, whence it is derived:)] (assumed tropical:) notorious for drinking and play: (TA:) [in the present day commonly used in this sense; and as signifying (assumed tropical:) waggish; or a way:] (assumed tropical:) a player, with another, at a game of hazard, or for stakes laid by both of them to be taken by the winner; (IDrd, K;) as also muxaAliEN↓; because the best, or choice part, of his property (xuloEatuhu) is [often] won from him: (S:) (assumed tropical:) one who applies himself constantly to games of that kind: (TA:) and xawolaEN↓ signifies (tropical:) a player at games of that kind, who has had the punishment termed HadRN inflicted upon him, and is always overcome in such games, or who is fortunate, and always overcomes in such games. (K, accord. to different copies; in some of which we read AlmuqaAmiru AlmaHoduwdu AlRaciI yuqomaru OabadFA; and in others, AlmqASr Almajoduwdu AlcI yaqomuru AbdA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A hunter, fowler, or fisherman; (S, Sgh, K;) so called because he is alone. (Sgh.) ― -b9- (tropical:) A [demon, or devil, &c., of the kind called] guwl; (S, K, TA;) because of its evil nature; (TA;) as also xawolaEN↓ (K) and xayolaEN↓. (TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) A wolf; (S, K;) as also xawolaEN↓ (K) and xayolaEN↓. (Sgh, K.) ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) The gaming-arrow that does not win (S, Kr, K) at first: (S, Kr:) or, accord. to some, the gaming-arrow that wins at first; as is said by Sgh and in the L: (TA:) pl. xilaEapN. (Kr.)

Colocynth, or its pulp, or seed,] when it is cooked until its samon [or decocted juice] comes forth, whereupon it is cleared, and put aside; and bruised dates of which the stones have been taken out are put upon it, and flour, and it is stirred about and beaten until it becomes mixed; then it is left, and put down; and when it becomes cold, its smn is restored to it: or, as some say, colocynth (HanoZal) bruised, moistened with something to sweeten it, and then eaten; also called mubasRalN.
