muxalRaEN AlOaloyatayoni A man (S) having the buttocks apart, or parted. (S, K.) ― -b2- And muxalRaEN A weak, and soft, or flabby, man. (Lth, K.) [See also xayolaEN.] ― -b3- (tropical:) A man (TA) in whom is what resembles a loss of reason, or a touch of insanity or of diabolical possession: (K, * TA:) and (tropical:) a man insane, or possessed by a jinnee. muxotaliEapN (tropical:) A woman divorced from her husband for a gift, or a compensation, from him, (S, K,) or from another: (K:) [see 8:] and [the pl.] muxotaliEaAtN [is explained as signifying] (tropical:) women who incite, urge, or induce, their husbands to divorce them for a gift, or a compensation, without any injurious conduct from the latter. xalufa
, inf. n. xalofN, He came after, followed, succeeded, or remained after, another, or another that had perished or died. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [vii. 168 and xix. 60], faxalafa mino baEodihimo xalofN (TA) And there hath succeeded them, or come after them, [a posterity, or] an evil posterity. (Bd in xix. 60.) And xalafahu He came after him, (S, A in art. dbr, Mgh, Msb, TA,) or behind him, (A ubi suprà, Mgh,) or following him nearly; (A ubi suprà;) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, TA,) and xilofapN also: (Mgh:) or he remained after him: (K:) and jaMCa xilaAfahu↓ likewise signifies [the same as jMC xalofahu; an inf. n. of xaAlafa being thus used as an adv. n.; i. e.] he came after him. (TA.) You say also, xalafa AllRayolu AlnRahaAra, inf. n. xalofN and xilofapN, The night followed, or came after, the day. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xalafotuhu, [aor. as above,] inf. n. xalofN, [perhaps a mistranscription for xalafa,] I was, after him, a substitute for him: (TA:) [I supplied his place: and I superseded him.] And xalafahu, (aor. as above, TA,) inf. n. xilaAfapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) and xalafN (TA) and xilRiyqaI, (S, * K, * TA,) which last is an inf. n. of the intensive kind, (Sgh, MF, TA,) He was, or became, his xaliyfap [i. e. successor, or vice-agent, &c.], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or his substitute; (TA;) fiI qawomihi [among, or in respect of, his people], (S, TA,) and Oaholihi [his family]; relating to good and to evil; wherefore one says, OawoSaI lahu biAlxilaAfapi [he charged him by his will with the being his successor, or vice-agent, &c.]; (TA;) or EalaI Oaholihi wamaAlihi [over his family and his property]: (Msb:) and Axtflhu↓ signifies the same; (Lh, Ibn-'Abbád, K;) he was, or became, his xaliyfap (Ibn-'Abbád, TA) after him. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) And xalafa fulaAnFA [alone] He was, or became, the xaliyfapN of such a one among, or in respect of, his family (K, TA) and his children. (TA.) And xalafahu rabRuhu fiI Oaholihi (K, TA) and waladihi, (TA,) inf. n. xilaAfapN, (K,) His Lord was [for him] a xaliyfap [or supplier of his place] to his family (K, TA) and his children. (TA. [In the CK, Axlf is made to signify the same; but this is in consequence of an omission.]) And one says, xalafa QllRehu Ealayoka May God be to to thee a xaliyfap [or supplier of the place] (S, Msb, K) of thy father; (S, Msb,) or of the one whom thou hast lost: (S, Msb, K:) thus one says to one who has lost by death his father (S, Msb, K) or mother (K) or paternal uncle (S, Msb) or any other who cannot be replaced: (Msb, K:) and xalafa QllRehu Ealayoka xayorFA, (K,) or bixayorK, (AZ, Msb, K,) or both, (L,) and xalafa QllRehu laka bixayorK, (AZ, Msb,) and QllRehu Ealayoka xayorFA Oaxolafa↓ and laka xayorFA: (K: [in which it is implied that these phrases mean May God supply to thee well the place of him whom thou hast lost: but it is implied in the Msb that the two of them there mentioned mean May God restore to thee good in the place of that which has gone from thee: and it appears from what here follows that all of these phrases have the latter meaning, whether or not they have the former meaning also:]) to him who has lost property or a child or a thing [of any other kind] of which the replacement may be asked, (S,) or to him of whom that which may be replaced has perished, or died, (K,) one says, QllRehu Ealayoka Oaxolafa↓ (S, Msb, K) May God restore to thee the like of that which has gone from thee, (S, Msb,) or may God restore to thee what has gone from thee; (K in a later part of the art.;) and AllReh laka Axlf↓; and xalafa AllReh lk: or xalafa AllReh Ealayoka is allowable in relation to property and the like; and yaxolafu, like yamonaEu is allowable as its aor., though extr., (K,) as it has no faucial letter to occasion the fet-h: (TA:) and one says also, xalafa QllRehu laka bixayorK meaning May God give thee good in the place of that which has gone from thee; (TA;) and Ealayoka xayorFA Axlf↓, (Msb, TA,) meaning the same; (TA;) and [so] laka xayorFA Axlf↓ and bixayorK: and QllRehu Ealayoka maAlaka Axlf↓ and laka maAlaka [May God restore, or replace, to thee thy property]. (Msb.) xalafa OabaAhu, (K,) aor.
xalufa
(TA,) means He became behind his father; (K;) and if so, its inf. n. is xalofN: (TA:) or it means he became in the place of his father; (K;) and if so, its inf. n. is xalafN: (TA:) and xalafa makaAna Oabiyhi, inf. n. xilaAfapN (K) and xalafN, (TA,) he became in the place of his father, exclusively of every other. (K.) You say also, xalafati AlfaAkihapi baEoDuhaA baEoDFA, (JK, K,) inf. n. xalofN, (JK, TA,) or xalafN, (TA, [the former being there altered to the latter (which is the more probably correct), or the latter to the former,]) and xilofapN, (JK, TA,) The fruit replaced other fruit; or became substituted for other fruit. (JK, * K,* TA. [In the CK, SaAra xalofFA is erroneously put for SaArato xalafFA.]) And xalafa fulaAnN EalaI fulaAnapa, inf. n. xilaAfapN, [like Eaqaba EalayohaA,] Such a man took as his wife such a woman after another husband [and thus supplied his place]. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- xalafa ulaAnFA, (aor.
xalufa
, TA,) He took, or seized, such a one from behind him; (JK, * K;) as also Axtlfhu↓. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) xalafa lahu biAlsRayofi (JK, TA) He came to him from behind him, and smote his neck, or struck off his head, with the sword. (TA.) ― -b4- xalafa fulaAnN biEaqibiI [is explained as meaning] Such a one stayed, or abode, after me. (Msb in art. Eqb) [But] ― -b5- xalafa biEaqabi fulaAnK is said by some to mean UilaI xaAlafahu↓ Oaholihi [q. v.]: accord. to As, however, it means He parted with such a one on the condition of doing a certain thing, and then came behind him [or behind his back] and did another thing after parting with him: and Az says that this is a more correct explanation than the former one. (TA.) [Hence, app.,] one says also, UinRa QmoraOapa fulaAnK taxolufu zawojahaA biAlnRizaAEi UilaI gayorihi UicaA gaAba EanohaA [Verily the wife of such a one is unfaithful to her husband by yearning towards another when he is absent from her: or deceives her husband behind his back by yearning towards another; for it is implied, by an ex. given, that AcA gAb EnhA is added by way of explanation]. (TA.) xalafahu also signifies He spoke of him, or mentioned him, [behind his back, or] when he was not present: so in the phrase, xalafahu bixayorK or biXarRK [He spoke of him behind his back well or ill]. (TA.) And one says, yaxolufu AlnRaAsa mino waraAYihimo [meaning He defames men behind their backs]: the action signified hereby is like giybapN, and may be [by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head. (TA in art. hmz.) ― -b6- xalafa Eano OaSoHaAbihi, (K, TA,) aor.
xalufa
, He remained behind, or after, his companions; did not go forth with them; as also OaSoHaAbihi qaEada xilaAfa↓ [similar to a phrase mentioned near the beginning of this
art.]; (TA;) i. q. txlRf↓; (K in explanation of the former phrase;) which is syn. with taOaxRara; (S, K;) as in the phrase txlRf EanRiI [which means He remained behind me, or after me]; (S;) [for] txlRf Eanohu means baqiIa xalofahu; (Mgh;) and [in like manner] you say, txlRf Eani lAqawomi He remained behind, or after, the people, or party, not going with them; [he held back, or hung back, from them;] and qaEadotu xilaAfahu↓ [i. e. I remained] behind him, or after him; (Msb;) and xAlf↓ EanRaA He remained behind us, or after us; syn. txlRf↓. (TA, from a trad.) It is said in the Kur [xvii. 78], UilRaA qaliylFA wa UicaA laA yalobavuwna xilaAfaka↓, i. e. [But in that case they should not have remained] after thee [save a little while]: (JK, TA: *) so accord. to one reading [instead of xalofaka, which means the same]. (TA.) And in like manner, rasuwli QllRehi fariHa AlmuxalRafuwna bimaqoEadihimo xilaAfa↓, in the Kur [ix. 82], means [Those who were left behind rejoiced in their remaining] behind the Apostle of God: (S, TA:) or the meaning here is, muxaAlafapa rswl AllReh [i. e. in disagreement with the Apostle of God]: (JK, S:) thus says Lh; but IB disagrees with him; saying that xlAf here means baEoda; and cites six exs. in which it has this meaning, from poets. (TA.) ― -b7- [Hence,] xalafa fulaAnN Eano kulRi xayorK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was, or became, kept back from all good; i. e.,] did not prosper, or was not successful. (TA. [It is there added, that it is explained in the A as tropical, and as meaning tagayRara wafasada: but this is perhaps a mistake, occasioned by the accidental omission of waxalafa AllRabanu or the like, of which this is a correct explanation: or the phrase thus explained in the TA, as from the A, may correctly mean He became altered for the worse, and corrupt; agreeably with other explanations of the verb below.]) ― -b8- xalafa, aor.
xalufa
, also signifies He (a man) retired, withdrew, or went away or apart. (JK.) And xalafato nafosahu Eani AlTRaEaAmi, aor.
xalufa
, inf. n. xuluwfN, (assumed tropical:) His soul turned away from, avoided, or shunned, the food, in consequence of disease. (JK, TA.) ― -b9- And He fled. (Ham p. 411.) ― -b10- And He (a man, Sgh) ascended a mountain. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, first sentence. ＝ -A3- xalafa, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. xuluwfN, (Lh, Msb, TA, and Ham p. 679,) [inf. n. xuluwfN,] said of the taste of water, It was, or became, different from, or contrary to, what it was thought to be: and [hence,] it was, or became, altered [for the worse]: (Ham ubi suprà:) [and] said of milk, (S, K,) and of food, (Lh, S, Msb, K,) and the like, (Lh, TA,) and some say xalufa, (TA,) aor.
xalufa
, inf. n. xuluwfN, (Lh, TA,) of both verbs, (TA,) it was, or became, altered [for the worse] (Lh, S, Msb, K) in taste, or in odour; (S, Msb, K;) as also Axlf↓: or, said of milk, the first signifies it became bad from being long kept; or, as in the A, (tropical:) what was good thereof became mixed (xulifa, i. e. xuliTa,) with other milk: and Axlf↓, said of milk, signifies also it was, or became, sour: (TA:) and the first, said of [the beverage called] nabiyc, it became bad. (K.) Also, inf. n. xuluwfN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and xuluwfapN (K) and xilofapN, (L, TA,) said of the mouth (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of a person fasting, (S, Msb, K,) It was, or became, altered [for the worse] in odour; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also Axlf↓. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad. that the xuluwf of the mouth of one who is fasting is sweeter in the estimation of God than the odour of musk: or, accord. to some of the lawyers and of the relaters of traditions, xaluwf; but [SM says,] I think this to be a mistake, as several affirm it to be, while others say that it is of a bad dial.: accord. to one reading, it is xilofap. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xalafa Eano xuluqi Oabiyhi, (K,) aor.
xalufa
, inf. n. xuluwfN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, altered [for the worse] from the natural disposition of his father. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And xalafa, (ISk, S, K,) inf. n. xalofN [or xuluwfN]; or xalofa, aor.
xalufa
, inf. n. xalaAfapN and xuluwfN; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, bad, or corrupt. (ISk, S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And xalafa, (K) inf. n. xalaAfapN (IAth, K) and xuluwfN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, stupid, or foolish; or one who had little, or no, intellect or understanding: (K, * TA:) or unprofitable: or a frequent promise-breaker: (IAth:) or xalafa and Axlf↓, said of a slave, he was, or became, idiotic, deficient in intellect, or bereft of his intellect. (JK.) ＝ -A4- xalafa, (K,) inf. n. xalofN; (S, * K, * TA;) and Axlf↓, and Astxlf↓; (S, K;) He drew water, (S, K, TA,) liOaholihi for his family: [app. because he who does so leaves his family behind him: see 2, first sentence:] (K, TA:) [or] Astxlf↓, said of a man, signifies AisotaEocaba AlmaMC [app. as meaning he sought, or drew, or brought, sweet water: see art. Ecb]: and, accord. to IAar, you say, Alqawoma Oaxolafotu↓, meaning properly I carried sweet water to the people, or party, when they were in the [season, or herbage, called] rabiyE and without sweet water, or when they were by salt water: UixolaAfN [as meaning the carrying, or drawing, of water,] being [properly] only in the rbyE: in other cases, metaphorically applied. (TA.) El-Hoteíäh says,
lizugobK kaOawolaAdi AlqaTaA raAva xalofuhaA↓
EalaI EaAjizaAti AlnRahoDi HumorK HawaASiluho
(assumed tropical:) [To, or for, downy ones, like the young ones of the katà, whose procurer of water has been slow in coming to those lacking the power of spreading their wings for flight, red in their crops]: he means mixolifuhaA↓ [or xaAlifuhaA], and has put in the place of this the inf. n.: and by HwASlh, accord. to Ks, he means HawaASilu maA cakoronaA [the crops of what we have mentioned]: but Fr says that the h relates to the zgb, exclusively of the EAjzAt, which [latter] has the sign of the pl.; for every pl. that has the form of a sing. may be imagined to be a sing., as in the saying of the poet,
mivolu AlfiraAxi nutifato HawaASiluho
[meaning “ like the young birds of which the crops have been plucked ”]; for AlfrAx has not the sign of the pl., but has the form of a sing., like AlkitaAb and AlHijaAb: another says, [but this is very far-fetched,] that the h relates to AlnhD, which [sometimes] means a place in the shoulderblade of the camel; and that the poet has used it metaphorically as belonging to the qTA. (S.) ＝ -A5- xalafa AlvRawoba, (S,) or AlqamiySa, aor.
xalufa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xalofN (Kr, TA) and xulofapN, in some copies of the K xalofapN, [so in my MS. copy of the K, and so in the TK,] and [in some] xulafN also, but these require consideration, (TA,) He took out from the garment, or shirt, the part that was worn out, (S, Msb, K,) that is, the middle part, which was worn out, (S, Msb,) and then sewed the [cut] edges together. (S, Msb, K.) And AlvRawoba Axlf↓ signifies the same as xalafahu, i. e. He repaired the garment [app. in any manner, or, as is implied in the S and TA, by substituting one piece for another]. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- The saying, in a trad. of Hamneh, faUicaA xalafato celika falotagotasilo, meaning (assumed tropical:) And when she has discriminated that period of days and nights during which she has been HaAYiD, [she shall perform a complete ablution of herself,] is from xalafa AlqamiyS signifying as explained above. (Msb.) ＝ -A6- xalafa signifies also He mixed [a thing with another thing; as, for instance, (see xulifa in a passage above,) milk with other milk]: and he mixed saffron, and medicine, with water. (TA.) ＝ -A7- xalafa bayotahu He put to, or made for, his tent, a pole, (K, TA,) termed a xaAlifap, (TA,) in the hinder part thereof. (K TA.) ＝ -A8- xalifa, aor.
xalafa
, (K,) inf. n. xalafN, (S, K,) He (a camel) inclined towards one side. (S, K.) ― -b2- xalafN is also an inf. n. (of xalifa, said of a man, TK) signifying The being Oaxolaf as meaning contrarious, hard in disposition, as though going with a leaning towards one side: ― -b3- and the being left-handed: ― -b4- and the being OaHowal [or squint-eyed]. (K.) ＝ -A9- xalifato, aor.
xalafa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xalafN, (Msb, TA,) She (a camel) was, or became, pregnant. (Msb, K.)

2 xlRfhu xlf xlfh xlfp
2. xlRfhu, (Msb,) and xlRfhu waraMCahu, (S, TA,) inf. n. taxoliyfN, (TA,) He left him behind him; (Msb;) namely, a man: (S, Msb, TA:) and xalafahu↓ [signifies the same: or] he made him to be behind him; as also Axlfhu↓ [q.v.], and Axtlfhu↓: (TA:) [whence the saying,] OaloHaHotu EalaI fulaAnK fiI AlAitibaAEi HatRaI Qxotalafotuhu↓ i. e. [I pressed upon such a one in following] until I made him to be behind me. (ISk, TA.) You say also, xalRafahumo, inf. n. as above, meaning He was, or became, or went, before them; and left them behind him. (TA.) And xlRfwA OavoqAlahum, inf. n. as above, They left their loads, or baggage &c., behind their backs; (O, K;) when they went away to draw water. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xlRfhu He made him, or appointed him, his xaliyfap [i. e. successor, or vice-agent, &c.]; (K;) and so Astxlfhu↓. (S, Msb, K.) So in the Kur [xxiv. 54], layasotaxilafanRahumo↓ fiI QloOaroDi kamaA Qsotaxolafa QlRaciyna mino qabolihimo [That He will assuredly make them to be successors in the earth, like as He made to be successors those who were before them]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xlRf binaAqatihi, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He bound one of the teats of his she-camel with the thing termed SiraAr [in order that her young one might not suck it]: (S, K:) from Yaakoob. (S.)

3 xAlfhu xAlf xAlfh xAlfp
3. xAlfhu, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. xilaAfN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) and muxaAlafapN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) He [or it] disagreed with, or differed from, him [or it]; or he dissented from him; (Mgh, Msb;) contr. of waAfaqahu; fiI kacaA [in, or in respect of, such a thing]: (Mgh:) and he, or it, was contrary, opposed, or repugnant, to him, or it: (TA:) [and he acted contrarily, contrariously, adversely, or in opposition, to him, or it; he, or it, contravened, or opposed, him, or it:] and he [or it] contradicted him [or it]. (M in art. nqD.) It is said in a prov., UinRamaA Oanota xilaAfa AlDRabuEi AlrRaAkiba, i. e. tuxaAlifu xilaAfa AlDRabuEi [Verily thou art one who acts with the contrariousness of the hyena towards the rider]: for the hyena [attacks a man on foot, but], when it sees the rider, flees from him. (IAar, TA.) You say also, xaAlafaniI Eano kacaA He turned away from such a thing [in opposition to me, or] when I betook myself to it: [see also the last sentence but one of the first paragraph of art. bht:] and xAlfnI UilaI kacaA He betook himself to such a thing [in opposition to me, or] when I turned away from it: (Mgh:) or xAlfhu UilaI AlXRaIoCi means he disobeyed him by betaking himself to the thing; or betook himself to the thing after he had forbidden him it. (TA.) And hence, (Mgh,) huwa yuxaAlifu UilaI QmoraOapi fulaAnK, (S, Mgh, *) or UilaI fulaAnapa, (O, L, TA,) in the K erroneously, hw yxAlf fulaAnapa, (TA,) He comes to the wife of such a one when he [the latter] is absent from her, (S,) or to such a woman when her husband is absent from her: (Mgh, * O, L, K, TA:) and xAlfhu UilaI Oaholihi [he came to his (another's) wife in his (the husband's) absence]: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. (Az, TA.) And xAlfhu Uilayohimo He watched to see him, and, when he was absent from them, namely, his family, he went in to them: (Jm, O, TA:) and, accord. to AZ, fulaAnN SaAHibahu Axlf↓ Such a one watched to see his companion, and, when he was absent, he came, and went in to him [or rather to his wife or to his family]: (TA:) [or] SaAHibahu xAlf↓ he watched to see his companion, and, when he was absent, went in to his wife: (K, and the like is said in the JK:) thus says IDrd, on the authority of AZ. (TA.) And xAlf UilaI qawomK He came to a party, or company of men, from behind them [or behind their backs]: or he feigned to them the contrary of that which he conceived in his mind, and took them unawares. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, [describing a collector of wild honey,]
UicaA lasaEatohu AlnRaHolu lamo yaroju lasoEahaA
waxaAlafahaA fiI bayoti nuwbK EawaAsili
(S in the present art., in which only the former hemistich is cited, and in art. rjw,) i. e. [When the bees sting him,] he fears not nor minds [their stinging], (S in art. rjw) [but comes, during their absence, to the hiving-place of bees occupied in gathering honey:] meaning, he comes to their honey, (S, TA, [in the latter of which, in the place of AlnHl, is put AldRaboru “ the swarm of bees, ”]) and takes it, (TA,) while they are feeding; (S, TA;) or, as AA says, he comes behind them to the honey while they are absent: AO explains it by xaAlafahaA UilaI mawoDiEK Mxara which [he says] means he keeps with them [to another place]; syn. laAzamahaA; [and thus this phrase (which is strangely misinterpreted in the TK and in Freytag's Lexicon) is explained in the K, but without any reference to the verse;] as also HaAlafahaA, with the unpointed H: (TA:) and some read the verse thus; but this reading is said to be a mistake. (TA in art. Hlf.) ― -b2- jaMCa xilaAfahu: see 1, near the beginning of the paragraph. And see also five other exs. in the middle portion of the same paragraph. ― -b3- xAlf bayona rijolayohi He put one of his legs forward and the other backward: and [hence,] AlmuxaAlafapu bayona AlrRijolayoni [as signifying the alternate shifting of the legs to and fro] is metonymically used as meaning the act of dancing. (Har p. 108.) [And xAlf bayona AlXRayoYayoni He put, or placed, the two things contrariwise; or on contrary sides; or in contrary directions. Hence,] Oawo tuqaTRaEa Oayodiyhimo waOarojuluhumo mino xilaAfK, in the Kur v. 37, [Or that their hands and their feet shall be cut off on contrary sides,] means that their right hands and left feet shall be cut off. (Bd, Jel. [See also similar exs. in the Kur vii. 121 and xx. 74 and xxvi. 49.]) [Hence also,] farasN bihi XikaAlN mino xilaAfK, (JK,) or cuw xadamataAni mino xilaAfK, (TA,) A horse having a whiteness in his right fore leg and his left hind leg [or the reverse]: (JK, TA:) and some say, lahu xadamataAni mino xilaAfK when he has a whiteness [or rather a ring of white a little above the hoof] in his fore leg [or right fore leg] and another in his left fore leg [probably a mistake of a copyist for his left hind leg]. (TA.)

4 Axlfhu Oxlf Oxlfh Axlfh Axlfp xlf
4. Axlfhu: see 2, first sentence. Also He put him, turned him, or made him to go back or stand back, behind him. (K, TA.) And Axlf yadahu He put his hand behind him. (Az, TA.) And also, (Fr, TA,) or Axlf biyadihi UilaI AlsRayofi, (JK,) or simply Axlf [used elliptically], (S, K,) He put [back] his hand to his sword, (Fr, S, K, TA,) in order to draw it, (JK, S, K, TA,) it being hung behind him. (Fr, * TA.) And Axlf AlsRayofa [He hung the sword behind him; or kept it hung behind him]: said, in a trad., of a man on the day of Bedr. (TA.) And Axlf Eani AlbaEiyri [for Axlf Eanohu AlHaqaba] He shifted [backwards] the hind girth of the camel, putting it next to his testicles, on account of its hurting the sheath of his penis, and causing a suppression of his urine; (As, S, K;) as also Axlf AlbaEiyra: (TA:) or you say only, Oaxolifi AlHaqaba, meaning remove thou the hind girth from the sheath of the penis. (Lh, TA.) And Axlf AldRaAbRapa biAlsRawoTi He struck the beast on the hinder part with the whip. (JK.) ― -b2- Axlf AlbaAzila [He (a camel) exceeded in age the bAzl, which is generally one that has entered his ninth year: as though he made the bAzl to be behind him: and so, app., Axlf alone; AlbaAzila being understood: see muxolifN]. El-Jaadee says,
Oaxolafa AlbaAzila EaAmFA Oawo bazalo
OayRidi AlkaAhili jalodK baAzilK
[Strong in the withers, hardy, a bAzl; that has exceeded in age him who has just become a bAzl by a year, or that has himself just become a bAzl]. (S, TA.) Some say that AlUixolaAfu is [a term denoting] the last of the ages [that have words to signify them] with respect to all beasts. (TA.) ― -b3- Axlf fulaAnN SaAHibahu: see 3, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- Axlfhu maA waEadahu, (S,) or mawoEidahu, (Mgh,) or waEodahu, (Msb,) or AlwaEoda, (K,) inf. n. UixolaAfN, (Mgh,) He broke, (Mgh,) or failed to perform, (S, K,) his promise, or the promise, to him: (S, Mgh, K:) restricted to future time: (Msb:) AlUixolaAfu is, in respect of the future, like Alkacibu in respect of the past: (S, K:) or the making a promise and not fulfilling it: (Lh, K:) and some say that it signifies one's seeking an object of want, or water, and not finding it. (TA.) It is said in a trad., UicaA waEada Oaxolafa, i. e. When he promises, he does not fulfil his promise, and is not true [to it]. (TA.) [Hence,] Oaxolafati AlnRujuwmu, i. e. (tropical:) [The stars broke their promise; meaning,] were attended with drought, not attended with rain: (S, K, TA:) a saying of the people in the Time of Ignorance: (S, TA:) and so Eano OanowaAYihaA Aixotalafato↓: for they used to believe and say that they were rained upon by such and such a nawoC. (TA. [See nawoCN.]) Hence also, Oaxolafati AlHumRaI (assumed tropical:) The fever, being tertian or quartan, came not in its time, or turn. (Mgh.) And Oaxolafato said of a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) She, having been covered by the stallion, did not become pregnant: (JK, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) she proved to be not pregnant when thought to be pregnant. (JK.) And in like manner said of a palm-tree; (JK;) (tropical:) It bore not one year: and (tropical:) it (a tree) bore no fruit: or lost the fruit that it had. (L, TA. [The verb, said of trees, has also another meaning, which see below.]) ― -b5- Axlfhu is also said, by El-Fárábee, to occur as meaning He acted according to his promise [or fulfilled his promise] to him; thus bearing two contr. significations: but this is strange. (MF.) ― -b6- Also He found him to be a breaker of his promise; (JK;) or he found his promise to be broken, or unfulfilled. (S, K.) ― -b7- Axlf Ealayoka and laka, each with an objective complement (xayorFA or maAlaka) expressed or understood: see 1, in six places, in the former half of the paragraph. You say also, Axlf fulaAnN linafosihi, (S, K,) or ligayorihi, (TA,) Such a one replaced to himself, (S, K,) or to another, (TA,) a thing that had gone from him, with another thing. (S, K.) Ibn-Mukbil says,
faOaxolifo waOatolifo UinRamaA AlmaAlu EaArapN
wakulohu maEa AldRahori AlRaciI huwa Mkiluho
[Then replace thou, and consume: wealth is but a loan: and devour it with time, which is a devourer thereof]: he means, gain a substitute for what thou hast consumed. (S, TA.) And the Arabs say to him who has put on a new garment, Oaboli waOaxolifo waQHomadi AlkaAsiI [Wear out thy garment, and replace it with another, and praise the Clother, meaning God]. (TA.) And
Oaboli wayuxolifu QllRehu [Wear out thy garment, and God will replace it with another; or, may God replace &c.]. (S in art. blw) ― -b8- See also Axlf AlvRawoba near the end of the first paragraph. ― -b9- Axlf said of a plant, or of herbage, It put forth the xilofap, (S, Msb, K,) meaning leaves that come forth after the first leaves, in the [season called] Sayof; (TA;) and in like manner said of trees: (Msb, TA:) or Axlf AlXRajaru means the trees put forth fruit after other fruit. (JK.) And, said of fruit, It came forth, some thereof after other thereof. (TA.) And Axlft AlOaroDu The land became affected by the cold of the latter part of the [season called] Sayof, and some of its trees consequently become green. (TA.) ― -b10- Also, said of a bird, (tropical:) It put forth feathers after the first feathers: (K, TA:) from the same verb said of a plant, or of herbage. (TA.) ― -b11- And, said of a boy, (assumed tropical:) He nearly attained to puberty. (JK, Az. K, TA.) ― -b12- And, said of a solid-hoofed beast, (assumed tropical:) He completed a year after the quruwH [or finishing teething, or shedding the corner-nipper]. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Axlfhu said of medicine, It weakened him (K, TA) by causing him to go frequently to the privy. (TA.) ― -b2- And AlUixolaAfu also signifies The bringing the stallion again to the she-camel when she has not conceived at once. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, in six places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

5 taxalRafa
5: see 1, in two places, in the middle of the paragraph. [Hence, txlRf ani AlOamori He held back from, or fell short of, doing the thing.]

6 taxaAolafa
6: see the next paragraph, in three places.

8 AixotilaAfN AxtlAf QxtlAf
8. AixotilaAfN signifies The following reciprocally; or alternating. (Mgh.) So in the phrase in the Kur [ii. 159 and iii. 187 and xlv. 4], waQxotilaAfi AllRayolu waAlnRahaAri And the alternating of the night and the day. (Mgh) [And in a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce OabolaI, in art. blw.] And hence the phrase, AixotalafaA DarobapF Each of them beat, or struck the other in turn. (Mgh.) And the saying, in a trad. of 'Alee, faQxotalafato bayona Eubayodapa boni AlHerivi waAlwaliydi boni Euqobapa DarobataAni [And two blows were interchanged between 'Obeydeh Ibn-El-Hárith and El-Weleed Ibn-'Okbeh]. (Mgh.) And the saying, in a trad. of Umm-Sabeeyeh, Aixotalafato yadiI waydu rasuwli QllRehi fiI UinaMCK waAHidK, meaning My hand and the hand of the Apostle of God were both put [by turns] into one vessel. (Mgh.) And AixotalafuwA signifies They followed, or succeeded, one another; whenever one went, another coming after him. (TA in art. Ewr.) ― -b2- Also The going, or moving, repeatedly, to and fro; so coming and going; or reciprocating; syn. taradRudN [in this sense, as is shown in this art. in the K and TA, and in the S and K in art. rwd &c.: and also as mean ing the returning, or repairing, time after time, or repeatedly, or frequently, to a person or place; because it implies coming and going: and sometimes it means simply the returning; because this cannot be without a previous going]. (K.) You say, huwa yaxotalifu UilaI fulaAnK, i. e. yataradRadu [He returns, or repairs, time after time, repeatedly, or frequently, to such a one]: and Aixotalafa Uilayohi QxotilaAfapF waAHidapF [He returned to him once]. (TA.) And huwa yaxotalifu UilaI majaAlisi AlEilomi He repairs frequently to, or frequents, the assemblies of science; syn. yataradRadu. (A in art. rd.) And Aixotalafa UilaI AlmutawaDRaOi [He returned, or repaired, time after time, &c., to the privy]. (S.) And Aixotalafa UilaI AlxalMCi [properly signifies the same: and hence, (assumed tropical:) He had a looseness of the bowels, or a diarrhœa]. (K.) And [perhaps as implying coming and going,] Axtlf also signifies He supplied, or gave, or offered, water. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also The disagreeing, differing, or varying, in state or condition or quality &c.; being dissimilar, different, diverse, various, incongruous, discordant, or dissentient:] Axtlf is the contr. of AitRafaqa; (K, TA;) and is said of anything that is dissimilar [in the parts or members &c. of which it is composed]; as also txAlf↓. (TA.) You say, AlOamoraAni txAlf↓ [and Axtlf AlAmrAn], i. e. lamo yatRafiqaA [The two things, or affairs, or cases, were, or became, dissimilar, &c.]. (TA.) And AxtlfwA and txAlfwA↓ (Mgh, Msb) [They disagreed, &c., fiI OamorK in a thing or an affair or a case;] every one of them took to, or held, a way, or an opinion, different from, or contrary to, that of another: (Msb:) both signify the same. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., sawRuwA Sufuwfakumo walaA taxotalifuwA fataxotalifa quluwbukumo [Make ye your ranks even when ye place yourselves to pray together, and be not dissimilar in your positions, for in that case your hearts would disagree]; meaning, when one of you advances, or stands, before another in the ranks, your hearts will be affected, and disagreement in respect of friendship and amity will arise among you: or, as some say, it means, your hearts will be made to recoil: or the Suwrap [or specific character] of your hearts will become changed into another Swrp. (TA.) [Hence,] Aixotalafato Eano OanowaAYihaA, said of stars: see 4, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- Also The being complicated, intricate, or confused. (KL.) [You say, Axtlf AlOamoru bayonahumo The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them: a phrase of frequent occurrence.] ＝ -A2- Axtlfhu: see 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- Axtlf SaAHibahu: see 3, near the middle of the paragraph.

10 Astxlfhu Ostxlfh Astxlfh Astxlfp Qstxlf Qstxlfh
10. Astxlfhu: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- Also He took it (a thing) as a substitute, or in exchange, for another thing; or in the place of another thing; syn. AisotaEowaDahu and Aisotabodalahu. (TA.) ― -b3- Astxlfti AlOaroDu The land produced the herbage of the [season called] Aisotabodalahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in the middle of the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

xalofN xlf
xalofN [meaning The location, or quarter, that is behind; and the time past;] (K; [so in my MS. copy, and thus it should be written as a simple noun; but in the CK xalofu;]) or Alxalofu; (Lth, K;) contr. of qudRaAmN [or AlqudRaAmu]: (Lth, K:) [and] xalofa [Behind; and after;] contr. of qudRaAma: (S: [thus in my tow copies; and said in the margin of one of them to be thus in the copy of IB, and in that of El-Jawáleekee:]) a simple noun: and an adv. n.: of the fem. gender [as meaning the jihap; but otherwise it seems to be masc.]. (TA.) You say, jaMCa xalofahu [and mino xalofihi, both meaning He came behind him, and after him]. (Mgh.) And jalasotu xalofa fulaAnK I sat after, or behind, such a one; syn. baEodahu (S.) And labiva xalofahu He remained after him. (K.) Some read, in the Kur [xvii. 78], waUicFA laAyalobavuwna xalofaka: others read xilaAfaka [which means the same, as mentioned above: see the middle of the first paragraph of this art.]. (TA.) ― -b2- xalofN signifies also The back (K, TA) itself: so says IAar: and particularly, of a house; the side corresponding to, or over against, that in which is the door; and as a house may have two doors, [in two different sides,] it may be said to have two backs, each of which may be thus termed; and the dual of this word seems to be used as meaning two backs in a trad. [respecting the building of the Kaabeh]. (TA.) ― -b3- And One who comes after another; (S, TA;) as also xalafN↓, or, accord. to some, there is a difference between these two, as will be shown in what follows; (S;) and xaAlifN↓ and xaAlifapN↓: it is originally an inf. n.: (TA:) and signifies one who remains after another, whether this other be dead or living: and one remaining after another who is dead; his follower, or successor; the follower, or successor, of one who has gone: used in praise and in dispraise: pl. xuluwfN: and the sing. also signifies [like the pl.] persons remaining after others; accord. to some: (IB, TA:) a remnant of people: (Lh, TA:) and a generation after a generation; (Lth, S, K;) as also xalafN↓: (Lth, TA:) but Lth says that the former is applied to the evil, and ↓the latter to the good, (K, TA,) whether meaning a generation or a son: (TA:) the latter means a good son (K, TA) remaining after his father: (TA:) and the former, a bad son: (K, TA:) [therefore] one says, huwa xalofu sawoCK mino Oabiyhi [He is a bad son] who has taken the place of his father, and SidoqK mn Abyh xalafu↓ [a good son] &c.: (S:) but sometimes each is used in the place of the other; so that one says, hw xalofu SidoqK mn Abyh: (K:) or both signify the same: (S, K:) so says Akh: some, he says, use the former; and some, the latter: but some say SidoqK xalafu↓ and xalofu sawoCK, meaning thus to distinguish between them: (S:) accord. to IB, xalafN↓ correctly signifies a man's successor who is a substitute for him, good and bad: and is originally an inf. n.: (TA:) and the pl. of this is OaxolaAfN: (AZ, IB, TA:) accord. to IAth, xalafu SidoqK means a good generation: and xalofu sawoCK, an evil generation: (TA:) and xalofN likewise signifies progeny [without restriction]. (K.) One says also, (S, K,) of a people following people more in number than they, (S,) heWulaMCi xalofu sawoCK [These are a bad generation. (S, K.) And baqiynaA fiI xalofi sawoCK We remained among an evil remnant. (Lh, TA.) And faxalafa mino baEodihimo xalofN, in the Kur [vii. 168
and xix. 60], is explained as meaning And there remained after them a remnant. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] (tropical:) One in whom is no good. (IB, K.) [And app. also Persons in whom is no good..] ― -b5- And (tropical:) A thing in which is no good: (IB, TA:) [and particularly] (assumed tropical:) a bad saying; (ISk, S, Msb, K;) a wrong, bad saying, like the xalof of mankind. (A 'Obeyd, Msb.) See also xulofN. It is said in a prov., sakata OalofFA wanaTaqa xalofFA (assumed tropical:) He held his tongue from a thousand words (sakata Eano Oalofi kalimap), and then uttered what was wrong. (ISk, S, Msb.) An Arab of the desert, who had been guilty of a breach of manners (Habaqa HaboqapF), pointed with his thumb towards his Aisot, and said, UinRahaA xalofN naTaqato xalofFA [which may be rendered, Verily it is a thing in which is no good: it uttered a thing in which was no good: but it obviously admits of being rendered otherwise]. (IAar, S.) ― -b6- Also People who have gone away from the tribe (T, K) to draw water, and have left their baggage &c. behind them: (T, TA:) and such as are present, [remaining behind,] of the tribe: thus bearing two contr. significations: pl. xuluwfN. (K.) You say HaIRN xuluwfN A tribe who are absent; none of them remaining behind: (S, TA:) or a tribe of which the men are absent and the women remaining: (TA:) and xuluwfN also signifies the contr., i. e. such as are present, (S, TA,) remaining behind. (S.) It is said of Mohammad, in a trad., lamo yatoruko Oaholahu xuluwfFA, i. e. He did not leave his family neglected, with no pastor nor protector. (TA.) See also a verse of El-Hoteíäh in the latter part of the first paragraph of this article. ＝ -A2- Old and worn out; applied to a waTob [or skin for milk, or for clarified butter and milk: as though it were a remnant thereof]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) ＝ -A3- A mirobad; (S, K;) i. e. a place of confinement for camels: (TA:) or such as is behind the tent or house. (JK, S, * K.) ＝ -A4- A large faOos [i. e. hoe or adze or axe]: or such as has one head: and the edge of a fOs: or the head thereof: (K:) you say faOosN caAtu xaloqayoni a two-headed fOs: (S, TA:) or caAtu xaloqayoni and caAtu xiloqayoni↓ are names of the fOs (K, TA) when two-headed: (TA:) and the pl. is cawaAtu Alxaloqayoni: (K:) pl. xuluwfN. (JK.) ― -b2- And The head of a razor. (K.) ― -b3- And The [pointed] head of a minoqaAr, [an iron instrument like the faOos, (A and K in art. nqr,) with which mill-stones &c. are pecked, or wrought into shape, (see minoqaArN,) and] with which wood is cut. (TA.) ＝ -A5- See also xilofN.

xulofN xlf
xulofN a subst. from UixolaAfN, (S, Msb, K,) relating to a promise, and restricted to future time; (Msb;) i. e. a subst. used in the place of UixolaAfN; (Lh, TA;) meaning The breach, or non-fulfilment, of a promise; as also xulufN↓, which is said to be the original form of the word, and xuluwfN↓: (TA:) it is, in respect of the future, like kacibN in respect of the past: (S, K:) some say that it signifies a false, or wrong, saying; which is a meaning of xalofN↓, with fet-h, before mentioned: but perhaps these two words may be syn. dial. vars. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (Msb,) or xulofapN↓, and xilofapN↓, (K, TA,) Disagreement, difference, dissension, contrariety, contrariousness, or opposition, (Msb, K, * TA,) in opinions or the like, (Msb,) or in respect of friendship and amity, (TA in explanation of the second of these words,) or in natural disposition; (K;) as also xilafonapN↓ (S, K) and xilafonaApN↓ and xaAlifN↓ and xaAlifapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- It is also pl. of xaliyfN, in its various senses.

xilofN xlf
xilofN: see xilofapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in seven places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, (Sgh,) i. q. lajuwjN [app. as meaning One who perseveres much in opposition or contention or the like]; (Sgh, K;) as also xaAlifapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also a subst. from UixolaAfN meaning The act of drawing water; and so xilofapN↓: (A 'Obeyd, K: *) [whence the saying,] mino Oayoni xilofatukumo Whence do ye draw water? (S, K.) ＝ -A3- The teat (Halamap) of the udder of the she-camel: (S, K:) and the two fore ones, and the two hinder ones: (S:) or the part of the udder upon which the milker lays hold: (TA:) or the extremity of the udder of the she-camel: (Msb, K:) or the hinder of the OaTobaMC [or teats]: (K:) or the udder itself; (Lth, TA;) [i. e.] it is, to the she-camel, (Msb, * K,) like the vadoI to the human being, (Msb,) or like the DaroE to the ewe or she-goat: (K:) or the xilof is of the camel and of the cloven-hoofed animal; and the TuboI, of the solid-hoofed animal and of the animal that has a claw: (Lh, TA:) the pl. [properly of pauc.] is OaxolaAfN (Msb, TA) and [of mult.] xuluwfN. (TA.) One says, darRato lahu OaxolaAfu AldRunoyaA (tropical:) [The world yielded him abundance of its good things]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- The shortest of the ribs of the side; (S;) [and] so xalofN↓; (K;) likewise called DilaEN Alxilofi and Alxalofi; it is the furthest and thinnest of the ribs; (TA;) [i. e.] the xilof is that next to the belly, of the small ribs; their quSayoraI: (K: [see AlquSoraI:]) pl. of the former (S) [and] of the latter (K) xuluwfN. (S, K.) ＝ -A5- caAtu xilofayoni: see xalofN, near the end of the paragraph.

xalafN xlf
xalafN A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in place of, or in exchange for, another thing. (A 'Obeyd, Th, S, Msb, K, TA.) You say, AijoEalo hecaA xalofFA mino hecaA Make thou this to be a substitute for this. (Msb.) And hecaA xalafN mimRaA Ouxica laka This is a substitute for what has been taken to thee. (IB.) And fiI heWulaMCi Alqawomi xalafN mimRano maDaI In these people are such as supply the place of those who have gone. (TA.) And fiI fulaAnK xalafN mino fulaAnK [In such a one is a substitute for such a one]. (TA.) And huwa mino Oabiyhi xalafN He is a substitute for his father. (IB.) See also xalofN, in six places, in the former half of the paragraph.

xalifN xlf
xalifN, applied to she-camels, i. q. maxaADN, i. e. Pregnant: n. un. with p: (S, K:) accord. to some, (TA,) the pl. of xalifapN, which signifies a pregnant camel, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or, as some say, one that has completed a year after bringing forth and has then been covered and has conceived, until she enters upon the term called AltRaEoXiyr, (TA, [from-the time when her pregnancy has become manifest, (see qaAriHN and laAqiHN,)] is maxaADN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) like as the pl. of AimoraOapN is nisaMCN; (Msb, TA;) and sometimes xalifaAtN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and xilaAfN: (TA:) but xalifN occurs in the saying of the rájiz,
maA laka tarogiyna walaA taroguwA Alxalifo
[What aileth thee that thou utterest a grumbling cry, when the pregnant camels utter not that cry?]. (IB.)

xulafN xlf
xulafN: see xulofapN.

xulufN xlf
xulufN: see xulofN.

xalofapN xlf xlfh xlfp
xalofapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xulofapN xlf xlfh xlfp
xulofapN: see xulofN. ― -b2- Also A vice, a fault, or an imperfection: (K:) and badness, corruptness, vitiousness, or dishonesty: (TA:) and foolishness, or stupidity; or paucity, or want, of intellect or understanding; as also xalaAfapN↓ [properly an inf. n., of xalufa, and before mentioned as such; (see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph;)] and idiocy. (K.) All of these meanings have been assigned to it in explanations of the saying, OabiyEuka hecaA AlEaboda waOaboraOu Uilayoka mino xulofatihi [I sell to thee this slave, but I am irresponsible to thee for his vice, &c.]: or, accord. to IAar, the meaning is, xilaAfihi [his contrariousness]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The last taste of food; (K;) as in the saying, UinRahu laTayRibu Alxulofapi [Verily it is good, or sweet, in respect of the last taste]; (TA;) and so xalofapN↓: pl. xulafN: and it (xulofapN) signifies also loss of appetite for food, in consequence of disease: (so accord. to the CK:) [or,] accord. to some copies of the K, xalofapN↓ has this latter signification; and so xulafN↓: accord. to other copies, xulafN is pl of xalofapN in this sense: but both these readings require consideration: what is found in the Lexicons is, xalafato nafosuhu Eani AlTRaEaAmi, aor.
xalufa
, inf. n. xuluwfN; meaning as explained above, in the latter half of the first paragraph. (TA.)

xilofapN xlf xlfh xlfp
xilofapN a subst. signifying A mode, or manner, of coming after [or behind]; like qiEodapN signifying “ a mode, or manner, of sitting. ” (Msb.) ― -b2- See also xulofN. ― -b3- It signifies also Difference [of any kind]: (K, * TA:) or the coming and going of the night and the day; (S, K, * TA;) and likewise of wild animals. (K.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xxv. 63], wahuwa QlRaciI jaEala QllRayola waQlnRahaAra xilofapF, (S, K, *) meaning cawaI xilofapK, (Bd,) i. e. [And He it is who hath made the night and the day] so that each replaces the other: or each follows the other: (K, * TA:) or so that he who is unable to accomplish a thing in the night may do it in the day, and the reverse. (Fr, L, K.) Zuheyr says, of wild animals, yamoXiyna xilofapF, meaning They go to and fro. (S, TA. [See Em p. 109.]) And one says, Oaxacatohu xilofapN, meaning He was
taken with [an affection causing] a frequent going to and from the privy. (S, K.) [And hence,] xilofapN signifies also, A discharging of the bowels; or a purging and vomiting together; (K;) or a disordered state of the stomach arising from [unwholesome] food; (TA;) a looseness, or diarrhœa. (JK, TA.) ― -b4- See also xilofN. ― -b5- Also The bringing of camels to the watering-place in the evening, after the people have gone away. (L, K.) ― -b6- And A man's watching to see another, (Oano yunaAZira in some copies of the K, and An yunaASira in other copies, being put for An yubaASiru, which is the right reading, agreeably with an explanation of Aixotalafa SaAHibahu, [for which see 3, near the middle of the paragraph,] TA,) and when he is absent from his family, going in to them, (K, TA,) or [rather], when he is absent from his wife, going in to her. (TA, after the explanation of the phrase above mentioned.) ＝ -A2- A thing that is suspended behind the rider; (JK, K;) such as is suspended behind the [kind of vehicle called] maHomil. (TA.) ― -b2- Remains of water in a trough or tank. (TA.) ― -b3- What remains, of food, between the teeth. (Lh, K.) ― -b4- A plant, or herbage, that comes forth after another plant, or other herbage, (S, Msb, K,) which has become dry, and broken in pieces: (S, TA:) or that comes forth not from rain, but by reason of the cold of the latter part of the night. (Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, K. [See also rabolN.]) ― -b5- What the trees disclose in the beginning of the cold, (K, TA,) by reason of the [rain called] SafariyRap [q. v.]: (TA:) or fruit that comes forth after other fruit: (K:) or fruit that comes forth after abundant fruit; (S, Mgh, TA;) this being termed the xilofap of trees: (S, Mgh:) or a growth of leaves after the falling away of other leaves: (K, * TA: duwna in the K is a mistake for baEoda: TA:) or leaves that come forth after the first leaves, in the [season called] Sayof. (Nh, TA.) ― -b6- What grows in the Sayof [or summer]; so says A 'Obeyd: (S, K:) or, (JK, Mgh, K,) as also xilofN↓, (K,) the herbage produced by the Syf, (JK, K,) or in the Syf, (Mgh,) after the springherbage has dried up. (JK, Mgh.) ― -b7- A produce of grape-vines after the grapes have turned black; the grapes being gathered while it is fresh and green, it then ripens: and so other fruits: or a new produce, by the vine, of fresh sour grapes. (K.) ― -b8- Grain that is sown (JK, * Mgh, K *) after the former has come to maturity: (Mgh, TA:) because taken as a substitute for wheat and barley: (K:) pl. xilafN. (Mgh.) ― -b9- A piece with which a garment is patched (K) when it is old and worn out. (TA.) ― -b10- A time after a time. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A3- Differing [one from another or others]; as also xilofN↓: (K:) it is applied in this sense to a people, or company of men: (AZ, S, K:) and to beasts, or horses or the like, as meaning differing (K, TA) in their colours and appearances: (TA:) and xilofataAni is applied to any two things that are different; (Ks, TA;) as also xilofaAni↓: (Ks, Msb, TA:) and xilofapN, (K,) or xilofataAni, (Ks, TA,) to any two colours that are combined [because different]. (Ks, K, TA.) AZ cites, as an ex., the saying [of a rájiz],
saAqiyaAhumaA dalowaAIo xilofaAni↓
[My two buckets are different, and their two suppliers with water]; (S, TA;) meaning that one of them [i. e. of the buckets] is ascending and full, and the other is descending and empty; or that one of them is new, and the other is old and worn out. (TA, in two places.) And one says of two children, or two male slaves; or two female slaves, that they are xilofataAni, (Ks, K,) and xilofaAni↓, (K,) applying to the male and the female, (TA,) meaning One tall and the other short: or one white and the other black. (Ks, K.) One says also, banuw fulaAnK xilofapN, meaning The children of such a one are half males and half females. (S.) And nitaAju fulaAnK xilofapN The offspring of the beasts of such a one are one year male and another year female. (JK, TA.) And waladato xilofayoni↓, said of ewe or goat, (K,) or of a camel, (L,) She brought forth one year a male and another year a female. (L, K.) The pl. [of xilofN↓] (K, TA) in all its senses (TA) is OaxolaAfN and xilafapN; (K, * TA;) the latter, [in the CK xilofapN,] like qiradapN as pl. of qirodN. (TA.)

xulofufN xlff
xulofufN and xulofafN and xulofufapN and xulofafapN: see xaAlifN, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- OumRu xulofufK (Sgh, K) and xulofafN Calamity, or misfortune: or the greatest calamity or misfortune. (K.)

xilafonapN xlf xlfnh xlfnp
xilafonapN and xilafonaApN: see xulofN: ― -b2- and see also xaAlifN, in the middle of the paragraph.

xilaAfN xlAf
xilaAfN an inf. n. of 3 [q. v. passim]. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Also The contrary, or opposite, of a thing; syn. DidRN. (Msb in art. Dd. [Very often used in this sense.]) You say, AlAixotilaAfu xilaAfu AlAitRifaAqi [i. e. AlAxtlAf is the contrary of AlAtRfAq] (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, Msb, K,) by the vulgar (O, Msb, TA) incorrectly pronounced with teshdeed (O, Msb, K, TA) and fet-h [to the x, i. e. xalRaAfN], (TA,) A well-known kind of tree; (S;) the [kind of tree called] SafoSaAf: (Msb:) or a species of the SfSAf, but not the SfSAf itself: (K:) [the salix Aegyptia of Linnæus; called by this name in the present day; and by some, improperly, baAnN, q. v.:] it abounds in the land of the Arabs; and is [also] called sawojarN [or sawoHarN]; and there are many varieties thereof; all of them soft and weak; (TA;) but it is seldom, or never, found in the desert: (Msb:) they assert that it is thus called because the torrent brings it from one locality to another, so that it grows in a place different from that of its origin; (AHn, Msb, K, * TA;) but this is not a valid assertion: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (Msb, TA.) suwRiyna mino xilaAfi, in the saying of the rájiz cited voce xufRN, means Made of different trees: it does not mean of the tree called xilaAf; because this is seldom, or never, found in the desert. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also The sleeve of a shirt. (IAar, K.)

xuluwfN xlwf
xuluwfN: see xulofN. ＝ -A2- It is also, as stated above, pl. of xalofN: (IB, K, TA:) ― -b2- and a pl. of xilofN. (TA.)

xaliyfN xlyf
xaliyfN: see xaliyfapN, in three places. ― -b2- Also One who holds back from the place, or time, of promise: and one who breaks a promise. (TA.) ― -b3- And A woman that has let down her hair behind her. (JK, O, K.) ― -b4- And A woman that has attained to the period of one day, or two days, after her having brought forth. (IAar.) [Perhaps from the signification next following.] ― -b5- A she-camel in the second day after her having brought forth: pl. xulufN and xulofN: (K, TA:) these two pls. are mentioned in the K in different places in this art., but both are correct, like rusulN and rusolN. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) one says, rakibahaA yawoma xaliyfihaA [He rode her on the second day after she had brought forth]. (K.) ― -b6- And The milk that is after the biestings: (AA, K:) pl. as above. (K.) One says also, HalabahaA xaliyfa libaYihaA He drew from her the milk that came after the biestings had passed away. (JK.) And AiytinaA bilabani naAqatika yawoma xaliyfihaA, i. e. [Bring thou to us the milk of thy she-camel of the day] after the cessation of her biestings; i. e., of the milking that is after her bringing forth by a day or two days. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A2- Applied to a garment, (S, K,) or a shirt, (Msb,) Having the middle, wornout part taken out, and the [cut] edges then sewed together: (S, Msb, K *:) and maxoluwfN↓ signifies the same; (JK;) or a garment composed of two pieces sewed together: or, as some say, this signifies a garment pledged. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, accord. to A 'Obeyd, The part beneath the armpit: and the xaliyfaAni of the camel are like the UiboTaAni of man: accord. to the S and the O, xaliyfaA AlnRaAqapi signifies the two armpits of the she-camel (UiboTaAhaA): but the author of the K, following the [first] explanation given by A 'Obeyd, says that this is wrong, and that the meaning is the parts beneath the two armpits of the she-camel. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And A gap between two mountains, (JK,) or between two mountain-tops, (TA,) of little breadth and length: (JK, TA:) or a road between two mountains: (S, K:) or a valley between two mountains: (K:) or a place where water pours forth (K, TA) between two mountains, or between two valleys, passing thence into a wide tract: (TA:) and any road in a mountain, (Skr, K,) or behind a mountain, or behind a valley: (TA:) or simply a road; as also maxolafapN↓; (JK, K;) this being either in a plain or in a mountain: (TA:) pl. of the former as above. (K.) One says ciyxu Alxaliyfi i. e. [The hairy male hyena] of the road between two mountains, (S, K,) or of the valley between two mountains; (K) like as one says ciYobu gaDFA. (S.) ＝ -A5- And A sharp arrow: (AHn, K:) or, accord. to Skr, the word in this sense is HaliyfN, with the unpointed H; and this is more probably correct. (TA.)

xalaAfapN xlAf xlAfh xlAfp
xalaAfapN: see xulofapN.

xilaAfapN xlAf xlAfh xlAfp
xilaAfapN inf. n. of xalafahu as meaning “ he was, or became, his xaliyfap ” [q. v.]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [And hence, as a simple subst., The office of xaliyfap.]

xaliyfapN xlyfh xlyfp
xaliyfapN A successor: and a vice-agent, vice-
gerent, lieutenant, substitute, proxy, or deputy: (KL:) one who has been made, or appointed, to take the place of him who has been before him: (JK:) an act. part. n. of xalafahu, inf. n. xalafN and xilaAfapN; as also xaliyfN↓: (TA:) or it may have the meaning of an act. part. n. or that of a pass. part. n.: and so in the sense next following: (Msb:) the supreme, or greatest, ruler or sovereign, (S, Msb, K, TA,) who supplies the place of him who has been before him; (TA;) [particularly the successor of the Prophet; whence “ Caliph, ” commonly used by English writers for “ Khaleefeh; ”] as also xaliyfN↓, (K,) which is the original form, (Msb,) without p; (Msb, TA;) disapproved by some, but mentioned by AHát and Ibn-' Abbád and IB, and occurring in a verse of Ows Ibn-Hajar cited by IB: (TA:) the p in the former is to denote intensiveness of signification, (Nh, Msb, TA,) as in EalRaAmapN and nasRaAbapN: (Msb:) or, as some say, lilnRaqoli [i. e. for the transference of the word from the category of epithets to that of substs.]: (TA:) it is also said that the word may be an epithet of which the subst. qualified thereby is suppressed, for nafosN xaliyfapN; but this requires consideration: (MF, TA:) it is an epithet applied to a man peculiarly: (Msb:) some make it fem.; (Fr, S, Msb, K;) saying hecaA xaliyfapN OuxoraI [This is another Khaleefeh]; though the proper way is to make it masc.: (Msb:) a poet says,
Oabuwka xaliyfapN waladatohu OuxoraI
waOanota xaliyfapN caAka AlkamaAlu
[Thy father was a Khaleefeh, whom another Khaleefeh begat; and thou art a Khaleefeh: that is perfection]: (Fr, S:) the pl. is xalaAYifu [generally applied to any people that have succeeded others, and supplied their places, as in the Kur x. 15], (S, K,) like as karaAYimu is pl. of kariymapN; (S;) and xulafaMCu [generally applied to successors of the Prophet], (S, K,) because, as it applies only to the male, and has p added, the p is dropped in forming the pl., which is thus like ZurafaMCu as pl. of ZariyfN: (S:) thus says ISk, and the like is said in the O: but what AHát and Ibn-'Abbád say requires not this straining: (TA:) [i. e.] xalaAYifu is pl. of xaliyfapN; and xulafaMCu, of xaliyfN↓: (JK:) or some, having regard to the original, make the pl. to be xulafaMCu, like as XurafaMCu is pl. of XariyfN; (Msb;) and this pl. is masc. only, so that you say valaAvapN xulafaMCa: (ISk, Msb, TA:) and some, having regard to the word itself [in its altered and used state], make the pl. to be xalaAYifu; (Msb;) and this pl. may have prefixed to it either a masc. or a fem. n. of number, so that you say valaAvapN xalaAYifa and valaAvu xalaAYifa; (ISk, Msb, TA;) both of which are chaste. (Msb.) You say, kaAna QllRehu xaliyfapa waAlidika Ealayoka [May God be to thee a supplier of the place of thy father]: (S, Msb: *) and in like manner you say, to a person, of any one whom he has lost by death, (S, Msb,) and who cannot be replaced; as the paternal uncle; (Msb;) or the mother. (K.) Some say that the application of the title xaliyfapu QllRehi [The Vicegerent of God] is not allowable, except to Adam and David because there is express authority in these instances [in the Kur ii. 28 and xxxviii. 25]; but others allow it in other cases, like suloTaAnu QllRehi and junuwdu QllRehi and Hizobu QllRehi and xayolu QllRehi; all of which have been heard: (Msb:) and Zj says that it is allowable to say of the Imáms that they are xulafaMCu QllRehi fiI OaroDihi [The Vicegerents of God in his earth]. (TA.)

xilRiyfapN xlyfh xlyfp
xilRiyfapN: see the middle of the next paragraph.

xaAlifN xAlf
xaAlifN: see xalofN, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also One who remains behind, or after, another, (Yz, K, TA,) or others, in the case of a war, or a warring and plundering expedition, and in other cases: (TA:) pl. xaAlifuwna (Yz, K, TA) and xawaAlifu, which latter is extr. [in this case], but is also said to be a [reg.] pl. of xaAlifapN↓, and as such to signify persons who do not go forth on a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition: and AlgaAziI xaAlifapu↓ signifies he who remains behind, or after, him who goes forth on such an expedition, being of his family. (TA.) faQqoEuduwA maEa AlxaAlifiyna, in the Kur [ix. 84], means Then stay ye with those who remain behind. (Yz, K. *) xawaAlifu is also pl. of xaAlifapN↓ [as fem. of xaAlifN], (TA,) and signifies Women (K, TA) remaining behind in the houses or tents: but some assign to it the first of the meanings explained above: and some say that it means the children remaining behind. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 88 and 94], raDuwA biOano yakuwnuwA maEa AlxawaAlifi↓, i. e. [They chose to be] with the women: (S, K: *) thus it is explained by Ibn-'Arafeh: but some say that the meaning is, with the bad, or corrupt, persons; and that xwAlf is here a pl. [of xaAlifN,] like fawaArisu. (TA.) For ― -b3- xaAlifN is applied to a man [as meaning Bad, or corrupt]; and xaAlifapN↓ to a woman as meaning bad, or corrupt, and remaining behind in her abode: and the former to a slave as meaning bad, or corrupt: and also contrarious: and in this last sense it is likewise applied to a companion: and some of the grammarians say that there is no word of the measure faAEilN having its pl. of the measure fawaAEilu, except xaAlifN and haAlikN and faArisN: but see this last: (TA:) and xilRiyfapN↓, also, has this last signification; (JK, TA;) or [rather] signifies very contrarious; (K;) as also xaAlifapN↓; (JK;) and so xilafonapN↓, and xilafonaApN↓, (Lh, JK, K,) in each of which the n is augmentative, and each of which is applied to a man and to a woman and to a pl. number; (Lh, K;) but xilafonayaAtN has been mentioned as pl. [of xlfnAp], and as applied to males and females: (TA:) and xaAlifuwna is likewise used in this sense applied to a number of men. (JK.) ― -b4- Also, applied to a slave, [and app. to any man, but in this latter case I find it written xlf, which I believe to be a mistranscription,] One who has withdrawn from the people of his house: so says Lh. (TA.) ― -b5- Also Stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; as also xaAlifapN↓, (K, TA,) but in an intensive sense, and also applied to a woman; (TA;) and Oaxolafu↓, (JK, K,) of which the fem. is xalofaMCu; (JK, TA;) and xulofufN↓, (K,) or xulofafN↓, (L,) or both, (JK,) likewise applied to a woman, as also xulofufapN↓, (K,) or xulofafapN↓: (JK:) or, as some say, xaAlifN signifies one in whom is no good: and, as also xaAlifapN↓, one who has not what suffices: or who often breaks his promises: (TA:) or both of these mean one who has not what suffices, and in whom is no good: or very contrarious. (JM.) One says that a man is Oaholi bayotihi xaAlifapu↓ and xaAlifu, Ahl byth, meaning The one in whom is no good, of the people of his house: (S, K:) and the ungenerous: (K:) or the stupid, or foolish: or the bad, or corrupt, and the evil: and it is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) And qawomN xawaAlifN↓ Persons in whom is no good. (JK.) ― -b6- And, [app. because he leaves his family behind him,] A drawer of water; (S, TA;) as also musotaxolifN↓ [q. v.]: both mentioned in the K; but AlsRaqRaMCu is there erroneously put for AlmusotaqiI. (TA.) ― -b7- And Weak, without appetite for food. (TA.) ― -b8- And Flesh-meat from which a slight smell is perceived, but in the chewing of which is no harm. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also xulofN.

xaAlifapN xAlf xAlfh xAlfp
xaAlifapN: see xalofN, in the former half of the paragraph. Also, particularly, [or perhaps OumRapN xaAlifapN only in this sense,] A nation, people, or race, remaining after another that has gone before. (I 'Abbád, K.) And One who comes to the water after him who has returned [from it]: whence Aboo-Bekr applied this appellation to himself, from a motive of humility, when asked if he were the Khaleefeh of the Apostle of God. (IAth, TA.) See also xaAlifN, in eight places: and see its pl., xawaAlifu, in the same paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, [like xilRiyfapN as explained in the K,] Very contrarious, or adverse, and inimical. (S, * K, * TA.) See also xilofN. ― -b3- maA OadoriI OaIRu xaAlifapa huwa, the word xAlfp being here imperfectly decl., (S, K,) because of the fem. gender and determinate, being explained by AlnRaAsi, (S,) or because determinate and occupying the place of a pl., like as one says OaIRu tamiyma and OaIRu Oasada, [or rather, I think, because used as a proper name, as MF, says, (though SM disputes this,) and with the sign of the fem. gender,] means I know not what one of mankind he is; (S, K;) as also OaIRu xaAlifapK, perfectly decl.; and OaIRu AlxaAlifapi; and OaIRu AlxawaAlifi; (K;) and so OaIRu xaAfiyapa; (K, TA, [in the CK AIR xaAlifapK again,]) imperfectly decl. (TA.) Lh says that AlxaAlifapu, writing it thus with Al, signifies AlnRaAsu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also One of the poles of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC: or one of the poles of a bayot [or tent] in the hinder part thereof: (K:) Lh says that the xaAlifap is the hinder part, or in the hinder part, (Aaxr, [i. e. Mxiru or Mxira, app. the latter,]) of a bayot; and one says bayotN cuw xaAlifatayoni [app.
meaning a tent having two poles in its hinder part]: (TA:) the pl. is xawaAlifu: (S, TA:) which is hence applied to the angles, or corners, of a bayot: AZ says that the xaAlifap of a byt is [app. the shirt thereof,] beneath the [ropes called] OaTonaAb, in the [part called] kisor [q. v.]; and it is also called the xyASp, and the frjp: [thus I find these two words written, without any syll. signs:] and he cites, as an ex.,
maA xifotu HatRaI hatakuwA AlxawaAlifa
[app. meaning And I feared not until they rent open the skirts of the tent, or tents]: (TA:) or, as some say, the xaAlifataAni are the two sides of a tent, and its riwaAq is its fore part, and its kifaMC is its hinder part. (TA in art. rwq.) ― -b2- xawaAlifu, (Yz, K,) or xawaAlifu mina AlOaroDi, (TA,) Lands that produce not plants, or herbage, save among the last of lands. (Yz, K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- See also xulofN.

Oaxolafu c
Oaxolafu: see xaAlifN, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also Contrarious, hard in disposition, as though going with a leaning towards one side: (K:) and [simply] leaning towards one side; applied to a camel: (S, K:) so says A'Obeyd; (S, TA;) and so As. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A camel that has the sheath of his penis slit, and that will not remain stationary, by reason of pain: (TA:) and maxoluwfN↓ signifies a camel having the sheath of his penis slit in the hinder part, (JK, TA,) when suffering suppression of his urine in consequence of the pressure of his hind girth upon his sheath: so says El-Fezáree. (TA.) ― -b4- And Left-handed. (JK, K.) ― -b5- And Squinteyed; syn. OaHowalu. (K.) ― -b6- Accord. to some, (TA,) A torrent: (K, TA:) or, as some say, a river. (Skr, TA.) ― -b7- And A male serpent. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) [All these meanings seem to have been assigned to the word as occurring in a verse of Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee, in which he likens the course of a wolf in a narrow road to the course of the Oaxolaf.] ＝ -A2- [Also More, and most, wont to break promises. Hence the prov., mentioned by Meyd, Oaxolafu mino EuroquwbK More wont to break promises than 'Orkoob: a certain man who rendered himself notorious for breaking his promises. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 454. ― -b2- And More, and most, disagreeing, differing, dissentient, contrary, contrarious, or opposing. See an ex. in a prov. cited voce viylN. ― -b3- And app. More, and most, offensive in the odour of the mouth. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ubi suprà.]

taxaAliyfu txAlyf
taxaAliyfu Different colours. (TA.)

maxolafN mxlf
maxolafN: see maxolafapN.

muxolifN mxlf
muxolifN A camel that has exceeded in age the baAzil; [which latter is generally one that has entered the ninth year;] (S, M, K;) beyond which there is no age [having an epithet to denote it]; therefore, (TA,) one says muxolifu EaAmK and muxolifu EaAmayoni [that has exceeded in age the bAzl by a year and by two years]; (S, TA; [see 4;]) applied alike to the male and the female; (S, K;) and the female is also termed muxolafapN: (K:) or this latter signifies (tropical:) a she-camel that appears, (S, K,) or is thought, (A,) to be pregnant, and is not pregnant: (S, A, K:) and the pl. is maxaAliyfu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also mixolaAfN. ― -b3- Also A man whose cattle have not obtained the [herbage termed] rabiyE. (JK.) ― -b4- rajulN muxolifN mutolifN, or mixolafN↓ mitolafN, and mitolaAfN mixolaAfN↓: see art. tlf. ― -b5- nawomapu AlDRuHaI muxolifapN lilofami, (K, TA,) also written maxolafapN↓, and in some copies nawomu AlDRuHaI, [which requires the reading maxolafapN,] (TA,) i. e. [The sleep, or sleeping, in the period of the morning when the sun is yet low is] a cause of the mouth's becoming altered [for the worse] in odour. (K, TA.) ― -b6- muxolifu janobK Having one half of his face and of his mouth turning sideways. (JK.) ― -b7- See also the explanation of the verse of El- Hoteiäh cited in the last quarter of the first paragraph. The qaTaA are termed muxolifaAtN because they draw water for their young ones. (JK.)

mixolafN mxlf
mixolafN: see the next preceding paragraph.

maxolafapN mxlf mxlfh mxlfp
maxolafapN: see muxolifN. ＝ -A2- See also xaliyfN, near the end of the paragraph. Almaxolafu↓ [as a coll. gen. n.] signifies The roads along which the people pass in Minè; (K) which are three: one says, AuTolabohu biAlmaxolafapi AlwusoTaI mino minFI [Seek thou him in the middle road of Minè]. (TA.) And maxolafapN baniI fulaAnK The place of alighting, or descending and stopping or sojourning or abiding or lodging or settling, of the sons of such a one. (K, * TA.) And maxolafapu minFI The place of alighting, or descending and stopping &c., of the people in Minè. (K.) ＝ -A3- A place in which are trees of the kind called xilaAf. (S, K.)

maxolafaAnu Albaladi mxlfAn Albld
maxolafaAnu Albaladi The ruler, or sovereign, (suloTaAn,) of the country; as also mixolaAfuhu↓. (TA.)

mixolaAfN mxlAf
mixolaAfN A man who often breaks his promises; (S, K;) as also muxolifN↓: (TA:) [whence the latter (which properly signifies simply breaking a promise) is applied to a star, or an asterism, as meaning (tropical:) Unattended with rain: (see 4:) and in the same sense to clouds (saHaAb): or, accord. to Freytag's Lex., in this or in the contr. sense.] ― -b2- See also muxolifN. ― -b3- And see maxolafaAn. ＝ -A2- Also A kuwrap [i. e. province, district, or region] (S, Mgh, Msb) pertaining to the people of El-Yemen, (S,) or in the dial. of El-Yemen; (Mgh, Msb;) pl. maxaAliyfu; (S, Msb;) every mxlAf thereof having a [distinctive] name whereby it is known; (S;) the mxAlyf of the people of El-Yemen being like the Oajonad of the people of Syria and the kuwar of the people of El-'Irák and the rasaAtiyq of the people of El-Jibál and the TasaAsiyj of the people of El-Ahwáz: (IB:) or mixolaAfN signifies a kuwrap (JK, M, K) to which a man comes; (M;) [in any country;] and hence the mxAlyf of ElYemen, (K,) i. e. its kuwar: (TA:) some say that there is a mxlAf in every country; (Msb;) so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh; (TA;) i. e. a naAHiyap [as meaning a district &c.]; (Msb;) and thus one says the mxlAf of El-Medeeneh, and of ElYemámeh, (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA,) and the mxAlyf of Et-Táïf: (AA, Msb, TA:) but properly it is peculiar to the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. bnkrd [a foreign word, and perhaps mistranscribed], i. e. The poor-rate of any particular people or party, which is given by them to [the poor of] their own community: so says Aboo-Mo'ádh: (L:) and maxaAlifu↓ [is its pl., as also, app., maxaAliyfu, agreeably with rule, and] signifies the poor-rates of the Arabs; (JK, TA;) [as in the saying,] AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaI maxaAlifi baniI fulaAnK [Such a one was employed as collector of the poor-rates of the sons of such a one]. (JK.)

maxoluwfN mxlwf
maxoluwfN: see xaliyfN: ― -b2- and Oaxolafu. ＝ -A2- Also A man affected with a looseness, or diarrhœa. (JK, TA.)

maxaAlifu mxAlf
maxaAlifu: see mixolaAfN, last sentence.

maxaAliyfu mxAlyf mxlAf
maxaAliyfu: pl. of mixolaAfN. (S, Msb, K, &c.) ＝ -A2- Also Camels that have pastured upon fresh herbs, or leguminous plants, and have not fed upon dry herbage, and to which their pasturing upon the former has been of no avail. (IAar, TA.)

qawolN muxotalifN qwl mxtlf
qawolN muxotalifN [Discordant speech;] speech expressing different opinions. (Bd and Jel in li. 8.) ― -b2- [TuruqN muxotalifapN Roads leading in different directions.]

musotaxolifN mstxlf
musotaxolifN: see xaAlifN, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- cahaba Almusotaxolifuwna yasotaquwna a saying mentioned by Lh as meaning Those going before [or leaving others in their places] went away to draw water. (TA.)

1 xaloqN xlq xlqp
1. xaloqN signifies The act of measuring; or determining the measure, proportion, or the like, of a thing; and the making a thing by measure, or according to the measure of another thing; or proportioning a thing to another thing; syn. taqodiyrN: (S, Msb, K, TA, and Bd in ii. 19:) this is the primary meaning. (Msb, TA, and Bd ubi suprà.) You say, xalaqa AlOadiymi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
xaluqa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. xaloqN (JK, S, Msb, K) and xaloqapN, (K,) He measured, or proportioned, (qadRara,) the hide, and sewed it: (K:) or he measured, or proportioned, (qdRr,) the hide, (JK, S, Msb, K,) limaA yuriydu [for, or to, that which he desired to make of it], (JK, * TA,) or lilsRiqaMCi [for, or to, the skin for water or milk that he desired to make], (Msb,) before cutting it; (S, K, TA;) he measured it (qaAsahu) to cut from it a water-bag, or a water-skin, or a boot: (TA:) and in like manner, xalaqa AlnRiTaEa he measured, &c., the nTE [q. v.]: when one cuts it, one says, faraAhu. (K.) And xalaqa AlnRaEola He determined the measure of the sandal, or proportioned it; (qadRarahaA;) and made it by measure. (Ksh and Bd in ii. 19.) Hence the saying of Zuheyr, (S,) praising Herim Ibn-Sinán, (TA,)
walaOanota taforiI maA xalaqota wabaEo
Du Alqawomi yaxoluqu vumRa laA yaforiI
In the preceding quotation, the final character of the first line and initial character of the second are missing in the original text. [(assumed tropical:) And thou indeed cuttest what thou hast measured; but some of the people measure, then will not cut]: (S, TA:) i. e., when thou determinest upon a thing thou executest it; but others determine upon that which they do not execute. (TA.) And El-Hajjáj said, maA xalaqotu UilRaA qarayotu waEadotu UilRaA wafayotu [(assumed tropical:) I have not measured unless I have afterwards cut, and I have not promised unless I have afterwards performed]. (S.) Oaxoluqu lakumo mina AlTRiyni kahayoYapi AlTRayori, in the Kur iii. 43, means I will form for you, (Jel,) or I will make according to its proper measure (OuqadRiru) for you, (Ksh, Bd,) and will form, (Bd,) of clay, a thing like the form of the bird, or of birds. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it signifies also The bringing a thing into existence according to a certain measure, or proportion, and so as to make it equal [to another thing], or uniform [therewith]: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 19:) or the originating, or producing, [a thing] after a pattern, or model, which one has devised, not after the similitude of anything preexisting: this is another meaning which it has in the [classical] language of the Arabs. (TA.) As the act of God, it signifies The originating, or bringing into being or existence, anything, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (TA:) [and the creating a thing; and thus it is generally best rendered; as meaning the bringing into existence from a state of non-existence: for] xalaqa QllRehu AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. xaloqN, means God brought the thing into existence (Mgh, * TA) after it had not been: (TA:) [or xaloqN, as the act of God, signifies the creating out of nothing: for it is said that] OuEobuduwA rabRakumu QlRaciI xalaqakumo, in the Kur ii. 19, means [Serve ye your Lord] who brought you into existence when ye were nothing. (Jel. [But in other passages of the Kur (vi. 2 &c.) it is said that God created (xalaqa) mankind of clay.]) Accord. to the A, xalaqa QllRehu Alxaloqa is a tropical phrase, meaning (tropical:) God brought into existence the creation, or created beings, or mankind, according to a predetermination (taqodiyr) required by wisdom. (TA.) You say, hecihi xaliyqatuhu AlRatiI xuliqa EalayohaA and xuliqahaA and AlRatiI xuliqa: see xuluqN. (Lh.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] xalaqa, (S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. xaloqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He fabricated speech, or a saying or sentence, &c.: (K, * TA:) (tropical:) he forged (S, Msb, K, TA) a saying, (Msb,) or a lie, or a falsehood; (S, K, TA;) as also Axtlq↓ (S, Msb, K) and txlRq↓. (S, K.) The Arabs say, HadRavanaA fulaAnN biOaHaAdiyvi Alxaloqi (tropical:) Such a one related to us fictitious tales or stories, such as are deemed pretty, or such as are told by night [for entertainment]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxvi. 137], accord. to one reading, Uino hecaA UilRaA xaloqu AlOawRaliyna, meaning (tropical:) This is nought but the lying, and forging, of the ancients. (TA.) And in the same [xxxviii. 6], Uino hecaA UilRaA QxotilaAqN↓ (tropical:) This is nought but forging, and lying. (TA.) ― -b4- xalaqahu, (K,) inf. n. xaloqN, (TA,) also signifies He made it smooth; (K;) and so xlRqhu↓; namely, an arrow, (S,) [and any other thing; for] of anything that has been made smooth one says, xulRiqa: (TA:) he made it equable, or even; namely, wood, or a stick; and so xlRqhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taxoliyqN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xaluqato, inf. n. xalaAqapN, said of a woman, (JK, K,) She had [a goodly] body and make: (JK:) or she was, or became, goodly in make, or well made. (K. [In the CK, instead of Hasuna xaloquhaA, is put Hasuna xuluquhA, meaning She was, or became, good in nature, &c.]) ― -b2- And xaliqa, aor.
xalaqa
, (JK, K,) inf. n. xalaqN; (JK, S; *) and xaluqa, aor.
xaluqa
, (K,) inf. n. xuluwqapN (TA) [and xalaAqapN, and perhaps xuloqapN q. v. infrà]; It (a thing) was, or became, smooth, (JK, K, TA,) and equable, or even. (TA.) [See also 12. And it seems that one says, xaliqati AlSRaxorapu, inf. n. xalaqN, q. v. infrà, meaning The rock was free from crack or fracture.] ― -b3- And xaluqa, (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor.
xaluqa
; (K;) and xaliqa, aor.
xalaqa
; and xalaqa, aor.
xaluqa
; (K;) inf. n. (of the first, JK, S) xuluwqapN (JK, S, K) and xalaAqapN (JK, TA) and [of the second] xalaqN (K) and [of the third] xuluwqN; (JK, TA;) It (a garment) was, or became, old, and worn out; as also Axlq↓, (JK, S, Msb,) inf. n. UixolaAqN; (JK, TA;) and Axlwlq↓. (TA.) [Hence,] diybaAjuhu Axlq↓ [lit.] His face became worn out; meaning (tropical:) it became used for mean service [so that it lost its grace, or was disgraced,] by his begging. (Har p. 476. [See also 4 below.]) [Hence also,] XabaAbahu Axlq↓ (assumed tropical:) His youth declined, or departed. (TA.) ― -b4- And xaluqa, (S, K,) aor.
xaluqa
, (K,) inf. n. xalAqapN, (Ham p. 522,) He was, or became, xaliyq, i. e. jadiyr [meaning adapted or disposed by nature, apt, meet, &c.: see xaliyqN, below]. (S, K.) You say, xaluqa lcelika [and bicelika (see xaliyqN) He was, or became, adapted, disposed, &c., for that]; as though he were one of those in whom that was reckoned to be, and in whom the symptoms, signs, or tokens, thereof were seen. (S.) [And xaluqa Oano yafoEala celika and biOano yfEl clk and liOano yfEl clk and mano Oano yfEl clk He was, or became, adapted, &c., to do that: see xaliyqN. And xaluqa may signify also It was, or became, probable; or likely to happen or be, or to have happened or been: see, again, xaliyqN.]

2 xlRqhu xlq xlqh xlqp
2. xlRqhu: see 1, latter half, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. taxoliyqN, (K,) He rubbed him over with xaluwq [q. v.]: (S:) or he perfumed him: (K:) or xlRqhu bixaluwqK he perfumed him with xlwq (TA.) And xalRaqotu AlmaroOapa biAlxaluwqi [I perfumed the woman, or rubbed her over, with the xlwq]. (Msb.) And xalRaqato jisomahaA She (a woman) rubbed her body and limbs over with xlwq. (TA.)

3 xaAlaqahumo xAlq xAlqhm
3. xaAlaqahumo, (K,) inf. n. muxaAlaqapN, (TA,) He consorted [or comported himself] with them (K, TA) according to their natures, or moral characters or qualities; (TA;) or with good nature, or moral character or qualities: (K:) or xAlqhm bixuluqK HasanK has this latter meaning. (TA.) One says, xaAliSi AlmuWomina waxaAliqi AlfaAjira, (S,) or wxAlq AlkaAfira, (TA,) [Act thou with reciprocal sincerity towards the believer, and comport thyself with the vitious, or the unbeliever, according to his nature, &c. See also 3 in art. xlS, where a similar saying is mentioned.]

4 Axlq Oxlq Axlq xlq
4. Axlq: see 1, latter part, in three places. ― -b2- Also He had old and worn-out garments. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Axlqhu He wore it out; namely, a garment; the verb being trans. as well as intrans. (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] Axlq AldRahoru AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) Time wore out, or wasted, the thing. (TA.) [Hence also,] one says to the beggar, Oaxolaqota wajohaka (tropical:) (TA) [lit. Thou hast worn out thy face;] meaning (tropical:) thou hast used thy face for mean service [so that it has lost its grace, or has become disgraced]: and in like manner one says, Ouxoliqu lahu diyabaAjatiI, i. e. wajohiI: and yuxoliqu diybaAjatayohi (tropical:) He uses his face for mean service by begging.
