(Har pp. 15 and 476.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or Axlqhu vawobFA, (S,) He clad him with an old and worn-out garment. (S, K.) And AxlqinI vawobahu He gave me his old and worn-out garment. (JK.) And some say, Axlqhu xalaqFA He gave him an old and worn-out garment. (TA.) ― -b3- And UixolaAqN AlvRawobi also signifies The cutting out of the garment: whence the saying, to UmmKhálid, OaboliI waOaxoliqiI [Wear out, and cut out new]; or, as some relate it, waOaxolifiI, i. e., “ and replace, ” which is the more likely. (TA.) ＝ -A3- maA Oaxolaqahu and Oaxoliqo bihi [have both of the following significations; though it is said that] the former signifies How likely is he, or it! (JK, TA;) and the latter, How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, or how worthy, is he, or it! i. q. Oajodiro bihi and OaHori bihi. (TA. [See 4 in arts. jdr and HrI.])

5 taxalRaqa
5: see 1, a little after the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- txlRq bigayori xuluqihi means He affected a xuluq [or nature, &c.,] that was not his own. (S, K.) And txlRq bikacaA He feigned such a thing, it not being in his nature, or not being created in him. (TA.) And txlRq lilnRaAsi bimaA layosa mino nafosihi, occurring in a trad., [He affected, to men, a nature, &c., that did not belong to him; or] he pretended [to men] that there was in his nature fiI xuluqihi) that which was contrary to his real intention; (Mbr, TA;) or that which was contrary to what he had in his heart: the verb is similar to taSanRaEa and tajamRala. (TA.) ＝ -A2- txlRq bihi; (S, K;) and txlRqt bh; (Msb;) He was, or became, rubbed over, (S,) or perfumed; (K;) and she was, or became, so; (Msb;) [or he rubbed himself over, or perfumed himself; and she did so;] with it; (S, Msb, K;) namely, with xaluwq. (S, Msb.)

8 Uixotalaqa
8: see 1, latter half, in two places.

12 Axlwlq Axlwlq
12. Axlwlq, said of the back (maton) of a horse, It was, or became, smooth; (K;) [like xaliqa and xaluqa; or very smooth; for] the verb is of a form intensive in signification. (TA. [See its part. n., maxolawoliqN, below.]) ― -b2- Said of a rasom [i. e. a trace,
or a remain or relic marking the place of a house or the like and cleaving to the ground,] It was, or became, even with the ground. (S, K.) ― -b3- Axlwlq AlsRaHaAbu The clouds became equable, or uniform, (JK, S, K, TA,) their sides becoming conjoined; or, as some say, they became smooth; (TA;) and, (K,) or as some say, (S, TA,) they became adapted, or disposed, to rain; (S, K, TA;) as though they were rendered smooth: or they became collected together after separation, and prepared to rain. (TA.) And Axlwlqt AlsRamaMCuOano tamoTura The sky was near, and likely, to rain. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, latter part.

xaloqN xlq xlqp
xaloqN inf. n. of xalaqa. (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.) You say rajulN taAmRu Alxaloqi [A man complete, or perfect, in respect of make, or proportion, &c.]. (S, K. * [See also xiloqapN.]) [In this and similar instances,] Alxaloq signifies The fashion of the outer man, and its [peculiar] qualities and attributes; like as Alxuluqu signifies “ the fashion of the inner man, ” &c. (TA.) ― -b2- Alxaloqu is also used in the sense of Almaxoluwqu↓ [meaning What is created; the creature]: (TA, and Bd in xxiii. 17, &c.:) [and, collectively, the creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created;] all created things: (Bd ubi suprà, &c.:) and [particularly] mankind; as also Alxliyqapu↓: (S, * K:) and mankind and the jinn, or genii, and others: (Jel in lv. 9, &c.:) and Alxliyqapu↓ and [its pl.] xalaAYiqu signify the same: you say, humo xaliyqapu QllRehi and also humo xalqu QllRehi [They are the creatures of God]: Alxaloqu being originally an inf. n.: (S, TA:) and Lh mentions [an instance of its having a pl., in] the saying, laA waQlRaciI xalaqa Alxuluwqa maA faEalotu kacaA, meaning [No, by Him who created] all creatures, [I did not such a thing.] (TA.) In the saying, falayugayRirunRa xaloqa QllRehi, in the Kur [iv. 118, lit. And they shall alter the creature of God], some say that castration is meant: (TA: [and Bd includes, with this, other unnatural actions:]) or the meaning is, the religion of God; (Bd, Jel, TA;) accord. to El-Hasan and Mujáhid. (TA.) And laA tabodiyla lixaloqi QllRehi, in the Kur [xxx. 29], means, accord. to Katádeh, [There shall be no changing, or altering,] of the religion of God. (TA.) ― -b3- xaloqN also signifies Anything made smooth. (TA.) [See also muxalRaqN.]

xuloqN xlq xlqp
xuloqN: see xuluqN, in four places.

xalaqu xlq xlqp
xalaqu inf. n. of xaliqa: as such, signifying The being smooth [&c.]. (JK, S. *) [As such also,] in a rock, Freedom from crack or fracture. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And, as such,] The being old, and worn out. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence, used as an epithet,] Old, and worn out: (S, Msb, K:) [and as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; meaning an old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth:] pl. xuloqaAnN (S, K) and OaxolaAqN. (S, * K, * TA.) And [as an epithet] it is masc. and fem.; (S, K;) because it is originally an inf. n., the inf. n. of Oaxolaqu meaning “ smooth, ” (S,) [or rather of xaliqa meaning “ it was, or became, old, and worn out; ” although it has pls.; and] IB mentions an instance of its dual, xalaqaAni: (TA:) Ks says, We have not heard them say, xalaqapN in any instance: (Lh, TA:) Fr says that it is without p [as a fem. epithet] because it was originally used as a prefixed noun; for one said, OaEoTiniI xalaqa jubRatika and xalaqa EimaAmatika [lit. meaning Give thou to me what is old, and worn out, of thy jbRp and of thy turban]; but Ez-Zejjájee says that this is nought. (TA.) You say vawobN xalaqN [An old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth], and miloHafapN xalaqN [an old and worn-out outer wrapping garment]: (S:) also rumRapN xalaqN [an old and worn-out piece of rope]: and daArN xalaqN [an old and decayed house]: and jisomN xalaqN [an old and wasted body]. (TA.) One says also vawobN OaxolaAqN, meaning A garment, or piece of cloth, altogether, or wholly, old and worn out; (Fr, S, K;) every portion of it being xalaq; (Fr;) like as they said buromapN OaEoXaArN &c.: (S:) and in like manner, mulaMCapN OaxolaAqN. (IAar.) And Ks mentions the saying, OaSobaHato viyaAbuhumo xuloqaAnFA wa xalaquhumo jududFA [Their garments became old, and worn out; and their old and worn-out garments became replaced by new]; with the sing. [in the latter clause] in the place of the pl. xuloqaAn: (TA:) or jududFA may be here put for jadiydFA. (L in art. jd.) In the phrase miloHafapN xulayoqN↓ [An outer wrapping garment that is a little, or somewhat, old, and worn out], the dim. is without p because it is [the dim. of] an epithet [applied without p to a fem. n.], and p is not affixed to the dims. of epithets [of this kind]: it is like nuSayufN dim. of naSafN an epithet applied to a woman. (S, K. * [See Lumsden's Arab. Gram. p. 623: but some of the grammarians consider these instances as anomalous.]) ― -b4- baAEahu biyEapa Alxalaqi, and bayoEa ciI Alxalaqi, the latter as used by a poet, [lit. He bought it, or sold it, (app. the former,) as one buys, or sells, the old and worn-out garment, like as we say “ dogcheap, ” and “ cheap as dirt ”], are phrases mentioned, but not explained, by IAar, who cites the following saying:
Oaboligo fazaArapa OanRiI qado Xarayotu lahaA
majoda AlHayaApi bisayofiI bayoEa ciI Alxalaqi
[app. meaning Tell thou Fezárah that I have purchased for them life-long glory (lit. the glory of life), with my sword, as cheaply, i. e as easily, as one purchases the old and worn-out garment]. (TA.) ― -b5- saHaAbapN xalaqapN: see the next paragraph.

xaliqN xlq xlqp
xaliqN [part. n. of xaliqa]. ― -b2- [Hence,] sHaAbapN xaliqapN A cloud in which is a sign, or trace, of rain; as also xaliyqapN↓: (S, K:) or a cloud giving hope of rain; as also xaloqaMCu↓; (JK;) both are said by IAar to signify the same: (TA:) and xalaqapN↓ [alone, as a subst., or probably saHaAbapN xalaqapN,] a cloud that is equable, or uniform, giving hope of rain. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.)

xuluqN xlq xlqp
xuluqN (S, Msb, K) and xuloqN↓ (S, K) A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. sajiyRapN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and TaboEN; (K, TA;) of which one is created: (TA:) and xiloqapN↓ signifies [the same; i. e.] the fiTorapN [or nature, &c.,] (S, Msb, K, TA) of which a man is created; (TA;) like [xuluqN and] xuloqN↓: (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, xaloq:]) and xaliyqapN↓ [also] signifies [the same; i. e.] the TabiyEap [or nature, &c.,] (S, K, TA) with which a man is created: (TA:) the proper signification of xuluqN is [the moral character; or] the fashion of the inner man; i. e. his mind, or soul, and its peculiar qualities and attributes; like as xaloqN signifies the “ fashion of the outer man, and its [peculiar] qualities and attributes: ” it signifies also custom or habit [as being a second nature]: (TA:) and, as also xuloqN↓, [which is merely a contraction thereof, and therefore identical with it in all its senses,] manliness; syn. muruwoCapN: and religion: (IAar, K:) the pl. is OaxolaAqN only: (TA:) [this is often used as signifying morals: and ethics:] and the pl. of xaliyqapN↓ in the sense explained above [said in Har p. 193 to be that of xuluqN] is xalaAYiqN. (S.) It is said in a trad., layosa XaIoCN fiI AlmiyzaAni Oavoqala mino Husoni Alxuluqi [Nothing is heavier in the balance in which good and evil will be weighed than goodness of the moral character, &c.] (TA.) And one says, EalayohaA AlRatiI xuliqa↓ hecihi xaliyqatuhu↓ and xuliqahaA↓ and AlRatiI xuliqa↓ This is his nature, &c., of which he was created. (Lh.) And UinRahu lakariymu Alxaliyqapi↓ Verily he is generous in respect of nature, &c. (AZ.) And SaAra celika lahu xuluqFA That became to him [a second nature, a habit, or] a thing to which he was habituated. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxvi. 137], Uino hecaA UilRaA xuluqu AlOawRaliyna This is nought but a custom of the ancients. (TA.) And in the same [lxviii. 4], wa UinRaka laEalaI xuluqK EaZiymK And verily thou art of a great religion. (Jel, TA.) And in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, kaAna xuluquhu AlqaroMna, meaning That whereto he clung was the Kur-án, with its rules of discipline and its command and its prohibitions, and the excellences and beauties and gracious things comprised in it. (TA.) ― -b2- nawomapu Alxulqi [i. e. Alxuluqi or Alxuloqi↓] The sleep of midday, which was prescribed by the Prophet. (Har p. 223. [See also HumoqN and xuroqN.])

xuloqapN xlq xlqh xlqp
xuloqapN Smoothness; (K, TA;) as also xuluwqapN↓ and xalaAqapN↓: (K:) but the second of these three, correctly speaking, [as also the third, accord. to analogy, and perhaps the first also,] is an inf. n. of xaluqa. (TA.)

xiloqapN xlq xlqh xlqp
xiloqapN [primarily signifies A mode, or manner, of xaloq, generally as meaning creation; a particular make: and hence,] constitution; syn. tarokiybN: (Mgh:) [and particularly the natural constitution of an animated being, as created in the womb of the mother; also termed fiTorapN:] see also xuluqN. You say rajulN Hasanu Alxiloqapi [A man goodly, or beautiful, in respect of make]. (A, TA.) fiI masolakK huwa xiloqapN means fiI TariyqK OaSoliIRK xiloqiIRK↓ [In a way, or road, that is natural, and original]. (Mgh.)

xalaqapN xlq xlqh xlqp
xalaqapN: see xaliqN.

xiloqiIRN xlq xlqI xlqp xlqy xlqyy
xiloqiIRN Natural; not accidental: [constitutional: of, or relating to, or belonging to, the natural constitution of an animated being, as created in the womb of the mother:] rel. n. of xiloqapN. (Msb.) You say EayobN xiloqiIRN A natural fault or imperfection &c. (Msb.) And SifapN xiloqiyRapN [A natural quality]; opposed to QxotiyaAriyRapN. (Msb in art. mdH.) See also xiloqapN.

xalaqiIRN xlq xlqI xlqp xlqy xlqyy
xalaqiIRN One who wears old and worn-out clothes. (TA.)

xuloqaAniIRN xlq xlqAn xlqAnI xlqAny
xuloqaAniIRN A seller of old and worn-out clothes. (TA.)

xalaAqN xlAq
xalaAqN A share, or portion: (JK, S, Msb:) and a good, just, or righteous, share or portion: (JK:) or a full, a complete, or an abundant, share or portion of good, (K, TA,) and of goodness, or righteousness: (TA:) and religion: or a share, or portion, thereof. (TA.) One says, laA xalaAqa lahu fiI AlMxirapi There is no share, or portion, [of good] for him in the final state of existence. (S. [See the Kur iii. 71, &c.]) And laA xalaAqa lahu He has no desire for good, nor righteousness in religion. (TA.)

xilaAqN xlAq
xilaAqN: see the next paragraph.

xaluwqN xlwq
xaluwqN A certain species of perfume; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) also termed xilaAqN↓; (Lh, Msb, K;) accord. to some of the lawyers, (Msb,) fluid, (Mgh, Msb,) but of thick consistence; (L, voce naDoxN;) and in which is a yellowness: (Mgh, Msb:) it is composed of saffron and other things; and redness and yellowness are predominant in it: it is forbidden [to men], because it is of the perfumes of women, who use it more than do men. (TA.)

xaliyqN xlyq
xaliyqN, applied to a man, (S, TA,) Perfect, or complete, in make; (TA;) as also muxotalaqN↓: (Ham p. 561:) or perfect, or complete, in make, and just in proportion; (S, TA;) and so ↓the latter; (S, K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, muxotaliq; in the TA expressly said to be of the pass. form;]) fem. of the former with p: (TA:) or ↓both signify goodly, or beautiful, in make: or the former is not applied to a man; but ↓each, with p, signifies a woman having [a goodly] body and make: (TA, in which this signification is said to be tropical:) and xaliyqN and xaliyqapN are alike, (JK, TA,) accord. to Lh, (TA,) in this last sense: (JK:) or the former of these two may be pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the latter, like as XaEiyrN is of XaEiyrapN: (TA:) and muxotalaqN↓ signifies anything just in proportion: (IF, TA:) muxalRaqN↓, also, signifies perfect, or complete, in make; applied to a camel (jml): (TA:) [or jml, here may be a mistranscription for Hamol; for] muDogapN muxalRaqapN↓ signifies [a fœtus when it has become like a lump of flesh] perfect, or complete, in make; (Fr, S, K;) so in the Kur xxii. 5; (Fr, TA;) or of which the make has become apparent. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- Also Adapted or disposed [by nature], apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; (KL, PS;) syn. jadiyrN (S, K) and HariIRN (TA) [and HaqiyqN &c.: pl. xulaqaMCu, and Freytag adds xuluqN]. You say, fulaAnN xaliyqN likacaA, i. e. jadiyrN bihi [Such a one is adapted or disposed by nature, &c., for such a thing]; as though he were one of those in whom that was reckoned to be, and in whom the symptoms, signs, or tokens, thereof were seen. (S.) [And huwa xaliyqN liloxayori He is adapted or disposed by nature to good; i. e., to be, or to do, or to effect, or to produce, what is good.] And UinRahu laxaliyqN Oano yafoEala celika and biOano yfEl clk and liOano yfEl clk and mno Oano yfEl clk [Verily he is adapted or disposed &c. for doing that; or worthy to do it]: so says Lh: and he adds that the Arabs say, yaA xaliyqu bicelika, using the nom. case; and yaA xaliyqFA bicelika, using the accus. case; [the latter being the usual form; both meaning O thou who art adapted or disposed &c. for that;] but ISd says, I know not the reason of this. (TA.) And licaAka hecaA maxolaqapN↓, i. e. majodarapN lahu [This is one that is adapted or disposed &c. for that]: (S, K: *) and laka hecaA AlOamoru maxolaqapN↓ [This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted &c. for thee]: and mino celika UinRahu maxolaqapN↓ [Verily it is adapted &c. for that]: like majodarapN and maHoraApN and maqomanapN: and in like manner one says of two, and of more than two, and of a feminine: so says Lh. (TA.) [maxolaqapN↓ properly signifies A place, and hence a thing, an affair, and a person, adapted or disposed &c.: it is of the same class as maEosaApN and maZinRapN and maYinRapN.] xaliyqN also signifies Habituated, or accustomed. (PS, TA. *) And one says, UinRahu laxaliyqN, i. e. laHariIRN, meaning Verily it is probable; or likely to happen or be, or to have happened or been. (TA.) And huwa xaliyqN lahu He, or it, is like to him, or it. (JK, TA.) ― -b3- saHaAbapN xaliyqapN: see xaliqN. ― -b4- [See also xaliyqapN, which, in several senses, is a fem. epithet used as a subst.]

xulayoqN xlyq
xulayoqN: see xalaqN (of which it is the dim.), in the latter half of the paragraph.

xalaAqapN xlAq xlAqh xlAqp
xalaAqapN: see xuloqapN.

xuluwqapN xlwq xlwqh xlwqp
xuluwqapN: see xuloqapN.

xaliyqapN xlyq xlyqh xlyqp
xaliyqapN: see xaloqN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The beasts, or brutes. (En-Nadr, K.) The saying, respecting the xawaArij [a sect of heretics, or schismatics], humo XarRu Alxaloqi wa AlxaliyqapN is explained by En-Nadr as meaning [They are the worst of mankind and] of the beasts, or brutes. (TA.) ― -b3- And A well (biYorN) just dug: (AA, K:) or a well in which is no water: or a hollow, cavity, pit, or hole, formed by nature in the ground: or a small hollow or cavity, in a mountain, in which water remains and stagnates: accord. to IAar, xlq [app. xuluqN, pl. of xaliyqapN, like as mudunN and SuHufN are pls. of madiynapN and SaHiyfapN,] signifies wells recently dug. (TA.) ― -b4- And Land (OaroDN) that is dug. (TA.) ― -b5- See also xuluqN, in four places.

xulayoqaMCu xlyqMC
xulayoqaMCu [dim. of xaloqaMCu fem. of Oaxolaqu]: see Oaxolaqu, in three places.

xalaAYiqu c
xalaAYiqu [pl. of xaliyqapN]. ＝ -A2- AlxalaAYiqu i. q. HamaAYiru AlmaMCi, i. e. Four large and smooth masses of stone at the head of the well, upon which the drawer of the water stands. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, HawoDN baAdiI AlxalaAYiqi means [A watering-trough of which] the [stones termed] naSaAYib [appear]. (JK, TA. [See naSiybapN.])

xulRaqN xlq xlqp
xulRaqN: see Oaxolaqu.

xalRaAqN xlAq
xalRaAqN: see the next paragraph.

xaAliqN xAlq
xaAliqN [act. part. n. of xalaqa:] A worker in leather and the like; (K, TA;) because he measures first, and then cuts. (TA.) To xaAliqaAt, meaning Women working in leather, as engaged in dividing a hide (Oadiym), El-Kumeyt likens genealogists. (TA.) ― -b2- AlxaAliqu, as an epithet applied to God, (K, Msb, TA,) properly, He who brings into existence according to the proper measure, or proportion, or adaptation; (TA;) [and hence, the Creator; or] the Originator, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (K:) or He who hath brought into existence all things after they had not been in existence: (Az, TA:) and AlxalRaAqu↓ signifies the same; (Msb, * TA;) [i. e. the Creator of all things; or, as an intensive epithet, the Great Creator;] or the Creator of many creatures: (Ksh and Bd and Jel, in xxxvi. 81:) Az says that this epithet, with the article Al, may not be applied to any but God. (Msb.) Accord. to IAmb, tabaAraka QllRehu OaHosanu AlxaAliqiyna means AHsn AlmuqadRariyna [i. e. Blessed be God, the Best of those who make things according to their proper measures, or proportions, or adaptations]. (TA.)

xawaAliqu xwAlq
xawaAliqu [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Smooth mountains: so in the saying of Lebeed,
wa AlOaroDu taHotahumo mihaAdFA raAsiyFA
vabatato xawaAliquhaA biSumRi Aljanodala
[And the earth beneath them a firm expanse; its smooth mountains being rendered fast by hard and solid stones]. (K, TA. [In the CK, bDamRi is erroneously put for biSumRi.])

Oaxolaqu c
Oaxolaqu Smooth: (JK, K:) smooth and solid; (S, K, TA;) applied in this sense to anything: (TA:) smooth and firm: (JK:) fem. xaloqaMCu. (JK, S, K.) You say HajarN Oaxolaqu Stone that is smooth (K, TA) and solid, upon which nothing makes an impression. (TA.) And SaxorapN xaloqaMCu A rock, or great mass of stone, smooth (K, TA) and solid: (TA:) or free from crack and fracture. (S, K, TA.) And firosinN xaloqaMCu A camel's foot in which is no crack. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And haDobapN xaloqaMCu [A hill, or the like,] destitute of herbage or vegetation. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Poor; syn. faqiyrN. (K.) You say rajulN Oaxolaqu mina AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) A man destitute of property. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., layosa Alfaqiyra faqiyru AlmaAli UinRamaA Alfaqiyru AlOaxolaqu Alkasobi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The poor in respect of property is not the poor the poor is only]
he who has no good deeds for which he will be rewarded in the world to come. (TA, in two places.) ― -b3- AlOaxolaqu also signifies The exterior of a horse's hoof. (JK.) ― -b4- And xaloqaMCu, (JK, S, K,) applied to a woman, (JK, S,) Impervia coëunti; (S, K, TA;) as also xulRaqN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b5- See also xaliqN. ― -b6- And AlxaloqaMCu [used as a subst.] The sky; because of its smoothness and evenness. (TA.) ― -b7- And The side of a camel &c. (K.) One says also, Darabotu xaloqaMCa janobihi (K, TA [in the CK ElI xaloqaACa janobihi]) I struck the outer part of his side. (TA.) ― -b8- And The interior (Lth, K, TA) and smooth part (Lth, TA,) of the gaAr, (K,) i. e., of [the upper part of the interior of the mouth, or] what is termed AlgaAru AlOaEolaI; (Lth, TA;) as also AlxulayoqaMCu↓ [the dim. of AlxaloqaMCu]: (Lth, K, TA:) or both signify what appears of the gAr: and the dim. form is that which is predominant in this case. (TA.) ― -b9- And The part of the forehead that is even (JK, K, TA) and smooth; (TA;) as also AlxulayoqaMCu↓. (JK, K, TA.) One says, suHibuwA EalaI xaloqaAwaAti jibaAhihimo [They were dragged along upon the even and smooth parts of their foreheads]. (TA [in which this is said to be tropical]) ― -b10- Alfarasi xulayoqaMCu↓ That [part] of the horse which is like the Eironiyn [or upper part of the nose] of man; (S, K;) the part where the forehead of the horse meets the narrow portion of the bone of the nose: AO says that the xulayoqaAwaAni in the face of the horse are [the two parts] where his forehead meets the bone of his nose, on the right and left of the xulayoqaMC, sloping towards the eye; and the xulayoqaMC is [the part] between the eyes; and some call it the xaloqaMC. (TA.) ＝ -A2- UinRa Oaxolaqa bika Oano tafoEala kacaA is a phrase mentioned by Ks, as meaning Verily the most apt, meet, suitable, fit, or proper, thing for thee to do is such a thing. (TA.)

maxolaqapN mxlqh mxlqp
maxolaqapN: see xaliyqN, in four places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

muxalRaqN mxlq
muxalRaqN: see xaliyqN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also, applied to an arrow, Made smooth (S, K, TA) and even. (TA.) [See also xaloqN, last signification; and muxotalaqN.]

maxoluwqN mxlwq
maxoluwqN [pass. part. n. of xalaqa. When used as a subst., signifying A creature, or created thing, its pl. is maxoluwqaAtN]. See xaloqN. ― -b2- qaSiydapN maxoluwqapN (tropical:) [An ode that is forged; or] ascribed to a person not its author. (S, K, * TA.)

muxotalaqN mxtlq
muxotalaqN: see xaliyqN, first sentence, in five places. ― -b2- Also Made smooth. (TA.) [See also muxalRaqN.] ― -b3- And Generous in [nature, or] natural dispositions. (Ham p. 561.) ― -b4- muxotalaqN lilomuloki, in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, means Created of a nature fitting for dominion: (S, TA:) and so liloOaSoHaAbi [for companions]; as in a verse of Ibn-Ahmar. (TA.)

muxolawoliqN mxlwlq
muxolawoliqN Very smooth; its measure being one of those that denote intensiveness. (Ham p. 358.)

xalanojN xlnj
xalanojN a Persian word, arabicized, (S,) A kind of tree, (S, K,) of the wood of which vessels are made: (TA:) or any [bowl of the kinds called] jafonap and SaHofap, or other vessel, made of wood having variegated streaks: (L:) pl. xalaAniju. (S, K.) The word is mentioned [in the S and K in art. xlj; but] in the L and some other lexicons in a separate art., because all the letters of a word which is not Arabic are regarded as radical. (MF.)

1 xalaA xl xlA
1. xalaA, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaxoluw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. xuluwRN, (S, Msb, K,) or xalaMCN, (Msb,) or both, (K,) said of a place, (K,) of a place of alighting or abode, (Msb,) and of a thing, (S, TA,) It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; (K, TA;) had none, and nothing, in it; (TA;) as also AxlI↓, (Msb, K,) and AstxlI↓, (K.) [xalaA AlmakaAnu mina AlnRaAsu wa AlmaMCi waAlkalaO means The place was, or became, devoid, or destitute, of human beings and water and herbage or pasturage; without human beings &c.] Of a place of alighting or abode, you say, xalaA mino Oaholihi and AxlI↓ [It was, or became, devoid, or destitute, of its occupants]. (Msb.) And of a vessel, xalaA mimRaA fiyhi It was, or became, empty of what was in it. (Mgh.) And xalawotu Eani AlTRaEaAmi (S) I became empty, in the belly, of food; (PS;) and Eanohu Oaxolayotu↓ signifies the same. (S.) And xalaA min AlEayobi, (Msb,) or Eani AlOamori, and minohu, (Kudot;,) inf. n. xuluwRN, He was, or became, free (Msb, K) from fault, (Msb,) or from the thing, or affair: (K:) and, accord. to IAar, xlA alone signifies he was, or became, free from a fault, or the like, of which he was accused, or suspected. (TA.) And xalato Eano maAniEi AlnRikaAHi, inf. n. xuluwRN, is said of a woman [as meaning She was, or became, free from any obstacle to marriage]. (Msb.) Accord. to the K, xalaA makaAnuhu [lit. His place became vacant] means (tropical:) he died: but accord. to IAar, xalaA alone has this signification [from the same verb signifying maDaI. explained below]: and if you add mkAnh, you say xalRaI, with teshdeed; which see below. (TA.) You say also, xalaA laka AlXRaIoCu and AxlI↓, both signifying the same, (AA, S, TA,) i. q. faraga [i. e. The thing was, or became, vacant, or unoccupied, for thee: (see an ex. of the former verb in a saying of Tarafeh cited voce jawRN:) and hence, the thing was, or became, exclusively for thee]. (TA.) AA cites as an ex. the saying of Maan Ibn-Ows,
OaEaAcilu halo yaOotiI AlqabaAYila HaZRuhaA
lanA Almawotu waHodanaA mina Almawoti Oamo OaxolaI↓
[O censurer, does their share of death come to the tribes in common, or is death exclusively for us alone?]. (S, TA.) See also the paragraph, below, commencing with xalaA as a word denoting exception. ― -b2- [Hence,] xalaA and AxlI↓, (S, K,) said of a man, (TA,) or the same two verbs followed by binafosihi, said of a man, (Msb,) both signify the same; (S;) He was, or became, [without any companion, i. e.] alone, by himself; (Msb;) or he became (waqaEa [q. v.]) in a vacant place, in which he was not pressed against, or straitened. (K.) And xalaA bihi, (S, Msb, K,) and Uilayohi, (S, K,) and maEahu, (K,) inf. n. xalowapN (S, Msb, K) and xalaMCN (S, K) and xalowN, (K, TA,) or xuluwRN, (CK,) or the first of these, i. e. xalowapN, is a simple subst., and the second and third are the inf. ns.; (TA;) and bh AxlI↓, (Lh, K,) and AxlAhu↓, (S, K,) and bihi AstxlI↓; (K; [the last omitted in the CK;]) He was, or became, alone with him; (Msb;) he was, or became, in company with him, or he met him, or had a meeting or an interview with him, in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied [by others, i. e., in a private place]. (S, K.) In the saying in the Kur [ii. 13], waUicaA xalawoA UilaI XayaATiynihimo, it is said that UilaI is used in the sense of maEa, [so that the meaning is And when they are alone with their devils,] as in that other saying in the Kur [iii. 45 and lxi. 14], mano OanoSaAriI UilaI QllRehu. (S.) A man says to another man, Auxolu maEiI HatRaI OukalRimaka, i. e. Be [or come] thou alone with me [that I may speak to thee in private]. (TA.) And one says, xalaA bizawojatihi, inf. n. xalowapN, [but see what is said of this noun above,] He was, or became, alone with his wife: but [properly speaking, according to the law,] the term xalowapN [or xalowapN SaHiyHapN, in this case,] is not used unless it be with the enjoyment of AlmufaAxacap, [see 3 in art. fxc,] and then it has an effect upon the circumstances of the marriage [by its rendering obligatory the payment of the dowry, though consummation has not taken place]: if with consummation, the act is termed duxuwlN. (Msb.) You say also, Oaxoli↓ Oamoraka and biOamorika Be thou alone in thine affair, with none to take part with thee in it; confine thyself to it exclusively of other things. (TA. [See also 5.]) And Uilayoka Oaxoli↓ Keep thou to thine affair, and be alone in it, with none to take part with thee therein. (JK.) And AlbukaMCu AstxlI↓ [app. for biAlbukaMCi] He was, or became, alone in weeping, with none to participate with him in it. (TA.) [And xalaA liloOamori: see 5.] And xalaAEalaI baEoDi AlTRaEaAmi He restricted himself to a portion of the food. (K.) Temeem say, xalaA fulaAnN EalaI AllRabani wa AllRaHomi (JK, * TA) i. e. Such a one fed upon milk and flesh-meat alone; (JK;) or such a one ate not, nor mixed, anything with milk and flesh-meat: and Kináneh and Keys say OaxolaI↓. (Lh, JK, * TA.) [And it seems to be indicated in the T that xalawoA signifies They selected a she-camel for a xaliyRap, q. v.: or i. q. taxalRawoA bixalayRipK: see 5.] ― -b3- xalaA also ssignifies He devoted himself to religious services or exercises [app. in solitude, or seclusion, or in a xalowap; or because one generally does so in solitude; or because the doing so involves abstraction from other affairs]. (TA. [See also 5; and see musotaxolK.]) ― -b4- And xalaA bihi
[sometimes] signifies (tropical:) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him: (Lh, S, Z, K, TA:) said by Az to be strange, and not known by him or any other authority than that of Lh: (TA:) from the saying, xalaA fulaAnN biEiroDi fulaAnK yaEobavu bihi [Such a one occupied himself alone with the honour, or reputation, of such a one, making sport with it]. (Ksh in ii. 13.) And i. q. xaAdaEahu (tropical:) [He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; &c.: or he strove to do so]: (TA:) as also xAlAhu↓, (JK, and K in art. xlI,) inf. n. muxaAlaApN. (JK.) ― -b5- And xalaA Ealayohi He relied upon him; [as though he betook himself to him alone;] syn. AiEotamada. (TA.) ― -b6- And xalaA, (JK, K,) inf. n. xuluwRN, (TA,) or xalaMCN, (JK,) said of a man (JK) and of a thing, (JK, TA,) He, or it, went, went away, or passed away. (JK, K.) Hence, (TA,) wa Uino mino OumRapKUilRaA xalaA fiyhaA naciyrN, in the Kur [xxxv. 22], means [And there is not any people but a warner] hath gone, and hath been sent, among them. (S, TA.) [Hence also xalaA explained above as meaning He died.] And xalaA minohaA [an elliptical phrase] She became old; the greater part of her life passed. (TA from a trad.) And xalaAka camRN [for xalaA Eanoka camRN] Blame passed away from thee; or may blame pass away from thee. (Ksh and Bd in ii. 13.) You say, AifoEalo kacaA wa xalaAka camRN Do thou such a thing, and thou wilt have an excuse; [i. e.] blame will fall from thee. (S. [See art. cm.]) And xalaAhu AlHuzonu Grief passed away from him, and quitted him. (Har p. 590, from the Tekmileh.) ― -b7- xalaA Eani AlXRaIoCi: see 2. ＝ -A2- xalaA [or xalaI, probably belonging to art. xlI, though mentioned in the present art.,] He ate what was good, sweet, or pleasant. (TA.)

2 xalRaI xl xlI xly
2. xalRaI, inf. n. taxoliyapN, [He left a place, &c., empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied.] Hence, xlRI makaAnahu [He left his place vacant;] meaning (tropical:) he died: (TA, and so in Ham p. 478:) a meaning assigned in the K to xalaA↓ makaAnuhu, and by IAar to xalaA alone, without tesh-deed; but when mkAnh is added, it is with teshdeed. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He went his way. (Ham p. 379.) And xlRI sabiylahu [He left his way free, or open, to him]. (S, TA.) And xlRI bayonahumaA [He left the way, or space, free between them two; meaning he left them two free, each to do to the other as he pleased]. (TA.) [And xlRI bayonahu wabayona kacaA He left him free access to such a thing.] And xlRI bayonahu wa bayona nafosihi He left him, or it, alone; syn. Oahomalahu. (S and O and K in art. hml.) [And xlRAhu wafulaAnFA He left him to do as he pleased with such a one.] And xlRI AlOamora He left, left alone, or let alone, the thing, or affair; as also txlRI↓ minohu and Eanohu; and xAlAhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. xilaMCN. (TA.) For taxoliyapN signifies The leaving, and making a thing to be alone. (Har p. 123.) [xlRAhu and xlRI Eanohu both signify He left, or left alone, it, or him.] It is said in a trad., xlRI Eanohumo OarobaEiyna EaAmFA He (God) left them, or left them alone, and turned from them, forty years. (TA.) [And xlRAhu likacaA He made him, or left him, vacant, unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure, for such a thing.] ― -b2- taxoliyapN also signifies The act of loosing; contr. of XadRN. (IAar, K in art. AbD.) [Hence,] xlRI Eani AlXRaIoCi, (JK, S, * TA,) in the K xalaA↓, without teshdeed, but this requires consideration, (TA,) He dismissed, loosed, let loose, or let go, the thing. (JK, K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence xlRAhu meaning He left it, permitted it, or allowed it: see the pass. part. n., below.] ＝ -A2- xulRiyato, said of a she-camel such as is termed xaliyRap; and hence, of a cooking-pot: see 1 in art. xlI.

3 xAlAhu xAl xAlAh xAlAp
3. xAlAhu He left, forsook, relinquished, abandoned, deserted, or quitted, him, being left, &c., by him; namely, another man; syn. taArakahu; (S;) inf. n. muxaAlaApN, syn. with muwaAdaEapN, (JK,) [and xilaMCN also: and he was, or became, distant, remote, far off, aloof, or apart, from him; for] xilaMCN is syn. with mubaAEadapN and mujaAnabapN (TA in art. xlO) and furoqapN. (TA in the present art.) And xAlI AlOamora, inf. n. xilaMCN: see 2. ― -b2- [Also He went, or came, out, or forth, to him, in the field; for] muxaAlaApN is also syn. with mubaArazapN. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (Lth, JK, K,) inf. n. muxaAlaApN, (Lth, JK,) He wrestled with him, each endeavouring to throw down the other; contended with him in wrestling: (Lth, JK, K: mentioned in the K in art. xlI:) because, when one does so, he is alone with the other, so that neither of them seeks aid from any other. (Az, TA.) And in like manner the word muxaAlaApN is used [app. as meaning The act of contending with another, by oneself,] in relation to any affair, or case. (Lth, JK, TA. [See its act. part. n., below.]) ― -b4- See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

4 Oaxolawa
4: see 1, in eleven places. ＝ -A2- AxlI AlmakaAna, (S, K,) or Almanozila, (Msb,) He made the place, (K,) or the place of alighting or abode, (Msb,) empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied: (Msb, K:) or it signifies, (S, K,) or signifies also, (Msb,) he found it empty, &c. (S, Msb, K.) One says in praying for another that he may have a long life, laA OaxolaI QllRehu makaAnaka [May God not make thy place vacant]. (TA.) ― -b2- AxlAhu maEahu [He made him, or found him, to be alone with him]. (K.)

5 txlRI Oxl OxlI txlI txly xl xlA xlI
5. txlRI He went forth into the field, or open country, to satisfy a want of nature. (TA.) And txlRI fiI AlxalaMCi He went forth into the vacant tract, or into the privy, to satisfy a want of nature: or he satisfied a want of nature therein. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He was, or became, or made himself, vacant from occupation, or business; [unoccupied; unemployed; or at leisure;] syn. tafarRaga: (S:) or so txlRI mina AlXRugoli. (K in art. frg.) You say, txlRI liloEibaAdapi He was, or became, or made himself, vacant for, or he confined himself exclusively to, the service of God. (TA.) [See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph. In like manner, one says also, liloOamori xalaA↓ He was, or became, or made himself, vacant for, or he confined himself exclusively to, the affair.] And taxalRawoA bixaliyRapK (S, K, TA) They confined themselves exclusively to a she-camel, or to she-camels, such as they termed xlyp, (K, TA,) yaHolubuwnahaA [milking only her, or them]. (S, TA.) And txlRI xaliyRapF He took for himself a xlyRp. (TA.) ― -b3- And txlRI mina AlOamori and Eanohu: see 2. ― -b4- And taxalRati AlUibilu bilaA raAEK [The camels were left to themselves without a pastor]. (K in art. swE.)

10 Uisotaxolawa
10: see 1, in three places. [And see also musotaxolK.] ＝ -A2- AstxlAhu majolisahu He asked him to leave his sitting-place vacant, or unoccupied, for him. (S. [But found by me in only one copy of that work.]) ― -b2- AstxlI Almalika He asked the king to have a meeting, or an interview, with him in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied [by others, i. e., in a private place; he asked the king to grant him a private meeting or interview]. (K.)

xalaA xl xlA
xalaA as a word denoting exception, (S, Mughnee, K,) when it governs a gen. case, (S, Mughnee,) as when you say, jaAWuwniI xalaA zayodK [They came to me, except Zeyd], is a particle, (S, Mughnee, K,) accord. to some of the grammarians, like HaAXaI; but accord. to some, a prefixed inf. n. (S.) ↓It. also governs an accus. case, as a verb: (S, Mughnee:) so that you say, jaAWuwniI xalaA zayodFA [meaning as above]; the agent of xlA being implied, (S, Mughnee, *) like that of HaAXaI [used as a verb]: it is as though you said, xalaA mano jaMCaniI mino zayodK [i. e. those who came to me were without Zeyd]: (S:) or correctly, accord. to IB, xalaA baEoDuhumo zayodFA [for mino zayodK, like as you say, xalaAka camRN, for xalaA Eanoka camRN]. (TA.) When you say maA xalaA, it is followed only by an accus., because mA xlA is equivalent to an inf. n.; (S, Mughnee;) so that when you say, jaAWuwniI maA xalaA zayodFA [meaning as above], it is as if you said, jaAWuwniI xuluwRa zayodK [or xuluwRFA zayodFA], i. e. xuluwRahumo mino zayodK, (S,) which two phrases mean jaAWuwniI xaAliyna mino zayodK [They came to me, they being without Zeyd]: (S, K:) [for] accord. to Seer, mAxlA occupies the place of a noun in the accus. as a denotative of state: but some say, as an adv. n. of time; so that, accord. to these, maA xalaA zayodFA means waqota xuluwRihimo Eano zayodK [in the time of their being without Zeyd]. (Mughnee.) You say also, maA Oaradotu masaMCataka xalaA OanRiI waEaZotuka, meaning [I desired not to displease thee,] but I admonished thee (UilRaA OanRiI waEaZotuka). (JK, TA.)

xilowN xlw
xilowN, and its fem. (with p), and dual: see xaAlK, in seven places.

xalowapN xl xlI xlw xlwh xlwp
xalowapN said by some to be an inf. n.: [see xalaA bihi &c. in the first paragraph of this art.:] by others said to be a simple subst.; (TA;) meaning Loneliness; solitude; lonesomeness; solitariness; desolateness; syn. waHoXapN. (S and K in art. wHX.) [Hence, app.,] rajulN saholu Alxalowapi [A man easy in private conference]. (Msb in art. sls. [See also a phrase in
the latter part of the next paragraph.]) ― -b2- Also An empty, a vacant, a void, or an unoccupied, place. (KL. [See also xalaMCN.]) [In the present day, it is often applied to A closet to which one retires for privacy; and particularly to a cell for religious retirement: and is vulgarly pronounced xilowap.] You say, AijotamaEa maEahu fiI xalowapK (S) or AjtmE bihi fI xlwp (K) [He had a meeting, or an interview, with him in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied by others, i. e., in a private place]. ＝ -A2- Also Each of the two sharp sides or edges of an arrow-head (AHn, JK, TA) or of a spear-head: (AHn, TA:) both together are called the xalowataAni: (AHn, JK, TA.)

xalaMCN xlMC
xalaMCN is primarily an inf. n. (MF, TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- [Then it is used as an epithet, syn. with xaAlK:] see xaAlK, in five places. ― -b3- Then it is used [as a subst.] in the sense of A vacant place [in a general sense]: (MF, TA:) or a place in which is nothing: (S, K:) [often applied in the present day to any open tract of country or desert:] and then, particularly, such as one takes for the purpose of satisfying a want of nature; (MF, TA;) i. q. mutawaDRaON, (S, Msb, K,) but not as meaning only a place for the performance of AlwuDuwC, as might be imagined from this explanation: pl. OaxoliyapN. (MF, TA.) It is said in a prov., (S, Meyd,) xalaAWuka OaqonaI liHayaAYika, (S, Meyd, K,) [in Freytag's Arab. Prov., (i. 436,) biHayaMyika,] i. e. [Thy place of retirement is] most preservative (Oalozamu) [of thy sense of shame, or modesty]; meaning it is most fit for thee to be alone in thine abode; (S, * Meyd;) for he who is so needs not to be careful for his shame, or modesty: it is used in blaming the mixing with others. (Meyd.) HuSira Ealayohi xalaAWuhu [His place of retirement for satisfying a want of nature was straitened to him] is used as meaning he suffered suppression of the feces, or constipation of the bowels. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. HSr.) ＝ -A2- UinRahu laHoluw AlxalaMCi, (TA,) or [as written in a verse in which it occurs in the TA in the present art., and in art. xlI,] AlxalaA, (JK, TA,) [without C, but whether this be the right reading, or only required by poetic license, seems to be doubtful,] is a phrase mentioned by Th, (TA,) meaning Verily he is good in speech. (JK, TA. [If the former reading be right, the meaning may be similar to that of saholu Alxalowapi, mentioned above: if the latter only, or rather AnRh lHlw AlxalaI, be right, it probably belongs to art. xlIK, and is tropical, from the herbage termed xalI; and this may also be the case if the former reading be right.])

xaliIRN xl xlI xly
xaliIRN; and its fem. xaliyRapN: see xaAlK, in twelve places. ― -b2- The fem. also signifies, applied to a she-camel, (S, Msb,) Loosed from the cord, or rope, with which her fore shank and her arm have been bound together, (S, Msb, K,) and left alone, or free, (S,) so that she pastures where she will. (Msb.) Hence, (Msb,) it is used by way of metonymy as meaning Divorced: (Lh, S, Msb, K:) one says to a woman, Oanoti xaliyRapN Thou art divorced; (Lh, S;) and thus a man used to say in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) and one says, hiIa xaliyRapN She is divorced: (Msb:) and a woman is divorced thereby when divorce is meant. (Lh, TA.) Applied to a woman, it signifies also Free from any obstacle to marriage: pl. xaliyRaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also A she-camel that is made to affect, with another she-camel, one young one, so that both yield their milk to it, and to which the people of a tent, or house, confine themselves exclusively of the other for the purpose of milking her: (S:) or a she-camel that is chosen as the one more abundant in milk, when one has brought forth and her young one is drawn away (yujarRu) as soon as born, before she smells it, and the young one of another, that has brought forth before her, is brought near to her, and she affects it; the other is left to suckle the young one, and is termed basuwTN, pl. bsT [app. busoTN or busuTN]: (Az, TA:) or a she-camel that is left, or left alone, to be milked: (K:) or that affects a young one [not her own], or is destitute of her young one, (JK, M, K,) whether she incline to another's young one or do not, or that is destitute of her young one by death or slaughter, (M, TA,) and whose milk one causes to flow by means of the young one of another; but only by her affecting a young one, and not suckling it: (M, K: *) or that brings forth, when abundant in milk, and has her young one drawn (yujarRu) from beneath her, and another put beneath her, and is then left, or left alone, to be milked; (Lh, K;) this being done because of her generous quality: (Lh:) or a she-camel, or two she-camels, to which the people of a tent, or house, confine themselves exclusively, for milking, when two or three she-camels are made to affect one young one, and to yield their milk to it; the young one [afterwards] sucking from one of them only: (K, * TA:) or a she-camel that brings forth, and whose young one is drawn away (yujarRu) in order that her milk may continue for their use, she being made to yield her milk by means of the young one of another, which is then withdrawn from her, and she is milked: sometimes, also, they bring together three and four xalaAyaA [pl. of xaliyRapN] to one young camel: and the doing so is termed talasRunN: (IAar, TA:) in this case they take as a xlyRp whichever of them they will. (ISh, TA.) [Applied to a she-camel in any of these senses, it seems to be an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; i. e., used without its having naAqapN prefixed to it.] ＝ -A2- See also the paragraph next following, in two places.

xaliyRapN xly xlyh xlyp
xaliyRapN [as fem. of the epithet xaliIRN: see the next preceding paragraph, and the places there referred to in its first sentence. ＝ -A2- As a subst. it signifies] A great ship: (T, S, K:) or a ship that goes of itself, without its being made to do so by the sailor: (JK, K:) or one that is followed by a small boat: (K:) the first held by Az to be the right meaning: (TA:) pl. xalaAyaA. (JK, S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and xaliIRN↓, (JK, Msb, K,) The habitation (bayot) of bees, [whether it be a manufactured hive or a hollow in the trunk of a tree or in a rock,] in which they deposit their honey; (S;) the place in which bees deposit their honey: (Mgh:) or the thing in which bees deposit their honey, (K, TA,) not manufactured for them: (TA:) or a thing like the [kind of jar called] raAquwd, of clay, (K, TA,) made for bees: (TA:) or a certain thing for bees, well known, of clay or of wood: (Msb:) or, accord. to Lth, if made of clay, it is called kwArp, (Msb, TA,) i. e. [kuwaArapN and kuwRaArapN and kiwaArapN] with kesr: (Msb:) or a piece of wood hollowed out for honey to be deposited therein [by bees]: or the lower part of a tree that is called xazamapN, [n. un. of xazamN, q. v., hollowed out for that purpose,] resembling the [kind of jar called] raAquwd: (K:) or xaliIRN↓ signifies the part of the kuwRaArap which is the place of the honey: (JK:) pl. as above. (Msb, TA.)

xalaAwapu xlAwh xlAwp
xalaAwapu: see the next paragraph.

xaAlK xAl xAly
xaAlK Empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; (Mgh, TA;) having none, and nothing, in it: (TA:) applied to a place, (Msb, TA,) as also xaliIRN↓ (TA) and muxolK↓; (Msb;) and to a thing, as also xaliIRN↓; (TA;) or a vessel. (Mgh.) You say also makaAnN xalaMCN↓, [as well as xalaMCN alone,] meaning A place in which is none (K, TA) and nothing. (TA.) And wajadotu AldRaAra muxoliyapF↓, meaning xaAliyapF [i. e. I found the house empty, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Vacant, or free; from a thing or an affair; or devoid, or destitute, of a thing; (TA;) and so xaliIRN↓ and xilowN↓; which last is the same as masc. and fem., though it has xilowapN also for fem., and OaxolaMCN for pl.; (K;) but properly, accord. to Lh, it has no dual form, nor pl., nor fem., though some give it such forms: (TA:) or xaliIRN↓, which has a dual, [i. e. xaliyRaAni,] and pl., (S, Msb,) i. e. xaliyRuwna and OaxoliyaMCu, (K,) signifies free [from a thing]; or clear or quit [of a thing or person]; as also xalaMCu↓, (S, Msb,) which, being [originally] an inf. n., has no dual nor pl. [nor fem.]; (S;) and xilowN↓. (Msb.) You say, mino hecaA Oanota xaliIRN↓ AlOamori and xaAlK, i. e. Thou art free from this thing, or affair. (TA.) And mina AlhamRi OanaA xaliIRN↓, meaning xaAlK [i. e. I am free from anxiety]. (Mgh.) And mino kacaA OanaA xilowN↓, meaning xaAlK [i. e. I am free from such a thing]: (S:) and humaA xilowN, and humo xilowN; and some say, humaA xilowaAni, and humo OaxolaMCN, which is not proper. (T, TA.) And mino muSiybatiI Oanota xilowN↓ Thou art free in mind from my affliction, or misfortune. (TA from a trad.) And minoka OanaA xaliIRN↓ I am clear, or quit, of thee. (S.) And OanaA minoka xalaMCN↓ signifies the same. (S.) And naHonu minoka AlxalaMCu↓ and AlbaraMCu [q. v.] We are clear, or quit, of you. (Fr, T in art. brO.) And mino hecaA AlOamori Oanota xalaMCN↓ Thou art clear, or quit, of this affair. (TA.) And OanaA mino hecaA AlOamori kafaAliji boni xalaAwapa↓ [lit. I am, with respect to this affair, like Fálij Ibn-Kha-
láweh], (S,) or faAliju bonu xalaAwapa, (so in the JK and K in this art., and in the S and K in art. flj,) meaning bariIoCN [i. e. I am clear, or quit, of this affair]: (JK, S, K:) a saying originating from its being asked of Fálij Ibn-Khaláweh, on the day of Er-Rakam, when Uneys killed the captives, “ Dost thou, ” or “ wilt thou, ” “ aid Uneys? ” and his answering, “ I am clear, ” or “ quit, ” “ of him. ” (S and K in art. flj.) And xaliIRN↓ [alone] signifies xaAlK mina AlhamRi [Free from anxiety]; contr. of XajiIRN. (S.) It is said in a prov., wayolN lilXRajiIRi mina AlxaliIRi↓, i. e. Woe to him who is occupied by anxiety from him who is free therefrom: (TA:) and in another, maA yaloqaI AlXRajiIRu mina AlxaliIRi↓, i. e. What will he who is occupied by anxiety experience from him who is free therefrom? meaning, accord. to AO, that the latter will not aid the former against his anxieties, but will censure him: it is said in the Tekmileh that AlxaliIR [in these provs.] is from xalaAhu AlHuzonu meaning “ Grief passed away from him, ” and “ quitted him. ” (Har p. 590.) And Oanoti xaliyRapN↓ means xaAliyapN mina Alxayori [i. e. Thou, O woman, art devoid, or destitute, of good]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also A man having no wife; (S, K;) [for xaAlK mina AlzRawajaAti, a phrase occurring in the TA:] and a woman having no husband; (K;) thus without p: (TA:) pl. OaxolaMCN: (K:) and xilowapN↓, also, has the latter meaning; dual xilowataAni, and pl. xilowaAtN: and so has muxoliyapN↓: and xaliyRapN↓ means a woman having no husband nor children; pl. xaliyRaAtN. (TA.) ― -b4- [And Alone; as also muxolK↓, and xilowN↓.] It is said in a prov., OaXadRu AlcRiYobu muxoliyFA↓ The wolf when [alone or] in a vacant place [is most courageous, or violent]; (TA;) or xaAliyFA [which means the same]. (JK. [And another reading is OasadN. See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 500.]) And one says, wajadotu fulaAnapa muxoliyapF↓, meaning xaAliyapF [i. e. I found such a woman alone]. (TA.) And wajadahumaA xilowayoni↓ i. e. xaAliyayoni [He found them two alone]. (K.) ― -b5- [Also Past, or past away: as well as going, going away, or passing away.] Alquruwnu xaAliyapu means [The generations] that have passed. (JK, S, TA.)

xalFI xl xlI xly
xalFI Fresh, green, or juicy, herbage: (S, IB, Mgh, Msb, K:) that which is dry is termed HaXiyX [but see this word]: (Msb, from the Kf:) or dry HaXiyX: (so in one place in the S: [app. a mistake occasioned by an omission:]) or i. q. ruTobN, (IB, Msb,) with damm, (IB,) [i. e. fresh, or green, pasture; or such as consists of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the rabiyE; or of these and of trees or shrubs:] or herbage that is cut, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the rbyE: (Lth, JK:) or, accord. to [the Imám] Mohammad, anything that is eaten as pasture, not [growing] upon a stem: (Mgh:) or slender herbage as long as it remains fresh, green, or juicy: (IAth, TA:) it is also written xalaMCN↓, with medd, like qaDaMCN: (Msb:) n. un. xalaApN: (S, Msb, K:) or this signifies any herb (baqolap) that one pulls up: (K, * TA:) pl. 10 Astxmrhu Astxmrh Astxmrp
10. Astxmrhu He made him, or took him as, a slave: (S, Mgh, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Mgh, TA.) [See 3.] So in the trad. of Mo'ádh, mano Qsotaxomara qawomFA OawRaluhumo OaHoraArN wajiyraAnN musotaDoEafuwna falahu maA qaSara fiI bayotihi [Whosoever hath made slaves, or taken as slaves, persons the first state of whomhath been that of freemen and neighbours, regarded as weak, to him shall belong what he hath held in possession in his house or tent]: (S, * L:) i. e., hath taken them by force, and obtained possession of them: (S:) meaning, whosoever hath made slaves, or taken as slaves, persons in the Time of Ignorance, and then El-Islám hath come, to him shall belong those whom he hath held in possession in his house or tent: they shall not go from his hand. (Az, TA.) Mohammad Ibn-Ketheer says, This is a phrase known to us in ElYemen, where any other is scarcely ever used [in its stead]. (S.)

xamorN xmAr xmr
xamorN [Wine: or grape-wine:] what intoxicates, of the expressed juice of grapes: (ISd, K:) or the juice of grapes when it has effervesced, and thrown up froth, and become freed therefrom, and still: (Mgh:) or it has a common application to intoxicating expressed juice of anything: (K, TA:) or any intoxicating thing, that clouds, or obscures, (lit. covers,) the intellect; as some say: (Mgh, * Msb: [but see what follows:]) and the general application is the more correct, because xamor was forbidden when there was not in El-Medeeneh any xamor of grapes; the beverage of its inhabitants being prepared only from dates in their green and small state, or full-grown but unripe, or fresh and ripe, or dried: (K, * TA:) or the arguing thus, from this fact alone, requires consideration: (MF:) AHn says, it is (assumed tropical:) sometimes prepared from grains: but ISd holds this to be an improper signification: (TA:) it is also sometimes applied to the (assumed tropical:) beverage called nabiyc, like as nbyc is sometimes applied to wine expressed from grapes: (L in art. nbc:) applied to (tropical:) expressed juice from which xamor [properly so called] is made, [i. e., to must, or unfermented nabiyc,] it is tropical: it is so used in a trad. in which xamor is said to have been sold by [a companion of Mohammad named] Samurah: xamor [in its proper acceptation] is so called because it veils (taxomuru, i. e. tasoturu,) the intellect: (K:) or because it infects (tuxaAmiru, i. e. tuxaAliTu,) the intellect: (S, K:) [as though acting like leaven: (see 1:)] so said 'Omar: (TA:) or because it is left until it has become mature [and fermented]; (K;) or until its odour has changed: (IAar, S:) [see 8:] the proper application of the root is to denote “ covering, ” and “ commingling in a hidden manner: ” (Sgh, Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the fem. gender, and sometimes masc.: (Msb, K:) you say huwa Alxamoru as well as hiIa Alxamoru:
but As does not allow it to be masc.: (Msb:) and xamorapN↓ signifies the same: (K:) [or a kind of wine:] or xamorN and xamorapN are like tamorN and tamorapN; [the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter its n. un.;] (S;) and xamorapN [thus] signifies some wine; lit., a portion of xamor: (Msb:) the pl. of xamorN is xumuwrN. (S, Msb.) You say [also] SirofN xamorapN↓ [Some pure, or unmixed, wine; using a masc. epithet, contr. to rule]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] maA Einoda fulaAnK xalRN walaA xamorN, (S,) or maA huwa bixalRK walaA xamorK, (K,) (tropical:) Such a one, (S,) or he, (K,) possesses neither good nor evil: (S, K:) [or neither evil nor good: for] AA says that some of the Arabs make Alxamoru to be good, and AlxalRu to be evil; and some of them make Alxmr to be evil, and AlxlR to be good. (Har p. 153.) ― -b3- xamorN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Grapes; (AHn, M, K;) in the dial. of ElYemen:) (M:) like as EinabN signifies “ wine ” in that dial. (AHn, TA in art. Enb.) It is said in the Kur [xii. 36], UinRiI OaraAniI OaEoSiru xamorFA Verily I thought myself pressing grapes: (ISd:) or the meaning is, pressing out wine from grapes. (Ibn- 'Arafeh.)

xamarN xmAr xmr
xamarN A covert of trees &c.: (ISk, S, Mgh, K:) or a place where the ground is eaten away by a torrent, or an oblong tract of sand collected together and elevated, forming a place for concealment: (ISk, S:) and a hollow, or cavity, in which a wolf conceals himself: and tangled trees. (TA.) You say, tawaAraI AlSRayodu minRiI fiI xamari AlwaAdiI [The game, or wild animal or animals, concealed itself, or themselves, from me in the covert, &c., of the valley]. (S.) And huwa yadibRu lahu AlDRaraMCa wa yamoXiI lahu Alxamara (assumed tropical:) [He creeps to him in the thicket, or place overgrown with trees; and he walks to him in the covert of trees, &c.: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. 913]: speaking of a man when he deceives, or circumvents, his companion. (S.) And jaMCanaA EalaI xamorK and ElI ximorapK↓ (assumed tropical:) He came to us secretly; unexpectedly; clandestinely. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) xamarN and xumaArN↓ and xamaArN↓ (S, K) and xamorapN↓ (K) (assumed tropical:) A crowding, (S,) or congregation, (K,) and multitude, of men or people. (S, K.) You say, AlnRaAsi daxala fiI xamaAri↓ and xamaArihimo↓, dial. vars. of gumaAr and gamaAr, i. e. (tropical:) He entered among the crowding and multitude of the men or people; (S;) and in like manner, fI xamarotihimo↓ and gamarotihimo; (TA;) as also fI xamarihimo and gamarihimo: (TA in art. gmr:) or among such [a crowd] of the people as hid him. (ISk, S.)

xamirN xmAr xmr
xamirN A place abounding with coverts of the description termed xamar; (IAar, S, K;) a place concealing by dense trees. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) A man infected, syn. muxaAmarN, (Sh, IAar, S,) by a disease: (TA:) thought by ISd to be a possessive epithet: (TA:) or in the last stage of the remains of intoxication. (S.) [See also maxomuwrN.])

xamorapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
xamorapN: see xamorN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) and ximorapN↓ (Kr, K) and xumorapN↓, (K,) The odour of perfume: (S, A:) or a sweet odour: (K:) and the last signifies also an odour which has infected (xaAmara, i. e. xaAlaTa,) a person; (K;) as also xamarapN↓. (AZ, K.) You say, wajadotu xamorapa AlTRiybi I experienced, or smelt, the odour of the perfume. (S, A.) ＝ -A2- See also xamarN, in two places.

xumorapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
xumorapN: see xamiyrN, in two places. ― -b2- Also a dial. var. of gumorapN [q. v.], A thing [or composition] which is used as a liniment for beautifying the complexion; (S;) [the plant called] waros and certain perfumes which a woman uses as a liniment (so in the K, or applies as a liniment to her face, as in other lexicons, TA) to beautify her face. (K.) ＝ -A2- Pain, and headache, and annoyance, occasioned by wine (xamor, for which in some copies of the K we find HumRaI erroneously put, TA); as also xumaArN↓: or the intoxication thereof, which has infected (xaAlaTa) [a person]; (K;) and so xumaArN↓: (TA:) or this latter signifies the remains of intoxication: (S:) pl. of the former xumarN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also xamorapN. ＝ -A3- A small pot or jar: and a vessel for leaven. (KL.) ＝ -A4- A small mat, (S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) [of an oblong shape,] large enough for a man to prostrate himself upon it, (Mgh, Msb,) used for that purpose [in prayer], (S, A,) made of palm-leaves (S, K) woven (turomalu) with threads or strings: (S:) so called because it veils the ground from the face of the person praying [upon it]: (Zj, * Mgh:) or because its threads or strings are hidden by its palm-leaves. (TA.)

ximorapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
ximorapN A hiding, or concealing, oneself: (IAar, TA:) [or, accord. to analogy, a mode, or manner, of doing so.] ― -b2- See also xamarN. ― -b3- A mode, manner, or way, of wearing the ximaAr. (K, * TA.) You say, UinRahaA laHasanapu Alximorapi [Verily she has a beautiful mode of wearing the xmAr]. (S.) And hence the saying of 'Omar to Mo'áwiyeh, maA OaXobaha Eayonaka biximorapi hinodK [How like is thine eye to Hind's (when she practises her) mode of wearing the xmAr!]. (TA.) Hence also, (TA,) UinRa AlEawaAna laA tuEalRamu Alximorapa [Verily she who has had a husband will not require to be taught the mode of wearing the xmAr]: (S, K, * TA:) a prov., (S, TA,) applied to him who is experienced and knowing: (K:) i. e. the experienced woman is not to be taught how she should act. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also xamorapN.

xamarapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
xamarapN: see xamorapN.

xamoriIRN xmAr xmr xmrI xmry
xamoriIRN Grapes (EinabN) fit for wine. (TA.) ― -b2- A colour resembling the colour of wine. (TA.)

ximirRN xmAr xmr
ximirRN: see ximaArN.

xamaArN xmAr
xamaArN: see xamarN, in two places.

xumaArN xmAr
xumaArN: see xamarN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also xumorapN, in two places.

ximaArN xmAr
ximaArN [A woman's muffler, or veil, with which she covers her head and the lower part of her face, leaving exposed only the eyes and part or the whole of the nose: such is the xmAr worn in the present day: a kind of veil which is called in Turkish yaXomaqo; as in the TK:) a woman's headcovering; (Mgh, TA;) a piece of cloth with which a woman covers her head; (Msb;) i. q. naSiyfN, (K,) pertaining to a woman; (S) as also ximirRN↓: (Th, K:) and any covering of a thing; anything by which a thing is veiled, or covered: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxomirapN (K) and [of mult.] xumurN (Msb, K) and xumorN. (K.) ― -b2- Also A man's turban; because a man covers his head with it in like manner as a woman covers her head with her xmAr: when he disposes it in the Arab manner, he turns [a part of] it under the jaws [nearly in the same manner in which a woman disposes her xmAr]. (TA.) [Hence,] maA XamRa ximaAraka, a prov., (TA,) [meaning] (assumed tropical:) What hath changed thee from the state in which thou wast? What hath befallen thee? (K.)

xamiyrN xmyr
xamiyrN (K) and maxomuwrN↓ and muxamRarN↓, (TA,) applied to dough, [Leavened;] having had xamiyr [as meaning leaven] put into it: (TA:) or, applied to dough, and to clay or mud (Tiyn, as in the K, but accord. to other lexicons perfume, Tiyb, TA), and the like, left until it has become good [or mature]: (K:) pl. [of the first] xamoraI. (TA.) You say also xubozN xamiyrN Bread [leavened, or] into which leaven (xamiyr) has been put: (Lh, TA:) or yesterday's bread; bread that has been kept over a night: (S:) and xubozapN xamiyrN, without p [in the epithet]. (Lh, TA.) And xamiyrN is also applied to Bread itself: or leavened bread. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- xamiyrN [used as a subst.] (S, A, Msb, K) and xamiyrapN↓ and xumorapN↓ (S, A, K) signify Leaven, or ferment, expl. by maA xumRira bihi, (K,) of dough, and of perfume; (TA;) what is put into dough, (S, A, Msb,) and into the beverage called nabiyc; (A;) and xumorapN↓ also signifies what is put into perfume, as well as what is put into dough and into nbyc: (Ks:) the xumorap of nbyc is its dregs, (K,) and its [ferment which is called] durodiIR; (TA;) or what is put into it, of wine (xamor) and of durodiIR; and so too of perfume; (S;) and the xumorap of milk is its ferment (ruwbap) which is poured upon it in order that it may quickly curdle, or coagulate, or thicken, or become thick and fit for churning. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AijoEalohu fiI sirRi xamiyrika (tropical:) Conceal thou it (i. e. a secret, A) in thy mind. (A, TA.) And Oaxoraja mino sirRi xamiyrihi sirRFA (tropical:) He revealed, or disclosed, a secret. (TA.) ― -b4- See also maxomuwrN.

xamiyrapN xmyr xmyrh xmyrp
xamiyrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

xamRaArN xmAr
xamRaArN A vintner; a seller of xamor [or wine]. (K.)

ximRiyrN xmyr
ximRiyrN (S) and musotaxomirN↓ (K) One who constantly drinks wine; (S, K;) a great drinker; devoted to drink. (K.)

muxamRirN mxmr
muxamRirN A maker of xamor [or wine]. (K.)

maxomuwrN mxmwr
maxomuwrN: see xamiyrN. ― -b2- Also, (S,) and muxamRarN↓ and xamiyrN↓, (TA,) A man affected with xumaAr, (S, TA,) i. e. the remains of intoxication. (S. [Like maboxuwrN. See also xamirN.])

muxotamirN mxtmr
muxotamirN, and with p: see muxamRarN.

musotaxomirN mstxmr
musotaxomirN: see ximRiyrN.

1 xamasa Alqawoma xms Alqwm
1. xamasa Alqawoma, (S, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
xamusa
, (S, Mgh, K,) [inf. n. xamosN,] He took the fifth part of the possessions of the people. (S, A, Mgh, K.) And xamasa AlmaAla, (A, Msb,) aor.
xamusa
, inf. n. xamosN, (Msb,) He took the fifth part of the property. (A, Msb.) xamosN signifies The taking one from five: and hence the saying of 'Adee Ibn-Hátim, rabaEotu fiI AljaAhiliyRap waxamasotu fiI AlUisolaAmi [I took the fourth part of the spoil in the Time of Ignorance, and I took the fifth part thereof in the time of El-Islám]; meaning, I headed the army in both those states; for the commander, in the Time of Ignorance, used to take the fourth part of the spoil; and in El-Islám, the fifth part was assigned to him. (TA.) ― -b2- xamasa Alqawoma, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
xamisa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xamosN, (Msb,) He was, or became, the fifth of the people: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he made them five by [adding to their number] himself. (S, K.) ― -b3- xamasa also signifies He made fourteen to be fifteen. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b4- And He made forty-nine to be fifty with himself. (A'Obeyd, S in that art.) ― -b5- xamasa AlHabola, aor.
xamisa
, inf. n. xamosN, He made the rope of five strands twisted together. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xamasati AlUibilu The camels drank on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (TA.) [See xamosN.] ― -b2- xamasa, said of a horse, He came fifth in the race. (T, M, L; all in art. vlv.)

2 xmRshu xms xmsh xmsp
2. xmRshu, inf. n. taxomiysN, He made it five. (EshSheybánee and K, voce waHRadahu.) ― -b2- He made it to be five-cornered; five-angled; pentagonal. (K.) ― -b3- xamRasato She brought forth her fifth offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b4- And xmRshu He made it five-fifths. (Msb.) ― -b5- xmRs liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained five nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sabRaEa.) ― -b6- taxomiysN also signifies [The watering of land or seedproduce on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first;] the watering of land that is [next] after the tarobiyE. (TA.)

4 Axms Alqawomu Axms Alqwm
4. Axms Alqawomu The party of men became five: (S, K:) ― -b2- also, The party of men became fifty. (M and L in art. vlv.) ― -b3- Axms AlrRajulu The man was, or became, one whose camels came to water on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (S, * K, * TA.) [See ximosN.]

xamosN xms
xamosN fem. of xamosapN [q. v.].

xumosN xms
xumosN: see xumusN.

ximosN xms
ximosN The drinking of camels on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first; their drinking one day, then pasturing three days, then coming to the water on the fifth day, the first and last days, on which they drink, being thus reckoned: this is the correct explanation, accord. to Aboo-Sahl El-Khowlee; and Aboo-Zekereeyà says the like; (TA;) or their pasturing three days, and coming to the water on the fourth day [not counting the day of the next preceding watering; for it is evident that this explanation is virtually the same as that preceding]: (S, K:) accord. to Lth, the drinking of camels on the fourth day, counting the day on which they returned from [the next preceding] watering; but Az says, that this is a mistake; the day of returning from watering not being counted [when it is explained as meaning the drinking on the fourth day]: (TA:) pl. OaxomaAsN, the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.) [See ZimoCN.] Hence, falaApN ximosN [as in copies of the K, or it may be falaApu ximosK,] A desert in which the water is far distant, so that the camels come to the water on the fourth day, exclusive of the [next preceding] day on which they drank. (Az, K, TA.) Hence also the saying, fulaAnN yaDoribu OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK (S, K *) (tropical:) Such a one makes a pretence of AxmAs [or fifth-day waterings] for the purpose of AsdAs [or sixth-day waterings]: i. e., he advances his camels from the ximos to the sidos: (K:) a prov.: (TA:) meaning, such a one strives to deceive, or circumvent: (S, K:) applied to him who acts towards another with artifice, pretending that he obeys him, or complies with his desire: (TA:) or to him who pretends one thing while he means another: (K:) and taken from the saying, related by AO and IAar, Daraba OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK [He made a pretence of AxmAs for the purpose of AsdAs]; said of him who proposes a thing whereby he means another thing, which he commences and by slow degrees accomplishes: (TA:) for a man, when he desires to make a long journey, accustoms his camels to drink ximosFA sidosFA [i. e. on the fifth day and then on the sixth, in each case counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first]: (K, TA:) the origin of the saying, accord. to IAar, being this: an old man was among his camels, accompanied by his sons, men, who pastured them, and who had been long far distant from their families; and he told them one day to pasture their camels riboEFA [i. e. watering on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first], which they did, proceeding in the way towards their families: then they proposed to do so ximosFA; and then, sidosFA: whereupon the old man, understanding what they meant, said, ye are doing nothing but making a pretence of AxmAs for the purpose of AsdAs: the object of your desire is not the pasturing of them, but it is only your families. (TA.) [See below, voce xumusN, a saying similar in words but different in meaning.] ― -b2- It is also used for sayoru ximosK [A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days; a journey in which the second and third and fourth days are without water]. (L in art. jlc.) You say ximsN baSobaASN, [and SaboSaAbN,] and qaEoqaAEN, and HavoHaAvN, [and HaSoHaASN, &c.,] i. e. A journey [in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days,] in the course of which, to the water, there is no flagging, by reason of its remoteness. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj uses the expression
ximosN kaHaboli AlXRaEari AlmunoHatRi
meaning, A [journey of the kind termed] xms without any deviation, like a rope made of hair that has fallen off and that is free from any unevenness. (L, TA.) ― -b3- ximosN also signifies The fifth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.) ＝ -A2- A [garment of the kind called] burod, (S, K,) of the fabric of El-Yemen; (S;) so called because first made for a king of El-Yemen named ximosN, (AA, S,) or Alximosu; (K, TA;) as also xamiysN↓. (TA.) For the latter word, we find in the work of Bkh, xamiyS, with S; which, if correct, is masc. of xamiySapN, which is a small kind of kisaMC. (IAth, and L.) [The pl. of ximosN applied to a burodap is OaxomaAsN.] See also maxomuwsN, in four places.

xumusN xms
xumusN and xumosN↓ A fifth part; (Msb, K;) as also xamiysN↓, (S, in art. vlv, and IAmb and Msb,) agreeably with a rule applicable in the case of every one of the units, except valiyvN: (TA:) some allow this last; but AZ disallows it, and xmys also: (S in art. vlv:) pl. OaxomaAsN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Daraba OaxomaAsahu fiI OasodaAsihi He turned his five senses towards his six relative points; [namely, above, below, before, behind, right, and left:] an allusion to the collecting all the thoughts to examine a thing, and turning the attention in all directions. (MF.)

xamosapN xms xmsh xmsp
xamosapN, (S, K,) masc.; and xamosN, fem.; (S;) [Five;] a certain number. (S, K.) You say xamosapu rijaAlK [Five men], and xamosu nisowapK [Five women]. (S.) You say also, EinodiI xamosapu daraAhimo [I have five dirhems], with refa: and if you please, you incorporate the p into the d [and say, xamosap dRaraAhima]: but when you prefix Al to drAhm, you say, EinodiI xamosapu AldRaraAhimi [I have the five dirhems], with damm; and may not incorporate, because you have incorporated the l into the d: and in the case of a fem. n. you say, EinodiI xamosu Alquduwri [I have the five cooking-pots]: also, hecihi Alxamosapu AldRaraAhimi [These five dirhems]; and, if you please, AldRaraAhimu, using it in the manner of an epithet: and in like manner [you use the other nouns of number] to EaXarapN [inclusive]. (S.) You say also, SumonaA xamosFA mina AlXRahori [We fasted during a period of five nights of the month with their
days]; making layaAlK to predominate over OayRaAm, when you do not mention the word AyRAm, though the fasting is in the day; because the night of each day precedes the day: but when you mention the word AyRAm, you say, SumonaA xamosapa OayRaAmK [We fasted five days]. (ISk, TA.) yaEaDRu biAlxamosi means He bites the fingers: these being [five in number and] of the fem gender: (Ham p. 790:) [i. e.] xamosN means the five fingers. (Har p. 76.) [Respecting a peculiar pronunciation of the people of El-Hijáz, and a case in which xamosap is imperfectly decl., see valaAvapN.] ― -b2- [xamosapa EaXara, masc.; and xamosa EaXorapa, fem.; Fifteen. For variations thereof, see art. EXr.]

xamosuwna xmswn
xamosuwna [Fifty, and fiftieth,] is also written and pronounced xamisuwna, with kesr to the xamasuwna, by poetic license, as related by Ks; or m, with fet-h, as related by others, after the manner of xamosapN and xamasaAtN: (Fr, TA:) accord. to the T, the variation xamisuwna, with kesr to the m, is [dialectic, being] similar to xamosa EaXirapa, with kesr to the X [in the dial. of Nejd]. (TA.)

jaAWuwA xumaAsa c
jaAWuwA xumaAsa, and maxomasa↓, They came five and five; [or five and five together; or five at a time and five at a time;] (K, TA;) like as they say, vunaMCa and mavonaI, and rubaAEa and marobaEa: (TA:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, not more than OuHaAda and vunaMCa and vulaAva and rubaAEa has been heard, except EuXaAra occurring in a verse of El-Kumeyt. (TA in art. EXr.)

xamiysN xmys
xamiysN: see xumusN: ― -b2- and maxomuwsN, in two places. ― -b3- An army; because consisting of five parts, namely, the van, the body, the right wing, the left wing, and the rear; (S, A, K;) or because the spoils are divided into fifths among it; but this latter assertion requires consideration; (ISd, MF;) for this division of the spoils is an affair of the Muslim law, whereas xmys [thus applied] is an old term: (MF:) or an army having numerous weapons; syn. jayoXN xaXinN. (TA.) ― -b4- yawomu Alxamiysi, (S, Msb, K,) and simply Alxamiysu, Thursday; the fifth day of the week; thus used for AlxaAmisu, in like manner as AldRabaraAnu is applied to the star [that follows the Pleiades, for AldRaAbiru]: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxomisapN and [of mult.] OaxomisaMCu (S, Msb, K) and OaxaAmisu. (Fr, TA.) AZ used to say, maDaI Alxamiysu bimaA fiyhi [Thursday passed with what happened in it], making it sing. and masc.: but Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDaIAlxamiysu bima fiyhinRa, making it pl. and fem., and using it as a n. of number. (Lh, TA.) It has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.) ＝ -A2- See also ximosN, last signification. ＝ -A3- maA OadoriI OaIRu xamiysi AlnRaAsi huwa means I know not what company of men it is. (Ibn-' Abbád, Sgh, K.)

xumaAsiIRN xmAs xmAsI xmAsy xmAsyy
xumaAsiIRN A boy five spans (OaXobaAr) in height: (S, Mgh, Msb, * K:) said of him who is increasing in height [but has not attained his full stature]: (Msb:) fem. with p: (Lth, TA:) and in like manner you say rubaAEiIRN: (S, Msb:) but you do not say subaAEiIRN, (Lth, S, K,) nor sudaAsiIRN; (Lth, K;) [i. e., in speaking of a boy;] for when he has attained seven spans, (S,) or six spans, (Lth, K,) he is a man: (Lth, S, K:) or to a slave you apply the epithet sdAsIR also; and to a garment, or piece of cloth, sbAEIR. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also maxomuwsN. ― -b3- [Also A word composed of five letters, radical only, or radical and augmentative.]

xamiysiIRN xmys xmysI xmysy
xamiysiIRN One who fasts alone on Thursday. (IAar, Th.)

xaAmisN xAms
xaAmisN [Fifth]: for this you also say xaAmK; (ISk, S, K;) whence the phrase, jaMYa fulaAnN xaAmiyFA [Such a one came fifth], for xaAmisFA: (ISk, S:) [fem. with p.] ― -b2- [xaAmisa EaXara and xaAmisap EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Fifteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.] ＝ -A2- UibilN xaAmisapN (TA) and xawaAmisu (S, K) Camels that drink on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first: [see ximosN:] (TA:) or that pasture three days, coming to the water on the fourth day [not counting the day of the next preceding watering]. (S, K.)

jaAWuwA maxomasa c
jaAWuwA maxomasa: see xumaAsa.

muxamRasN mxms
muxamRasN A thing five-cornered; five-angled; pentagonal. (S.) [See also muvalRavN.]

maxomuwsN mxmws
maxomuwsN Five cubits in length; applied to a spear, (S, A, K,) as also xamiysN↓; (K;) and to a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, A, K,) as also xamiysN↓, (S, A, Mgh, K,) which occurs in a trad. as meaning a small garment or piece of cloth, (Mgh,) and xumaAsiIRN↓ [q. v. suprà]; (TA;) and in like manner, burodapu OaxomaAsK↓ a [garment of the kind called] brdp fire cubits long. (ISk, TA.) Hence the saying, humaA fiI burodap OaxomaAsK↓ (assumed tropical:) They two have become near together, and in a state of agreement. (K.) A poet says,
SayRaraniI juwdu yadayhi wamano
OahowaAhu fiI burodapi OaxomaAsi↓
i. e., (assumed tropical:) The bounty of his hands has made me and the person whom I love to be near together, as though we were in a brdp five cubits long: (Th, TA:) app. meaning that the person thus spoken of had purchased for him a female slave, or had given for him the dowry of his wife. (Az, Sgh, TA.) You also say, layotanaAfiI burodapi OaxomaAsK↓, a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) Would that we were near together. (ISk, TA.) [See also burodN.] ― -b2- Also A rope made of five strands twisted together. (S, A, K.)

1. xamaXahu, (S, A, K,) aor
xamiXa
(S, Msb, K) and
xamuXa
, (S, K,) inf. n. xamoXN, (Msb,) He scratched it, namely, the face, with the nails, so as to cause bleeding or not; syn. xadaXahu: (S, * A, K:) only used in relation to the face: (A:) or also used in relation to the rest of the person: (TA:) and xmRXhu↓, inf. n. taxomiyXN, signifies the same: (TA:) [or denotes intensiveness, or muchness, like xadRaXahu.] And xamaXati AlmaroOapu wajahahaA biZuforahaA The woman wounded the exterior of the scarf-skin of her face with her nail. (Msb.) One says also, by way of imprecation, xamoXFA [May thy, or his, or her, face be scratched]; like as one says jadoEFA and qaToEFA. (TA.) ― -b2- He slapped it; namely, the face. (A, K.) ― -b3- He beat him, or it, (K, TA,) with a staff, or stick. (TA.) ― -b4- He cut off from him a limb, or member. (K.)

(L.) It is related in a trad., that Keys Ibn-' Ásim collected his sons at his death, and said, kaAna bayoniI wabayona fulaAnK xumaAXaAtN fiI AljaAhiliyRahi [There were, between me and such a one, wounds, &c., in the Time of Ignorance]. (L.) And you say, qado Oaxacotu xumaAXatiI mino fulaAnK I have retaliated upon such a one [my wound, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- xumaAXaAtN, also, (S, TA,) or xumaAXaAtu caHolK, (A, TA,) signifies (tropical:) Remains of caHol [or desire of retaliation, or the like]. (S, A, TA.)

You say, masasotuhu biyadiI wahoIa baAridapN fataxaAmaSa mino barodi yadiI (tropical:) [I touched him with my hand, it being cold, and he shrank from the coldness of my hand]. (Msb.) ― -b2- xamiySu AlbaToni, (A,) or xamiySu AlHaXaA, (S, K,) and xumoSaAnN↓, (S, A, K,) and xamaSaAnN↓, (A, K,) A man empty in the belly, (A,) or lank in the belly; (S, K;) as also xaAmiSN↓ AlbaToni: (K * and TA in art. rhf:) and slender in make: (TA:) fem. of the first with p, (S, A, K,) and so of the second, (Yaakoob, S, A, K,) and so of the third; (TA;) and IAar mentions xamoSaI↓ as a fem., occurring prefixed to AlHaXaA in a verse of El-Asamm Ed-Dubeyree: (TA:) pl., (S, A, K,) masc., (A, K,) ximaASN; (S, A, K;) and fem., [i. e., of xmySp,] xamaAYiSu: (A, K:) xumoSaAnN↓ has no pl. formed by the addition of w and n, though its fem. is formed by the addition of p; being made to accord with the measure faEolaAnN, of which the fem. is faEolaI. (TA.) ximaASN [also] signifies Hungry, in a pl. sense, (K,) and lank in the bellies: (TA:) mixomaASN↓ also signifies the same as xamiySN; and [its pl.] maxaAmiySu, lank in the bellies (xumoSu AlbuTuwni [whence it appears that OaxomaSu↓, sing. of xumoSN, is also syn. with xamiySN]). (TA.) You say also, huwa xamiySu AlbaToni mino OamowaAli AlnRaAsi, meaning (tropical:) He is one who abstains from [devouring] the possessions of men. (A.) And ximaASu AlbuTuwni mino OamowaAli AlnRaAsi xifaAfu AlZRuhuwri mino damaAYihimo, (A, TA,) meaning (tropical:) Persons who abstain from [devouring] the possessions of men, whose backs are light with respect to [the] burden [of their blood]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- zamanN xamiySN (tropical:) A time of hunger. (A, TA.)
