xamiySapN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, black, square, and having EalamaAni [i. e. two ornamental or coloured or figured borders]: (S, A, Mgh, K:) or a black ksAC, having a border such as is above described (muEolam) at each end, and which is of xazR, [q. v.], or of wool: (Msb:) if not bordered, it is not so called: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to As, a mulaMCap of wool, or of xazR, bordered (muEolamap); not unless bordered: so called because of its softness and thinness, and smallness of bulk when it is folded: Ahmad Ibn-Fáris says that it is the black kisaMC: and he says that it may be thus called because a man wraps himself with it, so that it is against his OaxomaS, meaning by this his waist: (Har p. 21:) pl. xamaAYiSu: or xmAYS are garments of xazR, thick, black, and red, and having thick OaEolaAm [or borders such as above described]; worn by people of old. (TA.) El-Aashà says,
UicaA jurRidato yawomFA Hasibota xamiySapF
EalayohaA wa jiroyaAla AlnRaDiyri AldRulaAmiSaA
[When she is stripped of her clothing, any day, thou wouldst think there was upon her a khameesah, and the glistening redness of gold]: As says, he likens her [long and spreading] hair to a xmySp, which is black. (S.) [See also xamiysN, voce ximosN, near the end of the paragraph.]

OaxomaSu Alqadami c
OaxomaSu Alqadami A man whose foot rises from the ground, [or is hollow in the middle of the sole,] so that it does not touch it: fem. xamoSaMCu: and pl. xumoSN: (Msb:) and xumoSaAnN↓ signifies having the middle of the sole of the foot moderately rising from the ground; which is a goodly quality; but when it is flat, or rises much, it is dispraised: so explained by IAar when he was asked by Th respecting 'Alee's saying of Mohammad, [cited, but not explained, in the K,] kaAna xumoSaAna AlOaxomaSayoni: or, accord. to Az, xumoSaAnN signifies having the part [of the sole] of the foot which does not cleave to the ground in treading very much retiring from the ground. (TA.) ― -b2- AlOaxomaSu [when without the article Al also written without tenween accord. to the best authorities, because the quality of an epithet is original to it, and that of a subst. is accidental,] also signifies The part [of the sole] of the human foot which does not cleave to the ground in treading; (Az, TA;) the part of the sole of the human foot which is hollow, so that it does not touch the ground; (S, K; *) the part of the bottom of the human foot which is thin, and retires from the ground; or, as some explain it, [meaning the same,] the xaSor of the human foot: (TA:) pl. OaxaAmiSu. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also xamiySN. ― -b4- Also The waist of a man. (Har p. 21.)

xamoTN The [kind of tree called] OaraAk: (Bd in xxxiv. 15:) or a species of the ArAk, having a fruit which is eaten: (Lth, S:) or the fruit of the ArAk: (IB, K:) or any trees having no thorns: (IDrd, Bd, K:) or trees having thorns; cited from Fr; and by Z, in the Ksh, on the authority of A 'Obeyd: (TA:) or certain trees like the sidor, (K, TA,) the fruit of which is like the mulberry: (TA:) or certain deadly trees: (K:) or deadly poison: (TA:) or any plant that has acquired a taste of bitterness, (Zj, Bd, K,) so that it cannot be eaten: (Zj, TA:) or scanty fruit of any trees: (AHn, K:) or the fruit of what is called fasowapu AlDRabuEi: (K:) or a certain fruit called fasowapu AlDRabuEi, having the form of the poppy, friable, and of no use: (IAar:) or it signifies, in the Kur xxxiv. 15, fruit that is disagreeable in taste, and choking: (Bd:) or, [as an epithet,] bitter, and disagreeable in taste, and choking: (Jel:) or bitter; applied to anything: or acid. (K.) In the Kur, ubi suprà, some read, cawaAtaIo Oakuli xamoTK: (S, IB, Jel:) this is the right reading accord. to him who makes xmT to mean the ArAk: but accord. to him who makes it to mean the fruit of the ArAk, the right reading of Akl is with tenween, and xmT is a substitute for that word. (IB.) [The pl. is ximaATN: see an ex. voce xalRN.]

(TA.)

xaAmilN A man obscure, unnoted, reputeless, or of no reputation; (S, Msb, K;) unknown, (JK, T,) and unmentioned; (T;) destitute of good fortune: (Msb:) and one says also xaAminN, by substitution [of n for l]: (TA:) pl. xamalN (K) and xamalapN, explained as signifying the lower or lowest, or meaner or meanest, sort of mankind. xanaAsN: see Oaxonasu.

AlxanRaAsu AlxnAs xnAs
AlxanRaAsu The devil: (S, K:) an epithet applied to him, (Msb,) because he retires, or shrinks, or hides himself, (yaxonusu, S, Msb, K, i. e., yataOaxRaru, as is implied in the S, or yanoqabiDu, Msb, or yagiybu, K,) at the mention of God; (S, Msb, K; *) being an intensive act. part. n. from xanasa. (Msb.)

xinRawosN xnws
xinRawosN: see Oaxonasu, in two places.

xaAnisN xAns
xaAnisN Going back or backwards; receding; retreating; retiring; or retrograding: or remaining behind; holding back; hanging back; or lagging behind: syn. mutaOaxRirN: pl. xunRasN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlxunRasu, (in the Kur lxxxi. 15, S,) (tropical:) The stars; (S, K;) i. e., all of them; because they retire, or hide themselves, (taxonusu,) at setting; or because they become concealed in the day-time: (S:) or the planets: (S, K:) or the five stars, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury: (Fr, S, K, Jel:) because they return, (taxonusu, i. c., tarojiEu, Jel,) in their course: (Fr, S, Jel:) when you see a star [thereof] in the end of a sign of the zodiac, it returns to the beginning of it: (Jel:) or because of their retrogression; for they are the erratic stars (AlkawaAkibu AlmutaHayRaripu), which [at one time appear to] retrograde, and [at another time to] pursue a direct [and forward] course: (S:) or because they sometimes return (txns) in their course until they become concealed in the light of the sun: (TA:) or because they hide themselves, as the devil does at the mention of God. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, i. e., from xaAnisN in the sense of mutaOaxRirN, the saying in a trad. of El- Hajjáj, AlUibilu DimRarN xinRasN, meaning, (assumed tropical:) [Camels are lean, and lank in the belly, and] patient of thirst. (TA.) ― -b4- And AllRayaAliI AlxunRasu The three nights of the lunar month during which the moon retires [from view]. (TA.)

Oaxonasu c
Oaxonasu [Having a camous, or camoys, nose;] having the configuration termed xanasN in the nose: (S, Msb, K:) [see xanisa AlOanofu:] accord. to some, having a nose of which the bone is short and the end turning back towards its bone: (TA:) fem. xanosaMCu: (S, Msb:) pl. xunosN. (S, A.) xanasN↓ in its original application is in gazelles and bulls and cows: (TA:) all bulls and cows are xunos, (S, A, TA,) and so are all gazelles: (TA:) or xunusN↓, with two dammehs, (K,) but written by Sh xunosN, (TA,) is used to signify gazelles: and bulls or cows: (K:) and xanosaMCu is an epithet applied to the wild cow: (K:) also Oaxonasu, to the tick: (Sgh, K:) and the lion; and so xinRawosN↓; (K;) which last is an epithet so applied as relating to his face and his nose: (Fr, TA:) and the last, xnRws↓, is also applied to a young pig: (As, TA:) or in this sense it is with S: (Fr, TA:) and xanaAsN↓ is syn, with xinRawosN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xunosN is metaphorically applied [as an
epithet] to arrows, in the following verse, describing a coat of mail:
lahaA EukanN tarudRu AlnRabola xunosFA
watohozaOu biQlomaEaAbili waQloqiTaAEi
[It has folds which repel the arrows turned up at the points, and mock at the broad and long, and the small and broad, arrow-heads]. (TA.) ― -b3- qadamN xanosaMCu A foot flat in the hollow part of the sole, and fleshy. (TA.)

xanosarN xnsr
xanosarN: and xinosirN: and xanosariIRN: and xinosiyrN: and xanaAsiru: and xanaAsiyru: see art. xsr.

xinoSiySN xnSyS
xinoSiySN: see xinRawoSapN.

xinawoSN xnwS
xinawoSN The young of the swine: (Ibn-'Abbád, S, K:) and the young, or little, of anything: (K:) pl. xanaAniySu. (S, K.) [See also xinRawosN.]

xinRawoSapN xnwS xnwSh xnwSp
xinRawoSapN The young of the babor, q. v.; (K;) as also xinoSiySN↓. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- Also A palm-tree which does not rise beyond reach of the hand. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

xinoSirN xnSr
xinoSirN (S, Msb, K) and xinoSarN, (A, K,) the latter [of a rare form,] like dirohamN, (TA,) The little finger: (S, A, K:) or the middle finger: (K:) the latter signification said by MF to be unknown; but it is mentioned in the L, as from the Book of Sb: (TA:) [and the little toe:] of the fem. gender: (Msb, K:) pl. xanaASiru: (Sb, S, K:) like firosinN, it has no pl. formed by the addition of At: (Sb:) its pl. is also used as a sing., as though every part were termed xnSr; as in the phrase UinRahu laEaZiymu AlxanaASiri [Verily he has a large little finger]. (Lh.) You say, fulaAnN tuvonaI bihi AlxanaASiru [The little fingers are bent in mentioning such a one with others of his class]: i. e., one begins with him in mentioning persons of his class. (Msb.) [See 1 in art. vnI.] And in like manner you say, EadRuwhu biAlxinoSiri [They counted him with the little finger]: i. e., they commenced with him in counting. (MF.)

1 xanaEa Uilayohi xnE Alyh xnE Alyp
1. xanaEa Uilayohi, and lahu, (ISd,) [aor.
xanaEa
,] inf. n. xunuwEN (S, ISd, K) and xanoEN; (ISd;) [and app. xaniEa, aor.
xanaEa
, inf. n. xanaEN; (see xanaEN, below; and xaniEN;)] He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (S, ISd, K,) to him, and petitioned him, or solicited him, he, the latter, not being a fit person to be petitioned, or solicited: (ISd:) or xunuwEN signifies the being low, vile, base, abject, or submissive; almost always in an improper case. (Ham p. 44.) ― -b2- Accord. to Lth, (TA,) xanoEN signifies The act of playing, toying, or dallying, and conversing with one of the other sex, enticing, or striving to induce, the latter to yield to one's desire, and behaving in a soft, tender, or blandishing, manner. (K, TA.) You say, xanaEa AlnRisaMCa, [or more probably, lilnRisaMCi,] He played, &c., with women, and behaved in a soft, tender, or blandishing, manner to them. (TK.) ― -b3- xanaEa, aor.
xanaEa
, (Lth, K,) inf. n. xanoEN and xunuwEN, (Lth,) also signifies He acted in a suspicious manner, or so as to induce suspicion or evil opinion; (K;) he acted vitiously, or immorally; or committed adultery, or fornication. (Lth, K.) You say, xanaEa UilayohaA He came to her for a vitious, or an immoral, purpose; or for the purpose of adultery, or fornication: (Lth, TA:) or, as some say, he listened to her. (TA.) ― -b4- And xanaEa bihi, aor.
xanaEa
, inf. n. xunuwEN, He acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, or treacherously, to him; or broke his compact, contract, covenant, or the like, with him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xanaEa fulaAnFA UilaI AlsRawoCapi He, or it, invited such a one to that which was foul, abominable, or evil; as also xaDaEa. (TA in art. xDE.)

4 OaxonaEataniI Uilayoka AlHaAjapu c
4. OaxonaEataniI Uilayoka AlHaAjapu (S, K *) Want, or need, made me lowly, humble, or submissive, to thee; or constrained me to have recourse to thee, and to require thine aid. (S, * K.)

xanaEN xnE
xanaEN [app. inf. n. of xaniEa,] Lowness, vileness, baseness, abjectness, or submissiveness; almost always, in an improper case. (Ham p. 44.)

xaniEN xnE
xaniEN [app. part. n. of xaniEa,] Low, vile, base, abject, or submissive. (KL.) [See what next precedes.]

xanoEapN xnE xnEh xnEp
xanoEapN A thing that induces suspicion or evil opinion; (S, K;) a vitious, or an immoral, act; or adultery; or fornication. (K.) [See a remark on one of the pls. of xaAniEN.] You say, AiTRalaEato mino fulaAnK EalaI xanoEapK I became acquainted with, or got knowledge of, a vitious, or an immoral, act of such a one. (TA.) And waqaEa fiI xanoEapK He fell into a thing of which one is ashamed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A vacant place. (O, L, K.) You say, laqiytuhu bixanoEapK faqaharotuhu I found him, or met him, in a vacant place, and I overcame him. (K, * TA.)

xunoEapN xnE xnEh xnEp
xunoEapN Necessity, or constraint: and excuse. (TA.) ― -b2- rajulN cuw xunuEaAtK A man in whom is corruptness, or vitiousness, or corrupt or vitious conduct. (TA.)

xanuwEN xnwE
xanuwEN Perfidious, unfaithful, or treacherous; one who breaks his compact, contract, covenant, or the like. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- One who turns away from, or shuns, or avoids, another. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

xanaAEapN xnAEh xnAEp
xanaAEapN The state of being bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, ugly, or hideous; or excessively bad, &c. (TA.)

xaAniEN xAnE
xaAniEN One who acts in a suspicious manner, or so as to induce suspicion or evil opinion; who acts vitiously, or immorally; or commits adultery, or fornication: (S, K:) pl. xunuEN (K, TA) and xanaEapN. (TA.) El-Aashà says,
humo AlxaDaArimu Uino gaAbuwA wa Uino XahiduwA
wa laA yarawona UilaI jaAraAtihimo xunuEaA
[They are the bountiful, if they be absent and if they be present; and they do not see persons acting in a suspicious manner, &c., towards their wives]. (TA.) [The latter hemistich of this verse is cited in the S; in one copy of which I find yurawona in the place of yarawona: and it seems to be there implied that xunuEN is pl. of xunoEapN; but I do not know any instance of fuEulN as the measure of a pl. of a word of the measure faEolapN.] ― -b2- One who commits a foul action whereof the disgrace returns upon him, and is ashamed of it, and hangs down his head towards the ground. (As, on the authority of an Arab of the desert.)

entry.key: OaxonaEu AlOasomaMCi Einoda QllRehi maliku AlOamolaAki

superEntry.entry:
OaxonaEu AlOasomaMCi Einoda QllRehi maliku AlOamolaAki c
OaxonaEu AlOasomaMCi Einoda QllRehi maliku AlOamolaAki, (K,) or UilaI QllRehi, (TA,) The vilest and most abasing (OacalRu and Oaqoharu) of names, (K,) for a man, and the most effectual to bring into a state of humility and humiliation, in the estimation of God, is “ king of kings; ” like [the Persian] XaAhinoXaAho; because this name belongs to God himself: a trad., which is variously related: (TA:) accord. to different relations, thus, and OanoxaEu, (K,) meaning “ most effectual to kill, and destroy, ” its owner, (TA,) and OaboxaEu, [which means the same,] (K, TA, [in the CK AanojaEu,]) and OaxonaI, (K,) meaning “ most foul, abominable, or the like. ” (TA in art. xnI.)

muxanRaEN mxnE
muxanRaEN applied to a camel, Broke; trained; rendered submissive, or manageable. (K, TA.) And in like manner applied to a place [app. as meaning Rendered easy to sit, or lie, upon; or, to travel]. (TA.)

xunofasN xnfs
xunofasN and its variations: see what here follows.

xunofasaMCu xnfsMC
xunofasaMCu (S, Msb, K) [in two copies of the S, in which it is without the article, written without tenween, but in the Msb and K it has the article prefixed, and is therefore necessarily without tenween,] and xunofusaMC, (Msb, TA,) which is more common, (Msb,) [but this I doubt, for I have found it nowhere else,] and xunofasN↓ (S, K) and xunofusN (TA) and xinofisN, (K,) which last is of the dial. of the people of El-Basrah, (TA,) and xunofusapN and xunofusapN, (K,) [The black beetle: or a certain species thereof:] a well-known creeping thing; (Msb;) a certain insect, (S, K,) black, (K,) of fetid odour, smaller than the juEal, found in the bottoms of walls: (TA:) the first and second of these words are both applied to the male and the female: (Msb:) or xunofasN is applied to the male, (AA, Msb,) by some of the Arabs, (Msb,) and is syn. with EunoZabN and HunoZabN, (AA, TA,) and xunofusN is not disallowable, being agree-
able with analogy: (Msb:) and xunofasaACapN is applied to the female, [which, if correct, shows xnfsMC to be with tenween,] and so is xunofasapN: (S:) or xnfsACp, with p, is not allowable; [and if so, xnfsMC is without tenween;] (As, TA;) and xnfsp is [not applied to the female, but] used by the Benoo-Asad for xnfsMC, as though they made the p a substitute for the A: (Msb:) [and this seems to indicate that the A is a fem. A, grammatically speaking, and that the word is therefore without tenween:] the pl. is xanaAfisu. (Msb.) One says, huwa OalaHRu mina AlxunofasaMCi [He is more persevering than the black beetle]: because it returns to thee as often as thou throwest it away. (TA.) [Accord. to the K, the n in the words of this art. is radical; but accord. to the S and Msb, augmentative.]

1 xanaqahu xnq xnqh xnqp
1. xanaqahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
xanuqa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. xaniqN (S Mgh, Msb, K) and xanoqN, (Msb, TA,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Msb,) or, accord. to El-Fárábee, the latter is not allowable, (Mgh,) He throttled him, or strangled him, i. e. squeezed his throat (Mgh, Msb) that he might die; (Msb;) [but it does not always mean he squeezed his throat so that he died; often meaning, simply, he, or it, throttled him, strangled him, or choked him; and frequently said of a disease in the throat, and of food;] and xnRqhu↓ signifies the same, (S, K,) [or has an intensive meaning,] and its inf. n. is taxoniyqN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlEaborapu xanRaqatohu↓ [and xanaqatohu] (assumed tropical:) Weeping [or sobbing] choked him; as though the tears throttled him. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And xuniqa He (a horse) was affected with the disease, or wind in the throat, termed xunaAqiyRap. (TA.) ― -b4- And xanaqa Alwaqota, aor. as above, (assumed tropical:) He postponed, or deferred, and [so] straitened, the time: and xanaqa AlSRalaApa (assumed tropical:) He straitened the time of prayer by postponing it, or deferring it. (TA.)

2 xanRaqa
2: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, xnRq AlsRaraAbu AljibaAla, inf. n. taxoniyqN, (tropical:) The mirage nearly covered the heads of the mountains. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And xnRq AlUinaMCa (tropical:) He filled the vessel: (K, TA:) or filled it up (sadRada maloOahu): and in like manner, AlHawoDa [the watering-trough]. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) ― -b4- And xnRq AlOarobaEiyna (tropical:) He (a man) nearly attained to [the age of] forty [years]. (K, TA.)

7 Uinoxanaqa
7: see what next follows, in three places.

8 Axtnq Oxtnq Axtnq Qxtnq
8. Axtnq He was, or became, throttled, or strangled; i. e. he had his throat squeezed that he might die; (JK, * S, * Msb, K; *) [and simply he was, or became, throttled, strangled, or choked;] as also Anxnq↓: (JK, * Msb:) or you say, Anxnqt↓ AlXRaApu binafosihaA [the sheep, or goat, became throttled, or strangled, or choked, by itself]: (S, K:) or AlAinoxinaAqu↓ signifies the having the xinaAq [q. v.] compressed upon one's throat: and AlAixotinaAqu, the compressing it upon one's own throat. (TA.)

xanoqN xnq
xanoqN: see muxanRaqN.

xaniqN xnq
xaniqN inf. n. of xanaqahu: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) ＝ -A2- and i. q. maxonuwqN q. v. (JK, K.)

xunuqN xnq
xunuqN: see xinaAqN.

xuniAqN xnAq
xuniAqN [Quinsy;] a certain disease which pre vents the passage of the breath to the lungs and heart; (K;) as also [xunaAqapN↓ thus in modern Arabic, and] xunRaAqN↓: pl. xawaAniyqu (TA) [and xanRaAniyqu, thus in modern Arabic]. ― -b2- See also muxanRaqN, in three places.

xinaAqN xnAq
xinaAqN A cord, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) or bow-string, or the like, (Mgh,) with which one is strangled; (JK, * S, * Mgh, K; *) also, metaphorically, termed xanRaAqK mixonaqapu↓. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also muxanRaqN, in two places. ― -b3- falohamN xinaAqN (assumed tropical:) A narrow vulva of a woman: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) and xunuqN↓ [or furuwju xunuqN, for xunuqN is app. pl. of xinaAqN, like as kunuzN is pl. of kinaAzN,] (assumed tropical:) narrow vulvas (IAar, K) of women. (IAar.) ― -b4- humo fiI xinaAqK mina Almawoti (assumed tropical:) They are in straitness by reason of death. (TA.)

xaniyqN xnyq
xaniyqN: see maxonuwqN, in three places.

xunaAqapN xnAq xnAqh xnAqp
xunaAqapN: see xunaAqN.

xunaAqiyRapN xnAq xnAqyh xnAqyp
xunaAqiyRapN A certain disease in the throats of birds and horses: (K:) or a certain disease that attacks the bird in its head, and the horse in its throat, and chokes it: (JK:) or a certain disease, or wind, that attacks men and horses or similar beasts in the throat, and sometimes attacks birds in the head and throat, mostly appearing in pigeons. (TA.)

xanRaAqN xnAq
xanRaAqN: see xaAniqN. ― -b2- Also One who sells fish [taken] with the xanRaAqap [q. v.]. (TA.)

xunRaAqN xnAq
xunRaAqN: see xunaAqN.

xanRaAqapN xnAq xnAqh xnAqp
xanRaAqapN A snare with which beasts of prey are taken (JK, TA) by the throat: and a snare with which fish are taken in El-Andalus. (TA.)

xaAniqN xAnq
xaAniqN One who strangles; (Msb, TA; *) as also xanRaAqN↓: (Mgh, Msb:) or the latter signifies one whose office it is to strangle. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xaAniqu AlcRiYobi and xaAniqu AlnRamiri and xaAniqu Alkalobi and xaAniqu AlkirosanRapi [in the CK AlkarosanRapu] Four herbs: (K:) [the first and second, in the present day, wolfsbane, or aconite: or, as Golius says, referring for the former and latter respectively to Diosc. iv. 78 and 77, the former is the aconitum lycoctonon; and the latter, the aconitum pardalianches: the third, dogsbane, or colchicum; or, as Golius says, referring to Diosc. iv. 81, apocynon: and the fourth, strangle-weed, (because it strangles the kirosanRap, or bitter vetch,) or broomrape, i. e., as Golius says, referring to Diosc. ii. 172 and Ibn-Beytár, orobanche:] the first is high (mXrf [but perhaps this should be muXoriq i. e. shining]) in the leaves, downy, and resembling the dlb [?]: the second is like the tail of the scorpion, glistening, about a span [in height], and has not more than five leaves: each of these is of the [season called] rabiyE; and they are poisonous; they kill all animals; the ciYob and the namir being particularized only because of the quickness of its acting in them: Ibn-Seenà says, in the “ Kánoon, ” the leaves of xAnq Alnmr, when mixed with fat, and kneaded and baked with bread, and given as food to wolves and dogs and foxes and leopards (nmr), kills them: whence it seems that this may be two herbs or one herb. (TA.) ― -b3- xaAniqN signifies also (tropical:) A narrow road or ravine, in a mountain: (S, * K, * TA:) or a narrow place or pass, between two mountains, and between two tracts of sand. (JK.) [See also muxotanaqN.] ― -b4- And (tropical:) A narrow street; syn. zuqaAqN; (S, K, TA;) in the dial. of the people of ElYemen. (S, TA.) ― -b5- See also maxonuwqN, in two places.

xaAnaqaAhN xAnq xAnqAh xAnqAp
xaAnaqaAhN A convent inhabited by righteous and good men, and Soofees; an arabicized word, from [the Persian] xaAnaho GaAho; [and post-classical, for] El-Makreezee says that the xAnqAh was instituted in the fifth century of the Flight, for Soofee recluses to employ themselves therein in the service of God: (TA:) [pl. xawaAniqu.]

xaAanqaAhiIRN xAnqAhI xAnqAhy
xaAanqaAhiIRN A man of, or belonging to, a xaAnaqaAh. (TA.)

maxonaqN mxnq
maxonaqN: see muxanRaqN, in two places.

mixonaqapN mxnq mxnqh mxnqp
mixonaqapN A necklace, syn. qilaAdapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) that surrounds the neck; (Mgh, Msb;) wherefore it is thus called; (Msb;) [i. e., because] it lies against the muxanRaq: pl. maxaAniqu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also xinaAqN. [And see ziraAdN.]

muxanRaqN mxnq
muxanRaqN: see maxonuwqN. ― -b2- [Hence,] gulaAmN muxanRaqu AlxaSori (assumed tropical:) A boy slender in the waist. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also The part, of the neck, which is the place of the cord [or the like] called xinaAq [wherewith one is strangled]; (S, K; *) i. e., (TA,) the throat; (K, accord. to the TA; in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K maxonaq↓;) and so xunaAqN↓, (S, K, in the former said to be syn. with muxanRaqN,) and xinaAqN↓ (K) and xanoqN↓. (TA; and so, accord. to the TA, in the K.) You say, Oaxacotu bimuxanRaqihi [I seized his throat]. (S.) And Oaxacahu bimuxanRaqihi (K, accord. to the TA, but accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K bimaxonaqihi↓,) and bixunaAqihi↓ and bixinaAqihi↓, i. e. [He took him, or seized him,] by his throat. (K.) And Oaxaca bimuxanRaqihi (A in art. zrd) and bixunaAqihi↓ (S) [properly He, or it, seized his throat, or throttled him, or choked him; meaning] (tropical:) he, or it, straitened him; as also Oaxaca bimuzarRadihi. (A in art. zrd.) And Oaxaca minohu biAlmuxanRaqi (tropical:) He, or it, constrained him, and straitened him. (TA.) And balaga minohu AlmuxanRaqa [properly It reached his throat; meaning (assumed tropical:) it straitened him, or distressed him]. (S.) balaga AlOamoru AlmuxanRaqa signifies the same as balaga AlmucamRara, (A in art. cmr,) which means (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, or event, reached a distressing pitch. (K in art. cmr.)

maxonuwqN mxnwq
maxonuwqN and xaniqN↓ and xaniyqN↓ (JK, K) and xaAniqN↓, applied to a man, [and to any animal, as also muxanRaqN↓, Throttled, or strangled, i. e. having his throat squeezed that he may die; but not always meaning, so as to be killed thereby; often meaning, simply, throttled, strangled, or choked;] (JK;) all signify the same; from xanaqahu: (JK, K:) or xaAniqN↓, in the place of xaniyqN↓, signifies cw xnAq [app. meaning having a xinaAq, or cord, &c., by which he is throttled, or strangled, round his neck; or perhaps having a xunaAq, or quinsy]: (TA:) and XaApN xaniyqapN↓ and munoxaniqapN↓ signify a sheep, or goat, throttled, or strangled, i. e. having its throat squeezed that it may die: (Msb:) or the latter of these two means a sheep, or goat, throttled, or strangled, or choked, by itself (Ainoxataqato binafosihaA). (S, TA. [See 8.]) It is said in a prov., (Meyd,) Aifotadi maxonuwqu, (Meyd, K,) i. e. yaA maxonuwqu [Ransom thyself, O thou who art throttled, or strangled, or choked]; applied to any one distressed and constrained; (Meyd;) meaning free thyself from difficulty (K, TA) and harm: (TA:) or, as some relate it, AifotadaI maxonuwqN [One throttled, or strangled, or choked, ransomed himself]. (Meyd.)

muxotanaqN mxtnq
muxotanaqN A narrow place or pass. (S, TA.) [See also xaAniqN, near the end of the paragraph.]

muxotaniqN mxtnq
muxotaniqN (tropical:) A horse whose blaze occupies his jaws, (K, TA,) extending to the roots of his ears. (TA.)

XaApN munoxaniqapN c
XaApN munoxaniqapN: see maxonuwqN.

1 xanaA xAn xn xnA xnnA
1. xanaA, aor. yaxonuw, inf. n. xanowN and xanFA: see xaniIa, in the art. here following.

1 xaniIa xn xnI xny
1. xaniIa (S, K) Ealayohi (S) fiI manoTiqihi (TA,) aor. yaxonaI, inf. n. xanFI; (TA;) as also xanaA, (JK, K,) aor. yaxonuw, (JK, TA,) inf. n. xanowN (K, TA) and xanFA; (JK, TA;) and AxnI↓ (JK, S, K) Ealayohi fiI manoTiqihi, (S, TA,) or fiI kalaAmihi, (JK,) He uttered foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech (JK, * S, K) against him. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- xanaI, (JK, K,) [aor. yaxoniI,] inf. n. xanoIN, (TA,) He cut, or severed, the trunk of a palm-tree (JK, K) with an axe; (JK;) as also xanaOa. (JK, TA.)

4 OaxonaIa
4: see 1. ― -b2- AxnI Ealayohi also signifies He, (a man, S,) or it, (misfortune, Ham p. 430,) corrupted, or marred, his state. (S, Ham, TA.) And the same, (S,) or AxnI Ealayohimo, (JK, K,) said of time, or fortune, (JK, S,) It destroyed him, or them. (JK, S, K.) And the former, said of time, It became long to him. (K.) ― -b3- AxnI bihi signifies Oasolamahu waxafara cimRatahu [or, app., bicimRatihi: a phrase which admits of two contr. meanings; He betrayed him, and broke his covenant, or the like; and he preserved him in safety, and fulfilled his covenant, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- AxnI AljaraAdu The locusts had many eggs. (AHn, K.) ― -b5- AxnI AlmaroEaI The pasturage had much and luxuriant herbage. (AHn, K. *)

xanFA xn xnA
xanFA [more properly written xanFI, originally an inf. n.,] Foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech: (S, TA, and Ham p. 489:) or the most foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, of speech. (JK, T, TA.) And xnAyp↓ [written without any syll. signs, app. xanaAyapN, like faHaAXapN,] is of the measure fEAlp from xanFA [and seems to be syn. therewith as an inf. n. or as a subst.]: it occurs in the saying of El-Katámee,
daEuwA AltRamora laA tuvonuwA EalayohaA xnAypF
faqado OaHosanota fiI julRi maA bayonanaA AltRamoru
[Leave ye dates: speak not of them in a foul manner, or speak not of them foul speech; for dates have benefited in most of what has occurred between us, or among us]. (TA.) ― -b2- xanaA AldRahori The calamities of time or fortune. (JK, K.)

kalaAmN xanK klAm xn
kalaAmN xanK Foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech; and kalimapN xaniyapN a foul, an abominable, an unseemly, or an obscene, word or expression or sentence: (S:) or most foul, &c.: (JK:) [or having a foul, an abominable, an unseemly, or an obscene, meaning; for] xanK is not a verbal epithet, since we know not xaniyati Alkalimapu, but a possessive epithet; like the instance, mentioned by Sb, in rajulN TaEimN, meaning cuw TaEaAmK; and nahirN, meaning [SaAHibu nahaArK or] sayamurRu biAlnRahaAri; &c. (TA.)

xnAyp xnAyh xnAyp
xnAyp: see xanFA.

AxnI AlOasomaMCi c
AxnI AlOasomaMCi The most foul, or abominable, or unseemly, of names. (TA.) [See OaxonaEu.]

xawRN xw
xawRN Hunger. (IAar, K.) [And so xawFI and xawaMCu, belonging to art. xwy; with which the present art. is intimately connected.] ＝ -A2- A wide valley: (K:) any wide valley in a soft, or plain, [low ground such as is termed] jawR; (Az, TA;) as also xawFI: (Az, TA in art. xwI:) and low, or depressed, ground; (TA;) as also xuwRapN↓: (JK, TA:) or the former, a soft place: (JK:) or soft ground; as in the saying, waqaEa garosuka bixawRF What thou hast planted has chanced to be in soft ground, in which it will take root and not fail to be productive. (TA.)

xuwRN xw
[xuwRN, by a mistake in the CK, in art. xwI, is made to signify Honey: see xuwaMCN in that art.]

xwRp xwh xwp
xwRp [app. xawRapN] Languor: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, wa Oaxaca OabaA jaholK xwRpN falaA yanoTiqu [And a languor seized Aboo-Jahl, so that he spoke not]. (IAth, TA.)

xuwRapN xwh xwp
xuwRapN A vacant land. (K.) ― -b2- See also xawRN. ＝ -A2- Also a dial. var. of OuxuwRapN. (IAth, TA in art. Axw: see 1 in that art.)

xaMCN xMC
xaMCN The name of the letter x, q. v.; as also xaA: [it is called xaA in a case of pause, and xaMCN when made a noun:] it is fem. and masc.: [its dim. is xayayRapN, meaning a x written small, or indistinct: (see HaMCN in art. HwO:)] and its pl. is OaxowaMCN and OaxoyaMCN and xaAMtN. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

xaMCi bika EalayonaA xMC bk ElynA
xaMCi bika EalayonaA, (AZ * and S * and TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp, and K and TA in the present art.,) in which xaMCi is a Sawot [or noun significant of a sound], indecl., with kesr for its termination; (S, TA;) and xaAYiI bk, as in the Book of the Nawádir by Ibn-Háni, (Az, TA,) in which latter, ISd says, the I is not for a sign of the fem. gender, because the word is a Swt; and, as Sh says, on the authority of A'Obeyd, xaAYibika; but correctly written as in the Book of Ibn-Háni; (Az, TA;) Hasten thou [to us]: (AZ, Az, S, K, TA:) it is also used in addressing a female, and two persons, and a pl. number: (S, TA:) you say [xaMCi biki, and] xaAYiI biki; and xMCi bikumaA, and xaAYiI bikumaA; and [xaMCi bikumo, and] xaAYiI bikumo. (TA.) In the saying of El-Kumeyt,
bixaAYiI bika QloHaqo yahotifuwna waHaIRa halo
[which app. means Calling out “ Hasten thou, come up with us, ” and “ Come, ” or “ come quickly, ” &c.,] it is held by Ibn-Selemeh to be used as an imprecation, meaning xibota [mayest thou be disappointed of attaining that which thou desirest]; the poet saying bixaAYibika for biOamorika QlRaciI xaAba waxasira [meaning By thine affair that shall result in disappointment, and be an occasion of loss]: which, as you see, is at variance with the explanation of AZ. (S, TA.)

xaAYiIRN c
xaAYiIRN and xaAwiIRN and xawiIRN [a mistranscription for xayawiIRN, like bayawiIRN and tayawiIRN] rel. ns. of xaMCN and xaA the names of the letter x. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllRynp.)

1 xaAba xAb
1. xaAba, aor. yaxuwbu, inf. n. xawobN, He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- See also xaAba in art. xyb.

xawobapN xwbh xwbp
xawobapN A state of utter destitution, in which nothing remains in possession: so in the saying, OaSaAbatohumo xawobapN [A state of utter destitution befell them]. (A'Obeyd, T.) ― -b2- Hunger: (AA, T, S, A, K:) pl. xawobaAtN. (TA.) So in the phrase, OaSaAbatohu xawobapN [Hunger befell him]. (AA, S.) Sh knew not this word, and thought it to be a mistake for HawobapN; (T;) which latter signifies “ want. ” (S.) [See the latter word.] ＝ -A2- A tract of land upon which rain has not fallen, between two tracts of land watered by rain. (AA, S, K.) ― -b2- Land that is bad, (S,) in which is no pasture (S, K) nor water. (TA.) So in the saying, nazalonaA bixawobapK mina AlOaroDi [We alighted in bad land, without pasture or water]. (S.) [See also HuwbapN.]

1 xaAta xAt
1. xaAta, (S, A, K,) aor. yaxuwtu, inf. n. xawotN (S, TA) and xawaAtapN; (TA;) and AxtAt↓, (S, K,) and AnxAt↓; (K;) He (a hawk, or falcon, S, K, and an eagle, A, TA) pounced down, or made a stoop, upon the prey, or quarry, (S, A, K,) to take it, or seize it, (S,) making a sound to be heard with his wings. (TA.) And xaAtati AlEuqaAbu, aor. taxuwtu, inf. n. xawaAtN, The eagle made a sound by the motion of its wings [in pouncing down]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also xAt, (K,) inf. n. xawotN, (TA,) He (for instance an eagle, TA) seized, or snatched away, (K, TA,) a thing; (TA;) and so txwRt↓, (IAar, K,) and AxtAt↓. (TA in art. xyt [where this last is said to belong to the present art.].) You say of the hawk, AlTRayora AxtAt↓ He seized, or snatched away, the birds: (TA in art. xyt:) and of the wolf, AlXRaApa AxtAt↓ (Fr, S, TA) He seized, or snatched away, the sheep or goat; (TA in art. xyt;) or he stole away the sheep or goat by stratagem. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b2- xAt maAlahu He (a man) lessened, or diminished, his property; or took from it by little and little; syn. tanaqRaSahu; (K;) as also maAlahu txwRt↓, (S, K,) and txwRfhu: (S:) and xaAtahu maAlahu, aor. yaxuwtuhu and yaxiytuhu, [he lessened, or diminished, to him his property; or did so by taking from it by little and little;] both signify the same. (K in art. xyt.) ― -b3- And xAt He (a man, TA) lessened, diminished, or impaired, his provision of corn or food (miyratahu); or made it defective, or deficient. (K.) ＝ -A3- xAt, (aor. as above, Msb,) also signifies He (a man) broke his promise: (IAar, S, Msb, K:) and broke, or dissolved, his compact, contract, or covenant. (K.)

3 xAwt Tarofahu duwniI xAwt Trfh dwnI xAwt Trfh dwny
3. xAwt Tarofahu duwniI, (K,) inf. n. muxaAwatahu, (TA,) i. q. saAraqahu [i. e. He cast his eye furtively towards a spot between me and him; meaning, towards me: see similar phrases in art. dwn]. (K.)

5 taxawRata
5: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 8, in two places.

7 Uinoxawata
7: see 1, first sentence.

8 Uixotawata
8: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- One says also, AxtAt baladFA, and txwRthu↓, He cut off for himself a land, or district. (IAar, TA in art. xwI.) ― -b3- And fulaAnN yaxotaAtu Hadiyva Alqawomi, (S, K, *) and yataxawRatu↓, (S,) Such a one takes of the discourse of the people, or party, and learns it by heart [one part after another]. (S, K. *) In [some of] the copies of the K, in the explanation of AxtAt AlHadiyva, for fataHafRaZahu is erroneously put fataxaTRafahu. (TA.) ― -b4- And UinRahumo yaxotaATuwna AllRayoli, meaning yasoruwna wa yaqoTaEuwna AlTRariyqa [Verily they journey by night, and make the road to be feared, relying upon their strength, and robbing and slaying men]. (S: [in two copies of which I find yasiyruwna in the place of yasoruwna.])

xawaAtN xwAt
xawaAtN The sound made by the motion of the wings of an eagle. (S, K. [In a copy of the S, I find it said that this word is fem., though its meaning is masc.; and the same is said in the TA, doubtless from another copy of the S; but this observation, which is omitted in one copy of the S in my possession, applies to xawaApN, mentioned in art. xwI in the S, as meaning SawotN.]) And A sound [absolutely]; (K;) as also xawaAtahu↓: (TA:) or the sound, or noise, of thunder, and of a torrent, or flow of water. (AHn, K.) A poet says,
falaAHisRa UilRaA xawaAtu AlsRuyuwli
[And there was no sound but the noise of the torrents]; (AHn, TA;) which shows that we should read in the K waAlsRayoli; not wAlsylu, as in some copies. (TA.)

xawaAtapN xwAth xwAtp
xawaAtapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

xawRaAtN xwAt
xawRaAtN A bold, daring, brave, or courageous, man. (S, K.) ― -b2- One who is always eating, but does not eat much. (K.) ＝ -A2- A great promisebreaker. (Msb.)

xaAYitN c
xaAYitN [act. part. n. of 1]. xaAYitapN signifies An eagle (EuqaAbN) pouncing down, or making a stoop, (S, K,) and thereby causing a sound to be heard. (S.) ＝ -A2- Breaking his promise; or one who breaks a promise. (Msb.)

xawoxN xwx xwxp
xawoxN [The peach, or peaches;] a well-known kind of fruit, (K, TA,) which is eaten; (TA;) i. q. duraAqinN: (K in art. drqn:) sing., (K,) or n. un., (S,) xawoxapN↓. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also what follows.

xawoxapN xwx xwxh xwxp
xawoxapN: see above. ＝ -A2- Also An aperture (S, A, Mgh, K) in a wall, (S, A, Mgh,) admitting the light (S, A, K) to a house, or chamber. (K.) ― -b2- A passage (muxotaraqN) between any two houses, not having a door, or gate: (K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (TA;) [and of Egypt, where it is applied to a lane leading from one street or quarter to another: coll. gen. n. xawoxN↓:] accord. to some, a passage (muxotaraqN) between any two things: and a small door-way between two houses, or chambers, with a door affixed to it. (L.) ― -b3- A wicket, or small door, (A, Mgh,) in a large door. (A.) [Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, explains it as meaning Fenestella in medio januæ.] ― -b4- [Also applied to A sluice in a rivulet: see daraqapN.] ― -b5- (tropical:) The anus; syn. duburN. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- A kind of green garment: (Az, K:) of the dial. of Mekkeh. (TA.)

2 xwRd xwd
2. xwRd, (L,) inf. n. taxowiydN, (S, L, K,) He (a camel, L) went quickly; or was quick in his pace or going: (S, L, K:) he went quickly, and threw out his legs: or, as some say, he shook, as though he were convulsed: and in like manner, a male ostrich: and sometimes it is said of a man, signifying as first explained above. (L.) ― -b2- xawRada raOoluhu: see art. rOl. ＝ -A2- He sent the stallion, fiIAlUibili among the camels. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- He obtained somewhat of food. (K.)

5 txwRd txwd
5. txwRd He (a camel) shook in going, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (A.) ― -b2- It (a branch) inclined, (A, TA,) or bent. (K.)

xawodN xwd
xawodN, applied to a girl, (S,) or young woman, (L,) or a female, (A, K,) Soft, or tender, (S, A, L, K,) and youthful: (A:) or goodly, or beautiful, in make, and youthful, (L, K,) not yet of middle age: (L:) pl. xawodaAtN (L, K) and xuwdN; (S, L, K;) the latter like ludonN as pl. of ladonN, an epithet applied to a spear. (S, L.)

1 xaAra xAr
1. xaAra, aor. yaxuwru, (S, A, Mgh,) inf. n. xuwaArN (JK, S, A, Mgh, K *) and xaworN, (JK,) He (a bull) uttered his cry; [i. e. lowed, or bellowed;] (Lth, JK, S, A, Mgh, K;) this being its primary signification: (Er-Rághib:) the inf. n. xwAr, used agreeably with this explanation, occurs in the Kur xx. 90 [and vii. 146]: (S:) it signifies the loud crying [i. e. the lowing or bellowing] of a cow and of a calf: (Lth:) and the crying [i. e. bleating] of sheep, or that of goats, and of gazelles, (K,) and of any beast: (Er-Rághib:) and the sounding [i. e. whizzing] of arrows: (K:) of any of these, you say, xaAra, aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.) [Hence,] lahu SawotN kaxuwaAri AlvRawori He has a voice like the bellowing of the bull. (A.) ― -b2- [And hence, (see 10,)] xAr Ealayohi (tropical:) He bent, turned, or inclined, towards him. (A.) ＝ -A2- xAr, aor. as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. xuWuwrN, (S, K, [for which Golius, as on these authorities, substitutes xuWuwrapN,]) said of a man, (S,) and of anything, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, weak, or feeble, (S, Msb, K,) and languid; (S, TA;) as also xawira, (TA,) aor. yaxowaru, (JK,) inf. n. xawarN; (S, * K, * TA;) and xiwRir↓, (JK, TA,) inf. n. taxowiyrN. (K.) xAr and xawira both signify It was soft, or fragile; said of anything, like a reed. (JK.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, lano yaxuwra qawiIRN maA daAma SaAHibuhaA banoziEu wayanozuw, meaning A possessor of strength (SaAHibu quwRapK) will not be weak as long as he can pull his bow and leap to his beast. (TA.) In a camel that is drinking, xawarN denotes, or implies, a quality that is praised; i. e. Patient enduring of thirst and fatigue: and a quality dispraised; i. e. the lacking patience to endure thirst and fatigue. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of heat, (S, TA,) and of cold, inf. n. xuWuwrN and xuWuwrapN, (JK,) (tropical:) It became faint; it remitted, or abated; (JK, S, TA;) and so xawira, inf. n. xawarN; and xwRr↓. (TA.) And xAr EanRaA, said of cold, It ceased from us; quitted us. (A.) ＝ -A3- xaArahu, (JK, S,) inf. n. xaworN, (S, K,) He hit, or hurt, his xaworaAn, (JK, S, K, *) in thrusting or piercing him with a spear or the like. (JK, S.)

2 xwRr xwr
2. xwRr: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- xwRrhu He attributed to him weakness, or feebleness, and languor. (TA.)

4 AxArhu AxArh AxArp
4. AxArhu, (S, K,) inf. n. UixaArapN, (S,) [app., in its' primary acceptation, He caused him to utter a cry. (See 10.) ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He bent, turned, or inclined, him, or it. (S, K.) You say, OaxaronaA AlmaTaAyaA UilaI mawoDiEi kacaA (assumed tropical:) We bent, or turned, the riding-camels to such a place. (S.)

6 txAwrti AlvRiyraAnu txAwrt AlvyrAn
6. txAwrti AlvRiyraAnu The bulls lowed, or bellowed, one to another. (A.)

10 AstxArhA AstxArhA QstxAr QstxArhA
10. AstxArhA [He endeavoured to make her (namely, a gazelle, or a wild cow,) to utter her cry; or] he uttered a cry in order that she should do the same. (TA.) The sportsman, coming to a place in which he thinks the young one of a gazelle or [wild] cow to be, utters a cry like that of her young one; and the mother, hearing it, if she have a young one, thinks the cry to be that of her young one, and follows the cry. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, TA,) AstxArhu (tropical:) He endeavoured to make him bend, turn, or incline: (JK, S, A, K, TA:) and he called him to him: and he interrogated him; or desired him to speak; syn. AisotanoTaqahu: namely, a man. (JK.) [AstxAr Almanozila is explained in the L and K as meaning AisotanoZafahu: to which is added in the TA, kOnRh Tlb xyrh, with the remark that it should therefore properly be mentioned in art. xyr: but an explanation in the sentence immediately preceding, and a verse cited below, evidently show that AstnZfh is a mistranscription for AisotanoTaqahu, and that xyrh should be xabarahu: so that the meaning is He interrogated the place of abode.] The author of the L cites, as an ex., the saying of El-Kumeyt,
walano yasotaxiyru rusuwma AldRiyaAri
liEawolatihi cuw AlSRibaI AlmuEwilu
[And he who is affected with youthful amorousness, wailing, will not ask the remains, or traces, of the dwellings to reply to his wailing: but for liEawolatihi I would rather read biEawolatihi; i. e., will not interrogate them with his wailing]. (TA.) ― -b3- AstxAr AlDRabRa, (K, TA, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, AlDRabuEa,]) and AlyarobuwEa, (TA,) He placed a piece of wood in the hole of the burrow of the [lizard called] DbR, (K, TA,) and of the jerboa, i. e. in the qaASiEaMC, (TA,) in order that it should come forth from another place, (K, TA,) i. e. the naAfiqaMC, so that he might catch it. (TA.) Lth falsely assigns the act of AlAisotixaArap to the DbR and the jerboa. (Az, TA.)

xaworN xwr
xaworN Low, or depressed, ground or land, (JK, S, K,) between two elevated parts; (JK, S;) like gawrN: (TA:) an inlet (lit. a neck) from a sea or large river, entering into the land: (Sh:) a place, or channel, where water pours into a sea or large river: (JK, K:) or a wide place or channel, where waters pour, running into a sea or large river; (TA:) or (as in the TA, but in the K “ and, ”) a canal, or cut, from a sea or large river: (K, TA:) and i. q. raHabapN [app. as meaning the part in which the water flows from the two sides of a valley]: (JK:) pl. xuWuwrN. (TA.)

xuwrN xwr
xuwrN a pl. of xawRaArapN, (S, K,) contr. to rule; (MF, TA;) and of xawRAr in the phrase xawRAru AlEinaAni. (JK, TA.) See xawRaArN, in five places.

xuwrapN AlUibili xwrp AlAbl
xuwrapN AlUibili, with damm, [app. originally xuyorap,] The best of camels, or of the camels; (IAar, K;) [see xayorN, (in art. xyr,) near the end of the paragraph;] and so xuwaAruhaA↓, and minohaA AlxuwraI↓. (Fr, TA.)

xuwraI xwr xwrI xwry xwryy
xuwraI fem. of Oaxoyaru, and properly belonging to art. xyr: see what next precedes.

xaworaAnN xwr xwrAn
xaworaAnN The maboEarN [or rectum], which comprises the HitaAr [or anus, with the extremities of its skin,] of the Sulob [or back], (K,) of a man &c.: (TA:) or the passage of the rawov [or dung, properly of a horse or the like, but here app. meaning of a man also]: (S:) or the head [or extremity] of the maboEarap [or rectum]: or the part in which is the dubur [or anus]: (K:) or the dubur [or anus] itself; (TA;) or it has this meaning also; (JK;) and so xawRaArapN↓, syn. AisotN; (K;) the dubur being so called because it is like a depressed place between two hills: (TA: [see xaworN:]) or the gap in which is the dubur [or anus] of a man; and that in which is the qubul [or anterior pudendum] of a woman: (TA:) or the gap in which is the dubur and the place of the cakar and that of the qubul of the woman: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) pl. xaworaAnaAtN and xawaAriyn: (K:) the former pl. of a form which any sing. subst. not significant of a human being may receive. (TA.)

xuwaArN xwAr
xuwaArN an inf. n. of xaAra as explained in the first sentence in this art. (S, A, &c.) ＝ -A2- xuwaAru AlUibilu: see xuwrap.

xaWuwrN c
xaWuwrN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xawRaArN xwAr
xawRaArN Weak, or feeble; (JK, S, Msb, K;) applied to a man; (S;) as also xaAYirN↓, (K,) and xaWuwrN↓: (AHeyth:) a weak man, who cannot endure difficulty or distress: (Lth:) and (tropical:) cowardly, or a coward: (A:) pl. of the first xawRaAruwna, and of the third xuwarapN. (AHeyth.) Applied to a camel, Slender (raqiyq) and beautiful: (K, TA: [for AlHisRi in the CK, I read AlHasanu, as in other copies of the K and in the TA:]) and the fem., with p, applied to a she-camel, having soft flesh and fragile bones: (TA:) pl. of the former [and of the latter] xawRaAraAtN. (K.) Applied to a spear, Weak: (S:) not hard: (Msb:) or weak and soft; (TA;) and in the same sense applied to an arrow, (A, TA,) as also xaWuwrN↓; (TA;) and so the fem. of the former, with p, applied to a reed or cane (qaSabapN); (A, TA;) and to land or ground (OaroDN) as meaning weak, (S,) or soft: (A, Msb:) pl. xuwrN↓. (S.) And xawRaAru AlEinaAni (tropical:) A horse (A) that turns easily, (JK, A, K,) and runs much: (K:) pl. xuwrN↓. (JK, TA.) And bakorapN xawRaArapN (assumed tropical:) A sheave of a pulley of which the pin runs [or turns] easily in the checks. (TA.) And AlHaXaAyaA xuwru↓ Beds, or the like, stuffed with soft substances. (TA, from a trad.) And xawRaAru AlSRafaA Smooth stones that sound [when struck] by reason of their hardness. (IAar.) And zanodN xawRaArN A znd [q. v.] that emits much fire; syn. qadRaAHN. (AHeyth, K.) [Hence,] huwa xawRaAru AlEuwdi [meaning (assumed tropical:) He is lavish when asked]: an expression of dispraise. (TA in art. ksr.) [Hence also,] xawRaArapN (tropical:) A she-camel abounding with milk; pl. xuwrN↓; (S, K, TA;) which is contr. to rule, and said by MF to be without a parallel: (TA:) and so a ewe or she-goat: (TA:) or a she-camel whose milk flows easily; and so a ewe or she-goat: (A:) or a she-camel thin-skinned, and abounding with milk: (AHeyth:) or one that is of a hue between dustcolour and red, with a thin skin; and such is the most abundant in milk: (Kf:) or of a red colour inclining to dust-colour, thin-skinned, and having long fur with [coarse] hair protruding through it, longer than the rest: such a she-camel is less hardy than others, but abounds with milk. (ISk.) Also (tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN) that bears much fruit. (JK, A, K.) ― -b2- xuwrN↓ as meaning (assumed tropical:) Women much suspected, on account of their corruptness, (K, TA,) and the weakness of their forbearance, (TA,) is [a pl.] without a sing. (K.)

xawaSa

AixowiySaASN; She (a ewe) had one of her eyes black, and the other white. (AZ, TA.)

[See also 2, above.] AxwS is also said of the Earofaj, (S, K,) and of the rimov, (TA,) [and of other trees, (see xuwSN,)] or of trees in general, (TA,) or of trees (AlXRajar) you say OaxaASa, inf. n. UixowaASN,
(AHn, ISd,) the verb being thus made infirm, and the inf. n. sound, (ISd,) or of all trees except thorny trees and herbs or leguminous plants, (TA,) meaning, It broke out with leaves: (S, K:) or, when said of the Erfj, its xuwS became perfect. [But the latter is trans.] You say, fulaAnFA UinRahu yuxaAwiSu↓, and ytaxaAwaSa lahu, Verily he blinks, or contracts his eyelids, looking intently, at such a one, as though he were aiming an arrow. (A, TA.)

xuwSN xwS

(T, TA.)

OaxowaSu A man (S, Mgh) having the eye sunk, or depressed; (S, Mgh, K;) having the quality of the eye termed xawaSN: [see 1:] fem. xawoSaMCu: (TA:) which is [also] applied to the eye, meaning sunk, or depressed: (Mgh:) or small, and sunk, or depressed: (A:) and to a ewe, meaning having one of her eyes black, and the other white: (AZ, K:) or having one eye black, and the other, with the rest of the body, white: (TA:) pl. xuwSN, which, prefixed to AlEuyuwn, is applied to camels. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] biYorN xawoSaMCu (tropical:) A deep well; a well of which the bottom is deep; (A, K, TA;) of which the beasts see not the water: (TA:) because one contracts his eyelids (yataxaAwaSu) in looking into it: (A, TA:) or xwSAC applied to a well (rakiyRap), signifies of which the water has sunk into the earth. And riyHN xawoSaMCu (tropical:) A hot wind: (K:) or a vehemently-hot wind: (A:) that makes the eye to blink, or contract the eyelids, (takosiruhaA,) by reason of heat: (K, * TA:) in which one does not see without blinking, or contracting the eyelids. (A.) And ZahiyrapN xawoSaMCu (tropical:) A summer mid-day vehemently hot: (A:) or most vehemently hot; (K, TA;) in which one cannot look without blinking, or contracting the eyelids. (TA.)

muxawRaSN mxwS

1 xaADa AlmaMCa xAD AlmMC
1. xaADa AlmaMCa, aor. yaxuwDu, inf. n. xawoDN (S, A, Msb, K) and xiyaADN, (S, A, K,) [He waded, or forded, through the water;] he passed through the water walking or riding: (S:) or he entered into the water; (A, K;) as also xawRaDahu↓, (K,) inf. n. taxowiyDN; (TA;) [or this latter has an intensive signification, as it is said to have in a phrase below;] and AxtADhu↓: (K:) or he walked in, or through, the water; (Msb;) as also txwRDhu↓: (TA:) or he entered into the water and walked in it, or through it. (TA.) You say also, xaADa biAlfarasi, meaning He brought the horse to the water; as also AxADhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UixaADahu; (AZ;) and xAwDhu↓, (K,) or xAwDhu fiI AlmaMCi, inf. n. muxaAwaDapN, as in the A: (TA:) or AxADwA↓ AlmaMCa signifies xaADuwhu bidawaAbRihimo [They waded or forded through the water, or entered into it, &c., with their beasts]: and you say also, xaAwaDotuhumo↓ fI AlmaMCi [I waded or forded with them through the water; &c.; meaning with men, not with beasts]: (so I find in a copy of the A:) and Alqawomu AxAD↓ signifies xaADato xayoluhumu AlmaMCa [The people's horses waded or forded through the water]. (S.) ― -b2- xaADati AlUibilu lujRa AlsRaraAbi (tropical:) [The camels passed through the great expanse of mirage]. (A.) ― -b3- xaADa Albaroqu AlZRalaAma (tropical:) [The lightning penetrated through the darkness]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- xaADa Uilayohi AlrRimaAHa HatRaI Oaxacahu (tropical:) [He forced his way to him through the spears until he took him, or it]. (A, TA. *) ― -b5- xaADa Alqawomu fiI AlHadiyvi, (S, A,) and fiyhi txAwDwA↓, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) The people, or company of men, entered [or waded] together into discourse. (S, A, K.) ― -b6- xaADa AlgamaraAti, (S, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. xawoDN, (TA,) (tropical:) He plunged into the submerging floods of ignorance, or the like; syn. AiqotaHamahaA. (S, K, TA.) ― -b7- xaADa fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He entered [or plunged] into the affair. (Msb.) ― -b8- In like manner you say, [xaADa fiI AlbaATili and] AlbaATila AxAD↓ (assumed tropical:) He entered [or plunged] into false, or vain, discourse or speech: (Msb:) and xaADa, alone, signifies (tropical:) He said, or spoke, what was false. (A.) It is said in the Kur [lxxiv. 46], (TA,) wakunRaA naxuwDu maEa AlxaAYiDiyna, i. e. fiI AlbaATili (tropical:) [And we used to enter into false, or vain, discourse or speech, with those who entered thereinto]; (Bd, Jel, K;) syn. naXoraEu: (Bd:) or and we used to follow the erring, &c. (O, K.) And again, [lii. 12,] AlRaciyna humo fiI xawoDK yaloEabuwna (tropical:) [Who amuse themselves in entering into false, or vain, discourse or speech]; (TA;) fI AlbATl being here, again, understood. (Bd.) And again, [ix. 70,] waxuDotumo kaQlRaciI xaADuwA, i. e. kaxawoDihimo (tropical:) [And ye have entered into false, or vain, discourse or speech, like their entering thereinto]. (K.) And again, [vi. 67,] AlRaciyna yaxuwDuwna fiI MyaAtinaA (tropical:) [Who enter into false, or vain, discourse or speech respecting our signs; meaning the Kur-án]. (TA.) xaADa fiyhi is also explained as signifying (assumed tropical:) He said what was false respecting it. (TA.) And xawoDN signifies (assumed tropical:) The confusing, or confounding, in an affair. (TA.) ― -b9- xaADa, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and xwRD↓, (A, TA,) also signify He mixed, (S, * K, TA,) and stirred about, (TA,) the beverage, or wine: (S, K, TA:) or he stirred about the sawiyq with the mixowaD. (A, Mgh. *) ― -b10- xaADahu biAlsRayofi (tropical:) He moved about the sword in him, having smitten him: (S, K, * TA:) or he put [or thrust] the sword into the lower part of his belly, and then raised it upwards. (A, * TA.) ― -b11- xuDotu biqidoHK fiI AlqidaAHi, (A, TA,) inf. n. xiyaADN; and AlqidaAHa xaAwaDotu↓, inf. n. xiwaADN; (TA;) (tropical:) I put an arrow, (A, TA,) which I had borrowed, and by which I expected to have good luck, (TA,) among the [other] arrows (A, TA) used in the game called el-meysir: (TA:) see an ex. (a verse of Sakhr-el-Gheí) in art. xD.

maxaADapN [A ford; i. e.] a place where people pass through water, walking or riding: (S, A, K:) or a place where one walks through water: (Msb:) pl. maxaADN↓, (S, K,) [or this is rather a coll. gen. n.,] or maxaAYiDu, (as in one copy of the S,) and maxaAwiDu (AZ, S, K) and maxaADaAtN. (Msb, TA.)

1 xaAfa xAf xAfy
1. xaAfa, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally xawifa, (Lth, L, &c.,) first pers. xifotu, (TA,) aor. yaxaAfu, (S, K, &c.,) originally yaxowafu, (L,) imperative xafo, (S,) inf. n. xawofN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and xiyfN↓, [originally xiwofN,] (Lh, TA,) erroneously written in the K with fet-h [to the x], but some say that this is a simple subst., not an inf. n., (TA,) and xiyfapN↓, (Lh, S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally xiwofapN, (K,) but some say that this also is a simple subst., not an inf. n., (TA,) and [therefore] its pl. is xiyfN, (Lh, JK, S, and so in the CK,) in [some of] the copies of the K erroneously written xiyafN, (TA,) or this [as well as the next preceding] may be an inf. n., for some few inf. ns. have pls., (ISd, TA,) and maxaAfapN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally maxowafapN, for which last, the first of these inf. ns. is used by a poet, and therefore made fem., (TA,) He feared; he was afraid or frightened or terrified; syn. faziEa. (K.) It is also trans.: (Msb:) you say, xaAfahu and txwRfhu↓ [He feared, or was afraid of, him, or it]; (Msb, TA;) both signifying the same: (TA:) [and so xaAfa minohu; or this may mean he feared what might happen to him from him, or it:] and Ealayohi XayoYFA txwRf↓, meaning xaAfahu [i. e. xaAfa Ealayohi XayoYFA He feared for him a thing]: (S, K:) and xaAafahu EalaI maAlihi and Ealayohi txwRfhu↓ [He feared him, or it, for his property]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it is also used in the sense of ZanRa [He thought, or opined]: and in this case, the Arabs sometimes use it in the same manner as a verb signifying an oath, and give it the same kind of complement; as in an ex. cited voce darida [q. v.]. (S in art. drd.) And He knew. (Lh, Kr, K.) Hence, waUini QmoraOapN xaAfato mino baEolihaA nuXuwzFA [And if a woman know that there is, on the part of her husband, injurious treatment, or unkindness, or estrangement], (K,) in the Kur [iv. 127]. (TA.) And hence also, famano xaAfa mino muwSK janafFA [And he who knoweth that there is, on the part of the testator, an inclining to a wrong course, or a declining from the right course, &c.], (K,) in the Kur [ii. 178]; thus explained by Lh. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xaAfahu, (S,) first pers. xufotuhu, (K,) aor. yaxuwfuhu, (S,) He exceeded him in fear. (S, K. *) You say, faxaAfahu xaAwafahu↓, (S,) inf. n. of the former muxaAwafahu, (TA,) i. e. [He vied with him to see which of them would exceed the other in fear, and] he exceeded him in fear. (S.)

2 xwRfhu xAYf xwf xwfh xwfp
2. xwRfhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. taxowiyfN, (TA,) i. q. OaxaAfahu. (Msb, K.) See the latter, in two places. He put fear into him. (JK, TA.) xawRifonaA [app. addressed to God] is mentioned by Lh as meaning Render the Kur-án and the Traditions beautiful to us in order that we may [give heed thereto and] fear. (TA.) ― -b2- He made him to be in such a state, or condition, that men feared him; (JK, K;) he made him to be feared by men. (M.) Hence, in the Kur [iii. 169], UinRamaA celikumu QlXRayoTaAnu yuxawRifu OawoliyaMCahu, i. e. [Verily that is the devil:] he causeth his friends to be feared by you: [or that devil causeth &c.:] or, as Th says, causeth you to fear by his friends. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He diminished it, lessened it, or took from it; and so xwRf minohu. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- xwRf ganabahu He sent away his sheep, or goats, flock by flock. (TA.)

3 xaAowafa
3: see 1, last sentence.

4 AxAfhu OxAf OxAfh UxAf UxAfp AxAfh AxAfp
4. AxAfhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. UixaAfapN (S) and UixaAfN, like kitaAbN, (Lh, TA,) [but the latter is irreg. and rare,] He, or it, (an affair, a case, or an event, Msb,) caused him, or made him, to fear, or be afraid; put him in fear; frightened, or terrified, him; (TA;) and xwRfhu↓, (Msb, K,) inf. n. taxowiyfN, (S, TA,) signifies the same. (S, Msb, K.) So in the phrase AxAf AlvRagoru [The enemies' frontier caused to fear, &c.; was insecure:] or fear entered from it. (TA.) You say also, maAla AlHaAYiTu faOaxaAfa AlnRaAsa [The wall leaned, and caused the people to fear]. (Msb.) And OaxaAfa AllRuSuwSu AlTRariyqa [for OaxaAfa AllRuSuwSu Oahola AlTRariyqi The robbers caused the people of the road, or the passengers thereof, to fear, &c.; or it may be rendered the robbers caused the road to be insecure]. (Msb.) And Oaxafotuhu AlOamora faxaAfahu [I caused him to fear the thing, or affair, &c., and he feared it; making the verb doubly trans.]; as also UiyRaAhu fataxawRafahu xawRafotuhu↓. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., OaxiyfuwA AlhawaAmRa qabola Oano tuxiyfakumo Make ye the venomous reptiles and the like to fear before they make you to fear; (TA;) i. e. kill ye them before they kill you. (JM, TA.) ― -b2- maA OaxowafaniI Ealayoka [How greatly do I fear for thee!]. (TA.)

5. txwRfhu: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also He took by little and little (S, L, K) from it, (S, K,) or from its sides; (L;) as also tHwRfhu: (S and K * in arts. Hwf and Hyf:) or he took from its extremities; so in the A; in which it is said to be tropical: accord. to IF, it is originally [txwRn,] with n [in the place of the f]. (TA.) Dhu-rRummeh says, (S,) or not he, but some other poet, for it is ascribed to several different authors, (L,)
taxawRafa AlrRaHolu minohaA taAmikFA qaridFA
kamaA taxawRafa Zahora AlnRaboEapi AlsRafanu
[Her saddle abraded from a long and high, compact hump, like as when the piece of skin used for smoothing arrows has abraded from the back of a rod of the tree called nbEp]. (S. [See also 5 in art. Hwf, where another reading of this verse is given. In the TA, in the present art., in the places of AlrHl and Zhr, I find AlsRayoru and Euwd.]) Hence, (S, K,) accord. to Fr, (TA,) OawoyaOaxacihimo EalaI taxawRufK, (S, K,) in the Kur [xvi. 49], (S,) which Az explains as meaning [Or are they secure from his destroying them] by causing them to suffer loss [by little and little] in their bodies and their possessions, or cattle, and their fruits: or, accord. to Zj, it may mean, after causing them to fear, by destroying a town, so that the one next to it shall fear. (TA.) You say also, txwRf mino maAliI He took by little and little from my property. (JK.) And taxawRafanaA AlsRanapu [The year of drought, or sterility, took from us by little and little]. (JK.) And taxawRfaniI HaqRiI [He diminished to me by little and little my right, or due]. (JK.) And taxawRafahu Hmoquhu (tropical:) i. q. AhoDamahu [an evident mistranscription for AihotaDamahu or haDamahu, meaning His stupidity deprived him of his right, or due]. (TA.)

[See also 4.] ― -b3- And Fighting: whence, faUicaA jaMCa Alxawofu [But when fighting cometh; in the Kur xxxiii. 19]. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also xaAYifN. ＝ -A3- Also A red hide from which are cut strips like thongs, (Kr, K, TA,) and then upon these are put [ornaments of the kind termed] Xacor; worn by a girl:

Sgr, and particularly OaSogara Alqirobapa,)] having its head [or border] raised, for honey; (K;) so says Skr, in explaining the following verse: or, as IB says, accord. to Aboo-'Alee, it is from the phrase AlnRaAsu OaxoyaAfN, meaning “ men, ” or “ the people, ” “ are different, one from another; ” for it is a xariyTap of hide, or leather, embellished with different kinds of embellishment; and if so it should be mentioned in art. xyf: (TA:) [but] the dim. is xuwayofapN↓. faOaSobaHa yaqotariI maXadFA biXiyqi
(S,) [He put beneath his armpit a xAfp in which was a receptacle for honey, and betook himself to making successive endeavours to reach the most difficult part of a mountain by means of a rope, or rope of palm-fibres; for] he means XiyqFA bimasadK; the phrase being inverted: (S and TA in art. Xyq:) or he means, [betook himself to] taking successive holds of a rope (yatatabRaEu HabolFA) tied to a Xyq [here best rendered mountain-top] in his descent to the place of the honey; so that there is no inversion. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- Also i. q. EayobapN [A kind of basket, or receptacle, of hide, or leather]; (TA;) the thing in which fruits are gathered; also called mixorafN. Tariyqu maxuwfN A road in which people fear: (S, * Msb, K:) or a road that is feared; (JK, TA;) as also maxiyfN↓, and xaAYifN↓; which last is tropical, of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (TA;) or, thus applied, this last [is a possessive epithet, and thus] means having fear: (JK: [see also muxaAfN:]) you should not say TariyqN muxiyfN↓, because the road does not cause fear, but only he who robs and slays therein. [a thing resembling] a pimple in the face, inclining to blackness: dim. xuwayolN↓ and xuyayolN: and pl. xiylaAnN. (JK. [See also art. xyl.]) ＝ -A5- The [kind of banner called] liwaMC, of an army or a military force. (S, K. 1. xaAnahu, (S, K,) aor. yaxuwnuhu, (S,) inf. n. xiyaAnapN and xawonN and maxaAnapN (S, K) and xaAnapN (K) and xaAYinapN, of the measure faAEilapN, like laAgiyapN &c.; (TA;) and AxtAnhu↓; (S, K;) He was unfaithful, or he acted unfaithfully, to the confidence, or trust, that he reposed in him; (K;) [he was treache rous, perfidious, or unfaithful, to him; or he acted treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully, towards him;] fiI kacaA [in such a thing]: (S:) xiyaAnapN is the contr. of OamaAnapN; and does not relate only to property, but also to other things: (Mgh:) or the neglecting, or failing in, OamaAnapN [which is trustiness, or faithfulness]: (El-Harállee, TA:) or i. q. nifaAqN, except that xyAnp regards a compact or covenant or the like, and trustiness, or faith fulness, and nfAq regards religion; so that the former is the acting contrary to what is right, by breaking a compact or covenant or the like: (Er Rághib, TA:) but [it is said that] the primary signification of xawonN is the making to suffer loss, or diminution; because the xaAYin makes the maxuwn to suffer loss, or diminution, of something. Ye used to act unfaith fully to yourselves] means ye used to act un faithfully, one to another: (S, * TA:) or ye used to act wrongfully to yourselves: AixotiyaAnN has a more intensive signification than xiyaAnapN. (Bd.) One says also, xAn AlEahoda He broke the compact or covenant or the like: whence, taquwlu AlnRiEomapu kufirotu walamo OuXokaro wataquwlu AlOamaAnapu xunotu walamo OuHofaZo [The benefit says, I have been disacknowledged, and have not been requited with thankfulness; and the trust says, I have been betrayed, and have not been faithfully kept]: the verb [xunotu] being here of the measure fuEilotu, a verb of which the agent is not named. (Mgh.) And xaAnahu AlEahoda, (Msb, K,) and fiI AlEahodi, (Msb,) and xAnhu AlOamaAnapa, (Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. xawonN and xiyaAnapN and maxaAnapN, (Msb,) [He was unfaithful to him in respect of the compact or covenant or the like, and the trust.] ― -b2- [Hence,] xAn sayofuhu (assumed tropical:) [His sword was unfaithful;] i. e., failed of taking ef fect upon the thing struck with it. (TA.) A cer tain person, being asked respecting the sword, said, Oaxuwka wa rubRamaA xaAnaka (assumed tropical:) [It is thy brother, but sometimes it is unfaithful to thee]. (TA.) ― -b3- And xaAnatohu rijolaAhu (assumed tropical:) [His two legs were unfaithful to him;] he was unable to walk. (TA.) ― -b4- And xAn AldRalowa AlrRiXaMCu (assumed tropical:) The well-rope broke off, or be came severed, from the bucket. (TA.) ― -b5- And xAnhu AldRahoru, inf. n. xawonN; (T, TA;) and txwRnhu↓; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) Time altered his state, or condition, (T, TA,) from softness, or easiness, to hardness, or difficulty, (TA,) or to evil; (T, TA;) and in like manner, AlnRaEiymu [enjoyment, &c.]: and of everything that has altered thy state, or condition, [for the worse,] one says, taxawRanaka↓. (T, TA.)

2 xwRnhu xAYn xwn xwnh xwnnh xwnp
2. xwRnhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taxowiynN, (K,) He attributed to him xiyaAnap [i. e. treachery, perfidy, or unfaithfulness]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 5, in two places.

5 txwRnhu txwn txwnh txwnnh txwnp wxI xAn xwn
5. txwRnhu: see 1, last sentence, in two places. You say also, taxawRanahumo meaning He sought [to discover, or show,] their xiyaAnap [i. e. treachery, perfidy, or unfaithfulness], and their slip, lapse, or wrong action; and suspected them, or accused them. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He, or it, diminished it, wasted it, impaired it, or took from it; and so xwRnhu↓, and xwRn minohu: (K:) or diminished it, wasted it, impaired it, or took from it, by little and little; syn. tanaqRaSahu. (JK, * S, Msb.) You say, taxawananiI fulaAnN HaqRiI Such a one took from me by little and little of my right, or due. (S, TA.) And Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
laA balo huwa AlXRawoqu mino daArK taxawRanahaA
marRFA saHaAbN wamarRFA baAriHN taribu
[No, but it is, or was, yearning of the soul arising from a place of abode from which some times raining clouds, and sometimes a hot wind carrying with it dust, took away by little and little, so as gradually to efface the traces thereof]. (S, TA.) And Lebeed says, (S, TA,) describing a she-camel, (TA,)
taxawRanahaA nuzuwliI waQrotiHaAliI
[Which my alighting and my journeying had wasted by little and little;] i. e. whose flesh and fat my alighting and my journeying had diminished by little and little. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He paid frequent attention to him, or it; or he, or it, returned to him, or it, time after time; syn. taEahRadahu; (JK, S, K;) and so xwRnhu↓: (K:) in this sense, the former verb is [said to be] from txwRlhu, by the substitution of n for l (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, [describing a young gazelle,]
laA yanoEaXu AlTRarofa UilRaA maA taxawRanahu
daAEK yunaAdiyhi biQsomi AlmaMCi maboguwmu
(S,) [He raises not his eye, or eyes, except when a caller calling him by the sound of maMCi returns to him time after time, addressed by the cry termed bugaAm:] i. e. except when he hears the bugaAm of his mother calling him by the cry maMCi maMCi: (TA in art. bgm: [it is there added, that the pass. part. n. maboguwm is used in this instance for the act. part. n.; but for this I see no sufficient reason:]) he says that the young gazelle is slum bering, not raising his eye, or eyes, unless his mother comes to him time after time: or, as some say, unless his mother's call to him takes by little and little from his sleep. (S in the present art.) One says also AlHumRaItaxawRanuhu [for tataxawRanuhu] The fever returns to him time after time: (S:) or in its time. (TA.)

8: see 1, in two places.

xaAnN xAn
xaAnN A place in which travellers lodge: (Msb:) a place in which travellers pass the night: and the dayor [i. e. monastery, or convent,] is the xAn of the Christians: (Kull pp. 96 and 97:) or the xAn is for merchants; (S, K;) i. q. funoduqN; (Har p. 325;) [a building for the reception of mer chants and travellers and their goods, generally surrounding a square or an oblong court, having, on the ground-floor, vaulted magazines for mer chandise, which face the court, and lodgings, or other magazines, above: a Persian word, arabi cized:] pl. xaAnaAtN (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A shop: or a shop-keeper: (K:) a Persian word, arabicised. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [It is also a title of honour, used by the Tartars (who apply it to their Emperor), the
Turks (who apply it to the reigning and to a deceased Sultán), and the Persians (who apply it to the governor of a province, and to a man of rank).]

xawonN xwn xwnn

xaAniIRN xAn xAnI xAny

(of pauc., of the first, S, Msb) is OaxowinapN and (of mult., S, Msb) xuwnN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) said by IB to be the only instance of its kind except buwnN pl. of biwaAnN, (TA,) originally xuwunN, like kutubN pl. of kitaAbN, (Msb,) but xuwunN is not used: (S:) the pl. of AxwAn↓ is OaxaAwinu, (Msb,) or OaxaAwiynu. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and xuwRaAnN↓, [accord. to the CK, each is with Al, but this seems to be a mis take, (see XahorN,)] The month [latterly called] rabiyEN AlOawRala: pl. OaxowinapN: (K:) but ISd says, "I know not how this is." (TA.)

AlxawRaAnapu i. q. AlAisotu [meaning (assumed tropical:) The anus]. (TA.)

xaAYinN c
xaAYinN and xaAYinapN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the latter an intensive epithet, (S, Msb,) like EalRaAmapN and nasRaAbapN, (S,) [and also fem. of xaAYinN,] and xaWuwnN↓ and xawRaAnN↓, (K,) [which are likewise intensive epithets,] Unfaithful, or acting unfaithfully, to the confidence, or trust, reposed in him; (K;) [treacherous, perfidious, or unfaithful; or acting treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully: thus the first signifies: the others signifying very un faithful, &c.:] pl. [of the first] xawanapN, (S, M, K,) which is anomalous, (M,) like HawakapN [pl. of HaAYikN], (S,) and xuwRaAnN. (K.) [Hence,] xaAYinN AlnRaZari Looking treacherously, and clandestinely, at a thing at which it is not allowable to look. (TA.) ― -b2- xaAYinu AlEayoni (assumed tropical:) [The languid in respect of the eye] is an appellation applied to the lion; (K, TA;) because of a languidness in his eye when he looks. (TA.)

xaAYinapN c

[Hence,] xaAYinapN AlOaEoyuni (as used in the Kur xl. 20, TA) A surreptitious look (JK, Mgh, K) at a thing at which it is not allowable to look: (JK, K:) or the looking with a look that induces suspicion or evil opinion: (Th, K:) or the making a sign with the eye to indicate a thing that one conceals in the mind: (TA:) or, as some say, the contracting of the eye, or eyes, by way of making an obscure indication: or the looking intentionally [at a thing at which it is not allowable to look]. (Msb.)

mutaxawRanN One to whom xiyaAnap [i. e. treachery, perfidy, or unfaithfulness,] is attributed. (TA.)

1 xawati AldRaAru xwt AldAr
1. xawati AldRaAru, (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor. taxowiI, (Msb,) inf. n. xawaMCN (S, Msb, TA) and xuwiIRN, (Msb,) The house became empty, vacant, or un occupied: (S:) in [some of the copies of] the S with teshdeed, [i. e. xawRat,] which is incorrect: (TA:) or became devoid, or destitute, of its occu pants; as also xawiyat, aor. taxowaI, inf. n. xawaMCN: (Msb:) or its occupants perished: (JK:) and it fell down: (S:) or it became demolished: and xawat and xawiyat, inf. n. xaIRN and xuwiIRN and xawaMCN and xawaAyapN, it became devoid, or destitute, of its occupants, (K, TA,) standing, without inhabitant. (TA.) And xawaI AlmakaAnu, aor. yaxowiI, inf. n. xaIRN, The place became empty, vacant, or unoccupied. (Mgh.) And xawiIa AlbaTonu, aor. yaxowaI, inf. n. xawFI, The belly became empty of food. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xawiIa, aor. yaxowaI, inf. n. xawFI [and xawaMCN], He was, or became, hungry; (JK;) as also AxwI↓: (K:) or his belly became empty of food: (Har p. 167:) or xawaI, like ramaI, [aor. yaxowiI,] inf. n. xawFI and xawaMCN, he was affected with un interrupted hunger. (K.) And xawato, said of a woman, She became empty in her belly on the occasion of childbirth; as also xawiyato: (S, K:) in [some of] the copies of the K, xawRato is here erroneously put for xawiyato. (TA.) And She abstained from food on the occasion of childbirth; (JK, K;) as also xawiyato. (JK, TA.) ― -b3- xawati AlnRujuwmu The stars inclined to setting: (so in two copies of the S:) or so xawRat↓, inf. n. taxowiyapN. (JK, Msb, and so in some copies of the S.) And the former, (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor. taxowiI, (JK, S,) inf. n. xaIRN, (JK, S, K,) The stars set; as also Axwt↓: and the stars brought no rain: (JK:) or the stars set aurorally and brought no rain; (S, Msb, * K; *) as also Axwt↓ (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K) and xwRt↓. (K.) ― -b4- xawaI AlzRanodu, (K,) inf. n. xawFI (TA) [or xaIRN], The znd [q. v.] failed to produce fire; as also AxwI↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- xawiIa, aor. yaxowaI, He called, or cried, out. (JK.) ＝ -A3- xawaI, (TA,) inf. n. xaIRN, (K, TA,) i. q. qaSada [He, or it, pursued a right, or direct, course; &c.: if trans., it may mean he aimed at, intended, or purposed, a thing]. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A4- xawaAhu, inf. n. xawFI and xawaAyahu, He seized it; took it, or carried it off, by force; or snatched it away; (K;) and so AxtwAhu↓. (IAar, TA.)

2 xwRt AlUibilu xwt AlAbl
2. xwRt AlUibilu, inf. n. taxowiyapN, The camels became empty (JK, M, Msb) and drawn up (M) in their bellies. (JK, M, Msb.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- And xwRI, inf. n. as above, said of a camel, (JK, S, TA,) He lay down upon his breast, and then set firmly upon the ground his [callous protuberances called the] vafinaAt: (JK:) or he made his belly to be separated by some interval from the ground, in lying upon his breast, (S, TA, *) and set firmly [upon the ground] his vafinaAt. (TA.) And in like manner, (S,) xwRI fiI sujuwdihi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) said of a man, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He raised his belly from the ground in his prostration: (S, * Msb:) or he put, or set, his upper arms apart, or remote, from his sides therein: (Mgh, Msb:) or he drew up his body, and made a space between his upper arms and his sides, in his prostration: (K:) thus a man is directed to do in prostrating himself in prayer. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b4- Said of a man, it signifies also He lowered his eyes, or looked towards the ground, desiring to be silent. (JK.) ― -b5- Said of a bird, It hung down its wings: (S:) or it spread its wings, (JK, TA,) and stretched out its legs, (TA,) desiring to alight. (JK, TA.) ― -b6- xawRati AlnRujuwmu: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- xawRayotuhaA, inf. n. as above, I dug (K, TA) for her, namely, a woman, (TA,) a hole, or hollow, in the ground, and kindled [fire] in it, and then seated her in it, or upon it, (fiyhaA [i. e. fiI AlHafiyrapi],) on account of a disease that she had. (K, TA.) One says of a woman for whom this is done, xuwRiyato. (As, TA.) ＝ -A3- And xwRI lahaA, (JK, Kr, S, K,) and xawRaAhaA, (K,) inf. n. as above, He made for her (namely, a woman,) the food called xawiyRap, (JK, Kr, S, K,) that she might eat it. (S.)

8. AxtwI He abstained from food: and it may mean he became void of everything but anger. (Ham p. 219.) ― -b2- He lost his reason, or intellect. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence. ― -b2- Also He took away a thing. (JK.) He took altogether, or entirely, what another possessed; as also AxwI↓. (JK, K.) ― -b3- He (a beast of prey) stole and ate the young one of a cow. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- He cut off for himself (AiqotaTaEa) a land, or district; (IAar, K;) as also AxtAt and txwRt. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- He thrust at a horse in his xawaMC; i. e., the space between his fore legs and his hind legs. (JK, K.)

xawFI Emptiness of the belly; (JK, K;) i. e. its emptiness of food; as also xawaMCN↓; (K;) [both inf. ns.;] the former of higher authority than the latter. (TA.) And Hunger; (JK, Msb;) as also xawaMCN↓, (TA,) i. q. xawRN. (K, TA. [In the CK, wAlxuwRu bAlDRamRi AlEasalu is erroneously put for wAlxawRu wabiAlDRamRi AlEasalu. (As, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. vaAbitN [Continuing, subsisting, lasting, &c.]: (K:) of the dial. of Teiyi. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A flow of blood from the nose; or blood flowing from the nose. (K. [In this instance the word is correctly given in the CK.])

A vacant space between two things; (K;) such between the heaven and the earth; (TA;) like hawaMCN. (K, TA.) ― -b3- A wide, or spacious, open tract of the earth, containing no herbage nor trees nor habitations. (TA.)

xuwaMCN xwMC

(K, * TA.) ― -b4- And The wide part of the interior of a raHol [or camel's saddle]. (K, TA. [In the CK, mn AlrRajuli is erroneously put for mn AlrRaHoli.]) ＝ -A2- See also xawaApN, second sentence.

xaAwK xAw xAwy
[xaAwK part. n. of 1.] fatiloka buyuwtuhumo xaAwiyapF, in the Kur [xxvii. 53], means [And those are their houses,] empty; or, as some say, fallen down: like the phrase in the same [ii. 261 and xxii. 44], xaAwiyapN EalaI EuruwXihaA having fallen down upon its roofs: (S:) or this means empty; its walls having fallen upon its roofs.
