waqaEuwA fiI waAdiI tuxuyRiba, (Ks, S, A, K, but in the last waqaEa,) and tuxayRiba, (A, K,) the last word being imperfectly decl. [in each of these instances], (Ks, S, A, K,) meaning fiI AlbaATili [i. e. They fell into that which was vain, unreal, nought, futile, or the like, and consequently, into disappointment], (Ks, S, K,) or fI baATilK [into a state of things that was vain, &c.]. (A.)

1 xaAta xAt
1. xaAta, aor. yaxiytu, (IAar,) inf. n. xayotN and xuyuwtN, (IAar, K,) and inf. n. of un. xayotapN, (IAar,) He made a sound, syn. SawRata; (IAar, K;*) [app. with his wings, in pouncing down, or making a stoop; see 1 in art. xwt;] said of a bird. (IAar.) ＝ -A2- xaAtahu maAlahu, aor. yaxiytuhu: see 1 in art. xwt.

1 xaAra xAr
1. xaAra, aor. yaxiyru, (K,) inf. n. xayorN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) was, or became, possessed of xayor [or good, &c.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [He was, or be came, good: and he did good: contr. of XarRa.] You say, xirota yaA rajulu [Thou hast been good; or thou hast done good, or well; O man]. (S.) And xaAraQllRehu laka fiI hecaA AlOamori [May God do good to thee, bless thee, prosper thee, or favour thee, in this affair: or] may God cause thee to have, or appoint to thee, good in this affair: (K:) or may God choose for thee the better thing [in this affair]. (A.) AlRehumRa xiroliI occurs in a trad., meaning O God, choose for me the better of the two things. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 8. ― -b4- xaArahu EalaI SaAHibihi, aor. as above, inf. n. xiyrapN and xiyarN (Msb, K *) and xiyarapN (K) and xayorN; (Msb, TA;) and xyRrhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taxoyiyrN; (TA;) He preferred him before his companion, (Msb, K. *) ― -b5- xaAyarahu faxaArahu: see 3.

2 xyRrhu xyr xyrh xyrp
2. xyRrhu He gave him the choice, or option, (S, A, * Mgh, * Msb, * K,) bayona AlXRayoYayoni [between the two things], (S, Mgh, Msb,) or byn AlOamorayoni [between the two affairs]: fataxayRara↓ [so he had the choice, or option, given him]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 1. It is said in a trad., xayRara bayona duwri AlOanoSaAri, meaning He preferred some among the houses of the Assistants before others of them. (TA.) And in another trad., xuyRira, meaning He was preferred, and pronounced to have surpassed, or overcome, or won, in a contest, or dispute. (IAth.)

3 xaAoyara
3: xaAyarahu faxaArahu↓, (A, K,) inf. n. muxaAyarapN, (A,) He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, or contended with him for superiority, in goodness, or excellence, (A, K,) in, or with respect to, (fiI,) a thing, (A,) and he surpassed him therein. (A, K.)

4 maA Oaxoyara fulaAnFA c
4. maA Oaxoyara fulaAnFA, (A,) and maA xayorahu↓, which latter is extr. [with respect to form, though more commonly used than the former], (TA,) [How good is such a one!] phrases similar to maAOaXRarahu and maA XRarahu [which have the contr. meaning]. (TA.) AllRabana lilomariyDi maA xayora↓ [How good is milk for the diseased!], (K, * TA,) with nasb to the r and n, is an expression of wonder: (K:) it was said to Khalaf El-Ahmar, by an Arab of the desert, in the presence of Aboo-Zeyd; whereupon Khalaf said to him, “ What a good word, if thou hadst not defiled it by mentioning it to the [common] people! ” and Aboo-Zeyd returned to his companions, and desired them, when Khalaf ElAhmar should come, to say, all together, these words (mA xyr Allbn llmryD), [in order to vex him], and they did so. (TA.)

5 txyRr txyr xAr xyr
5. txyRr, as an intrans. v.: see 2. ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 8.

6 txAyrwA fiyhi UilaI HakamK txAyrwA fyh Aly Hkm
6. txAyrwA fiyhi UilaI HakamK They contended together for superior goodness, or for excellence, in it, or with respect to it, appealing to a judge, or an arbiter. (A.)

8 AxtArhu OxtArh AxtArh AxtArp QxtAr QxtArh
8. AxtArhu; and txyRrhu↓, (S, * A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] xiyarapN↓, said by IAth to be the only instance of the kind except TiyarapN; (TA voce taTayRara;) and AstxArhu↓; (A;) and xaArahu↓; (K;) He chose, made choice of. selected, elected, or preferred, him, or it. (S, Msb, * K.) You say also, Aixotarotuhu AlrRijaAla, and mina AlrRijaAli, [I chose him from the men,] and Ealayohimo, (K,) which last signifies in preference to them. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [vii. 154], waQxotaAra muwsaI qawomihi saboEiyna rajulFA [And Moses chose from his people seventy men]. (TA.) walaqadi QxotaronaAhumo EalaI EilomK, in the Kur [xliv. 31, Verily we have chosen them with knowledge], may be indicative of God's producing good, or of his preferring them before others. (TA.)

10 AstxAr AstxAr QstxAr
10. AstxAr He sought, desired, or asked for, xiyrap (S, Msb, K) or xiyarap (as in some copies of the K) [i. e. the blessing, prospering, or favour, of God; &c.]. [And it is trans.; for] one says, Aisotaxiri QllReha yaxiro laka [Desire thou, or ask thou for, the blessing, prospering, or favour, of God; &c.; and He will bless, prosper, or favour, thee; &c.]. (S.) And Aisotaxarotu QllReha fiyhi faxaAra liI I desired, or asked, of God, the better of the two things, [or rather the better in it, meaning a case, or an affair,] and He chose it for me. (A.) ― -b2- See also 8.

xayorN xyr
xayorN [Good, moral or physical; anything that is good, real or ideal, and actual or potential; and, being originally an inf. n., used as sing and pl.;] a thing that all desire; such as intelligence, for instance, and equity; (Er-Rághib, and so in some copies of the K;) [or goodness;] and excellence; and what is profitable or useful; benefit; (Er-Rághib;) contr. of XarRN: (S, A, Msb:) pl. xuyuwrN, (Msb, K,) and also, accord. to the Msb, xiyaArN↓: (TA:) [but this latter seems to be properly pl. only of xayorN used as an epithet (see below) and as a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees: it may however be used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] xyr is of two kinds: namely, absolute xyr, which is what is desired in all circumstances and by every person: and what is xyr [or good] to one and XrR [or evil] to another; as, for instance, (Er-Rághib,) wealth, or property: (Zj, L in art. Xd, Er-Rághib, K:) it has this last signification, namely wealth, or property, in the Kur, ii. 176 (S, TA) and ii. 274 and xxiv. 33 and xli. 49: or in the first and second of these instances it is thus called to imply the meaning of wealth, or property, that has been collected in a praiseworthy manner, or it means much wealth or property; and this is its meaning in the first of the instances mentioned above, agreeably with a trad. of 'Alee; and also in the Kur, c. 8: (TA:) [being used as a pl. (as well as a sing.), it may be also rendered good things:] and it is also used by the Arabs to signify horses; (K, * TA;) and has this meaning in the Kur, xxxviii. 31: (TA:) [it is often best rendered good fortune; prosperity; welfare; wellbeing; weal; happiness; or a good state or condition: and sometimes bounty, or beneficence.] rajulN qaliylu Alxayori means [A man possessing little, or no, good; possessing few, or no, good things; or poor: and in whom is little, or no, good or goodness; or niggardly: and also] a man who does little good: (TA in art. ES:) or [who does no good;] who is not near to doing good; denoting the nonexistence of good in him. (Msb in art. ql.) [Thus it sometimes means the same as rajulN laA xayora fiyhi A man in whom is no good or goodness; devoid of goodness; worthless.] And qilRapu xayorK means Poverty: and also niggardliness. (A and TA in art. jHd.) huwa mino Oaholi Alxayori waAlxiyri is explained voce xiyrN. EalaIyadaIi Alxayori waAlyumoni [May it be with the aid of good fortune and prosperity] is a prayer used with respect to a marriage. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) And UinRaka maA waxayorFA means maEa xayorK, i. e., Mayest thou meet with, or attain, good. (K.) ― -b2- xayorN in the phrase fulaAnN xayorN resembles an epithet [like xayRirN↓, and signifies Good; or possessing good]; (Akh, S;) therefore the fem. is xayorapN, of which the pl. is xayoraAtN, (Akh, S, Msb, *) as occurring in the Kur, lv. 70; and they do not [there] mean by it [the comparative or superlative signification of the measure] OafoEalu: (Akh, S:) you say rajulN xayRirN↓, (S, A, Msb,) meaning [A good man; or] a man possessing xayor [or good]; (Msb;) and rajulN xayorN: (S:) and in like manner, AimoraOapN xayRirapN↓ and xayorapN, (S, Msb,) meaning [A good woman; or] a woman excellent in beauty and disposition: (Msb:) or xayorN and xayRirN↓ signify possessing much xayor [or good], (K,) applied to a man; (TA;) and in the same sense you say rajulN xayoraI↓, and xuwraI↓, and xiyarI↓: and the fem. of the first is xayorapN; and of the second, xayRirapN↓: (K:) and the pl. [of pauc.] (of the first, TA) is OaxoyaArN, and [of mult.] xiyaArN: (A, Msb, K:) you say also xiyaAru AlmaAli, meaning The excellent of the camels or the like: (Msb, K:) and in like manner you say of men &c.: (TA:) [see also below:] and the fem. is xayorapN, of which the pl. is xayoraAtN: (Msb:) xiyaArN is contr. of OaXoraArN, (S, Mgh,) [thus] used as an epithet: (Mgh:) and xayorapN↓ [used as a subst.] signifies anything excellent; and the pl. thereof in this sense, xayoraAtN, occurs in the Kur, ix. 89: (S:) or xayorN, (K,) or the fem. xayorapN, (Lth,) or each, (K.) signifies excellent in beauty: (Lth, K:) and xayRirN↓ and xayRirapN signify excellent in righteousness (Lth, K) and religion: (K:) or there is no difference in the opinion of the lexicologists [in general] between xayorapN and xayRirapN↓: (Az:) accord. to Zj, xayoraAtN and xayRiraAtN↓, both occurring in different readings of the Kur, lv. 70, signify good in dispositions: accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, xayorapN, applied to a woman, signifies generous in race, exalted in rank or quality or reputation, goodly in face, good in disposition, possessing much wealth, who, if she bring forth, brings forth a generous child: (TA:) [xiyaArN↓ is also applied as an epithet to a sing. subst., either masc. or fem.:] you say jamalN xiyaArN and naAqapN xiyaArN, meaning A he-camel [that is excellent or] excellent and brisk and so a she-camel. (TA.) See also muxotaArN, in three places. In the saying laEamaru Oabiyka Alxayoru, the word xayor is in the nom. case as an epithet of Eamor; [so that the phrase lit. means By the good life of thy father;] but properly it should be laEamoru Oabiyka Alxayori [By the life of thy good father]: and the like is said with XarR. (TA.) [See also art. Emr.] ― -b3- xayorN is also used to denote superiority: one says, hecaA xayorN mino hecaA This is better than this: and in the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir, hecaA Oaxoyaru↓ mino hecaA, with O, and in like manner, OaXRaru; but the rest of the Arabs drop the O in each case: (Msb:) you say, minoka huwa Oaxoyaru↓ [He is better than thou], and in like manner, OaXRaru minoka; and huwa xayorN minoka, and in like manner, XarRN minoka; and, [using the dim. form of xayorN,] minoka xuyayorN↓, and in like manner, XurayorN minoka. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) You also say, when you mean to express the signification of superiority, fulaAnapN xayoru AlnRaAsi [Such a
woman is the best of mankind]; but not xayorapu: [see, however, what will be found cited hereafter from the K,] and fulaAnN xayoru AlnRaAsi [Such a man is the best of mankind]; but not Oaxoyaru↓ [unless in the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir]: and [it is said that] xayoru when thus used does not assume the dual form nor the pl., because it has the signification of [the measure] OafoEalu: for though a poet uses the dual form, he uses it as a contraction of the dual of xayRirN, like mayotN and mayRitN, and hayonN and hayRinN: (S:) [but. this remark in the S is incorrect: for both xayor and Oaxoyar↓, when used in such phrases as those to which J here refers, have pl. forms of frequent occurrence, and of which examples will be found below; and, as is said by I 'Ak (p. 239), and by many other grammarians, you may say, AlzRayodaAni OafoDalaA Alqawomi, and AlzRayoduwna OafoDaluw Alqawomi and OafaADilu Alqawomi, and also hinodu fuDolaIAlnRisaMCi, &c.; and such concordance is found in the Kur, vi. 123; and is even said by many to be more chaste than the mode prescribed by J:] it is said in the K, that you say, huwa Oaxoyaru↓ minoka, like xayoru; and when you mean the signification of superiority, you say fulaAnN xayorapN AlnRaAsi, with p, and fulaAnapu xayoruhumo, without p: but [SM says,] I know not how this is; for in the S is said what is different from this, and in like manner by Z in several places in the Ksh; and what is most strange is, that the author of the K quotes in the B the passage of J [from the S], and adopts the opinion of the leading authorities [as given in the S]: (TA:) or you say, fulaAnapu Alxayorapu mina AlmaroOatayoni [Such a woman is the better of the two women]: and hiIa Alxayorapu, and Alxiyrapu↓, [so in the TA, but in the CK Alxiyarapu,] and AlxiyraI↓, and AlxuwraI↓, [the last being fem. of Oaxoyaru, originally xuyoraI, and so, app., the last but one, She is the better, or best:] (K:) and [using the dim. form of xayorN] you say, Oaholihi huwa xuyayoru↓ [He is the best of his family]: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) one says also, to one coming from a journey, xayora maA rudRa fiI OaholK wamaAlK, meaning May God make that with which thou comest [back] to be the best of what is brought back by the absent with family and property; (As, Meyd, TA;) or, as some relate it, xayoru, i. e. radRuka xayoru radRK [may thy bringing back be the best bringing back]; and fI is used in the sense of maEa: (Meyd:) [OaxoyaArN is pl. of pauc., and xiyaArN pl. of mult., and so app. is xiyraAnN, of xayorN thus used; and OaxaAyiru↓ is pl. of Oaxoyaru, and so is Oaxoyaruwna applied to rational beings: in the TA, OaxaAyiru is said to be a pl. pl. of Oaxoyaru, and so xiyraAnN; but this is app. a mistake, probably of transcription:] you say rajulN mino xiyaAri AlnRaAsi and OaxoyaArihimo and OaxaAyirihimo↓ [A man of the best of mankind]: (A, TA:) and laka xiyaAru hecihi AlUibili, and xiyratuhaA↓, [Thine are, or is, or shall be, the best of these camels,] alike with respect to a sing. and a pl.: (TA:) and Uibilihi naHara xiyrapa↓ and Uibilihi xuwrapa↓ [He slaughtered the best of his camels]: (IAar, TA:) and humu AlOaxoyaruwna↓ [They (meaning men) are the better, or best]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) ＝ -A2- maA xayora for maA Oaxoyara: see 4, in two places. ＝ -A3- xayoru bawRaMCu [from the Persian xiyrobuwaA Lesser cardamom;] a kind of small grain, resembling the qaAqulRap [or common cardamom], (K,) of sweet odour. (TA.)

xiyrN xyr
xiyrN Generousness; generosity; (S, A, Msb, K;) liberality; munificence. (Msb.) You say, fulaAnN cuw xiyrK Such a one is a possessor of generousness, or generosity, &c. (Msb.) And huwa mino waAlxiyri Oaholi Alxayori↓ [He is of the people of good, or of wealth, &c., and of generosity]. (A.) ― -b2- Eminence; elevated state or condition; nobility. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- Origin. (Lh, K.) ― -b4- Nature, or disposition. (A, K.) You say, huwa kariymu Alxiyri He is generous in nature, or disposition. (A.) ― -b5- Form, aspect, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineaments; guise, or external state or condition; or the like; syn. hayoYapN. (Lh, K.)

xuwrapN xwr xwrh xwrp
xuwrapN [app. originally xuyorapN]: see xayorN, near the end of the paragraph; and see also art. xwr.

xayorapN xyr xyrh xyrp
xayorapN fem. of xayorN [q. v.] used as an epithet: pl. xayoraAtN. (Akh, S, Msb.) ― -b2- [Also, used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, A good thing, of any kind: a good quality; an excellency: and a good act or action: &c.: pl. as above:] see xayorN, in the former half of the paragraph.

xiyrapN xyr xyrh xyrp
xiyrapN: see xayorN, in three places, towards the end of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see xiyarapN, in four places: ― -b3- and xiyaArN. ― -b4- It is also a subst. from xaAraQllRehu laka fiIhecaAAlOamori, (S,) and so xiyarapN↓; both signifying [The blessing, prospering, or favour, of God; his causing one to have, or appointing to one, good in an affair: or his choosing for one the better thing in an affair: or] the state that results to him who begs God to cause him to have good, or to choose for him the better thing, in an affair. (TA.) You say, kaAna celika xiyrapF mina QllRehi [That was through God's blessing, prospering, or favour; &c.: or through God's choosing the better thing in the affair]. (A.)

xiyarapN xyr xyrh xyrp
xiyarapN and xiyrapN↓ (of which the former is the better known, TA) are substs. from AixotaArahu, (K,) or from AixotaArahu QllRehu, (S,) both signifying A thing, man, or beast, and things, &c., that one chooses: (TA:) or [a thing, &c.,] chosen, selected, or elected: (Mgh:) as in the saying, muHamRadu xiyarapu QllRehi mino xaloqihi and xiyratuhu↓ [Mohammad is the chosen, or elect, of God, from his creatures]: (S, Mgh: *) or xiyrapN↓ is a subst. from AlAixotiyaArN, like fidoyapN from AlAifotidaMCu; and xiyarapN is syn. with xiyaArN and AixotiyaArN; or is from taxayRarotu AlXRaIoCa: or, as some say, xiyrapN and xiyarapN are syn.: (Msb:) see 8; and see also xiyaArN: and hecihi xiyratiI↓ (Msb, TA) or xiyaratiI (TA) means This is what I choose; (Msb, (TA;) and so hecaA xyrtI: and heWulaMCi xyrtI These are what I choose. (TA.) [See muxotaArN.] ― -b2- See also xiyrapN.

xuwraI xwr xwrI xwry xwryy
xuwraI: see xayorN, in two places.

xayoraI Oxyr xyr xyrI xyry xyryy

xiyraI: see xayorN, in two places.

[xayoriIRN Of, or relating to, xayor, or good, &c.]

xiyriIRN Oxyr xyr xyrI xyry xyryy
xiyriIRN Of, or relating to, or possessing, generousness, generosity, liberality, or munificence. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- And hence, (Msb,) or [thus applied] it is an arabicized word, (S,) [from the Persian xiyriIo,] The manovuwr [or gilliflower:] but generally applied to the yellow species thereof; [so in the present day;] for it is this from which is extracted its oil, which is an ingredient in medicines. (Msb.) [Accord. to Golius, “ Viola alba, ejusque genera: Diosc. iii. 138: ” and he adds, as on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, “ spec. luteum. ”] ― -b2- And xiyriIRu AlbarRi The xuzaAmaI [q. v.]; because it is the most pungent in odour of the plants of the desert. (Msb.)

xayoriyRapN xyr xyry xyryh xyryp
[xayoriyRapN The quality of xayorN; i. e. goodness.]

xiyaArN xyAr xyr
xiyaArN a subst. from AlAixotiyaAru; (S, Mgh, K;) meaning Choice, or option; (Msb;) and so xiyarapN↓ in the Kur [xxviii. 68], maAkaAna lahumu Alxiyarapu They have not choice, or option; (Mgh;) or the meaning of these words is, it is not for them to choose in preference to God; (Fr, Zj;) and so, accord. to Lth, xiyrapN↓, as being an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n., though this seems doubtful,] of AxtAr. (TA.) You say, UinRa fiI AlXRarRi xiyaArFA [Verily in evil there is a choice, or an option]; i. e. what may be chosen: a prov. (TA.) And Oanota biQlxiyaArK and biQlomuxotaAri↓ [in some copies of the K bAlmxyAr, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistranscription, Thou hast the choice, or option]; i. e. choose thou what thou wilt. (K.) And AlbayoEu SafoqapN Oawo xiyaArN Selling is decisive or with the option of returning. (Mgh in art. Sfq.) Hence, xiyaAru AlrRuWoyapi The choice of returning [on seeing it] a thing which one has purchased without seeing it. (Mgh, * Msb, * KT.) And xiyaAru Almajolisi [The choice of returning a thing purchased while sitting with the seller]. (TA.) And xiyaAru AlEayobi [and AlnRaqiySapi] The choice of returning a thing to the seller when it has a fault, a defect, or an imperfection. (KT.) And xiyaAru AlXRaroTi The choice of returning a thing purchased when one of the two contracting parties has made it a condition that he may do so within three days or less. (KT.) And xiyaAru AltRaEoyiyni The choice of specifying [for instance] one of two garments, or pieces of cloth, which one has purchased for ten pieces [of money, or some other sum,] on the condition of so doing. (KT.) ― -b2- See also muxotaArN, in three places. And see xayorN, in the middle of the paragraph, where it is explained as an epithet applied to a sing. subst., either masc. or fem. See also the first sentence of that paragraph. ― -b3- It is also a pl. of xayorN [q. v.] as an epithet, (A, Msb, K,) [and as a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees.] ＝ -A2- Also [A species of cucumber; cucumis sativus Linn. a fructu minore: (Delile, Flor. Aeg.
Illustr., no. 927:)] i. q. qivRaMCN: (S:) or resembling the qvRMC; (K, &c.;) which is the more suitable explanation: (TA:) or i. q. qavadN [q. v.]: an arabicized word: (Mgh:) [from the Persian xiyaArN:] not Arabic. (S.) ― -b2- xiyaAru Xanobara [The cassia fistula of Linn.;] a well-known kind of tree; (K;) a species of the xarRuwb, resembling a large peach-tree; (TA;) abounding in Alexandria and Misr; (K;) and having an admirable yellow flower: (TA:) the latter division [or rather the whole] of the name is arabicized [from the Persian xiyaAro Janobaro]. (TA.)

xuyayorN xyyr

xaAYirN c
xaAYirN [Doing good, or well: &c.:] act. part. n. of xaAra. (S, TA.)

Oaxoyaru c
Oaxoyaru, and its pls. OaxaAyiru and OaHoyaruwna: see xayorN, in eight places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

AixotiyaAriIRN AxtyArI AxtyAry QxtyAr QxtyAry QxtyAryy
AixotiyaAriIRN [Of, or relating to, the will, or choice]. SifapN QxotiyaAriyRapN [meaning A quality which originates from, or depends upon, the will, or choice, i. e. an acquired quality,] is opposed to xiloqiyRapN. (Msb in art. mdH, &c.)

maxoyarapN mxyr mxyrh mxyrp
maxoyarapN [A cause of good: and hence,] excel-lence, and eminence, or nobility: so in the phrase, fulaAnN cuw maxoyarapK [Such a one is a possessor of eminence, &c.]. (A, TA.)

muxayRirN mxyr
muxayRirN: see what follows.

muxotaArN mxtAr
muxotaArN act. part. n. [of 8, signifying Choosing, selecting, or electing]. (TA.) ― -b2- And pass. part. n. [of the same, signifying Chosen, selected, elected, or preferred: and choice, select, or elect; as also xiyaArN↓, which signifies like wise the best of anything; often used in this sense, as a sing. and as a pl.; and excellent, or excellent and brisk, applied to a he-camel and to a she-camel; as mentioned above, voce xayorN]. (TA.) You say also jamalN xiyaArN↓ in the sense of muxotaArN [A choice he-camel], and naAqapN xiyaArN↓ in the sense of muxotaArapN [A choice she-camel]. (TA.) [See also xiyarapN.] The dim. of muxotaArN is muxayRirN↓: the t is thrown out because it is augmentative; and the I is changed into I because it was changed from I in mxtAr: (S:) one should not say muxayotiyrN. 1 xaATa xAT
1. xaATa, (Msb, TA,) first pers. xiTotu, (S,) aor. yaxiyTu, (Msb,) inf. n. xiyaATapN, (S, TA,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb, TK,) and the inf. n. is xayoTN, (TK,) which is said in the K to be syn. with xiyaATapN, but this last is a mistake for xiyaATN as signifying “thread,” (TA,) or “a thread,” (AZ, TA,) though xiyaATN is also syn. with xiyaATapN, (TA,) He sewed, sewed together, or sewed up, a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, Msb, TA;) as also xyRThu↓, inf. n. taxoyiyTN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xaATa baEiyrFA bibaEiyrK (tropical:) He coupled a camel with a camel [by tying the end of the halter of one to the tail of the other]. (TA.) ― -b3- xaATati AlHayRapu, (TA,) inf. n. xayoTN, (K, TA,) (tropical:) The serpent ran along upon the ground. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- xAT Uilayohi xayoTapF↓ (tropical:) He passed by him, or it, [or to, or towards, him or it,] once: or xAT xayoTapF↓ he passed along quickly: (K, * TA:) and so AxtAT↓ and AixotaTaI. (K.) It is said by Kr to be formed by transposition from AlxaTowu: but this is a mistake; for, were it so, they would have said, xAT xawoTapF, not xayoTapF. (ISd.) Accord. to Lth, waAHidapF xAT xayoTapF↓ means (assumed tropical:) He made his journey [or a journey] without interruption. (TA.) In the A it is said that xAT fulaAnN xayoTapF↓ means (tropical:) Such a one journeyed on, not pausing for anything: and in like manner, xAT UilaI maqoSidihi (tropical:) [He journeyed on, not pausing for anything, to his place, or object, of aim]. (TA.)

2 xayRaTa
2: see 1. ― -b2- xayRaTa AlXRayobu fiI raOosihi, (S, K,) inf. n. taxoyiyTN, (K,) means (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, appeared upon his head (K, TA) in streaks, or lines: (TA:) it is like waxaTa: (S, TA:) or became like threads: (K:) and in like manner, fiI liHoyatihi in his beard. (TA.) Bedr Ibn—' Ámir El—Hudhalee says,
Oaqosamotu laA OanosaI maniyHapa waAHidK
HatRaI tuxayRiTa biAlbayaADi quruwniI
(S, TA) [I swear that I will not forget the loan (here meaning the qaSiydap, Skr) of one (meaning Abu—l—'Iyál [with whom he was carrying on a controversy], Skr)] until the sides of my head become streaked with whiteness: (TA:) but some read tuxayRaTa; and Ibn—Habeeb says that xayRaTa AlXRayobu AlrRaOosa signifies (assumed tropical:) Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, became conjoined and continuous upon the head, as though one part thereof were sewed to another: (IB, TA:) some read taxayRaTa↓; and accord. to the K, you say, taxayRaTa raOosuhu biAlXRayobi, meaning (assumed tropical:) His head became streaked, or marked as with threads, by whiteness of the hair, or hoariness: [the best reading seems to be taxayRaTa, for tatatxayRaTa:] and some read tawaxRaTa [for tatawaxRaTa, from tawaxRaTa as having the meaning here assigned to taxayRaTa]. (TA.)

xayoTN xyT
xayoTN Thread, or string; or a thread or string; syn. silokN; (S, K;) the thing with which one sews; (Msb;) [often used as a coll. gen. n.; n. un. with p;] and xiyaATN↓ [likewise] signifies the thing with which a garment, or piece of cloth, is sewed; as also mixoyaTN↓; besides having another signification, common to it with the last, namely “a needle; ” (K;) the pl. of xayoTN is OaxoyaATN [a pl. of pauc.] (IB, K) and xuyuwTN (S, Msb, K) and xuyuwTapN [both pls. of mult.]. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., waAlmixoyaTa OadRuwA AlxiyaATa↓, meaning [Bring ye] the xayoT and the needle. (TA.) And you say, OaEoTiniI xiyaATFA↓ and niSaAHFA, i. e. [Give thou to me] a single xayoT. (AZ, TA.) [OaEoTinaI xiyaATFA waniSaAHFA may, however, mean Give thou to me a needle and thread.] ― -b2- xayoTu AlrRaqabapi (assumed tropical:) The nuxaAE [or spinal cord] of the neck. (S, K) You say, jaAHaXa fulaAnN Eano xayoTi raqabatihi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one defended his blood. (S, O, L.) ― -b3- AlxayoTu AlOaboyaDu and AlxayoTu AlOasowadu, mentioned in the Kur ii. 183, mean (assumed tropical:) The true dawn, and the false dawn: (Msb:) or the whiteness of the dawn, and the blackness of night; (K, TA;) likened to a thread because of its thinness: (TA:) or the whiteness of day, and the blackness of night: (A 'Obeyd, Nh:) or the dawn that extends sideways, and the dawn that rises high, or, as some say, the blackness of night: (S:) or what appears of the true dawn, which is the musotaTiyr, and what extends with it of the darkness of night, which is the dawn termed the musotaTiyl: (Mgh:) or what first appears of the dawn spreading sideways in the horizon, and what extends with it of the darkness of the last part of the night: (Bd:) or the dawn that rises high, filling the horizon, and the dawn that appears black, extending sideways: (Aboo-Is-hák:) or the real meaning is the day and the night. (TA.) AlxayoTaAni also signifies (assumed tropical:) The night and the day. (L in art. wsd.) tabayRana AlxayoTu mina AlxayoTi means (tropical:) [The night became distinct from the day: or] what is termed AlxayoTu AlOaboyaDu became distinct from what is termed AlxayoTu AlOasowadu. (TA.) And xayoTN mina AlSRuboHi is also said to signify (assumed tropical:) A tint of the dawn. (TA.) [See bariymu AlSRuboHi in art. brm.] ― -b4- xayoTu baATilK (tropical:) What is called luEaAbu AlXRamosi and muxaATu AlXRayoTaAni, (S, TA,) which last is explained by Z and IB as meaning what comes forth from the mouth of the spider: (TA: [the author of which says that, accord. to this explanation, this term differs from lEAb AlXms: but in so saying he seems to be in
error: both evidently signify gossamer:]) it was applied as a surname, or nickname, to Marwán Ibn-El-Hakam; because he was tall, and loose, or uncompact, in frame: (S:) or it signifies the air; syn. AlhawaMCu [perhaps a mistranscription for AlhabaMCu, occurring in another explanation hereafter]: (K:) or light entering from an aperture in a wall [into a dark place] (Th, K:) or xayoTu AlbaATili signifies the scattered habaMC [or atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun] entering from an aperture in a wall [into a dark place] when the sun is hot: and one says, fulaAnN OadaqRu mino xayoTi AlbaATili (tropical:) [Such a one is less in estimation than the scattered atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun]; a prov., applied to him who is in an abject state; thus related, on the authority of Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, by Az and others; but by Sgh, erroneously, OaraqRu mino xayoTi baATilK. (TA.) ― -b5- See also what next follows, in two places.

[of pauc.] OaxoyaATN (IB) and [of mult.] xiyTaAnN: (K:) ↓which last, as also xayoTaAnN↓, signifies likewise a company of men. (TA.) [xiyTN may perhaps be originally xuyoTN, pl. of xayoTaMCu, q. v.]

(Skr.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, (S, TA,) describing the gathere of honey, (TA,)

bijarodaMCa mivoli Alwakofi yakobuw guraAbuhaA
(S, TA,) i. e. He let himself down [over against it, meaning the place of the honey, partly] by means of a rope (for so sibR signifies) and [partly by means of] a wooden peg or stake [to which the rope was attached, fixed] in a rock smooth like the [leather termed] wakof, i. q. niTaE, [the crow of which rock would fall prone upon its face for want of something therein to which to cling:] (TA:) or (in the K “ and ”) xyTp signifies a rope; (As, Az, K, TA;) [and if so, sibR here means “ a wooden peg, ” which is a signification assigned to it in the K in art. sb:] or, accord. to AA, a slender rope (S, L, TA) made [of the bark] of the tree called salab: (L, TA:) and (accord. to some, TA) a string which is with the gatherer of honey, (K, TA,) and with which he pulls the rope [app. when he has detached himself from the latter to gather the honey], it being tied to him: (TA:) or a [tunic of the kind called] durRaAEap, [of leather,] which he wears. maxiyTN and maxoyuwTN↓ A garment, or piece of cloth, sewed: (S, Msb, K:) the I in the former is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, changed into I because of its being quiescent and the preceding letter's being with kesr; the letter preceding it being made movent because it and the w are quiescent after the I has fallen out; [for by dropping the I it becomes changed from maxoyuwTN to maxowoTN;] and it is made movent with kesr [and thus changed from maxowoTN to maxiwoTN, which necessarily becomes maxiyTN,] in order to its being known that the letter which has dropped out is I: some say that the I in maxiyTN is the radical, and that the letter thrown out is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, in order that the word with w [for its medial radical] may be known from that with I; [so that it is changed from maxoyuwTN to maxoyuTN, and then to maxoyoTN, and then to maxiyTN;] but the former saying is the right, because the w is a formative augment, and it is not proper that such should be thrown out. (S.) ― -b2- Also, the former, (assumed tropical:) The whole of the exterior of the belly. (ISh.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A place of passage; (O, L, TA;) a meaning erroneously assigned in the K to xiyaATN↓ and maxoyaTN↓: (TA:) and particularly, (tropical:) of a serpent; (TA;) the place of creeping along of a serpent. xayofN [sing. of OaxoyaAfN]. [See 1.]) And OaxoyaAfN, (Mgh, Msb,) or UixowapN OaxoyaAfN, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) Brothers who are sons of one mother but of different fathers: (S, Mgh, Msb, * K:) and in like manner, banuw AlOaxoyaAfi, if of good authority. 1 xaAla xAl xAly
1. xaAla is syn. with ZanRa and tawahRama: (TA:) you say, xaAla AlXRaIoCa, (Msb, K,) first pers. xilotu, (JK, S,) aor. yaxaAlu, (Msb, K,) first pers. UixaAlu and OaxaAlu, (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.,) the former irregular, (Msb,) but the more chaste of the two, (S,) and the more used, (Msb,) of the dial. of Teiyi, but commonly used by others also, (El-Marzookee, TA,) the latter of the dial. of Benoo-Asad, accord. to rule, (S, Msb,) but of weak authority, (K,) though some assert it to be the more chaste, (TA,) inf. n. xayolN (S, Msb, K) and xayolapN and xiylN (K) and xiylapN (S, K) and xaAlN and xayalaAnN, (K, TA, [the last accord. to the CK xayalaAlN,]) or, as in the T [and JK], xiylaAnN, (TA,) and xayoluwlapN and maxiylapN (S, K) and maxaAlapN; (K;) and xaAla AlXRaIoCa, aor. yaxiylu, is a dial. var. thereof; (Msb;) meaning ZanRapu [He thought, or opined, the thing: and sometimes (see I' Ak p. 109) he knew the thing: but it seems to have originally signified twhRm AlXICa, i. e. he surmised, or fancied, the thing: see xaAlN, below]. (S, Msb, K.) This verb, being of the class of ZanRa, occurs with an inchoative and an enunciative; if commencing the phrase, governing them; but if in the middle or at the end, it may be made to govern or to have no government. (S.) You say, UixaAlu zayodFA OaxaAka [and, if you will, zayodN UixaAlu Oaxuwka and zayodN Oaxuwka UixaAlu, I think Zeyd is thy brother and Zeyd I think is thy brother and Zeyd is thy brother I think]. (JK.) Hence the prov., mano yasomaEo yaxalo, (S, TA,) i. e. He who hears the things related of men and of their vices, or faults, will think evil of them: meaning that it is most safe to keep aloof from other men: or, accord. to some, it is said on the occasion of verifying an opinion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8. ＝ -A3- xAl EalaIAlmaAli, aor. yaxiylu: see xaAla in art. xwl. ＝ -A4- xAl said of a horse, (JK, K, TA,) aor. yaxaAlu, (K,) inf. n. xaAlN, (JK, K,) He limped, or halted, or was slightly lame. (JK, K. *)

2 taxoyiylN txyyl
2. taxoyiylN signifies The imaging a thing in the mind, or fancying it; the forming an image, or a fancied image, thereof in the mind: (TA:) [and taxayRulN↓ has the same, as well as a quasipass., signification.] You say, [xayRalotuhu fataxayRala↓ liI and] liI fataxayRala↓ taxayRalotuhu↓ [I imaged it in the mind, or fancied it, and it became imaged in the mind to me, or an object of fancy to me]; like as you say, [SawRarotuhu fataSawRara liI and] taSawRarotuhu fataSawRara liI: (S:) for taxayRulN↓ [as inf. n. of a quasi-pass. verb] signifies a thing's being imaged in the mind, or fancied: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and AlXRaIoCu lahu txyRl↓ means taXabRaha. (K. [And the same is indicated in the Msb.]) You say also, xuyRila lahu kacaA [Such a thing was imaged to him in the mind; i. e. such a thing seemed to him]; from Alwahomu and AlZRanRu: (Msb:) and xuyRila Uilayohi OanRahu kacaA (S) It was imaged to him [in the mind, i. e. it seemed to him,] that it was so; syn. XubRiha; (PS;) from AltRaxoyiylu and Alwahomu: (S, TA:) and lahu OanRahu kacaA taxayRala↓ signifies [in like manner it became imaged &c.; i. e.] taXabRaha; as also txAyl↓: (S:) and so the first of these three verbs is used in the Kur xx. 69. (TA.) And fulaAnN yamoDiI EalaI maA xayRalato, (JK and S in explanation of the phrase fulaAnN yamoDiI EalaIAlmuxayRali↓,) i. e. XabRahato [Such a one goes on, notwithstanding what (the mind, or the case,) may image to him, or what is fancied by him, of danger of difficulty; AlnRafosu, or AlHaAlu, accord. to Z, (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 94,) being understood]; meaning, notwithstanding peril, or risk; without any certain knowledge. (S.) Whence the prov.,
EalaImaA xuyRilato waEovu AlqaSiymi
i. e. I will go on, notwithstanding what the soft tracts abounding in sand in which the feet sink may be imagined to be: [or the right reading is probably xayRalato, i. e. notwithstanding what the soft tracts &c. may image to the mind, of danger or difficulty:] the t in xyRlt relates to the word wEv, which is [regarded as] pl. of waEovapN; and ElI is a connective of a suppressed verb, namely, OamoDiI, with what follows it: the meaning is, I will assuredly venture upon the affair, notwithstanding its terribleness. (Meyd.) And AifoEalo celika EalaI maA xayRalato, i. e. EalaI maA XabRahato [Do thou that, notwithstanding what (the mind, or the case, as explained above,) may image to thee, of danger or difficulty]; (JK;) meaning, in any case. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xyRl lilnRaAqapi, and Oaxoyala↓, He put a xayaAl [q. v.] near the she-camel's young one, in order that the wolf might be scared away from him, (JK, * S, K, *) and not approach him. (JK, S.) ― -b3- And xyRl fiyhi Alxayora He perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or external sign, of good; as also txyRlhu↓ (K, TA) and txwRlhu: (TA: [see also 4 in art. xwl:]) or you say, Ealayohi taxayRalato↓, (T, S, TA,) meaning I knew him; or knew his internal, or real, state; (taxabRarotuhu, T,
TA;) or I chose him; (Aixotarotuhu, S, TA;) and perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or external sign, of good. (T, S, TA.) ― -b4- And xyRl Ealayohi, (S, Msb, K,) inf.n. taxoyiylN (Msb, K) and taxayRulN↓, (K,) [the latter anomalous, being properly inf. n. of taxayRala,] He conveyed doubt, or suspicion, (AltRuhomapa, S, K, or Alwahoma, Msb,) to him; so in the M, on the authority of AZ; (TA;) i. q. labRasa Ealayohi [he made (a thing, or case) dubious to him]. (Msb.) ― -b5- And xyRlt EalayonaA AlsRamaMCu The sky thundered and lightened [over us], and prepared to rain: but when the rain has fallen, the term taxayRulN↓ [so in my two copies of the S, app. used as an inf. n. of the verb in this phrase, as in a case above, or perhaps a mistranscription for taxoyiylN, though it will be seen from what follows that xyRlt and txyRlt are both said of the sky in the same sense,] is not used: (S:) or xyRlt AlsRamaMCu signifies the sky became clouded, but did not rain; (JK, and Har p. 36;) as also AxAlt↓ and txyRlt↓ and xAylt↓: (Har ibid.:) or, as also txyRlt↓ (Msb, K) and AxAlt↓, (Msb,) or Oaxoyalat↓, (K,) the sky prepared to rain, (Msb, K, TA,) and thundered and lightened, but did not yet rain: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, AxAlt↓ AlsRamaMCu signifies the sky became clouded: (Msb, TA:) and AlsRamaMCu txyRlt↓ the sky became clouded, and prepared to rain. (S.) [In like manner,] one says also, AlsRaHaAbu AxAlt↓ and Oaxoyalat↓ and xAylt↓ The clouds gave hope of rain: (S:) or AlsRaHaAbapu AxAlt↓ the cloud showed signs of rain, so that it was thought [or expected] to rain. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- xyRl also signifies, (JK, TA,) or txyRl↓, (Ham p. 39,) [or each of these,] He (a man) was cowardly, or weak-hearted, on the occasion of fight, (JK, TA, and Ham,) and did not act, or proceed, firmly, or steadily. (Ham.) And xyRl Eani Alqawomi and Oaxoyala↓, [but the former only is explained in this sense in the TA,] He held back from the people, or party, through cowardice: (K, TA:) so says Az, on the authority of' Arrám. (TA.)

3 xAylhu xAylh xAylp
3. xAylhu, (JK, TA,) inf. n. muxaAyalapN, (S, K,) He vied with him, rivalled him, or imitated him, (JK, S, * K, * TA,) in pride and self-conceit; (JK;) did as he did. (TA.) ― -b2- xAylt AlsRamaMCu, and AlsRaHaAbu: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph.

4 AxAl OxAl AxAl xAl
4. AxAl It (a thing) was, or became, dubious, or confused, or vague, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) Ealayohi to him. (JK, Mgh.) One says, hecaA OamorN laA yuxiylu [This is a thing, or an affair, or a case, that will not be dubious, &c.]. (S.) And laA yuxiylu caAka EalaI OaHadK That will not be dubious, &c., to any one. (JK.) ― -b2- AxAl AlXRaIoCu UilaI Alxayori, and Almakoruwhi, The thing exhibited an indication, or indications, of good, and of evil, or what was disliked or hated. (Msb.) [Hence,] AxAlt AlsRamaMCu, and Oaxoyalat: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph, in four places. And AxAlt AlsRaHaAbu and Oaxoyalat, or AxAlt AlsRaHaAbapu: see, again, 2, in the latter part of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b3- And hence, in the opinion of ISd, the she-camel in this case being likened to clouds [giving hope, or showing signs, of rain], (TA,) AxAlt AlnRaAqapu (tropical:) The she-camel had milk in her udder, (JK, K, TA,) and was in good condition of body. (JK, TA.) ― -b4- AxAlt AlOaroDu biAlnRabaAti, (K,) or, as in the M, AxtAlt↓, (TA,) (tropical:) The land became adorned, or embellished, with plants, or herbage. (K, TA. [See also 5.]) ＝ -A2- AxAl fiyhi xaAlFA mina Alxayori: see 4 in art. xwl; and see xaAlN, below. ― -b2- OaxoyalonaA and OaxalonaA We watched, or observed, or looked at, a cloud which it was thought would rain, to see where it would rain. (K, * TA.) And Oaxalotu AlsRaHaAbapu and OaxoyalotuhaA I saw the cloud to be such as gave hope of rain. (S. [See also 10.]) ＝ -A3- Oaxoyala lilnRaAqapi: see 2, in the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A4- Oaxoyala Eani Alqawomi: see 2, last sentence.

5 txyRl OxAl txyl xyl
5. txyRl, as a trans. v., syn. with xayRala; and its inf. n., syn. with taxoyiylN: see 2, first two sentences, in two places. ― -b2- txyRl fiyhi Alxayori, as syn. with xayRala: and taxayRalotu Ealayohi: see 2, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also, as a quasipass. v., similar in signification to xuyRila; and its inf. n.: see 2, first three sentences, in five places. ― -b2- And taxyRulN used as an inf. n. of xayRala Ealayohi: and app. as an inf. n. of xayRalato EalayonaA AlsRamaMCu: see 2, latter half, in two places. ― -b3- txyRlt AlsRamaMCu: see 2, latter half, in three places. ― -b4- txyRl as syn. with AxtAl: see the latter verb. ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] txyRlt AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land became abundant in its plants, or herbage: (JK:) [and, (as is shown by an explanation of the part. n. of the verb, below,) (assumed tropical:) the land had its plants, or herbage, in a state of full maturity, and in blossom; and so txAylt↓; whence,] a poet says,
taOazRara fiyhi AlnRayotu HatRaI taxaAyalato
rubaAhu waHatRaI maA turaI AlXRaMCu nuwRamaA
[The herbage in it became, or had become, tangled, or luxuriant, and strong, so that its hills were clad with plants in full maturity, and in blossom, and so that the sheep, or goats, were seen sleeping]. (S, TA. [In both, the meaning of the verb in this ex. is indicated by the context. See also 4, where a similar meaning is assigned to AxAlt or AxtAlt.]) ― -b6- taxayRulN also signifies The being, or becoming, of various colours. (JK, Ham p. 39. *) [Hence the saying,] taxayRala Algaroqu biAlsRafori, i. e. [The desert, or far-extending desert] became of various colours with the travellers, by reason of the Ml [or mirage]. (JK.) ― -b7- Also The going on, or away; or acting with a penetrative energy; and being quick. (JK, Ham p. 39.) ― -b8- See also 2, last sentence but one.

6 taxaAoyala
6: see 2, third sentence: ― -b2- and 8, in two places: ― -b3- and see also 5, in two places.

8 AxtAl OxtAl AxtAl QxtAl
8. AxtAl He was proud, or haughty; or he behaved proudly, or haughtily; (S;) as also xaAla↓, (JK, S,) aor. yaxiylu, (JK,) or yaxaAlu, (Ham p. 122,) and yaxuwlu, (JK, Ham,) inf. n. xaAlN and xawolN; (Ham;) and txyRl↓ and txAyl↓: (K, TA:) or he was proud, or haughty, and selfconceited: (Msb:) and he walked with a proud, or haughty, and self-conceited, gait: (MA, KL:) said of a man, and of a horse: (Msb:) and taxaAyulN↓ signifies the behaving, or carrying oneself, with pride, or haughtiness, combined with slowness. (JK.) You say of a horse, yaxotaAlu fiI miXoyatihi [He is proud and self-conceited in his gait]. (TA.) ― -b2- AxtAlt AlOaroDu: see 4.

10 AstxAl AlsRaHaAbapa AstxAl AlsHAbh AstxAl AlsHAbp
10. AstxAl AlsRaHaAbapa He looked at the cloud and thought it to be raining. (TA. [See also 4, last sentence but two.])

xaAlN xAl xAly
xaAlN i. q. ZanRN and tawahRumN [meaning Thought, or opinion: and surmise, or fancy: though tawahRumN is often explained as syn. with ZanRN]: (K:) an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.) So in the saying, OaSaAba fihi xaAliI [My thought or opinion, or surmise or fancy, was right respecting him, or it]. (TK.) ― -b2- I. q. ― -b3- maxiylapN, q. v., (K,) [accord. to the TA, which is followed in this instance, as usual, by the author of the TK, as meaning firaAsapN: but this is a mistake: for whI AlfrAsp, the explanation in the TA, we should read wahiIa mina AlfiraAsapi; as is shown by its being there immediately added that one says, fiyhi xaAlFA OxaAla↓, explained in art. xwl; (see 4, and xaAlN, in that art.; and see also maxiylapN in the present art.;) and by what here follows:] AlxaAlN is syn. with AlmaxiylapN and AlXRiyapu. (JK.) ― -b4- For another sense in which it is syn. with maxiylapN see the latter word, below. ― -b5- A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. xuluqN. (TA.) ― -b6- I. q. xuyalaMCu, q. v. (S, K *) ＝ -A2- A limping, or halting, or slight lameness, in a horse or similar beast: in this sense an inf. n. of xaAla. (JK, K. *) ― -b2- Gout; or gout in the foot or feet; syn. niqorisN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Lightning: (K:) [app. as being a sign, or token, of coming rain.] ― -b2- Clouds; syn. gayomN: (S:) or clouds (gym) lightening: (JK, M, TA:) and also rising, and seeming to one to be raining; and the single cloud (saHaAbap) is termed muxiylapN↓: (JK:) or rising, and seeming to one to be raining, and then passing beyond one; but when having thunder, or lightning, therein, termed muxiylapN↓, though not when the rain has gone therefrom: (Har p. 36, from the 'Eyn:) or clouds (saHaAbN) raining: (T, TA:) or clouds (sHAb) that fail not to fulfil their promise of rain; (K, * TA;) and a cloud of this description is termed maxiylapN↓: (JK:) or in which is no rain, (K, TA,) though thought, when seen, to be raining. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A liberal, bountiful, or generous, man: (JK, T, M, K:) as being likened to the raining clouds, (T, TA,) or to the lightening clouds, (JK, M, TA,) which are so termed. (JK, T, M, TA.) ― -b4- A man in whom one sees an indication, or a sign, or token, of goodness. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Free from AltRuhomap [as meaning what occasions suspicion]. (K.) ― -b6- A man who manages cattle, or camels &c., (K, TA,) and pastures them, (TA,) well: (K, TA:) or xaAlu maAlK
one who manages cattle, &c., and watches them, well. (JK.) And One who keeps to a thing, (K, TA,) and manages, orders, or regulates, it. (TA.) A king who manages, orders, or regulates, the affairs of his subjects. (JK.) [See also xaAlN in art. xwl.] ― -b7- An owner of a thing: (K:) from xaAlahu, aor. yaxuwlu, meaning “ he managed it, ” &c. (TA.) You say, mano xaAlu hecaA Alfarasi Who is the owner of this horse? (TA.) [See xaAlN in art. xwl.] ― -b8- See also muxotaAlN, in three places. ― -b9- A man free from an attachment of love. (K.) ― -b10- A man having no wife. (K.) ― -b11- A man weak in heart and body: (K:) but this is most probably [xaAlRN,] with teshdeed, from xalRa laHomuhu, meaning “ he became lean. ” (TA.) ＝ -A4- As meaning A maternal uncle, it is mentioned in art. xwl. (TA.) ＝ -A5- A mole, syn. XaAmapN, (K,) a black XAmp, (TA,) upon the person; (S, K, Msb, TA;) [a thing resembling] a pimple in the face, inclining to blackness; (JK, T, Mgh, TA;) or a small black spot upon the person: (TA:) dim. xuyayolN↓ (JK, S) accord. to him who says maxiylN and maxoyuwlN [as meaning “ marked with many moles upon the person ”], (S,) and xuwayolN (JK, S, Msb) accord. to him who says maxuwlN, (S,) which shows it to be, in one dial., of the art. xwl [in which it is also mentioned]: (Msb:) pl. [of mult.] xiylaAnN (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OaxiylapN. (Msb.) ＝ -A6- A garment, or cloth, of the garments, or cloths, of the juhRaAl [here meaning people of the Time of Ignorance]: (S:) a soft garment or cloth (JK, K, TA) of the garments or cloths of El-Yemen: (JK, TA:) and a [garment of the kind called] burod, of the fabric of El-Yemen, (K, TA,) red [or brown], with black lines or stripes, which used to be made in the first ages: but Az makes these two to be one: it has been mentioned before, in art. xwl, to which also it may belong. (TA.) ― -b2- A garment, or piece of cloth, with which a corpse is shrouded. (K.) ― -b3- The [kind of banner called] liwaMC (JK, T, K) that is tied [to its spear-shaft] for a commander, (K,) or to denote one's having the authority of a prefect, commander, ruler, or the like: (T, TA:) [SM adds,] I do not think it to be so called for any other reason than that it was of the buruwd of the kind termed xaAlN. (TA.) [See also xaAlN in art. xwl.] ― -b4- The office of Khaleefeh; (K;) because belonging to one for whom a banner is tied [on the occasion of his appointment]. (TA.) ＝ -A7- A big mountain. (K.) ― -b2- And (as being likened thereto, TA) (assumed tropical:) A big camel: (JK, K:) pl. xiylaAnN: to such, a poet likens certain men, as resembling camels in their bodies and in their being devoid of intellect. (TA.) ― -b3- And A black stallion-camel. (IAar, K, * TA.) Mentioned also in art. xwl. (TA.) ＝ -A8- A place in which is no one, or no one by whose company one may be cheered. (K.) [Probably from xaAlK, part. n. of xalaA, aor. yaxoluw.] ― -b2- A small [hill such as is termed] Oakamap. (K.) ＝ -A9- The lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bit with its appertenances,] of a horse: (K:) app. a dial. var. of xawalN, q. v. (TA.) ＝ -A10- A certain plant, having a blossom, well known in Nejd. (K.)

xaAlK xAl xAly
xaAlK, formed by transposition from xaAYilN: see muxotaAlN.

xayolN Oxyl xyl
xayolN Horses, (JK, S, K,) collectively; (JK, K;) as some say, (Msb,) applied to Arabian horses and [such as are of inferior breed, termed] baraAciyn; (Mgh, Msb;) the males thereof and the females: (Mgh, TA: *) but of the fem. gender: (Msb, TA:) a quasi-pl. n., (Mgh,) having no sing. (Msb, K) formed of the same radical letters: (Msb:) or the sing. is xaAYilN↓: (K:) so called because of their AixotiyaAl, (Msb, K, * TA, *) i. e. pride and self-conceit, (Msb,) in their gait: so says AO; but ISd says that this is not well known: (TA:) or because no one rides a horse without experiencing a feeling of pride: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl., (Msb, CK,) or pl. pl., (so in copies of the K and in the TA,) [of mult.,] xuyuwlN (S, * Msb, K) and xiyuwlN and [pl. of pauc.] OaxoyaAlN. (K.) And the dual form is used, [although xayolN has a pl. signification,] like as are [the duals UibilaAni and ganamaAni and] liqaAHaAni and jimaAlaAni. (ISd, TA.) One says, fulaAnN laAtusaAyaru xayolaAhu, or laAtuwaAqafu, (K, TA,) and laAtusaAyaru xayolaAhu walaA tuwaAqafu, (TA, and so in the CK,) [Such a one, his two troops of horses will not be competed with in going, or running, nor in standing still,] meaning (tropical:) he is not to be endured in respect of calumny and lying: (K, TA:) it is said of a great, or frequent, liar. (TA in art. syr.) And Alxayolu OaEolamu mino furosaAnihaA [The horses are more knowing than their riders]; (Meyd, K;) a prov., (Meyd,) applied in relation to him of whom thou formest an opinion (Meyd, K, TA) that he possesses, or possesses not, what suffices, (TA,) and whom thou findest to be as thou thoughtest, (Meyd, K, TA,) or the contrary. (Meyd.) And Alxayolu OaEolamu bafurosaAnihaA [The horses are possessed of most knowledge of their riders]; a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) seek thou aid of him who knows the case, or affair. (Meyd.) And Alxayolu tajoriI EalaI masaAwiyhaA, another prov. [explained in art. swO]. (Meyd.) ― -b2- Also Horsemen, or riders on horses. (S, Msb, K.) Thus in the Kur [xvii. 66], waOajolibo Ealayohimo bixayolika wa rajolika. (S. [See 1 in art. jlb.]) ＝ -A2- See also xuyalaMCu.

xayalN Oxyl xyl
xayalN: see xuyalaMCu.

xayolapN Oxyl xyl xylh xylp
xayolapN: see xuyalaMCu.

xiylapN Oxyl xyl xylh xylp
xiylapN: see xuyalaMCu.

xayalapN Oxyl xyl xylh xylp
xayalapN: see xuyalaMCu.

xayoliIRN Oxyl xyl xylI xyly xylyy
xayoliIRN An equerry; one who has the superintendence of horses. (TA.)

xuyalaMCu xylMC
xuyalaMCu (S, Msb, K, &c.) and xiyalaMCu↓ (S, Sgh, TA) and xaAlN↓ (S, K) and xayolN↓, (K, TA,) or xayalN↓, (CK,) and xayolapN↓, (K, TA,) or xayalapN↓, (CK,) or xiylapN↓, (JK,) and maxiylapN↓ (S, K) and Oaxoyalu↓, (Lth, JK, K,) [of all which the first is the most common,] Pride (S, Msb, K) and self-conceit; (Msb;) [or vanity; i. e.] pride arising from some fancied, or imaginary, excellence in oneself. (TA.) One says, huwa cuw xuyalaMCa &c. He is possessed of pride [and self-conceit, or vanity]. (S.)

xiyalaMCa xylMC
xiyalaMCa: see what next precedes.

xayaAlN xyAl
xayaAlN primarily signifies An incorporeal form or image; such as that which is imaged in sleep, and in the mirror, and in the heart or mind: then applied to the form of anything imaged; and to any subtile thing of a similar kind: (Er-Rághib, TA:) anything that one sees like a shadow: and the image of a man in a mirror, (T, Msb, TA,) and in water, (Msb,) and in sleep: (T, TA:) and a thing that sometimes passes by one, resembling a shadow: (T, Msb, TA:) xayaAlN and xayaAlapN↓ both signify the same; (JK, S, K;) i. e. i. q. TayofN [meaning an apparition; a phantom; a spectre; a fancied image; an imaginary form; and particularly a form that is seen in sleep]; (S, TA;) anything that one sees like a shadow [as the former word is explained above]; and a thing that is seen in sleep; (JK;) a form that is imaged to one in the mind when awake, and when dreaming: (K:) the former word is both masc. and fem.: (Ham p. 316:) pl. OaxiylapN (K) [a pl. of pauc.; and probably xiylaAnN also, as a pl. of mult., mentioned as one of the pls. of xayaAlN in another sense, below]. You say, taxayRala liI xayaAluhu [His apparition, or phantom, &c., became imaged to me in my mind]. (Msb, TA.) And a poet says, (S,) namely, El-Bohturee, (TA,)
falasotu binaAzilK UilRaA OalamRato
Alkacuwbu biraHoliI Oawo xayaAlatuhaA↓
[And I do not alight but she visits my abode, or her false apparition]. (S.) ― -b2- [In philosophy it signifies] A faculty that retains what the fancy perceives of the forms of objects of sense after the substance has become absent, so that the fancy beholds them whenever it turns towards them: thus it is the store-house of the fancy: its place is the hinder part of the first venter of [the three which are comprised by] the brain. (KT. [In this sense, it is incorrectly written in Freytag's Lex. (in which only the Arabic words of the explanation are given, preceded by the rendering “ phantasia, ”) xiyAlN.]) ― -b3- The xayaAl of a bird is The shadow of himself which a bird sees when rising into the sky; whereupon he pounces down upon it, thinking it to be a prey, and finds it to be nothing: he is [the bird] called xaATifu ZilRihi. (TA.) ― -b4- xayaAlN and xayaAlapN↓ signify also The person, or body, or corporeal form or figure which one sees from a distance, syn. XaxoSN, (S, K,) of a man; and his aspect. (K.) ― -b5- And the former also signifies A piece of wood with black garments upon it, (S,) or with a black [garment of the kind called] kisaMC upon it, (K,) which is set up to make the beasts and birds fancy it to be a man: (S, K:) or a piece of wood with a garment thrown upon it, which is set up for the sake of the sheep or goats, in order that the wolf, seeing it, may think it to be a man: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxiylapN (Ks, TA) and [of mult.] xiylaAnN. (TA.) A poet says,
OaxiI laA OaxaA liI gayoruhu gayora OanRaniI
karaAEiI xayaAlK yasotaTiyfu bilaAfikori
(S, TA) [cited by J as an ex. of xyAl in the former of the senses explained in the sentence immediately preceding: but the meaning seems to be, My brother: I have no brother but he: but I am like one watching an image dressed up to decoy; going round about without reflection: for,] as some say, (TA,) raAEiI AlxayaAli means the young ostrich for which the sportsman sets up a xayaAl [i. e. an image dressed up to decoy], (JK, TA,) in order that it may become familiar therewith, and the sportsman may then take it, and the young ostrich may follow him. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A thing that is set up in land in order that it may be known to be prohibited to the public, and may not be approached. (T, Msb.) ＝ -A2- And A certain plant. (K.)

xuyayolN xyyl
xuyayolN: see xaAlN, of which it is a diminutive.

xayaAlapN xyAl xyAlh xyAlp
xayaAlapN: see xayaAlN, in three places.

xayaAliIRN xyAl xyAlI xyAly xyAlyy
[xayaAliIRN Of, or relating to, the fancy: a rel. n. from xayaAlN.]

xayRaAlapN xyAl xyAlh xyAlp
xayRaAlapN Owners, or attendants, of horses. (JK, S.) [In modern Arabic, Horsemen; and a troop of horsemen.]

xaAYilN c
xaAYilN [act. part. n. of 1]: see muxotaAlN, in two places: ― -b2- and see xayolN, first sentence. ― -b3- Applied to a horse, Limping, halting, or slightly lame. (JK, TA.)

Oaxoyalu c
[Oaxoyalu More, and most, proud and self-conceited. (See also Oaxowalu, in art. xwl.) Occurring in several provs.; as, for ex.,] Oaxoyalu mino guraAbK [More proud and self-conceited than a crow]: because the grAb is proud and self-conceited in its gait. (Meyd.) ＝ -A2- See also xayalaMCu. ＝ -A3- Also Having a xaAl, meaning [a thing resembling] a pimple, inclining to blackness, [i. e. a mole,] upon his face: (Mgh:) or, as also maxiylN↓ and maxoyuwlN↓ (S, Msb, K) and maxuwlN, like maquwlN, (S, Msb,) this last belonging to art. xwl, as xaAlN, whence it is derived, does in one dial., (Msb,) A man (S, Msb) having [or marked with] many xiylaAn [or moles upon his person]: (S, Msb, K: *) fem. [of the first] xayolaMCu. (K.) ＝ -A4- AlOaxayolu, (S, Msb, K,) when indeterminate, [OaxayolN or Oaxayolu,] perfectly decl., [thus] used as a subst., but some make it imperfectly decl. both when determinate and when indeterminate, and assert it to be originally an epithet, from AltRaxayRulu, (S, O,) [though accord. to others it seems to be from Oaxoyalu as meaning “ having many moles, ”] A certain bird, (JK, S, Msb, K,) regarded as of evil omen, (JK, S, K,) that alights upon the rump of the camel, and is app. for that reason held to be of evil omen; (TA; [see maxoyuwlN;]) [applied in the present day to the green wood-pecker, picus viridis;] the Surad [q. v.]: (K:) or the green Surad: (TA:) or the XiqirRaAq [a name likewise now applied to the green wood-pecker, and to the common roller, coracias garrula]: (Fr, S, Msb, K:) so called because upon its wings are colours differing from its general colour: (Skr, TA:) or so called because diversified with black and white: (K:) or the XaAhiyn [q. v., a species of falcon]: (JK, TA, and Ham p. 705:) pl. OaxaAyilu, (JK, T, S, Msb, TA, and Ham ubi suprà,) or xiylN. (K.)

OuxaAyilN c
OuxaAyilN: see muxotaAlN, in two places.

maxiylN mxyl
maxiylN: see its fem., with p, in the next following paragraph, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also Oaxoyalu.

muxiylN mxyl
muxiylN A thing dubious, confused, or vague. (TA.) ― -b2- Exhibiting a xayaAli [or fancied image, or rather a xaAl or maxiylap, i. e. an indication, &c., (see 4,) of anything, as, for instance,] of good [and of evil]. (TA.) You say XaIoCN muxiylN UilaIAlxayori, and Almakoruwhi, A thing exhibiting an indication, or indications, of good, and of evil, or what is disliked or hated. (Msb.) Hence, (TA,) huwa muxiylN liloxayori, (S, TA,) said of a man, (S,) He is adapted or disposed by nature to good [i. e. to be, or to do, or to effect, or to produce, what is good]. (S, TA. [See also maxiylN in art. xwl.]) And saHaAbapN muxiylapN (JK, Msb, K) and muxayRilapN↓ (K, TA, in the CK muxayRalapN) and muxayRilN↓ and muxotaAlapN↓ (K) and mxAylp [i. e. muxaAyilapN↓] (Har p. 36) and maxiylapN↓ (Msb [but see what follows]) A cloud thought [or expected] to rain, (JK, Msb, K, TA, and Har ubi suprà,) when seen, (TA, and Har,) because showing signs of rain: muxiylapN, with damm, being an act. part. n., as meaning causing to think; and maxiylapN↓, with fet-h, being a pass. part. n., as meaning thought: and in like manner, accord. to Az, samaMCN muxiylapN and maxiylapN↓, meaning a clouded sky: (Msb:) or you say maxiylapN↓, with fet-h, when [you use the subst.] meaning a cloud itself [showing signs of rain]; and its pl. is maxaAyilu: (T, TA: see xaAlN, in the former half of the paragraph:) and saHaAbapN muxiylapN lilomaTari a cloud giving hope of rain. (S.) See also xaAlN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. You say also, AlsRamaMCu muxiylapN lilomaTari, meaning The sky is ready to rain. (Har p. 36.) ― -b3- AimoraOapN muxiylapN A woman having no husband. (JK.)

maxiylapN mxyl mxylh mxylp
maxiylapN as fem. of the pass. part. n. maxiylN: see muxiylN, in three places. ― -b2- As a subst.: see, again, muxiylN. And see xaAlN, mentioned a second time in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b3- Hence, A great banner or ensign; as likened to a cloud that fails not to fulfil its promise of rain. (JK.) ― -b4- Also An indication; a symptom; a sign, mark, or token, by which the existence of a thing is known or inferred; syn. XiyapN (JK) and maZinRapN; (TA;) and so xaAlN↓, q. v.: (JK:) pl. of the former maxaAyilu: originally used in relation to a cloud in which rain is thought to be. (TA.) You say, Zaharato fiyhi maxaAyilu AlnRajaAbapi, i. e. The indications &c. [of generosity, or nobility, appeared in him]. (TA.) ― -b5- You say also, of a cloud (saHaAbap), maA OaHosana maxiylatahaA and xaAlahaA↓ How good is its [apparent] disposition to rain! (S, TA.) ― -b6- See also xuyalaMCu.

muxayRalN mxyl
muxayRalN [A thing imaged to one by the mind or by a case; or fancied]. You say, fulaAnN yamoDiI EalaI AlmuxayRali; explained above: see 2. (JK, S.) And waqaEa fiI muxayRalaI kacaA [Such a thing occurred in what was imagined, or fancied, by me], and fiImuxayRalaAtiI [among the things imagined, or fancied, by me]. (TA.)

muxayRilN mxyl
muxayRilN; and its fem., with p: see muxiylN.

maxoywulN mxywl
maxoywulN: see Oaxoyalu. ＝ -A2- Also A camel lacerated in his rump by a bird of the kind called Oaxoyal that has alighted upon it. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) A man whose reason has fled in consequence of fright: a sense in which it is used by the vulgar; but correct. (TA.)

saHaAbapN muxaAyilapN sHAbp mxAylh sHAbp mxAylp
saHaAbapN muxaAyilapN: see muxiylN.

muxotaAlN mxtAl
muxotaAlN and xaAYilN↓ (S, K) and xaAlN↓ and xaAlK↓, which is formed by transposition, (K,) and OuxaAyilN↓, (S, K,) like OudaAbirN and OubaAtirN, (S,) which are [said to be] the only other epithets of this measure, (TA,) [i. e. of the measure OufaAEilN, though there are many of the measure fuEaAlilN,] applied to a man, Proud (S, K, TA) and self-conceited: [or vain:] (TA in explanation of all, and K in explanation of xaAlN:] or xaAlN↓ signifies having much xuyalaMC [or pride and self-conceit, or vanity]: and OuxaAyilN↓ one who walks with a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (JK:) xaAYilN↓ has for its pl. xaAlapN; (S, TA;) which is also fem. of xaAlN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also muxiylN.

OaroDN mutaxayRalapN c
OaroDN mutaxayRalapN (assumed tropical:) Land having its plants, or herbage, in a state of full maturity, and in blossom; (JK, S;) as also mutaxaAyilapN↓. (S.)

OaroDN mutaxaAyilapN c
OaroDN mutaxaAyilapN: see what next precedes.

1 xaAma xAm
1. xaAma as syn. with xayRama: see the latter. ― -b2- xaAma Eanohu, aor. yaxiymu, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. xayomuwmapN (S) and xayomN and xayamaAnN and xuyuwmN and xuywmapN and xiyaAmN, (K, the last but one omitted in the CK,) He held back, or refrained, from him, or it, through cowardice, (JK, S, K,) and fear: (JK, K:) i. e., from war, (JK,) or from encounter, or conflict. (Ham p. 164.) And one says also, xaAmuwA fiI AlqitaAli They held back, or refrained, through cowardice, in fight, and attained no good: and the poet Junádeh Ibn-'Ámir El-Hudhalee says, xAm AlqitaAla for xAm fiI AlqitaAli. (TA.) ― -b3- And xAm also signifies He drew back, (JK, K, *) through cowardice and fear, (JK,) from a stratagem, or plot, after he had devised it, (JK, K, *) not seeing in it what he liked, or approved. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xAm rijolahu, (S, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. xayomN, (S,) He raised his leg, or foot. (S, K.)

2 xyRm xym xymp
2. xyRm, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taxoyiymN, (TA,) [originally] He pitched his tent; (TA in art. rfD;) [like txyRm: and hence, ― -b2- ] He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in a place; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also xAm↓, aor. yaxiymu: whence, in a trad., lahu AlrRijaAlu qiyaAmFA mano OaHabRa Oano yasotaxiyma↓ [Whoso loveth that men should remain before him standing]; as some relate it; but others relate it differently, saying yasotaximRa, and yasotajimRa, as mentioned before [in arts. xm and jm]. (TA.) He alighted, or descended and stopped or sojourned or abode, in a place; as also xayRafa. (JK in art. xyf.) And xyRm AlwaHoXiIRu fiI kinaAsihi The wild animal remained in his covert, not quitting it. (TA.) And xayRamati AlrRaAYiHapu, (TA,) or AlrRiyHu AlTRayRibapu, (JK,) (tropical:) The odour, or sweet odour, remained; (JK, TA;) as also txmyRt↓; (K, TA;) in a garment, (JK, K, TA,) and in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- xayRamuwA They entered into a xayomap [q. v.]. (JK, K.) ＝ -A2- xyRmhu He made it like a xayomap. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) He covered it with a thing in order that its odour might cling to it. (K, TA.)

4 UixaAmap AxAmh AxAmp
4. UixaAmap, [inf. n. of OaxaAma,] in the phrase UixaAmap Alfarasi, (K, TA,) which signifies The horse's standing upon three legs and the extremity of the hoof of the fourth, (TA,) or raising one of his fore legs or one of his hind legs, (JK,) belongs to the present art. and to art. xwm. (K, TA.) Accord. to Fr and IAar, yuxiymu fiIUiHodaI rijolayohi, inf. n. as above, signifies He (a man, or a beast,) is unable to place one of his legs, or feet, firmly upon the ground, and to rest upon it, by reason of a fault therein. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- OaxaAma xayomapF, and OaxoymahaA, He constructed a xayomap; (IAar, K;) as also xayRamahaA↓. (TA.)

5 txyRm bimakaAni kacaA c
5. txyRm bimakaAni kacaA, (S,) or txyRm hunaA, (K,) [like xyRm,] He pitched, or fixed, his xayomap [in such a place, or here]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 2.

10 Uisotaxoyama
10: see 2.

xaAmN xAm
xaAmN A skin, or hide, untanned: or not tanned much, or thoroughly: and a kirobaAs [or coarse garment or piece of cloth, or garment or piece of cloth of white cotton,] unwashed: (K:) a Persian word, (TA,) arabicized. (K.) Unbleached cloth. (Msb, in art. xwm.) Paper that is polished, [app. a mistake for not polished,] or to be polished. (TA.) [Crude, or raw; applied in this sense to silk, contr. of maTobuwxN; and to sugar, &c.: anything unprepared for use.] Honey of dates (dibos) untouched by fire: (AHn, T:) which is the best thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also xaAmap.

xayomN xym xymp
xayomN: see xayomapN, in three places.

xiymN xym xymp
xiymN Natural, or innate, dispositions or tempers or the like: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, K:) a Persian word, arabicized: (TA:) having no sing. (S, K) of its own radical letters: (S:) or largeness, or liberality, of disposition: (JK, TA:) and the original, or primary, state, or condition, syn. OaSol, of the soul, or mind. (TA.) You say, huwa kariymu Alxiymi [He is generous in respect of natural dispositions &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, syn. firinod, of a sword. (K.) ― -b3- And I. q. HamoDN [app. meaning the kind of plants called HamoD]. (TA.)

xaAmapN xcAmh xcAmp
xaAmapN belongs to the present art., and J has erred, (K,) in mentioning it in art. xwm: (TA:) [but why this is said, I know not; nor do the commentators on this passage, as is observed in the TA, give any explanation of it worthy of notice:] it signifies A fresh, or juicy, plant: (S, Msb: both in art. xwm:) or an ear of corn: (IAar, TA:) or a shoot of seed-produce when it first grows forth upon a single stalk: (JK:) or xaAmapu AlzRaroE signifies what grows forth, of seedproduce, upon a single stalk: (M, K: *) or the fresh, or juicy, bunch thereof: or the fresh, or juicy, plant thereof: (M, K:) pl. xaAmaAtN (Msb) and [coll. gen. n.] xaAmN↓. (Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., mavalu AlmuWomini mavalu AlxaAmapi mina AlzRaroEi tumiyluhaA AlrRiyHu marRapF hekacaA wamarRapF hekacaA [The similitude of the believer is that of the fresh, or juicy, plant of seed-produce, &c., which the wind bends, at one time thus, and at one time thus]: (S, TA: *) but Fr related it differently, saying AlHAfp, [app. a mistranscription for AlxaAfap, which see in art. xwf,] and explained this as meaning “ the bunch ” of seed-produce. (TA.)

xayomahN xym xymh xymp
xayomahN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) with which xayomN↓ is syn., (S, Msb,) [though said by some to be a pl., as will be seen below,] A bayot [here meaning booth, or the like,] (S, Msb, K,) of any kind (K) such as is built, or constructed, (S, Msb, K,) by the Arabs, (S, Msb,) of the branches of trees: (S, Msb, K:) so says As, holding that the xymp is only of trees, and that otherwise it is called bayotN [q. v.]: but others hold that it is [a tent; i. e.] made with pieces of cloth and tent-ropes; because taxoyiymN signifies the “ remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding; ” wherefore it is thus called, as being used on the occasion of alighting: (IB, TA:) this latter is the meaning commonly known; but accord. to the saying of As, it is tropical: (TA:) or, accord. to IAar, it is applied by the Arabs only to a construction of four poles roofed over with vumaAm [or panic grass]; and is not of cloths; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) the miZalRap, he says, being of cloths and of other things: or i. q. miZalRap: (TA:) accord. to AHát, the same as the Persian xaro PuXotaho [lit. “ ass's back; ” like the French “ dos d'âne; ” meaning a high-pitched span-roof]: (Mgh:) or any round bayot [which may here mean either booth or tent]: or three poles, or four, over which is laid vumaAm; by means of which one is shaded in the heat: (K:) or poles set up, with rafters laid across, covered with trees; so that it is cooler than are Oaxobiyap [pl. of xibaMC]: or poles upon which xiyaAm [pl. of xayomN] are constructed: or a construction of trees and palmbranches with their leaves upon them, which a man uses for shade when he brings his camels to water: and applied by the Arabs to a bayot [or tent &c.], and a place of abode [in an absolute sense]: (TA:) the pl. of xayomapN is xayomaAtN and xiyamN (S, Msb, K) and xayomN↓, (K,) or this last is [a coll. gen. n., or] syn. with xayomapN, (S, Msb,) and xiyaAmN, (K,) or this is pl. of xayomN↓, (S, Msb,) and is applied also to (tropical:) [women's vehicles of the kind called] hawaAdij; these being likened to xiyaAm [properly so termed]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlXRahiydu fiI xayomapi QllRehi taHota AlEaroXi (assumed tropical:) [The martyr is in the tabernacle of God, beneath the empyrean: this signification of xymp being perhaps taken from the phrase ἡ σκηνὴ τοῦ θεοῦ in Rev. xxi. 3]. (TA.)

xaAmiIRN xAm xAmI xAmy xAmyy
xaAmiIRN (K, TA) A preparer of skins, or hides, of the kind termed xaAmN. (TA.)

xiyamiIRN xym xymI xymp xymy

xayRaAmN xyAm xymp
xayRaAmN and xiyamiIRN↓ One who applies himself to the fabrication of the [kind of tent, or booth, called] xayomap. (TA.)

maxiymN mxym
maxiymN, like makiylN, (in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, like mikotalN, TA, [in the CK like mikoyalN,]) A collection of bundles, or handfuls, (juraz, [in the CK jizar,] of reaped seed-produce. (K, TA.)

xayawiIRN xywI xywy
[xayawiIRN rel. n. of xA: see xaAYiIRN, in art. xwO.]
